DOC.HEAD: Connecticut Senate Guarantees Right to Abortion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to RECAST, UPDATE with comments from co-sponsor of bill, background. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `The Senate...'
DOC.TEXT: The Connecticut Senate on Friday approved a bill guaranteeing a woman's right to choose abortion even if the U.S. Supreme Court overturns its 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion. The bill effectively codifies into state law much of Roe vs. Wade, making Connecticut the first state to take such action. It now goes to Democratic Gov. William A. O'Neill, who has said he will sign it. ``Even if the Supreme Court were to reverse Roe v. Wade ... this statute would be the governing standard for the state of Connecticut,'' said Sen. Richard Blumenthal, the Democratic vice-chairman of the Judiciary Committee and a co-sponsor of the bill. ``I think what the Supreme Court is saying in effect to the states ... is we're going to turn this issue over to you. Connecticut has taken the gauntlet and said we're ready to face that issue and we're going to be pro-choice,'' he said. The legislature was spurred to address the issue in part because of last summer's Supreme Court decision in Webster vs. Reproductive Health Services of Missouri, which gave states greater latitude to restrict abortion. The measure, which also repeals the state's unenforced anti-abortion statutes, requires girls 15 and under to get counseling before an abortion and encourages them to tell their parents. Because the bill contains the counseling provisions, the Pro-Life Council of Connecticut as well as pro-choice activists have claimed victory with its approval. A similar bill approved by the New Hampshire legislature was vetoed earlier this year by Gov. Judd Gregg, and an effort to override the veto failed last week. Proponents argued the New Hampshire measure merely wrote into state law the guidelines of Roe vs. Wade. But Judd said the measure would have gone farther, allowing abortions until the point a woman's doctor determined the fetus could survive outside the womb. The Connecticut bill, in a slight variation on the Roe vs. Wade decision, allows abortions late in pregnancy _ when the fetus is capable of living outside the womb _ only when the life or health of the mother is in danger. ``Now that we've placed Roe vs. Wade in Connecticut's law books, we need to fight hard to protect it,'' said Betsy Wacker of the Connecticut branch of the National Abortion Rights Action League, which lobbied for portions of the bill. A NARAL statement said last summer's Supreme Court decision ``sounded an alarm which woke up the pro-choice majority.'' The Senate vote came after about 45 minutes of debate and was witnessed by numerous House members, who had endured five hours of debate on the bill last week. The Senate easily rejected three Republican amendments, one of which would have restored criminal sanctions against anyone performing an abortion and permitted the father or grandparent of the fetus to sue for $10,000 in damages. That was rejected 31-4. Another amendment, rejected 27-8, would have required minors to notify parents before an abortion could be performed. The bill as approved requires girls 15 and under to get counseling before an abortion; but it only encourages them to talk with their parents beforehand. ``It's a sad day in the state of Connecticut when we would intervene to deny parents' fundamental rights,'' said Sen. Thomas Scott, Republican sponsor of the parental notification amendment. Allowing a child to make such a decision on her own, Scott added, ``is unconscionable.'' But Sen. Lee Scarpetti, also a Republican, said that ``all the laws in the world won't change'' family relationships.

DOC.HEAD: Riot Police Storm Strike-Bound Shipyard; Sparks Street Battles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with police gaining control of yard but street battles break out. 20 injured, 300 arrested. Pickup 4th graf `The three-day-old...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos ULS1
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of riot police firing tear gas stormed the world's largest shipyard at dawn Saturday to expel striking workers armed with steel pipes, propane gas tanks and homemade cannons. The crushing of the strike at the Hyundai shipyard sparked a massive street protest by thousands of workers. Militants hurled rocks and firebombs and fought police in hand-to-hand combat. Two police buses were torched and burned. One armored van used to fire tear gas was destroyed and at least 10 other police vehicles were damaged in the fighting on streets near the shipyard. Major streets were closed and air flights were canceled into Ulsan. Some estimates said as many as 20,000 workers were involved in the protests, many from affiliated Hyundai companies in the Ulsan area. Initial police reports said about 300 workers were arrested and at least 20 people were injured in the storming of the shipyard. There were no immediate casualty figures from the street fighting. The three-day-old strike had shut down the Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. shipyard in this city about 200 miles southeast of Seoul and was threatening to spread to other industries. Talks to try to end the strike, which centered on worker demands to free four jailed labor leaders, had broken down hours earlier. Authorities said the strike was illegal. Police bulldozers ripped down steel barricades the workers had erected at the gates to the sprawling shipyard, and an estimated 10,000 riot police rushed in, wearing gas masks and helmets and carrying clubs and shields. They were backed up by at least 10 armored vans firing clouds of choking tear gas. At the same time, about 600 riot police stormed the seaside complex by boat. A company guard inside the yard said tear gas was so dense he could hardly see, and black smoke was billowing from several workers' tents which had been set afire. About 100 workers on or around a giant 240-foot crane erected on the docks taunted police, shouting insults and threats. The workers hurled firebombs, rocks and pices of metal and combat-clad police retaliated with volleys of tear gas, witnesses said. About 2,000 workers in the shipyard overnight had maintained a vigil around blazing bonfires, said Munhwa Broadcasting Co. Many were seen fleeing as police launched their attack. Before the assault began, a police helicopter hovered overhead, dropping leaflets calling on workers to leave peacefully. Police using loudspeakers shouted three times before storming the gates: ``Disperse, disperse, disperse!'' Last year, about 12,000 police firing tear gas stormed the shipyard to end a 109-day strike. At one point Friday, 43 busloads of riot police drove past the shipyard's main gate as strikers jabbed their fists in the air shouting insults. ``We have no choice but to fight,'' one union leader said after a rally attended by about 10,000 workers. Steel ladders and other iron fixtures and parts were piled at the main gate to create a 9-foot-high wall. Hundreds of workers wearing helmets and armed with steel pipes patrolled the shipyard in small groups. Gas and power supplies to the shipyard were cut and about 4,000 management workers withdrawn after last-minute negotiations between union leaders and company executives broke down Thursday night. About 20,000 of the shipyard's 24,000 employees are unionized. According to the Japan Shipbuilding Industry Association, the Hyundai shipyard is the world's largest, capable of building 14 large ships simultaneously. Sales last year totaled $1.5 billion. Workers are demanding the release of four labor leaders arrested in earlier protests that were deemed illegal. The company maintains that judicial matters are out of its domain. Government officials say the strikes are illegal because workers have not gone through the required legal steps, including a cooling-off period. Union leaders say the complexity of labor laws makes it virtually impossible to stage a legal strike. Hyundai has 32 subsidiaries in Ulsan, including the shipyard, and union leaders issued a joint statement saying workers at all Hyundai companies would begin a general strike if police moved into the yard. In Seoul, radical students hurled firebombs at four showrooms of Hyundai Motor Co., a sister firm of the Hyundai shipyard. No one was hurt, but several windows wee broken, police said. Radical students held anti-government rallies Friday on two campuses in Seoul and burned an effigy of Jung Joo-yong, chairman of the Hyundai group, vowing to support striking workers. Also in Seoul, workers of the state-run Korea Broadcasting System staged sit-in protests for the 16th day Friday to demand the resignation of the network's government-appointed president. About 5,000 of the network's 7,000 workers have been staging peaceful protests since April 12. They claim the new president, Suh Ki-won, a former government official, will give the government greater control over TV and radio broadcasts and stand in the way of press freedom.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Finds Union Leaders Condone Violence Against Greyhound
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the Greyhound bus drivers' union have condoned, permitted or ratified acts of violence against the company during their 8-week-old strike, a judge ruled Friday. A Greyhound spokesman said the ruling shows that the company suspicion of a coordinated union effort at intimidation is correct. But a union spokesman said leaders of the Phoenix-based Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions have been solidly opposed to violence. In a lawsuit filed by Dallas-based Greyhound Lines Inc. against the union and related defendants, Cook County Circuit Judge Thomas J. O'Brien issued an injunction to set limits on picketing in Chicago and to bar union members from any direct or indirect acts of violence. The strike against Greyhound began March 2. Since then, several incidents of shootings at buses have occurred nationwide. As part of the text of his injunction, O'Brien wrote he had enough evidence to believe 12 instances of violence or intimidation cited in the lawsuit and directed at Greyhound, its employees or passengers, had occurred in Chicago since the beginning of the strike. He also wrote he found union members or officials to have direct or indirect blame. The judge wrote that union President Edward M. Strait of Phoenix, as well as named officials of union locals 1150, 1303 and 1126, had ``condoned, permitted and-or ratified the acts of violence, intimidations and-or harassment.'' While the case is local and specifies picketing rules at two Greyhound facilities in Chicago, Gravley said the ruling backs up what Greyhound officials have been saying _ that violence aimed at Greyhound buses and facilities nationwide ``are not sporadic ... events.'' Union spokesman Nick Nichols said from Washington, D.C., that he couldn't comment on Friday's opinion because he hadn't seen it, but the union has been opposed to violence. ``Obviously, we would take issue with the judge's view on this,'' Nichols said. ``The union and the union leaders involved at the national and the council level have made it very, very clear that under no circumstances do they condone violence.'' He added that just Thursday, bulletins were sent to all locals asking members with information about any violent acts involving Greyhound to contact the FBI. In addition to enjoining union members from any violence or intimidation, O'Brien's ruling limits to two the number of pickets at any vehicle or pedestrial entrance or exit at the two main Greyhound facilities in Chicago. Non-picketing demonstrators must be at least 20 feet away. Friday's injunction follows a similar temporary restraining order issued by Circuit Judge Anthony Scotillo March 2, and extended March 8 by O'Brien. On April 9, Greyhound filed a $30 million civil lawsuit against the Amalgamated Transit Union and 20 union officers and members claiming the unions have campaigned to cripple Greyhound financially and have cost the company at least $10 million. Triple damages are being sought.

DOC.HEAD: Intense Interest, But Work-and-Wait Attitude, in Astronomy Community
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: While astronomers rejoice that the Hubble Space Telescope is finally circling Earth, some of them are busy building new instruments that will make the world's best observatory even better. Three Orbital Replacement Instruments under development will be added to the telescope years from now by astronauts making orbital service calls. Rodger Thompson of the University of Arizona's Steward Observatory is principal investigator in development of the $80 million Near Infrared Cameras and Multiple Objective Spectrometers, or NICMOS, which he expects to be taken up to the Hubble in about six years. ``Our particular part of it is scheduled for 1996 launch _ February 10th, 1996, if you want to believe a shuttle manifest that goes out that far,'' said Thompson, who heads the project's 20-astronomer team. NICMOS, with three cameras and three spectrometers, will concentrate on different wavelengths in the near-infrared portion of the light spectrum, which none of the five instruments now aboard the $1.5 billion Hubble can view. Infrared also is invisible to the human eye. Astronomer Richard Green, of the Tucson-headquartered National Optical Astronomy Observatories, is a co-investigator on another second-generation instrument being developed, the Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph, or STIS. He said the Hubble, originally scheduled for launch in 1983, is ``flying technology that's really out of date.'' The STIS is intended to replace the telescope's two present spectrographs that will separate light into different wavelengths, like a prism. The new device will be able to capture an entire high-resolution spectrum of light from a star in one exposure, versus about 25 that the instruments now aboard the Hubble will require, Green said. In addition, he said, ``We're working now to fly in '96 more modern optical light detectors, solid-state imagers and new light-gathering equipment that will just make massive improvement in the performance of the telescope,'' he said. The third instrument to be installed in orbit is a Wide Field-Planetary Camera 2, which will take advantage of advances in electronics that were not available when the current wide field camera was installed on the Hubble. Its principal investigator is John Trauger of Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif. Each of NICMOS' three cameras will look at different portions of the field of view, and at different resolutions, said Thompson. He described it as ``like having three different lenses on your camera'' _ very high-resolution that sees only a small part of the field, intermediate and a wide-angle view. Similarly, each spectrometer will examine different parts of the spectrum, and all six instruments will operate at the same time, greatly increasing efficiency, he said. The spectrometers and cameras, each loaded with an array of light detectors called charged coupled devices, will show how much light is coming at each wavelength. That will enable astronomers to identify the composition of the source objects, temperature, physical conditions under which the objects are being created, even pressure, density and velocity, he said. ``That's why spectroscopy is such a powerful instrument,'' said Thompson. ``It allows you to learn a lot of detail about the object that you're looking at.'' Infrared sightings will shed new understanding on the birth of stars and makeup of gas clouds, planets and planetary atmospheres. NICMOS is expected to help determine whether the center of our galaxy is a black hole or an extremely dense star cluster. ``It allows us to see new objects being formed, new galaxies, new stars and perhaps new planets,'' Thompson said. He said it will let astronomers see through clouds of galactic dust and gas ``right down into, let's say, the stellar nurseries, where new stars are being born, new galaxies are being born.'' NICMOS is in its final design stages, with construction set to start next year. The launching of the Hubble was ``just the first step for us,'' Thompson said. ``We will not be sitting on our hands by any means. We have so much to do. We will learn a lot from how the telescope operates that we'll be able to use in putting our instrument together in the best possible way.'' ``It's a learning experience. We hope we learn very fast,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: President Copes With Sellout Charges on Lithuania
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's cautious policy on Lithuania so unsettled the leader of the breakaway Baltic republic the other day he charged Bush with ``another Munich.'' The allegation by Vytautas Landsbergis coupled Bush with Neville Chamberlain, the British prime minister who struck a deal with Hitler before World War II permitting Germany to dismember democratic Czechoslovakia. Chamberlain and his black umbrella became modern history's symbol of appeasement when Hitler invaded Poland in 1939 and set the world on fire. Millions died on battlefields and in concentration camps, and even the victory of the Allies in 1945 did not return democracy to Czechoslovakia. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, meanwhile, lost their independence in another notorious Nazi pact _ the one in 1939 with Moscow that precipitated the Soviets' absorption of the Baltics a year later. And how did Bush merit this badge of dishonor pinned on him by the Lithuanian president? By deferring economic sanctions against the Soviet Union while waiting to see if the Kremlin and Lithuanians agree on terms for negotiations to settle their dispute peacefully. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III repeatedly have asserted their support for Lithuanian independence, publicly and privately. ``The people of Lithuania must not be denied their rights,'' Baker said in testimony Wednesday to a Senate appropriations subcommittee. ``We support the aspirations of the Lithuanian people for freedom and self-determination.'' That same day Landsbergis was on the telephone to members of Congress complaining that ``the West doesn't want to help Lithuania.'' He said ``our reaction is one of discouragement and disappointment. It feels as if our worst fears are being realized.'' The Soviets have set a precondition for dealing with the Lithuanians _ that they withdraw their March 11 declaration of independence. Two Western leaders, President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, on Thursday urged Lithuania to take that step. If they do, the Soviets are willing to permit Lithuanian independence under a new legal procedure. It could take up to five years, and the Lithuanians would be required to negotiate financial and territorial terms with Moscow. But in the end they stand to regain their independence. Czechoslovakia's prospects after Munich were horrendously different. Chamberlain, with the acquiescence of France, had signed an agreement with Germany in September 1938 guaranteeing peace. Within days, Germany occupied the German-speaking Sudetenland. The following March, Hitler made a protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia. Slovakia proclaimed its independence with Germany's support. Independent Czechoslovakia was no more. Soviet troops entered the country in 1944, and in 1948 communists seized control of the country. It is only now reverting to the democracy proclaimed in 1918 and lost at Munich. Chamberlain proclaimed ``peace in our time'' when he returned to London from Munich. He had widespread support from the British people. They turned to Winston Churchill, who had opposed the pact with Hitler, only after the Nazis' real intentions became apparent. Bush, responding to Lithuania's Landsbergis, declared on Wednesday: ``The policies and decisions I've taken have had strong support from the American people, and that's who I work for.'' But that is where the parallel with Chamberlain reasonably should end. Both leaders enjoy public support, but the American president and Lithuania are on a vastly different course from the one Chamberlain and Czechoslovakia traveled a half-century ago.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid covers diplomacy for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: AAA: Motorists Paying to Get Rid of `Ping' Get `Pot Luck'
DOC.TEXT: Those yellow and black federal labels that give the octane rating on gas pumps should be torn off because of cheating by gas stations and lax enforcement, the American Automobile Association says. Reacting to a congressional report Thursday that estimates octane cheating could be costing motorists $150 million a year, AAA spokesman William Berman said car owners have only a 50-50 chance of getting the octane they pay for. The report by the General Accounting Office found cheating by more than half of the service stations tested in Detroit and St. Louis last year, although it said only suspected cheaters were tested and that those results could not be projected nationwide. ``Car owners shouldn't have to take pot luck when they fill up their tank,'' Berman said. ``Those aging octane stickers out on the gas pumps are essentially meaningless and should be removed.'' A representative of service station operators accused Berman of exaggerating the problem and criticized the report as too sweeping an indictment of an industry that sells 113 billion gallons of gas a year. ``Service station operators have investments of $100,000 or more, and they're not going to jeopardize that,'' said Joseph Koach, executive director of the 60,000-member Service Station Dealers of America. But he acknowledged that there are some ``fly-by-night cheaters.'' ``If the consumer wants to be protected, he can be protected by buying gas from qualified members of associations,'' Koach said. A report by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said that motorists who are buying higher-octane gas to get the ``ping'' out of their engines may be paying a premium price for gas that sometimes comes from the same storage tank as cheaper regular fuel. Federal law requires that uniform labels on gas pumps show the octane rating of each type of gas _ 87 for regular unleaded, 89 for leaded regular and mid-grade unleaded and 91 to 94 for premium grades. The higher the octane, the more ability the gas has to get rid of ``ping'' or metallic ``knocking'' in the engine. A low-octane gasoline can reduce engine efficiency, mileage and emissions in high-powered engines, the GAO said. The GAO said the federal government has done little to stop the deception, although nearly half the states have testing programs that have curbed cheating. Rep. Philip R. Sharp, D-Ind., who released the report with Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., said the study's estimate of $150 million in losses is conservative. He said the figure could reach as high as $600 million through growing mislabeling of octane ratings at the pump. ``Unfortunately, consumers cannot determine octane ratings visually or in other ways that allow them to know if they are getting what they are paying for,'' the report said. It said problems were found in seven non-testing states visited by GAO investigators, mainly at the distribution and retail levels. Frequent octane mislabeling was found in one-time tests conducted in Michigan, Missouri, Oregon and Tennessee, the GAO said, and investigators also found concern about octane cheating from officials interviewed in Indiana, Montana and Washington. In 1989 Michigan tests conducted primarily in Detroit, 51.9 percent of stations had inflated ratings averaging 2.3 octane points, and in St. Louis 52.6 percent had mislabeled an average of 2.2 points, the report said. In tests conducted in 1988, 21.8 percent of samples in Oregon and 22.2 percent in Tennessee were mislabeled, the GAO said. States that now handle their own tests and enforcement are Alabama, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Iowa, Louisiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Missouri, New York, North Carolina, North Dakota, Oklahoma, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Virginia and Wisconsin.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Affirms Pregnant Women's Right to Set Medical Care
DOC.TEXT: It's too late for Angela Carder to claim victory, but her parents say they hope they've helped others by winning a court ruling that affirms the right of pregnant women to control their own medical care. Carder, 27, a terminal cancer patient who was 26 weeks pregnant, died two days after a court-ordered Caesarean section at George Washington University Hospital here. Her baby died less than three hours after the operation, which was listed as a contributing cause in Carder's death. Her parents say she did not want the surgery and did not give informed consent. ``We really thought all along that Angie would be vindicated in some way,'' said Daniel Stoner, her father. ``It's too late for her now. But I guess it will help somebody else. If there's ever another case like this, it should really help.'' The closely watched case was resolved Thursday when the District of Columbia Court of Appeals said a lower court was wrong to weigh Carder's rights against those of the fetus when the heavily sedated patient's wishes were unclear. The appeals court said the lower court should have tried harder to figure out what Carder would have wanted done, given her goals, values, prognosis and attitude toward her pregnancy. In any case, the opinion said, a pregnant woman's decision to refuse medical treatment is almost always paramount _ even when survival of a fetus is at stake. ``A fetus cannot have rights ... superior to those of a person who has already been born,'' the court said in a 7-1 decision that took nearly two years to emerge. It said only in a rare, exceptional circumstance would it be legal to override a pregnant woman's decision. The appeals court ruling is binding only in the district, but there are so few precedents in the area that other courts are expected to look to it as they wrestle with questions of maternal versus fetal rights. More than 100 groups backed the American Civil Liberties Union in the quest to reverse the lower-court ruling. They all declared victory, as did the hospital and the lawyer who represented the fetus. ACLU attorney Lynn Paltrow, who brought the case, faulted the lower court judge for failing to visit Carder's bedside to see if she were competent to make a decision. She contends the woman could have. ``He treated her as if she were already dead,'' Paltrow said. ``The bottom line is you can't deny women their civil rights. You can't treat women as dead just because they're pregnant.'' Dawn Johnsen, legal director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, called the case a significant precedent that could stem a trend toward government interference on behalf of so-called fetal rights. She said the interference has ranged from ordering Caesarian sections to jailing pregnant women so they don't drink or take drugs. ``Since there are so few decisions on this issue, I would expect it (the D.C. ruling) to be extremely persuasive in other areas of the country,'' Johnsen said. Vincent Burke, the attorney for the hospital, agreed that the decision would be valuable for doctors, lawyers and families facing such situations. ``The main reason we went to court was that it was a difficult issue and there was no precedent,'' he said. ``We weren't seeking a specific outcome. We wanted guidance and the court's now given us guidance.'' The path laid out by the court involves a procedure called ``substituted judgment,'' in which a court tries to extrapolate from a patient's values and goals what kind of decision he or she would make. The primary factor in such a judgment would be a patient's previously expressed wishes, the court said. Barbara Mishkin, who represented the fetus, said she was happy with the opinion and agreed that ``it's her life. It's her right. It's her body. It's her medical decision.'' However, she asserted that Carder would have wanted the operation and that is what a substituted-judgment proceeding would have concluded. As for the opposition of Carder's parents, Mishkin said they did not believe Carder's husband would bring up the child and ``they didn't want to be stuck taking care of a baby.'' In a dissenting opinion, Judge James A. Belson said he agreed with the lower court's decision to weigh the interests of Carder against those of her fetus. The judge said an unborn child's interests and the state's interest in preserving human life are entitled to ``substantial weight'' when they are in conflict with a patient's decision on medical treatment. The Stoners have filed a civil suit against the hospital, charging their daughter did not get proper care because the hospital feared the effect of treatment on the fetus.

DOC.HEAD: US, Soviet Union Reach Agreement to Normalize Trade Relations
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is hailing a new agreement to normalize trade relations with the Soviet Union for the first time in nearly a half-century, but the proposal is expected to encounter stiff opposition in Congress. One congressional critic said the administration couldn't have picked a worse time to negotiate the agreement because of the Soviet crackdown in Lithuania. The pact, if ratified by Congress, would clear the way for significantly lower tariffs on Soviet products while expanding business opportunities for U.S. companies in the Soviet Union. While President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had made signing a trade agreement a top priority for their upcoming summit, Bush was urged by some in the administration to cancel the talks to protest Soviet actions in Lithuania. However, the president announced Tuesday that he had decided against imposing economic sanctions for fear that such an action would imperil the progress being made in pulling Eastern Europe away from Soviet control. This decision cleared the way for the trade talks to proceed in Paris. Deputy Trade Representative Julius Katz, head of the U.S. delegation, said at the end of Thursday's discussions that both sides had reached basic agreement. Katz predicted the document would be ready for signing at the May 30-June 3 summit in Washington. He said all that remained was resolving wording disagreements in four relatively minor areas. ``Fundamentally, we have reached agreement on the text,'' Katz said in a telephone conference call from Paris. Under U.S. law, the new economic agreement cannot be signed until Bush certifies that the Soviet Union is allowing the free emigration of Jews and other dissidents. Bush has said he will sign such a waiver once the Soviet Union's more liberalized emigration policy is written into law by the Soviet legislature. The trade agreement must be approved by Congress before it can take effect, however. Some members' unhappiness over the Soviets' refusal to grant independence to Lithuania is certain to be an issue raised by opponents. ``There couldn't be a worse time'' for the agreement, said Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y. ``We're selling at a cut rate the rope that would be used to hang the Lithuanians.'' Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, which would have jurisdiction over the pact, has warned that he would work to block Senate approval because of an unrelated trade issue. Bentsen, D-Texas, is unhappy because the administration apparently has decided not to target Japan as an unfair trader under a tough section of the 1988 trade act. He said such a decision would ``poison the well'' in Congress not only for the Soviet trade agreement but for other administration trade initiatives. Bush has expressed the hope that normalizing U.S.-Soviet trade relations would give a boost to the ailing Soviet economy and bolster Gorbachev's political reform efforts. The agreement is needed to grant the Soviet Union most-favored-nation status, qualifying it for the lowest tariffs granted to any other country. Currently, Soviet products sold in the United States bear duties as much as 10 times higher than imports from other countries. By one estimate, the price of Soviet vodka could drop by $1.25 per bottle. The higher tariffs were the result of the 1974 Jackson-Vanik amendment, which was passed by Congress in retaliation for Soviet emigration restrictions in effect at the time. U.S. officials have predicted that trade between the Soviet Union and the United States could double or even triple over the next three years with a new trade agreement. Private economists doubt that assessment, given the numerous troubles plaguing the Soviet economy. Last year, trade between the countries totaled $5 billion. U.S. export sales, which totaled $4.3 billion, reflected primarily grain shipments. Soviet sales in this country, totaling $703 million, included petroleum and consumer items such as vodka and furs.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Turns Up `Serious Deficiencies' In Seawolf Computer Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Rep. Coyners to Conyers throughout
DOC.TEXT: The Navy's $44 billion Seawolf attack submarine program is moving ahead despite serious deficiencies in a computer program that guides the craft and its weapons, a congressional oversight panel reported Thursday. The congressional investigation turned up an internal Navy memo pointing out problems in the computer system. Rep. John Conyers Jr., D-Mich., who headed the probe, questioned whether the Navy can produce a submarine that can hunt and kill enemy submarines as it is supposed to do. ``Without the computer software, the Seawolf submarine is just so much metal floating around out there,'' said Conyers, chairman of the national security subcommittee of the House Government Operations Committee. The probe conducted by the subcommittee and the General Accounting Office, Congress' investigative arm, focused on the BSY-2 computer system, referred to colloquially as the ``busy-two.'' The highly sophisticated system is built for the Navy by General Electric. It is designed specifically for the Seawolf, which is built in Groton, Conn., by General Dynamics Corp., and in Newport News, Va., by the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Co. ``It has recently come to my attention that serious deficiencies in the busy-two software development program have been identified by Department of Defense software experts,'' Conyers said. ``However, it is by no means clear that corrective actions have been taken.'' At Thursday's hearing, top Navy officials in charge of Seawolf said they were unaware of a March 19 internal Navy memo detailing problems in the computer software. Conyers had copies of the memo but did not release it to the public. The Navy's top acquisition official, Assistant Secretary Gerald A. Cann, said he would respond to the memo as soon as it could be studied. But he said there was little risk that any technical problems would significantly delay delivery of the system to Groton, where the first Seawolf is under construction. ``I don't think we have a flaming disaster here,'' Cann said. A spokesman for G.E. said he would seek a response to the issues raised at the hearing from experts familiar with the computer system. According to Conyers, the memo listed a number of problems including the Navy's failure to program all of the computers' complex function in a single computer language developed for sophisticated weaponry. The memo, written by a Navy software expert, questioned the reliability of the computer systems, which govern virtually all of Seawolf's movements and weaponry. The BSY-2 is specifically designed to enable Seawolf to detect and locate targets faster than existing submarine combat systems and to allow operators to detect and attack multiple targets. Frank Conahan, who headed the GAO investigation of Seawolf, called the BSY-2 system ``one of the most technically challenging and complex software development efforts ever undertaken for a submarine.'' The Navy has no alternative to the BSY-2 system under consideration, Conahan warned, and problems in development of the computer could lead to costly delays in completion of the submarines. Rep. Frank Horton, R-N.Y., the ranking Republican on the subcommittee, noted that there has already been a $10 million cost overrun in completion of the first two BSY-2 systems. Pending congressional approval, the Navy plans to buy 29 Seawolfs by the year 2000 at an estimated cost of $44 billion. G.E. was awarded a $1.8 billion contract to develop the BSY-2 in 1988. Assuming the entire run of submarines is built, the computer equipment alone would account for $7.4 billion of the cost, according to Conahan. It is far more likely, Conyers said, that the pressure to reduce defense spending will scale down the size of the Seawolf program significantly. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is conducting a detailed review of the need for Seawolf and is expected to present findings next month. Conyers said the problems with the Seawolf program discovered by the subcommittee and the GAO will be a part of Cheney's review.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: It's been 2{ years since Joan Rivers' husband committed suicide but the comedian says she only recently was able to listen to a taped message he left her. ``It was terrible, terrible because the voice is the voice of someone I loved who had already taken pills and was saying goodbye,'' she said in an interview published in Sunday's Parade magazine. ``That's all I want to say but I will never listen to that tape again. Never.'' Her husband of 22 years, Edgar Rosenberg, took an overdose of prescription drugs in August 1987. Rivers said getting fired from her syndicated show on the Fox network and the negative publicity she received when she left NBC contributed to her husband's depression. ``He blamed himself for everything,'' Rivers said. ``Edgar internalized it. He thought, like everyone else, that my career was over, and he thought he had brought it on.'' But Rivers refused to give up on her 25-year career. She went to England and was a hit; today she's packing Atlantic City clubs and is host of a daily syndicated, daytime talk show. ``Edgar would have loved seeing me come full circle,'' she says.

Aretha Franklin, the Queen of Soul, got into a storytelling groove as she helped a suburban Detroit library celebrate 1990 International Literacy Year. Franklin, accustomed to entertaining thousands in concert, said her 30-minute reading of ``The Three Little Pigs,'' ``The Gingerbread Boy'' and ``A Letter to Amy'' before about 150 listeners at Oakland County's Bloomfield Township Library on Wednesday made her a little nervous. ``It's not exactly singing the `Freeway (of Love)' in concert,'' she said, referring to one of her recent hit songs. Franklin appeared as part of an American Library Association campaign to get celebrities to push reading.

Walter Lantz, creator of the impish Woody Woodpecker cartoon character, received the first star on Universal Studios Florida's ``Walk of Fame'' as part of his 90th birthday celebration. The star Lantz received Thursday is similar to those on Hollywood Boulevard in California. The $600 million Orlando studio's grand opening is June 7. Lantz, who turns 90 today and has been affiliated with Universal since the 1930s, has drawn cartoon characters for more than 800 animated films shown in 72 nations, said studio president Steve Lew.

David Bowie's new Sound & Vision Tour, which starts its American leg tonight in Miami, will feature his hits from the 1970s and early '80s _ and Bowie says this is the last time he'll perform them. ``After this, I'm through with it all,'' he told the Sun-Sentinel in Fort Lauderdale. ``You'll never hear those songs again. It's the '90s. A new decade. What better way to start out than by cleaning house, getting it out of the way and moving on.'' ``I won't be singing `Suffragette City' when I'm 50.'' The tour, which has already visited Canada and Europe, features all-request shows, with Bowie playing songs named by fans calling a 900 telephone number.

Billy Joel says he can't wait to play Yankee Stadium _ he'll be playing music and a little baseball on the field where Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Joe DiMaggio, Mickey Mantle and other greats once gamboled. Two popes and several heavyweight fights have sold out the stadium, but Yankees officials say the native New Yorker and five-time Grammy winner will be the first rocker to headline a show there when he appears June 22. Other bands have played there following Yankee games. ``It's the House that Ruth Built, man. It's a magic place,'' Joel said in a telephone interview from Chicago. ``The day we set up, I'm going to walk out to the mound and do a little pitching, maybe shag a few flies.'' His piano will be set up in left-center field.

West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has accepted an invitation to deliver Harvard University's commencement address on June 7, university officials announced. ``Chancellor Kohl has emerged as one of the world's most influential political figures and has contributed significantly to redrafting the political and economic map of Europe,'' Harvard President Derek Bok said Thursday. Kohl, 60, became chancellor in 1982. He has played an active role in defining the changing relationship between East and West Germany since the fall of the Berlin Wall.

Attorneys for singer Gloria Estefan have filed a lawsuit in federal court seeking at least $400,000 damages for a March accident that broke two vertebrae in her back. Ms. Estefan's family and staff joined her in the lawsuit, filed Thursday. The defendants are two truck drivers, their employers and other companies associated with the trucking firms at the time of the March 20 accident. Ms. Estefan, lead singer of the Miami Sound Machine, and her family and staff were headed from Washington, D.C., to a concert in Syracuse, N.Y., when their bus was rear-ended by a tractor-trailer while stuck in traffic halted because of an accident involving another tractor-trailer. Surgery to repair her back was performed in New York and she later moved back to her Miami area home, where she is recuperating.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Approves Recommendation to Ban North, Poindexter
DOC.TEXT: Costa Rica's congress has approved a recommendation to bar from the country John Poindexter, Oliver North and others involved in the Iran-Contra scandal. Thursday's vote is not legally binding, however. The legislature voted 51-1 with five abstentions in favor of the recommendations of a commission that also said former U.S. Ambassador Lewis Tambs and businessman Richard Secord should not be allowed to enter the country. The commission said Costa Rica was used during the Iran-Contra affair as a supply route for the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. President Oscar Arias, who hands over power to President-elect Rafael Angel Calderon on May 8, has not commented on the recommendations. Poindexter, North and Secord have been convicted in the secret operation during the Reagan adminstration to sell arms to Iran and use the profits to support the rebels fighting the then-leftist Nicaraguan government. Poindexter was national security adviser and North a White House aide during the Reagan administration. Secord is a retired Air Force major general. Tambs was accused of having knowledge of North's activities but was never charged. The commission found that Poindexter and North supported sending supplies to the Contras through Costa Rica, in violation of the Central American nation's neutrality. It also alleged that Tambs and rancher John Hull were involved in Contra operations in Costa Rica. ``This network allowed Colombian and Panamanian drug traffickers to transport drugs to the United States in exchange for arms for the Contras,'' the commission said in a statement. It recommended that Hull's Costa Rican nationality be annulled. The Indiana-born Hull, 70, took Costa Rican citizenship while living 20 years in the country as a rancher. Earlier this year, Costa Rica began seeking his extradition from the United States, where he fled last year while out on bail on charges of aiding the Contras. Hull has denied the charges. The congressional vote came two days after former President Daniel Oduber was suspended from participation in his political party for a year. The governing National Liberation Party banned Oduber for having accepted campaign contributions from an American accused of drug trafficking. Lionel Casey, who allegedly donated $12,000 to Oduber in 1985, is in jail in Costa Rica awaiting extradition to the United States on drug charges. Casey, 60, of Raleigh, N.C., has been in Costa Rica since 1982. The commission recommended that he be deported.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Warn That Brisbane Could Become Another Los Angeles
DOC.TEXT: Australia's third-largest city, Brisbane, could soon face smog as bad as the pollution in Los Angeles, scientists said today. The researchers warned in a report that without action, the city of 1 million could become an ``environmental disaster'' within a decade. Like Los Angeles, the capital of Queensland state is especially vulnerable to pollution because of its geographic location and atmospheric conditions, they said. The Brisbane area is the fastest growing in Australia, and the city's population is expected to more than double in the next 10 years. The study, by scientists at Griffith University, called for a reduction in the number of private cars in the city and better emission control for trucks. It also called for better public transport and stricter controls on industry. Without such measures, the report said, Brisbane could find itself choking in ``a petrochemical smog caused by an extremely unpleasant mixture of gases'' that could lead to health problems including respiratory disease, heart failure and eye irritation.

DOC.HEAD: Study Links Radon Gas to Variety of Cancers
DOC.TEXT: Radon gas, long known to cause lung cancer, may be linked to a variety of other cancers as well, British researchers said today. In an article in The Lancet, a respected British medical journal, three physicists from Bristol University said they had found a connection between radon levels and the incidence of certain non-lung cancers. The study used data from 15 countries, including the United States. Margo Oge, director of the radon program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, said that previously researchers have failed to link radon and non-lung cancers. Studies purporting to do so ``haven't been able to pass scientific scrutiny,'' she said Thursday in a telephone interview ahead of the article's publication. She said she could not comment specifically on the British study because she had not seen it. Radon is a dense, odorless gas, created by the radioactive decay of small quantities of uranium found in many types of rock. It has been known for decades to cause lung cancer. The scientists said they stumbled on the link to other cancers last September when they realized radon is highly soluble in the fatty globules found in bone marrow. ``Previous researchers seem to have made the mistake of only considering the amount of radon in the blood, where it appeared the effect was negligible,'' said physicist Jonathan Eatough, one of the authors. ``But when the fatty globules are examined, the radon becomes a significant factor in the dose to the bone marrow.'' The scientists said they found an association of radon exposure and leukemia in children and adults; brain, spine, bone and skin cancer in children; and kidney and skin cancer in adults. ``Our observations in general clearly warrant urgent and detailed further investigations to determine whether radon is indeed the causative factor as we hypothesize,'' the scientists said. They said some findings, such as the association of radon exposure and incidents of skin cancer, were unexpected. But they said it could explain current anomalies in the pattern of these cancers, such as the high incidence of melanoma in Scandinavian countries, where the population is not exposed to high levels of harmful ultra-violet rays from the sun. Dr. Denis Henshaw, another of the authors, said the study is actually ``good news scientifically'' because ``we believe we may have found a cause for cancer you can do something about.'' Radon seeps into homes and buildings through foundations and floorboards. Steps can be taken to keep it out, including sealing floorboards with plastic sheeting and installing below-floor extractor fans to channel the gas away. The countries in the study were Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, West Germany, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Norway, Netherlands, Poland, Switzerland, Sweden, Britain and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Farmland Values Up for Third Straight Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 1st Add is state-by-state table.
DOC.TEXT: Farmland values nationally rose in 1989 for the third straight year and may go up again in 1990, but the Agriculture Department isn't saying much about this year's prospects. Roger Hexem of the department's Economic Research Service says the agency's 1990 forecast will be issued later this spring. There are always uncertainties about farmland prices, and this year is a bit more complicated than usual, he said. Weather and general economic conditions are the usual concerns. And this year Congress is slowly grinding out a new farm bill that will set national agricultural policy for the next five years. Some of that will bear on federal price supports for key commodities such as wheat, corn and cotton. Export subsidies, research and marketing programs also enter into decisions on whether to buy or sell farmland. Hexem said the current multinational negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade are other unknowns that could influence land price movements. But the USDA economist said Thursday in a telephone interview that the average increase of farmland values in each of the last three years was a little more than 4 percent, which ``pretty much tracked the rate of inflation'' during the same period. ``I'm not saying that's going to happen (in 1990),'' Hexem said. ``But that's been kind of the historical trend over the last three years.'' A week ago, the USDA agency reported that farmland values nationally rose 4 percent, averaging $693 per acre as of Jan. 1, up from a revised average of $667 a year earlier. Hexem said revisions were made in state and national farmland values as a result of the 1987 census of agriculture. These revisions, based on the census information collected every five years, are part of the agency's regular longstanding procedure, he said. Despite the recent upturn in farmland values _ which include land and buildings _ the Jan. 1, 1990, national average of $693 per acre was still 16 percent below the record of $823 per acre in 1982. Hexem said estimates were developed from an ``opinion survey'' of farmers and ranchers about land values in their counties. The figures are not based on actual sales of farmland. The Jan. 1 land values in the Corn Belt showed only a 2 percent increase from a year earlier, including a 1 percent dip in Ohio and a 4 percent increase in Missouri. ``I would have expected the percentage increase (in the Corn Belt) to be higher than the survey indicated,'' Hexem said. Lower soybean prices probably had a dampening effect, he said. Pockets of drought still exist in the western Corn Belt and northern plains, which also can affect the price outlook. States estimates can vary greatly and often show much greater movements than the national figures, Hexem said. Some things happen in one state and not another. For example, Hexem said, the importance of water and the structure of agriculture in many of the Western states is much different from other regions. ``There's quite a range in the value of farmland, depending on whether or not you have water,'' he said. And there are other regional factors. In the Northeast, which has the highest regional value for farmland _ $1,802 per acre _ prices range from $5,080 per acre in Rhode Island to $1,029 in Maine. Hexem said the Northeast has no water problems as in the West, but there is a ``mix of demand'' for land in some states, including the demands of developers and people looking for second homes and retirement homes. The figures are for 48 states, with Alaska reported separately and Hawaii omitted entirely. Hexem said Alaska has farmland but that it represents a small portion of the state and is considered a special case for statistical purposes. Hawaii has a relatively small amount of farmland, which he said doesn't change hands very often. Here is a state-by-state list of weighted average per-acre values of farmland and buildings. The first column shows, in dollars, the revised value as of Feb. 1, 1989, and the second is the value as of Jan. 1, 1990. An 11-month period was used because the agency shifted to a Jan. 1 reporting date. Alaska, not on the following list, was reported at $232 per acre, down from a revised $250 a year earlier. There was no listing for Hawaii.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Town Snubs Governor, Votes to Hold Prairie Dog Shoot
DOC.TEXT: Ranchers and their friends voted to hold a prairie dog shooting contest and told the governor and others who didn't like the idea to ``buzz off.'' The Ten Ring Gun Club of Nucla and neighboring Naturita organized the contest recently to thin out the prairie dog population. They said the animals carry bubonic plague and dig holes that break the legs of cattle. Townspeople hoped the contests would be a tourist attraction. They invited hunting enthusiasts and visitors to the depressed town for the July 14-15 contest, where they estimated about 500 prairie dogs would perish. Animal rights got wind of the contest and lobbied Gov. Roy Romer and Democratic Rep. Ben Nighthorse Campbell, who announced their opposition. So the gun club held an open meeting in this town of 1,000 Thursday night to decide the fate of the contest. Only three of the 318 people who showed up voted against it. ``Governor Romer, Congressman Campbell, buzz off,'' Nucla Mayor John Vanderpool said after the vote. Romer and Campbell had said the hunt was a cruel spectacle and not a proper method of rodent extermination. Animal rights groups and humane societies wanted to save the prairie dogs. Officials in Nucla and Naturita, in a remote corner of southwest Colorado, said they hoped to make the shoot an annual affair. The towns are so desperate for jobs they tried unsuccessfully to lure a low-level radioactive waste dump to the area. The town needs something to bring it back to life, said elderly Nucla resident Thomas Langan. ``I don't care if it's a prairie dog shoot or a yuppie shoot,'' he said to great laughter from the crowd. Doylene Garvey said she was angered by city folk telling ranchers how to care for the land. ``They live in polluted cities where homeless people go, so why don't they put their energies to that,'' she said. Several speakers said the shoot was preferable to poison. Federal agencies have banned the use of most poisons because they enter the food chain when eagles, coyotes and other natural predators of prairie dogs eat the carcasses. One of the three people who voted against the shoot, Katherine Hesse of Nucla, said she is not against shooting prairie dogs and has shot many herself. ``But I don't like the circus ... It's not right,'' she said. ``If you have a problem on your land, take care of it and not for money. This is a poor way to handle it.''

DOC.HEAD: Suspect Unlikely to Stand Trial in Stabbing of Politician, Prosecutor Says
DOC.TEXT: A mentally disturbed woman who said she stabbed opposition politician Oskar Lafontaine to ``get in the news'' is probably unfit to stand trial, a prosecutor says. Lafontaine, who was stabbed in the neck with a butcher knife at a campaign rally, was in satisfactory condition at a Cologne hospital Thursday, a day after the attack. The attack on Lafontaine, a Social Democrat and Helmut Kohl's leading challenger in the December election, was the most serious on a top-ranking West German politician in the country's 41-year history. It raised security concerns among politicians in both East Germany and West Germany, but many conceded that absolute security is impossible without shutting off public access to officials. There was no indication the attack was politically motivated, said Helmut Schaefer, chief prosecutor for the state of North Rhine-Westphalia. Authorities said the suspect, identified as Adelheid Streidel, 42, was sent to a a psychiatric clinic for evaluation. She has a history of mental illness, they said. They said she admitted stabbing Lafontaine after approaching him with flowers and asking for his autograph at the campaign rally in Cologne. Schaefer said the woman probably is not fit to stand trial because of her mental condition. He quoted her as saying: ``I wanted to kill Mr. Lafontaine so that I would have to go to court and then I'd get in the news.'' Friends who visited Lafontaine Thursday said he was able to get out of his hospital bed and make jokes. Hans Jochen-Vogel, the Social Democratic Party chairman, said Lafontaine intends to ``remain the chancellor candidate.'' Vogel said Lafontaine narrowly escaped death. The knife missed a main artery by just a ``couple of millimeters,'' he said. ``Otherwise we would be in mourning.'' Social Democratic Party officials, told during a special meeting in Bonn that Lafontaine was out of danger, burst into applause. Lafontaine, 46, the governor of tiny Saarland state, is one of West Germany's most colorful and popular politicians. His stabbing brought an outpouring of sympathy from across the political spectrum. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was among those who sent telegrams wishing Lafontaine a speedy recovery, the official East German news agency ADN said. Lafontaine, whose left-leaning party trounced Kohl's Christian Democratic Union in state elections in January, is considered a tough opponent for the December national elections. He has opposed Kohl's call for speedy German unification.

DOC.HEAD: Former Welfare Recipient Offers Moral Support to Those Still on the Dole
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: When Lynda Wright was on welfare, strangers berated her in supermarket lines, social workers asked about her sex life and her heart sometimes told her she was doomed to fail. Five years after pulling herself off public aid, Wright helped found Welfare Alumni to spare today's recipients some pain. ``I want to hold out my hand to them and say, `You can make it,''' said the 46-year-old mother of four. ``Being on welfare is ... an experience that leaves scars.'' The organization was formed last year to attack myths about people on welfare. High on the list, Wright said, is that ``they're lazy .... and watch TV all day.'' In 1988, about 3.7 million families nationwide got help under the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program, according to the American Public Welfare Association in Washington. Association studies show about 30 percent of family heads who become eligible for assistance stay on welfare for less than a year, said spokesman Rick Ferreira. About 75 percent, like Wright, are on for less than five years. Wright's group is compiling a book to encourage those who are struggling to become self-sufficient. It will include photographs and stories of people who have gotten off welfare. Alumni members also speak to church, school and community groups, often retelling personal stories. Wright's nightmare, like other women on welfare, started when her husband divorced her 10 years ago and left her and the children with no money. ``I had the American dream: the family, the house, the kids, the car,'' she said of her 17-year marriage. ``And then all of a sudden I went from a nice income to zero. I went straight down.'' Wright couldn't find a job and was barely scraping together money to feed her children. Within months, her telephone, gas and electric service were cut off. ``We lived from day to day. If there wasn't anything for that day, sometimes my neighbors would be kind and lend us some food,'' Wright said. ``I remember standing at the door one day and breaking down. I knew I had to go on welfare. ... I didn't want to see my children starve.'' Wright had many dehumanizing experiences. A shopper behind her in a food store once criticized her for buying a beef roast intended to celebrate her daughter's good grades. The woman, Wright recalled, said, ```I'm working and I can't afford a beef roast. I can't see how you can afford one.''' Social workers on house visits eyed her possessions to make sure she wasn't spending money frivolously. They asked if she was sleeping with anyone to make sure there wasn't another source of support in the house that would make her ineligible for benefits. ``I felt less than a human being,'' Wright said. ``I felt like I was just stupid _ everybody knew how to get a job except me. Everybody had skills except me.'' But things changed. Wright found meaningful work and went off welfare. She has a fulltime job at the Public Welfare Coalition, an advocacy group where she and other women got the idea for forming the Alumni. ``We were just talking about how we'd been through a lot,'' Wright said. ``And we wanted to see how we could help somebody who's still going through it.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Cinema Group Woos Hollywood
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: First there was a Moscow McDonald's. Can a Gorky ``Porky's'' be far behind? Maybe not. The USSR Film Service Corp. has opened a Los Angeles office, encouraging U.S. moviemakers to film their projects in the Soviet Union. All comers _ from historical films to a Soviet ``Lonesome Dove'' called ``A Cowboy and a Cossack'' _ are welcome, say the organizers, even leftover Cold Warrior types. So far, the office has provided production assistance for filming in the Soviet Union of the movies ``Peter the Great'' and ``Dark Eyes,'' and the television shows ``Dallas,'' ``Head of the Class'' and ``Road to Africa.'' The two-person Film Service staff now is handling 60 projects in various stages of development. The latest is the cable movie ``Final Warning,'' starring Jon Voight as Dr. Robert Gale, the U.S. doctor who treated radiation sickness caused by the Chernobyl disaster. What are the advantages of shooting in the Soviet Union? The USSR Film Service tempts producers with an array of outdoor locations, affordable labor, a growing pool of actors and technicians and some fairly modern equipment. Such improvements only came recently. ``We have 39 motion picture studios in the country,'' said Yuri Spilny, the company's chief executive officer. ``But they are not in perfect shape and some of the equipment is outdated.'' Soyuzkinoservice, known as SKS, is the parent company of the Film Service, and helps provide logistical support. If you need the Soviet army for a battle scene, SKS will arrange it. Need help getting through customs? They can assist you there, too. SKS has entered into a joint deal with a British supplier to provide catering trucks, makeup trailers and lighting equipment for all productions. For the upcoming feature film, ``The Siege of Leningrad,'' SKS helped reconstruct a model of the title city in World War II period detail. ``It's a huge construction job,'' Spilny said. ``To do this in the United States would probably be four to five times more expensive.'' The film also will use German equipment left behind in the war. What happens if somebody wants to make a movie similar to the red scare drama ``Red Dawn''? ``If a film is pure nonsense _ well, it's still possible, but government organizations will not get involved with it,'' Spilny said. Several U.S. companies have expressed interest in making a film about Stalin, said David Gamburg, the president of Film Service. ``The Soviet Union hasn't yet dealt with Stalin himself because it's such a painful subject,'' Gamburg said. ``We've been trying not to do with Stalin what the NBC miniseries did about Mussolini. We want to make a philosophical drama and not romanticize him.'' The company takes on the work for a percentage of the film's budget, and will make close to $1 million for its work on ``Final Warning.'' Spilny said that in three years the company will be profitable. As a side business, the office is also trying to bring more Soviet films to American theaters. ``Russia wants to get into the world market,'' Spilny said. ``We do about 150 theatrical films a year, but there is no distribution beyond our borders.''

DOC.HEAD: Administration Accused of Blocking Testimony on Dam's Effects
DOC.TEXT: A House Interior Committee leader is accusing the Bush administration of blocking testimony from officials who could explain whether an electricity-producing dam is damaging the Grand Canyon. An Interior Department spokesman, however, says the administration will cooperate with Rep. George Miller's subcommittee probe of the Glen Canyon Dam on the Colorado River. ``The Department of Interior, by imposing a gag order on National Park and U.S. Fish and Wildlife employees, has demonstrated again its unwillingness to engage in a full public discussion about the impact of its operations on the Grand Canyon,'' Miller said Thursday after witnesses from those agencies failed to appear before his subcommittee on water, power and offshore energy resources. Miller says the Interior Department is moving too slowly on an environmental impact statement on the effects of the dam. He has introduced a bill that would force the department to change operations at the dam until the study is complete. The witnesses who testified at a hearing Thursday presented a scenario that pits preservation of one of the world's natural wonders against the need for electrical power in the southwestern United States. The daily fluctuations in the river flow caused by the dam have greatly changed the ecosystem of the river bed and the Grand Canyon, said W. Linn Montgomery, biologist from Northern Arizona University. Miller said a Department of Interior study issued last year found that the dam was having ``substantial adverse effects on the downstream resources'' including the Grand Canyon. ``It might as well be running hundreds of bulldozers down the canyon floor daily,'' he said. When only Dennis Underwood, commissioner of the Bureau of Reclamation, showed up at Thursday's hearing, Miller refused to accept his testimony. ``As chairman of the subcommittee, I could not allow the department to present distorted, one-sided testimony,'' said Miller. Steve Goldstein, Interior Department spokesman, said Underwood was prepared to present all views on the dam from the department, including those in disagreement with current policy. ``We don't dispute there is a dissenting view within the department,'' said Goldstein. ``That's normal with an agency with 10 bureaus and 70,000 employees.'' But he said Underwood was sent as a representative of the administration's view. Miller said he would schedule another hearing when the others could testify. Goldstein said they would appear. In a letter to Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan, sent after the hearing, Miller said: ``Glen Canyon Dam is being operated in a manner which threatens the Grand Canyon National Park, Glen Canyon National Recreation Area, endangered species and other fish and wildlife resources.'' ``The members of our subcommittees are entitled to have witnesses available who have the expertise and authority to address these problems,'' said Miller. There is no environmental emergency related to operation of the dam, said Joe Falbo of the Colorado River Energy Distributors Association, whose members buy power generated by the Glen Canyon Dam and others in the Colorado River Storage Project. ``Glen Canyon is really the backbone of the system and accounts for 70 percent of all the power that can be generated on CRSP dams in the Upper Colorado River Basin,'' said Falbo. He said the utilities turn to power from the dams at peak periods, allowing them to burn less coal and oil. ``Hydropower is a clean, renewable electric resource,'' he said. But Montgomery said, ``My greatest fear is that short-term financial gain may overrun considerations of the native plants and animals as a driving force behind management decisions,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: New Brakes on Shuttle Would Make Kennedy Landings Likely
With PM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: When Discovery glides to Earth after its mission to set loose the Hubble Space Telescope, the shuttle will be testing new brakes that could pave the way for Kennedy Space Center landings. Discovery is scheduled to touch down Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., where most of the 34 previous shuttle missions have ended over the past nine years. It will take about a week and $1 million to return Discovery to Kennedy Space Center, where it will be prepared for its next flight in October. If this cross-country trip could be avoided in the future, it would diminish the turnaround time for shuttle flights. The new carbon brakes, believed to slow shuttles quicker, are ``a stepping stone toward the program's desires to one day be able to at least plan on Kennedy landings again,'' said Discovery commander Loren J. Shriver. ``Whether they're done routinely or not, that will be a subject of many, many meetings,'' Shriver said in an interview prior to the mission. Kennedy's three-mile-long concrete runway provides considerably less room for maneuvering than the 44-square-mile lakebed at Edwards Air Force Base. The desert lakebed has eight designated runways up to 7{ miles in length. A concrete runway stretches 2.8 miles, but extends onto the natural clay surface of the lakebed. Twenty-seven shuttle landing occurred at Edwards. In 1982, Columbia was diverted to White Sands, N.M., because the normally dry lakebed was flooded. Five shuttle flights ended at Kennedy, the last one in April 1985. In that flight, Discovery suffered extensive brake damage and blew a tire. During the investigation that followed the Jan. 28, 1986 Challenger explosion, astronauts voiced concern over further Kennedy landings. The new carbon brakes, used for years by passenger planes, can withstand longer braking distances and higher braking temperatures than the older carbon-lined beryllium brakes. They also can be applied at higher landing speeds and are good for 50 touchdowns, compared to six or so for the beryllium brakes. Until the beryllium brakes were modified in the late 1980s, ``we used to find chunks of brakes on the runway,'' said Karen Corne, a NASA engineer who helped install the new brakes on Discovery in December. After Discovery lands, the brakes will be sent for analysis to B.F. Goodrich, their Ohio designer. ``Hopefully, we'll get to the point so we can just inspect them on landing, leave them on .. just put new wheels and tires on and fly again,'' Corne said. The brakes are similar in size and design, although the carbon brakes weigh 182 pounds each, 30 pounds more than the beryllium ones. The carbon brakes have an additional rotor and stator, and the axles are wider and stiffer to minimize tire wear. Shriver and Discovery pilot Charles Bolden Jr. flew simulators to get a feel for the new brakes a few months ago at Ames-Dryden Flight Research Facility at Edwards. They liked them better. ``I have a pickup truck and in the morning, the first time you drive it, you pull out of the driveway and you ease on the brakes and it wrrrrrrk, it just kind of grabs until it's ready,'' Bolden said. ``The carbon brakes, they don't grab.'' Discovery was the first shuttle to be modified for the new brakes. Depending on the results of the landing and another Discovery landing to be attempted on a concrete Edwards runway in October, Atlantis will be modified in 1991, followed by Columbia. NASA's newest shuttle, Endeavor, will have the carbon brakes when it comes on line next year. NASA will be shooting for one out of every two or three landings at Kennedy starting in late 1991. Central Florida's temperamental weather, however, is expected to be a determining factor. ``The weather can be perfectly good one minute and 15 minutes later, it's disastrous,'' Bolden said. Bolden ought to know. On his only other shuttle flight, in January 1986, the crew tried to land at Kennedy for three days but had to settle for Edwards. Two other, earlier flights also were moved from Kennedy to Edwards. ``The weather just didn't cooperate,'' Bolden said. ``The program will just have to live with that as we go along.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Finds Navy Negligent in AIDS Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Maureene is cq, 4th graf
DOC.TEXT: AIDS had no name in 1981. But that year the virus that causes the disease was present in blood Matsuko Gaffney received in a transfusion at a Naval hospital. In time the disease killed her and her son and infected her husband, a Marine officer, and a federal judge ruled Thursday that government negligence was to blame. U.S. District Judge Rya Zobel found that Mrs. Gaffney had to have the transfusion because doctors failed to perform a caesarean section when she was two weeks late in delivering her first child in September 1981. Though AIDS was unknown at the time, Zobel ruled that ``infection with a communicable disease was a foreseeable consequence of administering blood to a patient even in 1981.'' AIDS was identified as a disease in September 1982. Zobel's ruling lets Chief Warrant Officer Martin Gaffney seek compensation from the federal government. The judge ordered a second trial to determine damages for Gaffney and his daughter, Maureene, on whose behalf the government was sued for $55 million two years ago. Maureene, who is 6, is the only family member not infected by the virus. Gaffney's lawsuit claimed Dr. John Yeast, an obstetrician at the Long Beach Naval Hospital in California, mishandled Mrs. Gaffney's pregnancy by failing to perform a caesarean section when the birth was overdue. The baby eventually was stillborn and Mrs. Gaffney became infected and lost blood. It was then she received the contaminated blood. Gaffney, 40, who is still in good health and working at the South Weymouth Naval Air Station about 15 miles south of Boston, said he never doubted Zobel would rule in his favor. ``I'm just surprised it took this long for the decision. It's obviously very good news,'' Gaffney said. ``I just wish my wife had heard this before she left this world.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Marianne Bowler, who represented the government in the case, did not return requests for comment. Susan Hicks Spurlock, a spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office, refused to comment while the second trial is pending. Navy Lt. Bruce Williams, a spokesman at the Pentagon, said the Navy could not comment on the ruling until the judge's decision had been reviewed. The Long Beach Naval Hospital no longer has an obstetrics department and the doctor named in the case could not be located Thursday. Nearly two years after the transfusion, Mrs. Gaffney gave birth to Maureene and, two years after that, to a boy, John. Within a few months of his birth in July 1985, John became sickly and in May the following year he was diagnosed as having AIDS. The rest of the family was then tested for the deadly virus. The parents proved to be carrying the virus, but Maureene was not. John died of AIDS in August 1986 at the age of 13 months. His mother, a Japanese citizen, was 38 when she died less than a year later, in May 1987. The couple had been married seven years. The Navy discovered the blood was tainted by the AIDS virus after tracing the two donors for Mrs. Gaffney's transfusion. One donor tested negative. The other refused to be tested and it was learned he had been discharged from the Navy for homosexual activity.

DOC.HEAD: Town Settles With Ticketed Professor
DOC.TEXT: A college professor who claimed he was roughed up by a police officer during an arrest for failing to pay a $2 parking ticket won a $10,000 settlement from the town. William A. Rust filed a lawsuit in federal court in Boston in 1986, charging the officer violated his civil rights in the May 1983 arrest. Rust said a wrist injury he had suffered was aggravated by the officer's unnecessary use of force. ``I have no criminal record. I wasn't a threat to law and order and I certainly wasn't going to leave town,'' Rust said this week. Rust, a professor of politics at Framingham State College who has lived in Shrewsbury for 24 years, was arrested at his home after he failed to pay a 1981 parking ticket for violation of a parking ban on his street. Town Counsel T. Philip Leader said Rust had been notified several times that he was in default. Rust's attorney, Stewart Herrick, denied his client had been advised. ``I think it's an awful miscarriage of justice that he got $10,000,'' said Shrewsbury Police Chief Robert McGinley. The settlement was paid by the town's insurance company. Herrick countered, ``Certainly there must be more important things for the police to concern themselves with, or Shrewsbury must be an awfully peaceful little town.''

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Gets Earful From Mexico's President Over Abduction-Arrest
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari told Vice President Dan Quayle new rules are needed in the war on drugs following the abduction of a Mexican who was taken to the United States to face charges in the torture-slaying of a drug agent. Salinas ``indicated he would like to establish new rules of understanding between Mexico and the United States on drug cooperation,'' Quayle said after meeting with the president on Thursday. Mexico has accused the United States of having a role in the abduction of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, who now is awaiting trial in Los Angeles in the 1985 torture and murder of a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent. The incident caused intense controversy in Mexico and created resentment in the Salinas administration, which had boosted cooperation with the United States in fighting drug trafficking. A Bush administration official told reporters Salinas wants provisions for better advance notice of U.S. drug operations that involve Mexico and a better system of information sharing. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Quayle told the Mexican president that ``he thought we already were sharing information.'' The meeting was Quayle's final stop in a trip to ease Latin American hard feelings over December's U.S. invasion of Panama. Quayle's third Latin American swing since January ``completes the mission,'' said the vice president's press secretary, David Beckwith. Quayle on Wednesday attended the inauguration of Nicaraguan President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and delivered the first installment of a $24 million U.S. food aid package. The vice president said he and Salinas also discussed U.S.-Mexico trade relations and the situation in Central America following Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration. Mexico claims the seizure of Alvarez Machain violated its sovereignty, and Salinas said Monday in Los Angeles the incident threatened the international drug-fighting effort. ``This runs the risk of creating illegal habits among those who have the obligation of defending the law and could create a problem much larger than the one we are trying to combat,'' he said at the annual luncheon of The Associated Press. Quayle on Thursday reiterated the U.S. position that DEA agents in Mexico were not involved, as claimed by the Mexican government. The DEA has denied published reports that agents in the United States offered a bounty for Alvarez Machain's delivery. Quayle said U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh was still investigating.
