Alvarez Machain's lawyer has said DEA agents met a plane carrying Alvarez Machain at the airport in El Paso, Texas, on April 3, after he was abducted from his office in Guadalajara. Alvarez Machain is charged with reviving DEA agent Enrique Camarena after torture sessions so he could face more questioning. The Mexican attorney general's office has also been conducting an investigation into the abduction case, and published reports Thursday said six people had been arrested, including four members of the Mexican federal judicial police. Mexico has sentenced two drug lords and more than 20 others to long prison terms in the Camarena killing, but Alvarez Machain was never charged. The Salinas administration has greatly expanded the fight against drug trafficking and corruption in Mexico, seizing more cocaine in one year than had been seized in the previous decade. Salinas wants to reduce the drug issue's role as an irritant to U.S.-Mexico relations and focus on trade and commercial ties to revive Mexico's economy. However, the Alvarez Machain case brought domestic criticism that he is insufficiently concerned with Mexico's national integrity.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Committee Approves Line-Item Veto Measures
DOC.TEXT: The president would be able to reduce or veto outright individual items within money bills under proposed constitutional amendments approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee. ``Forty-three states give similar authority to their governors and I think it is time to have that at the federal level,'' Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., one of the sponsors, said after the measures won 8-6 approval Thursday. The committee's action, which came one day after President Bush renewed his call for line-item veto powers, set the stage for Senate floor action. Senate approval would send the proposals to the House. Approval there would put the issue before the nation's state legislatures. Bush told a White House ceremony on Wednesday that the ``president needs the power to make the tough calls on spending, take the heat and I'm perfectly prepared to do that.'' He urged speedy approval. Lawmakers, seldom enthusiastic about sharing the power of the purse, have been killing line-item veto proposals for more than a century. Simon's office said the Library of Congress reported that nothing similar had emerged from the Senate Judiciary Committee since April 21, 1884. Voting in favor of the measure were six Republicans plus Simon and Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala. Six Democrats voted against the measure. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, usually a critic of the concept, voted to send the measures to the Senate floor, saying their importance merited a decision by the full Senate. But he said he would be an opponent if a floor debate developed. Simon's version, co-sponsored by Sen. Alan J. Dixon, D-Ill., would give the president his choice of reducing or eliminating altogether individual line items in money bills. A simple majority in both houses of Congress could override the president's veto. The other version, sponsored by Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., would empower the president to veto line items but not reduce them. Overriding his action would take a two-thirds vote of both houses. Simon's version was similar to a provision in the Illinois state Constitution.

DOC.HEAD: US Allows Saudi Arabia to Lease Supercomputers
DOC.TEXT: The United States is allowing Saudi Arabia to lease two supercomputers but so far refuses to let Israel buy the same machines, according to industry and government officials. The computers have been leased to the government-owned Saudi Arabian Oil Co. to help increase the production of its oil wells. One of the supercomputers, a CRAY-2, was installed at the Saudi Arabian Oil computer center in the town of Dhahran late last year, according to the machine's manufacturer, CRAY Research of Minneapolis. The oil company already has one other supercomputer, an IBM model, a U.S. official said. An Israeli newspaper reported Thursday that Iraq had tapped into the Saudi computer to conduct sophisticated calculations for its missile development program. But U.S. officials said they could not confirm the report. A spokeswoman at Cray said each computer includes a sophisticated security system designed to prevent unauthorized use of the machine, including secret access codes and other devices. The spokeswoman, Kate Neessen, also said such lease deals include government-to-government pledges that the supercomputers would only be used for peaceful purposes. Another source familiar with the CRAY-2s said buyers undertake to prevent remote access to the computer so that only authorized personnel at the site can use it. The Saudi CRAY is being used to simulate conditions in underground oil reservoirs and compute the wells' capacity. ``These simulation models are highly complex, and Saudi Arabia's oil fields are the largest in the world,'' said a statement issued by Cray. The Saudi oil company already has one other supercomputer, an IBM model, a U.S. official said. Israel has applied for licenses to buy four supercomputers, CRAY-2s and IBMs, but its requests have been pending for as long as two years or more, according to U.S. officials. Two of the machines would go to universities, one to the Weizman Institute of Science and another to Israel's Military Industries, according to American sources. U.S. government agencies considering the requests are concerned that Israel could use the computers to improve its nuclear and missile arsenals. ``With the Saudis we don't have the same kinds of concerns,'' said one government official. ``They have no nuclear use for the machines; they are very far away from any nuclear capability,'' he added. This source and others who discussed the issue spoke on condition that they not be identified. The Commerce Department, which by law must license all supercomputer exports, does not comment on such sales. Also, Saudi Arabia has signed the international nuclear non-proliferation agreement, which Israel has not, another official said. The leases with Saudi Arabia were not considered controversial and received almost automatic approval from the Commerce Department, one official said. But the requests from Israel, as well as pending license applications from India and Brazil, are under review by an inter-agency committee that deals with licensing for countries with nuclear capabilities. U.S. officials are willing to sell India a supercomputer for a research institute but only on condition that the Indians allow outside inspections and follow other security guidelines. India already has one supercomputer that is used to forecast monsoons. Supercomputers are simply much larger and faster than normal computers, able to tackle in hours problems that might take weeks or months to run on a normal computer. Such problems include the complicated calculations necessary for designing nuclear weapons, breaking codes, predicting the behavior of oil reservoirs and forecasting the weather.

DOC.HEAD: Link Between Disease, Diet Supplement Maker Found in Four States
DOC.TEXT: Researchers in four states suspect that dietary supplement L-tryptophan from a single Japanese manufacturer caused the outbreak of a rare, sometimes deadly blood disorder, but the hunt for a contaminant continues. Scientists in South Carolina, New York, Oregon and Minnesota reported many of their states' cases of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, or EMS, occurred after patients took L-tryptophan made by the Japanese company. The fact that a single manufacturer has been implicated in the EMS outbreak means the likely cause of the illness is a product contamination, and not the supplement itself, said Dr. Ed Kilbourne, an EMS specialist for the national Centers for Disease Control. But researchers still don't know what sort of contaminant might be responsible or how it got there. ``The L-tryptophan use that's causing people to get ill is virtually universally from one particular company,'' Kilbourne said Thursday. The Food and Drug Administration recalled L-tryptophan earlier this year after it was linked to the painful blood disorder that has struck 1,500 Americans. Twenty-one EMS patients have died. South Carolina and New York researchers reported their findings Thursday during two days of meeting at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. Epidemiologists from Oregon and Minnesota reported similar findings Wednesday. The CDC has refused to name which of several Japanese L-tryptophan manufacturers produced the suspect product. ``There are still a number of ongoing investigations which are not yet complete,'' Kilbourne said. ``This is still a very complicated investigation.'' But the Showa Denko Co., one of Japan's largest chemical manufacturers, said in a statement Thursday that studies ``show a statistically significant association between our bulk L-tryptophan and the outbreak last fall'' of EMS. Showa Denko has been named in at least one lawsuit from an EMS patient, a $20 million claim from an Oregon woman. ``Although the precise cause of EMS has not been identified, we are pleased that progress has been made toward solving the medical mystery,'' Koji Yanai, president of Showa Denko America, said in the statement. ``We will continue to cooperate with state and federal health authorities and independent researchers with the goal of finding the precise cause and treatment of EMS.'' L-tryptophan is taken for excess weight, sleeplessness and depression. Before its recall by the Food and Drug Administration, it was widely sold in health food stores. The blood disorder is marked by severe muscle and joint pain, breathing difficulties, swelling of the arms and legs, skin rash, fatigue, cough and sometimes fever. In some cases, victims show signs of congestive heart failure and develop a condition that causes progressive weakness and sometimes leads to paralysis.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Budget Panel Rejects Bid to Cut Social Security Taxes
DOC.TEXT: A politically sensitive proposal to cut Social Security taxes failed its first formal congressional test. The Democratic-run Senate Budget Committee voted 17-6 Thursday against endorsing a plan that would slash the retirement program's payroll tax by $36.5 billion next year. The vote was non-binding, but it provided the first sounding of lawmakers' attitudes toward an idea that has been in the spotlight since its introduction last December by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y. The tally came as the Budget Committee remained stalled in its efforts to craft a $1.2 trillion budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The panel rejected five deficit-cutting plans containing savings ranging from $43 billion to $56.5 billion. Across the Capitol, the House debated its own $1.24 trillion budget for next year, which provides less for defense and more for domestic programs than President Bush prefers. Final House approval of the Democratic-written plan is expected Tuesday. The House rejected two Republican-sponsored alternatives. A proposal by Rep. John Kasich of Ohio to freeze military and domestic spending at current levels lost, 305-106. A plan by Rep. William Dannemeyer of California featuring the use of gold-backed bonds to reduce the government's debt costs was defeated, 354-48. Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said he expected his panel to adopt a budget next week that would slash the deficit by about $40 billion. The Gramm-Rudman law requires at least $37 billion in deficit-reduction in the upcoming fiscal year. ``I'm not discouraged at all,'' Sasser said after Thursday's repeated ``no'' votes. The Social Security tax cut proposal, offered by Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., was virtually identical to the bill introduced by Moynihan. Moynihan advanced the idea as a way of shrinking annual Social Security surpluses, which he says mask the true size of the budget deficit. He says the tax hits low- and middle-income people the hardest because it applies to only the first $51,300 of annual wages. Moynihan's plan ignited political warfare. The White House accused Democrats of using it as an excuse to eventually reduce Social Security benefits. Some Democrats hailed it as their party's own tax-cut plan, while others complained that the proposal would balloon the deficit even further. Nine Democrats and eight Republicans voted against Hollings' measure, while four Democrats and two Republicans supported it. The provision would have lowered the 6.2 percent payroll tax to 5.1 percent next Jan. 1. The tax is paid by both wage earners and employers. A family with an income of $32,000 would save $400 a year. The Budget Committee's Democrats were split over each of the five deficit-cutting plans. Passage was impossible because GOP senators voted solidly against the proposals. Republicans say congressional negotiations with the White House are the only way to concoct money-saving measures that have a chance of becoming law. All the Democratic plans relied more on defense cuts and tax collections than Bush wants. They also surpassed the $37 billion in deficit reduction the president proposed in January.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Closes Up
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 29,584.80, up 160.22 points, or 0.54 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Fake Pictographs for Oliver Stone Film Won't Come Off
DOC.TEXT: Moviemakers defaced a limestone cavern in the Mojave Desert by painting fake Indian pictographs on the rock for a scene in an Oliver Stone film on singer Jim Morrison, park rangers said. State officials had allowed Stone to shoot part of his film, ``The Doors'' at Mitchell Caverns Natural Preserve in the Providence Mountains State Recreation Area. The artists were required to paint the pictographs using a powdery substance they said could be vacuumed off the walls. But someone used water in the process, causing the substance to seep into the limestone. The problem was discovered when the film company tried to vacuum the designs after the filming in March and failed, said Steven Hansen, chief ranger for the state park system's Mojave River District. ``This is absolutely criminal,'' said Elden Hughes of the Sierra Club. ``This shows total disrespect for a tremendous and rare resource.'' Producers of ``The Doors,'' which comes from the name of the late Morrison's rock group, said they contacted art restoration experts and specialists at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu to tackle the problem. ``This is something we are very concerned with,'' said Alex Ho, producer of ``The Doors.'' The film company ``will spare no expense to remove the symbols, but experts are few and far between. We are making every effort to solve this problem.'' Mitchell Caverns, about 35 miles west of Needles, is known for its spectacular stalagmite, stalactite and other mineral formations created several million years ago. For 500 years, the caves were used by the Chemehuevi Indians for shelter and ceremonial purposes. ``The whole cave site was part of the initiation process for the shamans,'' said Scott Simons, president of the Mojave Desert chapter of the Sierra Club. ``This is like taking a can of spray paint into a cathedral.'' Hansen said Stone applied in February for permission to shoot a scene in the largest cavern, the 250-foot-long Tecopa Cave. Actor Val Kilmer, portraying Morrison, wanders about the cave in a hallucinatory state and meets a holy man. The scene calls for Morrison to study Indian pictographs on the cave walls, which the Academy Award-winning Stone had to create. About 100 stick figures and other Indian symbols were drawn on the limestone. ``We're not going to rest until it's off and everyone is happy,'' said Larry Fulton, the film's art director.

DOC.HEAD: Seawolf Submarine Faces Pentagon, Congressional Scrutiny
DOC.TEXT: The Seawolf attack submarine hasn't touched the water and it is already on the defensive at the Pentagon and on Capitol Hill. With Defense Secretary Dick Cheney expected to complete an evaluation of Seawolf next month, a congressional panel added to the siege atmosphere Thursday by detailing ``serious deficiencies'' and cost overruns in the sub's computer system. ``The Seawolf represents the newest generation of attack submarines and perhaps the newest generation of waste and abuse at the Pentagon,'' said Rep. John Conyers Jr., D-Mich., chairman of a House Government Operations subcommittee investigating the program. The inquiry turned up an internal Navy memo pointing out problems in a sophisticated computer system that runs everything from the engine to the sub's weapons systems. ``Without the computer software, the Seawolf submarine is just so much metal floating around out there,'' said Conyers. The probe conducted by Conyers' national security subcommittee and the congressional General Accounting Office focused on the BSY-2 computer system, referred to colloquially as the ``busy-two.'' The computer is built for the Navy by the General Electric Co. in Syracuse, N.Y. It is designed specifically for the Seawolf, which is to be built in Groton, Conn., by General Dynamics Corp., and in Newport News, Va., by the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Co. ``It has recently come to my attention that serious deficiencies in the busy-two software development program have been identified by Department of Defense software experts,'' Conyers said. ``However, it is by no means clear that corrective actions have been taken.'' At Thursday's hearing, Navy officials in charge of Seawolf said they were unaware of a March 19 internal Navy memo detailing problems in the computer software. Conyers had copies of the memo, but did not make them publicly available. The Navy's top acquisition official, Assistant Secretary Gerald A. Cann, said he would respond to the memo as soon as it could be studied. But he said there was little risk that any technical problems would significantly delay delivery of the system to Groton, where the first Seawolf is under construction. ``I don't think we have a flaming disaster here,'' Cann said. GE spokesman George Jamison said it was inappropriate to comment on an internal Navy memo. According to Conyers, the memo listed a number of problems including the Navy's failure to program all of the computers' complex function in a single computer ``language'' developed for sophisticated weaponry. The BSY-2 is specifically designed to enable Seawolf to detect and locate targets faster than existing submarine combat systems and to allow operators to detect and attack multiple targets. Frank Conahan, who headed the GAO investigation of Seawolf, called the BSY-2 system ``one of the most technically challenging and complex software development efforts ever undertaken for a submarine.'' The Navy has no alternative to the BSY-2 system under consideration, Conahan said, and problems in development of the computer could lead to costly delays in completion of the submarines. Rep. Frank Horton, R-N.Y., the ranking Republican on the subcommittee, noted there has already been a $140 million cost overrun in completion of the first two BSY-2 systems. Pending congressional approval, the Navy plans to buy 29 Seawolfs by the year 2000 at an estimated cost of $44 billion. GE was awarded a $1.8 billion contract to develop the BSY-2 in 1988. Assuming the entire run of submarines is built, the computer equipment alone would account for $7.4 billion of the cost, Conahan said. Conyers said it is far more likely that the pressure to reduce defense spending will scale down the size of the Seawolf program significantly.

DOC.HEAD: No Cloaks and Daggers in Today's World of Corporate Snooping
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to fix typo; SUBS 8th graf, `He was,' to DELETE extraneous words
DOC.TEXT: Bob Margulies doesn't believe in cloaks and daggers, midnight break-ins or bugging. He's a spy by another name _ manager of competitive assessment. Margulies uses computer know-how and industry smarts as the chief snoop for McDonnell Douglas Corp. in Long Beach, Calif. He probes the competition with legal methods. ``In our business, when you launch a new design, they're so expensive that you're really betting the farm,'' Margulies said Thursday. ``So if you make a mistake, you don't have a second chance.'' As recently as a few years ago, most American corporations were satisfied to concentrate on researching their own markets and customers. But many are finding that knowing the competition thoroughly can help a company capitalize on its own strengths, shore up weaknesses, take advantage of opportunities and counter threats. Enter Margulies, and hundreds of other corporate spies who have banded together to form the Society of Competitor Intelligence Professionals _ written code of ethics and all. ``It's clearly a profession whose time has come,'' said Jan P. Herring, a CIA analyst for 20 years, until 1983. ``What has caused it to happen is competition, particularly among American companies that for the first time are experiencing both international and corporate competition.'' Herring is vice president of The Futures Group in Glastonbury, Conn., a consulting company that helps corporations design, develop and operate their own intelligence organizations. He was on hand Thursday for the annual meeting of the 4-year-old, 1,400-member society. In Japan, corporate spying is an old and respected custom, Herring said. ``The Japanese are the professionals,'' he said. ``They're the ones who started it. They do it almost second nature. It's just part of their companies.'' Margulies, new president of the society, said the Japanese ``have honed their techniques for gathering and analyzing information to the point where they play it like an instrument like a professional musician.'' Corporate spying, unlike its notorious relative _ industrial espionage _ is an honorable business, Margulies said. Corporate spies don't try to ferret out confidential information or bug meetings in their rivals' offices. Rather, they rely on public information and interviews with experts. ``It is not glamorous work,'' said Margulies. ``It is pure, unadulterated research _ collecting data, interpreting that data and communicating to your management or customer.'' The information explosion of the past decade, fueled by more powerful computers and a proliferation of data banks and specialized publications, has enabled corporate spies to find out almost anything they want about competitors. Advanced degrees and computer expertise are the new cloaks and daggers. ``Ninety-five percent of what you need is readily accessible. That additional five percent that you can't get legally is not going to help you that much. So why throw your career down the drain? Why embarrass your company. It's a no-no,'' Margulies said. Margulies estimated that more than 10,000 people work in competitor intelligence for hundreds of companies, many of them in marketing, strategic planning or financial departments. Those who are good at it are precious, Herring said. ``A good intelligence analyst ... pulls together the pieces of the puzzle,'' he said. ``You'll never get all the pieces. You may sometimes get 70 percent. But he can see the picture. When you find those kinds of people, they're real jewels.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress Ponders `Gratuity' To Senator's Widow
DOC.TEXT: It pays to die in Congress. The $3.4 billion spending bill that Congress is considering includes a $98,400 ``gratuity'' for the widow of the late Sen. Spark Matsunaga of Hawaii. Matsunaga died nearly two weeks ago after a long battle with cancer. The Senate benefits office said the one-time benefits have been routinely paid to spouses of members of Congress who die in office. The payment equals the amount of the lawmaker's annual salary. The payment is unrelated to any life insurance policy the lawmaker might have, the benefits office said. Members of Congress are eligible to participate in the life insurance programs offered to other federal employees.
DOC.HEAD: Administration: Ban on `Saturday Night Specials' Would Harm Citizens
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration argues that extending a ban on imported ``Saturday night specials'' to domestic arms manufacturers would deprive some Americans of the ability to defend themselves with handguns. Assistant Attorney General S.G. Dennis Jr. told the House Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on crime Thursday that a total ban on the handguns commonly known as ``Saturday night specials'' would ``deprive citizens who do not already own a handgun of their ability to obtain one suitable for self-defense but not for sporting purposes.'' Gun control opponents paint the attempt to outlaw small, cheaply made handguns as a class and racial issue because poor people, especially blacks, are more often the victims of crime and inadequate police protection. But the committee's chairman, William J. Hughes, D-N.J., and other Democrats said it was hypocritical to ban imports and not domestic versions of the weapons.
DOC.HEAD: Dugan To Be Nominated As Air Force Chief Of Staff
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has chosen Gen. Michael J. Dugan, commander in chief of U.S. Air Forces in Europe, to be Air Force chief of staff at the Pentagon. The selection was announced Thursday. If his nomination is confirmed by the Senate, Dugan will succeed Gen. Larry D. Welch, whose term expires June 30. Dugan, 53, from Albany, N.Y., holds several posts in Europe simultaneously. He is commander of Allied Air Forces Central Europe; commander in chief of U.S. Air Forces in Europe; and Air Force component commander, United States European Command.
DOC.HEAD: Rehnquist Rejects Seabrook Appeal
DOC.TEXT: A final appeal to delay start-up of the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant has been turned aside by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. The decision Thursday clears the way for the reactor to begin routine operations. Without comment, Rehnquist rejected a bid by opponents of the plant to hold up operation until a lower-level federal appeal can be heard next September. ``We and the other (opponents) continue to have very serious concerns about the operation of that plant and that's why we could not in good conscience go ahead without exhausting every legal remedy available,'' said Mary Breslauer, a spokesman for Massachusetts Attorney General James Shannon, who is leading the anti-Seabrook forces. Plant spokesman Ron Sher said the Seabrook reactor is currently being operated at 8 percent power and the power plant is on the verge of producing its first commercial electricity, more than two decades after it was first conceived. ``That will be the most significant milestone in Seabrook station's history,'' Sher said. ``That will mark the first time that Seabrook's electricity will be traveling through the power lines of New England to homes and businesses and industries.''

DOC.HEAD: M-19 Leader Led One of Colombia's Most Active Guerrilla Groups
With PM-Colombia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Seven weeks after leading his leftist guerrillas into the political system, presidential candidate Carlos Pizarro died the violent death he long eluded as an insurgent. Pizarro was on a campaign trip when he was assassinated aboard a crowded jetliner in flight Thursday. He completed a peace settlement with the government on March 8, and in a dramatic ceremony members of his April 19 Movement guerrilla group surrendered their weapons to international observers. Mortars, machine guns, assault rifles and pistols were stacked in a huge pile and hauled off to a forge to be melted down for a peace monument. The government pardoned the guerrillas and allowed the country's most notorious guerrilla group, also known as M-19, to become a political party. Pizarro was its candidate for the May 27 presidential elections. He was murdered before the monument could be made and before he could test democracy's promise of a better future. Pizarro, 38, was from an upper-class family, the son of a navy admiral. But he came to believe Colombia's rigid political system could only be changed through violence. He was a handsome man, standing a trim 5-foot-10, fair-skinned, with dark, curly hair cropped short and a mustache. He had a sharp jaw that he thrust forward in defiance when he was angry. His hobby was guns. Pizarro, who never married, joined M-19 in 1974. The April 19 Movement took its name from the date of a presidential election that Pizarro and other university students said was fraudulent. The group started off with high spirits and high adventure. The rebels stole the sword of Latin American liberator Simon Bolivar from a Bogota museum. It has yet to be returned. Pizarro and friends hijacked milk trucks, took them to poor neighborhoods and distributed the milk to people who thronged around them, cheering and clapping the rebels on the back. The emboldened group then began to kidnap people, hijack planes and raid small towns to rob banks. It blew up police stations and ransacked stores for supplies. M-19's bloodiest operation came on Nov. 6, 1985, when about three dozen rebels seized the Palace of Justice in Bogota. More than 100 people, including 11 Supreme Court justices and all the guerrillas, were killed in fighting during the next three days. Pizarro became commander of M-19 in 1986, after its fifth successive leader was killed. Last year, he started negotiating the peace agreement with the government. After disbanding the guerrilla group last month, Pizarro changed his combat gear for brightly colored sports coats and began campaigning for the presidency. His vehement attacks on the United States ended, and his views took a 180- degree turn. Fidel Castro should allow other political parties in Cuba, he said. He applauded Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's victory in the presidential election over leftist Sandinistas in Nicaragua. He also said Panama's former strongman, Gen. Manuel Noriega, now in a Florida jail facing drug trafficking charges, got what he deserved because of his corruption. Last year, in an interview with The Associated Press at his mountain stronghold, he told of his desire to negotiate peace. He was asked whether he feared coming down out of the mountains and being killed by right-wing death squads who have murdered hundreds of leftists in Colombia. ``I'm willing to die for what I believe in,'' Pizarro replied.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Nikkei Close Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed higher against the yen Friday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rose moderately. The dollar finished the week at 159.08 yen, up 0.31 yen from Thursday's close of 158.77 yen. After opening at 159.43 yen, the currency ranged between 158.95 yen and 159.47 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which shed 139.78 points Thursday, gained 160.22 points, or 0.54 percent, to close at 29,584.80. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond slipped to 85.83 points as of 3 p.m., down from Thursday's close of 86.09. Their yield rose to 7.405 percent from the previous day's 7.350 percent. Dealers said the dollar's strength reflected its rise in New York overnight, where climbing long-term interest rates boosted the currency. Rates on long-term U.S. Treasury bonds rose above 9 percent for the first time in almost a year. Dealing was more active in cross-trading involving the yen and European currencies such as the West German mark, said Masato Hayashi, a Bank of Tokyo dealer. ``Ahead of the GNP report in the United States and long holidays here, trading will remain inactive today,'' he predicted. The Commerce Department is scheduled to report its initial estimate for the U.S. gross national product later Friday. Trading also was quiet because of Japan's ``Golden Week'' series of holidays, which starts Saturday and continues through May 6 for most Japanese companies. Next week, the stock and currency markets will only be open Tuesday and Wednesday. The dollar is unlikely to continue rising as investors are inclined to sell the currency at around 159.50 yen to take profits, Hayashi said. The price of the benchmark No. 119 Japanese 10-year government bonds fell to 85.88 from Thursday's close at 86.09. That boosted their yield to 7.395 percent from 7.35 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Tobacco Industry Denies Health Agency's Promotions Accusation
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials say tobacco companies are using snappy promotions to target young people in marketing campaigns far afield of their traditional techniques. The national Centers for Disease Control said Thursday more than two-thirds of the tobacco industry's record $3.3 billion advertising and promotion budget in 1988 went to such things as event sponsorships and free sample giveaways. ``Promotional efforts differ in important ways from traditional advertising,'' the CDC said. The health agency contended free samples may encourage children to try smoking and sponsorship of sports events such as televised tennis and racing increases children's recognition of cigarette brands. But an official of The Tobacco Institute insisted that promotion is the best way to target a shrinking smokers' market and said accusations that the industry is targeting children are ``dead wrong.'' The CDC's accusations are ``a judgment call based on the preconceived notion that the industry is attempting to recruit underage smokers,'' said Thomas Lauria, assistant to the president of The Tobacco Institute. ``The industry will fire anyone working who gives cigarettes to kids _ that's in our code of ethics,'' he said. ``And if there are underage people watching tennis on TV, they're watching the tennis.'' He also criticized the CDC for ``grazing in marketing pastures.'' ``There's some question in my mind what the CDC is doing over in a field far unrelated to its research,'' he said. ``I wouldn't think of going into AIDS research and making comments based on their numbers.'' Citing Federal Trade Commission data, the CDC said the industry in 1988 spent just over $1 billion on publication and sign advertising, or 32 percent of total ad and promotion expenses, while $2.2 billion, or 68 percent, went to promotions. That was a flip-flop from 1975, when $366 million, or 75 percent, was spent on advertising, and $125 million, or 25 percent, went to promotions.

DOC.HEAD: Going Door-to-Door To Do the Counting
LaserPhoto NR1
DOC.TEXT: An army of census counters has hit the streets to fill in the blanks on some 37 million American households whose residents have yet to be counted. Thousands of ``enumerators'' began their door-to-door mission Thursday in 100 metropolitan areas nationwide. U.S. Census Bureau officials, concerned about the response to the pavement beaters, sought to assure people that it was safe to open doors. ``They're people from your neighborhood,'' said B.J. Welborn, a spokeswoman for the Boston regional office of the U.S. Census Bureau. ``We're trying to put a human face on the count.'' Nearly 40 percent of more than 95 million census questionnaires sent out in March haven't been returned, and millions more people never received forms. The door-to-door canvassing is aimed at filling in all those missing names. The next phase in the $1.3 billion census, beginning May 3, is to take the door-to-door counting to 300 smaller communities. Collecting data on about 250 million Americans couldn't be expected to be easy. But the 1990 count has been especially vexing. For one thing, there are more doorbells to be rung than during the last census. Only 63 percent of households nationwide mailed back census forms this year, 12 percent fewer than in 1980, officials say. In some big cities the return rate is even lower. The Census Bureau says only 52 percent of New York City residents returned their census forms. That does not include households that never got forms: The city said 19 percent of 2,008 residents it polled had not received census forms in the mail. ``That translates to 600,000 households or 1.5 million people,'' said Hulbert James, the New York City census coordinator. ``That is very scary to us.'' Another potential problem will be getting and keeping enough enumerators to finish the census, said William M. Hunt, who studies the project for the General Accounting Office. ``It's going to be much tougher than the bureau thought it would be,'' Hunt said. ``We'll have to wait and see whether the recruitment is enough to sustain them through the process. They tend to lose a lot of people.'' Recruiters have been struggling in more affluent areas, like New York's Park Avenue and California's Silicon Valley, but have gotten more than enough applicants for counting jobs in poorer areas like New York's East Harlem and around Kentucky coal mines, The New York Times reported today, citing a survey of district census offices. The jobs pay between $5 and $8 an hour. The 1,200 Boston area counters sworn in Thursday were looking at a long afternoon of dancing around potholes, befriending neighborhood dogs and knocking on doors when no one is at home. ``I don't like going into strange people's houses,'' said Sheila Moretti, a mother of two and lifelong fixture in this city's close-knit, mostly Italian North End neighborhood. ``But it helps that I'm a familiar face. People know they can trust me.'' But getting in the door is only half the battle. ``Then you have to convince people that everything we ask is confidential,'' said Paula DeCosta, who manages a district census office. ``We would be fined and imprisoned if we gave out any information.'' New immigrants, who sometimes associate the federal government with taxes or deportation, are often among the most reluctant to confide in badge-carrying counters. ``They don't know it's for their own good,'' said Yuri Quinnie of the city's Hyde Park section. ``I didn't understand it at first either.'' Communities nationwide will earn their piece of the federal pie based on the 1990 census results. Congressional representation and federal funding for education, housing, medical and other local needs are at stake. Mike Costelnik, an enumerator in Bayonne, N.J., wasn't discouraged by getting replies from only five of the 50 households he tried on his first day on the job. `It was the afternoon,'' Costelnik said. ``I can always come back and get them tomorrow night. I am confident I will get them at some point.''

DOC.HEAD: OAS Supplying Contras With Food, Despite Refusal to Hand in Weapons
DOC.TEXT: The Organization of American States has begun providing food to Contra rebels, even though the fighters say they will keep their weapons until their Sandinista enemies leave the military. The guerrillas are supposed to lay down their weapons in return for such aid, but one OAS official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Thursday the organization fears the rebels would resort to ``felonies'' if they go hungry. One rebel commander threatened that his forces would ``survive by whatever means necessary'' if provisions were cut off. The rebels promised to disarm by June 10, but they have balked over fears of retaliation by leftist Sandinistas who remain at their posts in the police and the military. President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro announced Wednesday she would allow Gen. Humberto Ortega to remain a leader of the army. Ortega is brother of former President Daniel Ortega, who led the Sandinistas in their nine-year war against the U.S.-backed Contras. Mrs. Chamorro's decision has split her own U.S.-backed coalition. On her first full day in office Thursday, two Cabinet appointees were refusing to serve as long as Gen. Ortega remained in place. A Thursday morning news conference by Mrs. Chamorro was canceled without explanation, and she remained out of sight for most of the day. Victor Jimenez, an OAS delegate providing aid to demobilize the Contras, said more than 900 pounds of rice, corn and beans had been delivered since the previous afternoon to rebel chiefs for distribution among the troops. Jimenez spoke in an interview at the U.N.-OAS tent camp headquarters outside the mountain hamlet of El Amparo in north-central Nicaragua. In an accord signed last week, the Contras, the Sandinistas and the new government agreed OAS aid would be provided to combatants after they turned their weapons over to U.N. peacekeepers. In El Amparo, Maj. Ed Peterson of the U.N. force told journalists that not a single Contra had turned over his weapon as of Thursday afternoon. El Amparo sits in a valley in one of five internationally monitored areas. An estimated 9,000 Contras are supposed to gather in the designated areas in coming days. On Thursday, the rebels roamed the 450-square-mile area around El Amparo at will and unsupervised. They were well armed with Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifles, grenade launchers and other materiel. Under last week's accord, they were to begin handing over weapons to U.N. forces Wednesday afternoon following Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration. However, an assembly of 500 rebels on Wednesday ridiculed an invitation from Mrs. Chamorro's delegate and U.N. and OAS representatives to begin giving up their arms. The Contras say they will remain armed, mobilized and ready to resume civil war until the army is either disbanded or overhauled to eliminate Sandininsta control. ``In any case _ demobilized or not _ these people have to continue eating,'' said Jimenez, defending the food program. Cmdr. ``Jimmy Leo,'' a member of the Contra general staff, and four other commanders in the hamlet of El Destino scorned any attempt to try to link delivery of food to the surrender of weapons. ``If they think they're going to condition food on the handing over of a rifle, they can load up their food and take it back where they got it,'' said Jimmy Leo, who spoke in an interview five miles from the U.N.-OAS base. Israel Galeano, the Contras' top commander, told his troops in an address Wednesday: ``If, for not receiving any weapons, the international organizations pack up and leave and don't give us any food, so be it. We will remain intact and vigilant, waiting for the changes that have to be made.'' Jimmy Leo said that, in the event of a cutoff of OAS supplies, ``We would consider the accords broken and would spread out throughout the country. We're guerrillas and prepared to survive by whatever means necessary.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Riot Police Deployed at Shipyard Occupied by Strikers
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of striking workers armed with steel pipes and firebombs set up barricades today to keep out 18,000 riot police deployed outside the country's largest shipyard. Management and union officials of Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. said there was little room for compromise. The shipyard has been closed, and news reports quoted government sources as saying force may be used to end the strike. The main dispute is the union's demand for the release of four labor leaders arrested in earlier protests. The company maintains that judicial matters are out of its domain. Last year, the government sent in 12,000 police, supported by helicopters, to end a bitter 109-day strike at the shipyard. Hyundai said it lost $6 million a day in last year's strike. The mood in Ulsan, an industrial city about 200 miles southeast of Seoul, was tense today as riot police with shields and clubs surrounded the huge seaside shipyard. About 10,000 militant workers, many of whom have occupied the yard for three days, held a rally and burned a coffin symbolizing the police. ``We have no choice but to fight,'' said one union leader speaking on condition of anonymity. The workers piled up ladders and other giant steel fixtures to create a wall to seal off the shipyard's main gate. Hundreds of workers wearing helmets and armed with steel pipes patrolled the yard. News reports said police were mobilizing fire trucks, helicopters and bulldozers to prepare for action. ``Police intervention appears imminent,'' the influential Chosun Ilbo newspaper quoted a government official as saying. Gas and power supplies to the shipyard were cut Thursday night. Cafeterias inside were shut down, and 4,000 management workers were withdrawn, the company said. The Hyundai shipyard has about 24,000 workers on its payroll; about 20,000 are unionized. The company said its shipyard is the world's largest, capable of building 14 large ships simultaneously. Sales last year totaled $1.5 billion. The shipyard is a subsidiary of the giant Hyundai group, which produces cars, computers and many consumer goods. Negotiations between the company and the union broke down Thursday night, and the union said there were no plans for further talks. On Thursday, the government warned ``strong countermeasures'' would be taken to end what it called any ``illegal'' strikes that are liable to increase social unrest and hurt the Korean economy, already in a recession. Hyundai workers said three union leaders resigned Thursday, charging that the union is controlled by hard-liners connected with dissident groups fighting for political causes. In Seoul on Thursday night, radical students firebombed four automobile showrooms of Hyundai Motor Co. No one was hurt, but some windows were broken, police said. A major radical student group, the National Council of Student Representatives, claimed responsibility for the attack. It pledged to mount more protests in support of the striking Hyundai shipyard workers.

DOC.HEAD: Survivors Cling to Branches, Wade to Rescue in Texas
DOC.TEXT: Survivors told of clinging to tree branches and wading to rescue in the dark through floodwaters swollen by up to 16 inches of rain in north-central Texas. Storms that swept the area Wednesday and Thursday left at least three dead. Two others, swept from their vehicle into 13-foot-deep waters Wednesday in the Texas Panhandle, were still missing. No rain was forecast for the area today or Saturday. National Guard troops pulled people from their homes before dawn Thursday in Brownwood, 120 miles southwest of Fort Worth, where 16 inches of rain fell overnight. About 45 people were in a shelter there Thursday night. ``It was just like a lake,'' said resident Robert B. Allen. ``I had heard the weather reports on the TV and radio, but I didn't expect it to happen so quickly.'' Four young children were rescued Thursday from Dry Creek in Young County, about 100 miles west of Dallas, after the canoe they were riding in capsized, spilling them and their father. Six-year-old Sarah Smith and her siblings, David, 7, James, 9, and Karen, 10 _ all of them wearing lifejackets _ clung to branches of trees for an hour until they were rescued, officials said. They said the family had decided to go canoeing because the creek, as its name suggests, is usually dry. Authorities evacuated up to 130 campers, many elderly people stranded atop recreation vehicles and mobile homes, from a park in Proctor Lake, 100 miles southwest of Fort Worth on Wednesday night. For rain-weary authorities in Parker County, just west of Dallas, the flooding was the third in a series of disasters. A twister caused widespread property damage in the area Wednesday, when emergency officials were still trying to mop up a 4,200-gallon oil spill into the water supply. Flooding also hit Galveston Island. No evacuations had been ordered by early today, a sheriff's dispatcher said. A tornado ripped the roofs off two mobile homes in the Highland area of Houston on Thursday, residents said. Some motorists were stranded on freeways and winds overturned a tractor-trailer rig on Interstate 10. No injuries were reported. In Parker County, emergency workers waited for daylight today before resuming their effort to evacuate a private clubhous were two dozen people were holding a party and brushed off attempts to get them to leave Thursday, even as floodwaters from the Brazos River lapped at the building. ``We can't force them to leave,'' said county Emergency Coordinator Jo Schweikhard. ``The clubhouse is already flooded and what it basically boils down to is there are 25 people feeling no pain ... who are endangering themselves, the rescuers and it's a dangerous situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Taking Pictures of Austin's Comet
DOC.TEXT: Japanese astronomers have produced detailed pictures of Austin's Comet, which is heading toward the sun and observable through telescopes in the northern hemisphere, officials said today. Researchers at Tokyo University took the photographs through a telescope at their observatory in northern Japan Wednesday night. Details of the comet's 4.4 million-mile-long tail were clearly visible in the photos, giving researchers a chance to study it, an observatory official said. A comet's tail is essentially a vapor trail created by solar wind striking the comet's icy surface. The pictures are the first of Austin's Comet taken by Japanese researchers for astronomical observation, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The comet is named for Rodney Austin, an amateur astronomer from New Zealand who discovered it last year. The comet is moving west, advancing about 3.8 million miles a day, the observatory official said. Unlike periodical comets, such as Halley's, he said, once this one passes the sun it will never return. Austin's Comet will be observable throughout much of the Earth's northern hemisphere until the end of May, but it is not bright enough to be seen by the naked eye, he said. He said the Japanese observation effort is being conducted at 30 locations in the nation. Data on Austin's Comet, including photos, will be passed on to the Smithsonian Observatory in the United States, the official said.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: It ain't the Plaza, but $20 a night is rock bottom for this town, so budget-conscious tourists shouldn't complain about the bunk beds. New York now has a youth hostel, a no-frills lodging place for travelers of all ages in a city where the average hotel room goes for $135 a night. ``We want the adventurous and people looking for fun,'' Janet Thompson, president of American Youth Hostels, said Thursday. Until now, New York was the missing link in a chain of hostels in American ports of entry, such as Seattle, Portland, Ore., San Francisco and Miami. There are 5,366 hostels in 69 countries. ``I couldn't believe New York didn't have a youth hostel,'' said City Councilwoman Carolyn Maloney. ``That was the only way I could travel for many, many years.'' The hostel began limited operations about two months ago and will be in full swing in a few weeks with 480 beds. A typical room has three or four bunks beds, with a drawer for each person underneath. There are six family rooms, each with one bunk bed and one double bed. The hostel is in a national landmark building designed in 1883 by Richard Morris Hunt, whose only other remaining works are the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the pedestal of the Statue of Liberty.

Thieves posing as valet car parkers at a popular restaurant left a Canadian police officer a few bucks on the dashboard when they swiped his car. Patrick Broderick of Montreal drove his 1977 Corvette to the Wildflower Restaurant to dine with a friend Monday night. He left inside his clothes, $600 and his golf clubs when he turned the keys over to three youths standing in the parking lot. Broderick asked them if he was dressed properly for the restaurant, and they assured him he was. The car was discovered missing after Broderick's companion told him the restaurant had no valet parking. ``What a welcome to the city,'' police Sgt. Mike McCutcheon said Wednesday. But not all was lost. The car was found Tuesday. The cash was gone, but the thieves left the chagrined diner $22 on the dashboard. More importantly to Broderick, they left his golf clubs.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Nikkei Close Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished higher against the yen today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange posted a moderate gain. The dollar closed the week at 159.08 yen, up 0.31 yen from Thursday's close of 158.77 yen. After opening at 159.43 yen, the currency ranged between 158.95 yen and 159.47 yen. ``The dollar still holds its underlying strength, while the yen sold against major European currencies in cross trading, causing the yen's retreat against the dollar for the past couple of days,'' said a dealer with Sanwa Bank who spoke anonymously. Other dealers said the market was awaiting the release of the U.S. Commerce Department figures on the nation's gross national product for the first quarter of this year. The announcement was to be made later today in Washington. Meanwhile, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which shed 139.78 points Thursday, rose 160.22 points, or 0.54 percent, to close at 29,584.80. The index gained 69.99 points at the close of the morning session. Volume totaled 480 million shares on the first section, down from Thursday's 550 million shares. Securities dealers said trading remained thin with many market participants inactive ahead of long holidays in Japan. Yu Yoshida, an equity analyst with Yamaichi Securities, said the market generally was held by a wait-and-see mood, but buying of high-technology issues in the afternoon session pushed up the index's overall level. Yoshida said the market environment was not necessarily good because of the yen's decline and rising interest rates in Japan, but added that many investors were encouraged by the fact that there has been little effect on the market from a weekly report on arbitrage trading. The Tokyo Stock Exchange's move to announce arbitrage trading information on a weekly basis was taken to eliminate investors' worries about arbitrage trading, which has been partly blamed for the market's slump since the beginning of this year. In arbitrage trading, investors seek to profit from the spread between the spot and futures marekts. In the bond market, the price of benchmark No.119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 85.83 points, down from Thursday's close of 86.09. The yield rose to 7.405 percent from the previous day's 7.350 percent. Japan's Golden Week series of holidays begins Saturday and runs through May 6 for most Japanese companies. Next week, the stock and currency markets will only be open Tuesday and Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev in Urals Meets Lithuania Protest, Defections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for 10-13 bgng, `In Moscow...' to UPDATE with man who burned himself dying; pickup graf 14 pvs, `In Sverdlovsk...'
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev battled critics on two fronts during a visit to the Ural Mountains, where protesters denounced the crackdown on Lithuania and a group of Communists quit the party. The president came to the industrial city of Sverdlovsk, about 870 miles east of Moscow, to make a pitch for the economic reforms he says the Soviet Union desperately needs. But some residents were more concerned about events in Lithuania. One of the pro-Lithuania demonstrators, Tatiana Karelina, said she and other members of the political group Democratic Union mingled among 200 people in Sverdlovsk as Gorbachev spoke Thursday in the city's Youth Palace. As he was leaving the palace, a Democratic Union member unfurled a banner that read: ``Gorbachev is a Political Hypocrite.'' A plainclothes officer immediately grabbed the banner and tore it up, Mrs. Karelina said in a telephone interview. Other banners read ``No to the Economic Blockade of Lithuania!'' Official Soviet media carried no reports of protest, and it was not clear whether Gorbachev saw the banners. The Lithuanian crisis has come up repeatedly during Gorbachev's visit to Sverdlovsk. The Kremlin has cut off supplies to Lithuania to pressure the Baltic republic to rescind its March 11 declaration of independence. President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany urged Lithuania on Thursday to meet Moscow's demands for a suspension of its independence drive. In a letter to Lithuanian representatives in Moscow, Mitterrand and Kohl said Lithuanian President Vytautus Landsbergis should rescind pro-independence laws to clear the way for talks with the Kremlin ``so that the current crisis ends in a solution acceptable to all parties.'' Lithuanian parliamentary spokesman Ed Tuskenis said by telephone from Vilnius, the republic's capital, that Landsbergis said he would study the letter carefully. In Moscow, a Lithuanian man died after setting himself on fire near the Bolshoi Theater, Soviet authorities said today. Police said the man, identified as Stanislovas Jamaitis, was drunk. The independent Post-Factum news agency reported bystanders said he had been shouting ``various things, including demands for Lithuanian independence.'' In Sverdlovsk, Gorbachev also faced problems within the Communist Party, and he expressed alarm over the resignations of local party members the day he arrived. In a meeting Wednesday with workers of UralMash, a gigantic machine-building complex, Gorbachev said the party cannot be at the forefront of reform unless it keeps in touch with the working class. Then he broke the news about the resignations. ``I am greatly alarmed that today, 12 workers here gave notice about their withdrawal from the party,'' said Gorbachev, who was elected to the top party post in March 1985. ``I would look at it this way: The time now is such that some come, and some go. I would ask ... simply that party comrades, factory people, meet with them, to try to understand what's the matter,'' he said. The remarks were not reported until Thursday. Tass did not explain why the party members quit or whether they timed their resignations to coincide with Gorbachev's visit. Foreign reporters were not allowed to accompany Gorbachev to Sverdlovsk, which is closed to foreigners because it is a center for defense industry. In advance of a Communist Party congress scheduled in July, some members are considering splitting off to form a faction, a prospect Gorbachev has condemned. The party this year gave up its constitutionally guaranteed monopoly on power and decided to allow other political parties. Gorbachev said the main purpose of his trip to Sverdlovsk was to explain plans to move the centrally planned and sluggish Soviet economy toward a market-oriented system. Inside the Youth Palace, Gorbachev offered reassurances that the government will protect low-income families from some of the expected hardships of his economic reforms. The reforms are expected to free prices and close inefficient industies. Gorbachev said they are needed to end a ``foolish'' economic system that stifles initiative and technological progress. He also discussed his finances during one of his Sverdlovsk meetings, saying he was responding to rumors that he has a Swiss bank account into which he deposits royalties. He said all his royalties, including those from a book he published in the West about his reform program known as perestroika, have been put into party coffers. ``I have deposited in the party account a million rubles (about $1.6 million at the official exchange rate) and didn't take a kopeck for myself,'' he said, according to a Tass dispatch.

DOC.HEAD: Record High Temps Midwest to East
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered across the Midwest and into the East today and sections of Texas that already were soaked got another drenching. Temperatures were above normal from the Great Lakes to the Atlantic Coast. High temperature records were broken or tied at about two dozen locations Thursday. Spring snow fell in high country of Colorado and Wyoming. Showers and thunderstorms ranged from Minnesota across western Wisconsin and were scattered across Iowa. Rain also spread across western Kansas, eastern Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana. Rain was scattered across Washington, Colorado, northwest Kansas, western Nebraska, the Dakotas and eastern Montana. Thunderstorms rumbled across southeast New York and northeastern Pennsylvania. Rain in Texas added to the soaking that began in north central sections of the state Wednesday afternoon, though much of the state was clearing. A total of 17.5 inches of rain had fallen at Delion since Wednesday afternoon, the National Weather Service said. Temperatures were well into the 80s and edged into the 90s in sections of the Midwest and East on Thursday. A 95-degree reading in Baltimore broke a record of 90 set in 1960. Snow fell in the northern and central mountains of Colorado and the Big Horn Mountains of north central Wyoming. High temperature for the nation Thursday was 102 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif., and Palm Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Georgia Vows to Fight Ruling of Judicial Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: State officials said they would defend their judicial election system that the U.S. Justice Department found discriminates against blacks. But one of the 25 Superior Court judges who could lose their jobs under the ruling warned on Thursday that defending the system instead of changing it could devastate the courts' ability to render justice. ``It would be an impossible situation,'' Superior Court Judge David L. Cavender said. ``We need judges to hear cases. It would have a very damaging effect.'' The Justice Department on Wednesday declared one-third of Georgia's Superior Court judgeships illegal because the state's system of electing judges by districts often composed of more than one county dilutes black voting strength. The ruling affects 48 sitting judges _ including 25 who would have been up for re-election in November _ and an additional 10 judgeships created in 1989 and 1990 that never have been filled. Georgia has 136 Superior Court judges. Attorney General Michael Bowers called the order ``an unwarranted expansion of the Voting Rights Act.'' Bowers said he believes the state will spend whatever it takes to defend its judicial election system, even if it means putting sitting judges out of work rather than holding new elections for their seats. ``It could last for years,'' he said. ``Is it worth a million dollars? Five million? I say yes.'' Asked whether he would risk letting criminals loose because of too few judges to handle cases, Bowers said, ``That would certainly be no change from what's happening right now.'' Gov. Joe Frank Harris' spokeswoman, Barbara Morgan, said the governor would have no immediate comment. Bowers said he would put off action until a three-judge federal panel in Savannah rules on the state's request that sitting judges be allowed to stay in office until a federal lawsuit over the matter is settled. The lawsuit challenges 48 judgeships created since 1964. It contends that these judgeships were not first cleared by the Justice Department, as is required under the Voting Rights Act of 1965. The 22 plaintiffs in the lawsuit, led by state Rep. Tyrone Brooks of Atlanta, were jubilant in praising the Justice Department ruling. They blasted state leaders for ``squandering the taxpayers' money'' in defending the system. ``I think this makes it clear that fundamental change is going to have to happen to have justice in Georgia,'' said plaintiff's attorney Kathleen Wilde. ``From the sound of his (Bowers') press conference, there is no room for negotiation.'' The plaintiffs and their attorneys conceded that the Justice Department action is probably only the beginning of a lengthy battle. ``We've got more rounds to go, unfortunately,'' said American Civil Liberties Union attorney Laughlin McDonald. ``It's clear that what the state's strategy has been is to do nothing until they're forced to comply.'' Brooks added: ``We're headed for the Super Bowl at the Supreme Court.''

DOC.HEAD: Christians Close Holy Places to Protest Jewish Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Christian leaders today closed the church on the site where Jesus was buried for the first time in more than 800 years as part of a one-day strike to protest a Jewish settlement in the old city of Jerusalem. Other churches and Christian shrines throughout the Holy Land also were closed, and church bells in Jerusalem, Bethlehem and other towns rang in somber, funeral cadence for about five minutes every hour. About 150 clergymen, including representatives from nine major Christian sects, gathered to oversee the closing of the massive wooden doors of the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, site of the crucifixion and burial of Jesus. Black flags were raised, including one atop the church. In a show of solidarity, Moslem leaders closed to visitors the Al Aqsa mosque and Dome of the Rock shrine. Only worshipers were permitted in the complex. Bishop Samir Kafiti, the head of the Anglican Church in Jerusalem, told reporters ``the settlers infringement of the Christian Quarter where we have been for 2,000 years is a serious matter.'' He said an Israeli Supreme Court decision to evict the 150 Jewish settlers by Tuesday was ambiguous because the judges did not return full control to the Greek Orthodox Church. The church owns the 72-room St. John's Hospice into which the settlers moved on April 11 during Easter Week celebrations. It claims the four-building complex was illegally leased to the settlers. ``It is a half solution,'' Kafiti said, referring to the court's decision to allow 20 guards and maintenance staff to remain in the building pending a final ruling on the tenancy dispute. George Hintlian, secretary to Armenian Patriarch Torkum Manoogian, said if the courts did not eventually rule in favor of the Greek Orthodox Church, `stronger protests will be considered by the heads of churches, probably longer periods of closure.'' ``The general mood here is that we are very disappointed,'' he said. The church leaders, including Latin Patriarch Michel Sabbah and Greek Orthodox Patriarch Diodoros I, prayed inside a chapel of the Church of the Holy Sepulcher and then read in Arabic, Armenian and Greek ``The Lord's Prayer'' before closing the doors. It was a rare display of unity by the leaders of the various sects, who frequently squabble over control of the holy sites. Wajih Nusseibeh, a Moslem whose family keeps the key of the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, said it was the first time the doors were closed since the Crusaders were driven out of the city by the Islamic warrior Saladin in the 12th century A.D. The Nusseibeh and Jodeh families have been the custodians and doorkeepers of the church for the past 1,200 years to avoid conflicts among Christian sects. Outside St. John's Hospice, where the Neot David settlement was established, about eight police and two private guards could be seen. Benny Elon, a spokesman for the Jewish residents, said they had no intention of leaving before the end of Israel's Independence Day holiday Monday. At that point, he said, ``all the families who are not linked to the building will leave. The 20 people representing the company will stay.'' Creation of the settlement triggered immediate protests from church leaders and Palestinian Moslems and Arabs alike. The U.S. State Department described the move as provocative, and the Greek government also protested. Meanwhile, the army imposed curfews on three trouble spots in the occupied Gaza Strip after three Palestinians were killed and more than 120 wounded. Twelve soldiers were also hurt. A fourth Palestinian was killed by soldiers in the West Bank on Thursday, at the start of the Moslem holiday of Id al-Fitr. The Hebrew daily Yediot Ahronot decribed the clash in the Jabalia refugee camp in Gaza as the worst since the start of the uprising against Israeli rule more than 28 months ago. Maj. Gen. Natan Vilnai, head of the southern command, said several hundred Moslems leaving the Yellow Mosque in Jabalia were incited with calls to storm an army outpost and then ran toward it. Palestinian witnesses, however, said the trouble began when soldiers at an army encampment mistook the intentions of a procession of 4,000 Palestinians. They said the crowd was headed toward a cemetery to pay respects to the dead when soldiers opened fire with tear gas. Palestinians responded with stones and bottles. Thursday's deaths brought to 680 the number of Arabs killed by Israeli gunfire in the rebellion. In addition, 209 Palestinians have been slain by other Arabs as suspected pro-Israeli collaborators. Forty-three Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Former Calif. State Senator Gets 6{-Year Prison Term For Vote Selling
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge delivered a stern lecture on political corruption to a former powerful state senator he sentenced to 6{ years in prison for selling votes to special interests. U.S. District Judge Milton L. Schwartz told Joseph Montoya that vote-selling was ``the most serious type of white collar crime.'' In a brief statement before sentencing Thursday, Montoya said: ``The system has found me guilty. ... I will live with the consequences and so will my family.'' He lashed out at the news media, claiming reporters had ``tried and convicted me before I even came to trial.'' Montoya, who was chairman of the Senate Business and Professions Committee, was the first California legislator in 35 years to be convicted of a felony while in office. He was the first person to stand trial on charges stemming from an FBI sting of statehouse corruption. He resigned from the Senate on Feb. 9, a week after he was convicted of one count of racketeering, one count of money laundering and five counts of extortion. Montoya was convicted of demanding campaign contributions and honorariums in exchange for votes and other legislative favors. Schwartz also ordered Montoya to three years' probation, fined him $32,000, and ordered him to pay $8,000 in restitution. He said the amounts could be reduced based on Montoya's ability to pay. Defense attorney Michael Sands said Montoya had been ``financially devastated'' by the case. Schwartz ordered Montoya to surrender by June 29. Defense attorneys said they would appeal, and a hearing on a motion to allow Montoya to remain free pending appeal was tentatively scheduled for May 24.

DOC.HEAD: City's Worst Cabbie Being Deported
DOC.TEXT: The man whose shameful taxi etiquette earned him the title of worst cabdriver in the city is being deported to Turkey, according to a published report. Driver Vehbi Gunduz was placed Wednesday in the federal detention center and will be returned to his native country soon, Immigration and Naturalization Service spokesman Charles Troy told the New York Post in today's editions. An immigration judge had ordered Gunduz to leave the country in 1985, but Gunduz kept appealing until last month, when he lost his case, Troy said. It wasn't his driving record that got him in trouble, though. Gunduz must leave because when he entered the United States he concealed a drug conviction in Italy for which he served more than a year in prison, Troy said. Gunduz began driving a cab in June 1985. In five years, he was hit with 88 summonses and 199 violations. He was cited for driving recklessly, bullying passengers, harassing dispatchers, overcharging, assaulting a taxi inspector and dumping riders' luggage on an airport road because the passengers only wanted to go from one terminal to another. The Taxi and Limousine Commission took away Gunduz's license in October when the agency set limits on the number of violations a driver can commit before having his license suspended. Gunduz surrendered his license in March. Troy said the INS had been working on the case long before Gunduz was fingered as the city's worst taxi driver.

DOC.HEAD: `Accomplice,' A Comedy Thriller, Opens on Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 4 grafs with what other critics said. No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: There are enough bizarre twists and turns in ``Accomplice,'' which opened Thursday at Broadway's Richard Rodgers Theater, to satisfy the most dedicated of contortionists. Unfortunately, all of them occur in the second act. It takes a long, slow Act 1 to set the convoluted plot of Rupert Holmes' new comedy-thriller in motion. And not much of that can be discussed here without revealing the surprises. The play starts out as an awful sendup of those British theater mysteries _ you know, the kind that run forever in London's West End with such titles as ``Let's Murder Your Wife.'' Holmes obviously has an affection for these hoary theatrical offerings but his adoration doesn't translate very well on stage. At the Rodgers, the laughs are scattered, and the chills more tepid than terrifying. ``Accomplice'' takes place in the moorland cottage of Derek and Janet Taylor. He's perpetually mixing a gin and tonic. She's always complaining about their sex life. Derek's business partner, John, and his wife, Melinda, are expected for dinner. Any more details _ and they do accumulate _ would spoil the story. Holmes is something of a mystery buff and gamesman. He adapted Charles Dickens' unfinished novel, ``The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' as a musical. In that show, he let the audience choose the murderer by having them vote at the end of the show. ``Accomplice'' is filled with similiar pranks. In fact, they pile up, one after another, especially in the second act. Some are ingenious; others are exasperating, mere gimmicks to kill time as well as characters. The only thing you can be sure of in this play is that nothing is what it seems to be. That puts a strain on the actors _ Jason Alexander, Pamela Brull, Natalia Nogulich and Michael McKean. They are forever backtracking and doubletaking, unable to give their roles any personality. As characters, they are little more than chess pieces to be moved wherever the author wants them to go. Considering the continual surprises, Art Wolff's direction is heavy-handed. The actors hammer home the less than scintillating laugh lines. Holmes has included a great many inside theater jokes, yuks about show biz that will mean little to a lot of folks west of the Hudson River. Designer David Jenkins' opulent country house setting is fun, particularly a sinister, rotating wine cellar, while Alvin Colt's garish costumes are exactly right in their awfulness. They complement all the empty flashiness the author has put on the stage. Holmes has turned out more of a theater game than a play. ``Accomplice'' is long on clever, but short of any real style or wit. What other critics said: Frank Rich, The New York Times: ``Accomplice'' is one of those plays ... at which the patrons must be sworn to secrecy lest the author's surprises be ruined for future customers. Those secrets are safe with me because I found ``Accomplice'' incomprehensible after intermission, even though much of Act 2 is given over to extended roundable discussions among the characters as to what has happened or won't happen or can't happen. Howard Kissel, the Daily News: ``Accomplice'' spends too much energy trying to fool the audience to be a satisfying play. It is the work of a sorcerer's apprentice, who has read the instructions but doesn't know that sorcery requires belief, not cynicism. Clive Barnes, the New York Post: As a true genre piece, ``Accomplice'' is perhaps a little too generic, with more spills than thrills, yet it does have many good points, and audiences determined to connive at contrivance and suspending even their suspenders might find themselves willing accomplices to ``Accomplice.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS MAGGIE VALLEY, N.C.-dated last item in rdp to add time element.
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Michael W. Murphy, who in 1971 became the oldest man to be ordained as a Roman Catholic priest, died Wednesday at the age of 98. A native of Michigan, Murphy had lived in Maggie Valley since 1952. In 1968, Catholic bishops and friends encouraged Murphy, then 78, to become a priest. He entered a Detroit seminary shortly afterward. He returned at age 81 to be ordained a priest at St. Margaret's Catholic Church here in 1972, and served as its pastor until his death. Murphy was born on a berry farm near Detroit in 1891. He worked with his family on the farm and later in land development after the city absorbed the farm.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Challenges Congress to Make Hard Choices on Defense Cuts
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney challenged his Capitol Hill critics today to end their ``bold talk'' about cutting the defense budget and come up with specifics for paring the nation's military in a time of reduced superpower tensions. Speaking a day after he proposed sharp reductions in the B-2 stealth bomber production and cutbacks in other major warplane programs, Cheney said he was ``pleased with the response'' he'd received during his testimony. But he also had a blunt message for those lawmakers who say he's not cutting enough: put up or shut up. ``What I have heard consistently from the Congress ... is a lot of bold talk about wanting to take down the top line on defense. I have yet to see them deliver in terms of being willing to cut programs, cut bases, reduce force structure to achieve those levels,'' Cheney told reporters. ``It's easy to pontificate about what the overall top line ought to be. But as soon as we get down to the real nitty-gritty of how we're going cut the defense budget ... there's a noticeable lack of any significant, substantive plans on Capitol Hill,'' the secretary said. Asked to respond to criticism from House Armed Services Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., that his program was too modest in spending cuts, Cheney said that Aspin has had trouble in the past with gaining enough support in his own committee to support his views, let alone prevail on the House floor. He then challenged the lawmakers to come up with, and vote on, a defense budget if they think they can improve on the administration's plan. `If they've got a better plan, let em' put it out there. If they've got the votes to change it, ... produce them,'' Cheney said. But the secretary predicted that the dissension on Capitol Hill about how to revamp the military in such a time of sweeping change _ and during an election year _ means that ``serious bargaining'' won't begin until late this fall, and that a lame-duck session of Congress could be necessary before an agreement can be reached. Cheney's aircraft review calls for reducing the proposed number of B-2 bombers from 132 to 75 and reducing the proposed purchase of the C-17 long-range transport plane from 210 to 120. The defense secretary also called for cutting back on the Navy's A-12 attack aircraft and delaying purchases of the Air Force's Advanced Tactical Aircraft and Advanced Tactical Fighter. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, praised Cheney's efforts but declined to adopt the proposed numbers. ``I don't want to commit to any specific quantities of these weapons or the total of annual production rates until we know the results of the testing that will occur now at a more orderly way,'' Nunn said. Cheney cited the lessening Soviet threat to the West and the impact of the faltering Soviet economy on the military budget as the rationale for the aircraft reductions. The proposal ``is based on an unrealistically pessimistic view of the Soviet threat,'' Aspin said. And at least one Republican questioned whether likely congressional cuts in defense spending guided Cheney's hand. ``What is different on the B-2 now ... that we had to have 132 three months ago and all of sudden 75 will do the job. Is it because you think Congress is going to do it anyway?'' Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., told Cheney. ``If we can go from 132 to 75, I may start saying, hey, well maybe 16 is fine,'' Lott said. Cheney, responding to the Democratic clamor for military cuts in response to rapid changes in Europe, said his blueprint would trim $2.4 billion from President Bush's $307 billion defense budget for 1991 and would save $34.8 billion through 1997.
