Cheney said he intends to cut the number of B-2 aircraft to be purchased in the next fiscal year to two planes, from the five currently proposed at a cost of $5.5 billion. The defense secretary also proposed: _Buying 120 of the C-17 long-range transport planes instead of the 210 originally planned at a proposed savings of $11.9 billion over the life of the program. The plane is designed to replace the aging C-141 transport plane. _Purchasing 620 rather than the originally requested 858 of the Navy's A-12 all-weather medium attack planes. The A-12 is designed to replace the Navy's A-6E Intruder, which is reaching the end of its service life as an aircraft carrier-based long-range strike jet. The cuts could mean elimination of two of the Navy's 14 aircraft carrier battle groups, he said. _The Air Force's version of the plane, the Advanced Tactical Aircraft, is supposed to be used for deep attack missions now handled by the F-111 and F-15. Production of the ATA would be delayed beyond 1997, Cheney said.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Fire Rockets Into Israeli Position in South
DOC.TEXT: Guerrillas fired 20 rockets at Israeli soldiers and detonated a roadside bomb in southern Lebanon, wounding at least one Israeli soldier, security sources said today. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said eight Soviet-designed Katyusha rockets were fired today at an Israeli army position in the southern village of Kawkaba. ``The rockets scored direct hits on the Israeli position. A casualty report was not immediately available,'' one source said. The unidentified guerrillas fired 12 Katyusha rockets at Israeli positions in the southern Marjayoun region late Thursday and denotated a roadside bomb as a two-vehicle Israeli patrol drove through the adjacent Ahmadiyeh hill, the source said. ``The bomb exploded, inflicting damage on one of the armored personnel carriers. One Israeli soldier was wounded and evacuated by ambulance from the scene,'' the source added. He said the targets were in Israel's self-proclaimed ``security zone'' of southern Lebanon. The source said the rockets were fired from truck-mouted launchers deployed in southeast Lebanon, just north of the 6-to-10-mile security zone. Israel carved out the zone when it withdrew the bulk of its invading army from southern Lebanon in the summer of 1985, ending a three-year occupation of the predominantly Shiite Moslem region. The zone, which extends from the Mediterranean coast in the west to the slopes of Mount Hermon in the east, serves as a buffer to absorb cross-border guerrilla infiltrations into northern Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Jews Stage Mass Reading of Sacred Text to Complete 7{ Year Cycle
DOC.TEXT: Twenty thousand Orthodox Jews gathered in Madison Square Garden to celebrate the end of a 7{-year cycle of reading the Talmud, a sacred text of Jewish law handed down by the ancient rabbis. ``These are not dead letters of a printed book. They are alive,'' Rabbi Simon Schwab of Congregation K'hai Adath Jeshurun in Manhattan told the assemblage Thursday night. The Talmud is believed to have been given to Moses by God at Mount Sinai and handed down orally until the 6th century B.C., when it was transcribed. It is divided into tracts on agriculture, blessings, civil law, matters pertaining to women and families, holiness and synagogue services, and purity, including what is kosher. The ancient codes and commentary have been reinterpreted and debated through the ages to answer contemporary questions. ``We extend the great chain that binds us with the earlier traditions,'' said Rabbi Chaskel Besser, chairman of the Daf Yomi Commission of Agudath Israel, a coalition of Orthodox groups that organized the ceremony. Daf Yomi means daily page. It refers to the fact that the same page of the Talmud is studied each day by Jews everywhere. The Talmud has 2,711 double folios, and the cycle of reading that began in 1982 ended Thursday. The new cycle begins today. The written Torah is the first five books of the Old Testament; the oral Torah is the Talmud. Most of the men attending the event were Hasidim, ultra-Orthodox Jews who sport long beards, long black coats, black pants and wide-brimmed black hats. The sexes are segregated during Orthodox services, so women attending the celebration sat separately in the balcony. Most were modestly dressed in long-sleeve blouses and skirts that fell below the knee. The service was dedicated to the memory of the 6 million Jews who died in the Holocaust. Daf Yomi participants include Jewish scholars as well as laymen who spend an hour a day studying the tracts, sometimes in study groups, sometimes squeezing the reading in with a pocket edition on the subway. There are also cassette tapes and a recorded telephone announcement called Dial-a-Daf to assist one's understanding of the text. Women are not forbidden to study the Talmud, but in the Orthodox tradition they usually do not.

DOC.HEAD: ANC President Oliver Tambo Leaves Swedish Clinic
DOC.TEXT: Oliver Tambo, president of the African National Congress, has left Sweden after a five-month recuperation from a stroke, officials said today. Tambo, the longtime ANC leader, was staying at a Stockholm clinic during the swift changes that saw his organization legalized and his old friend, Nelson Mandela, freed from prison. Tambo came to Stockholm on Jan. 3 after being treated in London for a stroke he suffered late last year. He returned Thursday to London without fanfare. The Swedish news agency TT said the exiled Tambo wanted to return to South Africa as quickly as possible, but it was unlikely he would be able to resume an active leadership role in the ANC. Senior ANC leaders are to meet the South African government next week for talks aimed at clearing the way for formal talks on ending white minority rule. Tambo reportedly gave Mandela, who was named deputy president of the ANC, his full support as acting ANC leader when the freed activist came to Sweden in March for a reunion of the two former law partners. Mandela was released Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison in South Africa. He was jailed on charges of helping plan the start of the ANC's guerrilla campaign against the government. ANC officials in Sweden were not available to comment on Tambo's plans.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Fishing Trawler Seized After High-Speed Coast Guard Chase
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet trawler seized by the Coast Guard for allegedly fishing in U.S. waters is being escorted to an Alaskan port and is expected to arrive Sunday, officials said. When it arrives at Kodiak it will be charged with violating the Magnuson Act, a 1976 law establishing the nation's 200-mile exclusive fishing zone, said assistant U.S. attorney Tim Burgess. Kodiak is about 250 miles southwest of Anchorage. The factory trawler Ilya Ilyin was seized Thursday after a high-speed chase by the Coast Guard cutter Yocona inside the United States' Exclusive Economic Zone northwest of the Pribilof Islands in the Bering Sea, said Dennis Fradley, spokesman for Sen. Frank Murkowsk, R-Alaska. Coast Guard surveillance aircraft spotted the trawler and the Yocona was diverted to intercept it, according to a statement from Coast Guard district headquarters in Juneau. The Coast Guard said the Yocona ordered the Soviet ship to halt, but the vessel attempted to elude the cutter and return to international waters. ``The cutter pursued the vessel at high speed for the next hour and a half, crossing into international waters before the vessel stopped and was boarded,'' the statement said. The Coast Guard told Murkowski's Washington, D.C., office they found records providing clear evidence of illegal fishing. ``This one is pretty clear cut,'' said Bill Woolf, a fisheries expert on Murkowski's staff. He said the ship was observed with its fishing gear in the water and was believed to be fishing for pollock. The United States and several other nations with high-seas fishing fleets have clashed for years over the rich and lucrative North Pacific fisheries. The United States has seized a number of Canadian, Taiwanese and other vessels in the North Pacific in recent years, but seizures of Soviet fleet fishing vessels is less common. The last time the Coast Guard seized a Soviet fishing vessel in the North Pacific was in May 1989, when the trawler Novoelnya was captured with 940 metric tons of pollock aboard. The Soviets paid $275,000 in fines, Burgess said.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Delayed By Mrs. Marcos' Illness
DOC.TEXT: The trial of Imelda Marcos on fraud charges was postponed until next week today after doctors told the judge she was suffering from high blood pressure and it would ``not be a good idea'' for her to continue. Judge John F. Keenan sent the jury home, saying it was expected that the former Philippines first lady would be able to return to court on Monday. A hypertension specialist was called in on the case, he said. ``She said she felt fine, but she didn't look fine to me,'' her attorney, Gerald Spence, told the court after Mrs. Marcos visited the doctor early in the day. He said she would be wearing a device to monitor her blood pressure ``wherever she goes.'' The trial was abruptly halted Thursday after Mrs. Marcos fell ill during a lunch break. That morning, she had sobbed through testimony that recalled the day in February 1986 when she and her late husband, former president Ferdinand Marcos, were forced to leave the Philippines following his ouster from power. The 60-year-old Mrs. Marcos broke down after a U.S. Customs agent described the arrival of the Marcoses and their entourage in Hawaii aboard a U.S. Air Force plane. During the lunch break, she rested at a nurse's office in the U.S. courthouse, and then left the building after recessed the trial for the afternoon on the advice of her doctor. Her blood pressure was measured at 230 over 100; normal readings would be 120 over 80. The U.S. government charges that Mrs. Marcos and her late husband embezzled $220 million from their country's treasury to support a life of luxury and investments such as artwork and New York real estate.

DOC.HEAD: Cruise Ship's Ban of Disabled Woman Protested
DOC.TEXT: Advocates of the disabled plan to picket this weekend to protest a cruise line's refusal to allow a woman who's confined to a wheelchair on board its ship. Peggy Smith of Galveston said Thursday that Pride of Mississippi ship officials refused to let her board the 500-foot cruise ship in her wheelchair April 13 to take a daylong cruise with her boyfriend and several other people. ``It was going to be my last evening out with my boyfriend because he was going away for a few months,'' said Ms. Smith, a 26-year-old paraplegic horse trainer and riding instructor at Galveston's Hope Arena. She lost use of her legs five years ago in an accident while exercising a horse at a California racetrack. Bernard Allen, a spokesman for Pride Cruise Lines, said Thursday that passengers in wheelchairs could cause greater risks for themselves and others in emergencies. ``It would create a very serious problem for the passenger and other passengers to try to get them embarked into a lifeboat,'' Allen said. Salli Phillips, president of the Galveston Chapter of Coalition for Barrier Free Living, said her group intended to picket Saturday at the Galveston dock where the Pride of Mississippi is located. Galveston Mayor Barbara Crews said she has received complaints about the incident and has asked the city attorney's office to see if the refusal to sell tickets to people with disabilities violates state and federal laws.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Delegation Goes to Lebanon Seeking Hostages' Release
DOC.TEXT: A Red Cross delegation arrived in this southern provincial capital today, seeking word on the possible release of two kidnapped Swiss Red Cross workers. The delegation's four members made no statement upon arriving at the office of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut. However, a committee source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the four planned to maintain ``daily presence in Sidon this week, waiting for a contact concerning our two kidnapped colleagues.'' The team was led by the Red Cross chief delegate in Lebanon, Michel Dufour, and the committee's spokeswoman for the Middle East, Marjolaine Martin, who flew into Beirut from Geneva on Wednesday. ``We remain optimistic after our talks here about the release of our two officials,'' Dufour said, without elaborating. The delegation is seeking the release of Red Cross orthopedic technicians Emanuel Christen, 33, and Elio Erriquez, 24. They were kidnapped by unidentified gunmen in Sidon on Oct. 6. No group claims responsibility for their seizure. However, Lebanese and foreign security sources blame the Fatah-Revolutionary Council group of Palestinian terrorist Abu Nidal. The group has denied involvement and urged the captors to release Christen and Erriquez. The Red Cross team held talks on Thursday with Mustafa Saad, who heads the Sunni Moslem independent Nasserite organization whose 1,000-strong Popular Liberation Army militia dominates Sidon. Saad renewed his appeal for the release of the two Red Cross workers, saying failure to free them ``will be considered a hostile act against us.'' Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi, as well as Palestinian and Lebanese groups, have appealed for the pair's release. In addition to the two Swiss, the Western hostages believed to be held mainly by pro-Iranian factions in Lebanon are seven Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, an Irishman and an Italian. American journalist Terry Anderson, 43, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held foreign captive in Lebanon. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Says Cuts in Defense Would Help Pay For Unification
DOC.TEXT: The government today said defense spending should be cut to help pay for German unification. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's senior aide predicted agreement on merging the two countries' economies within a week. Rudolf Seiters, Kohl's chief of staff, also told Parliament that local and state governments will help pay the costs of merging the two Germanys and said the process will be easier if citizens show courage. East and West German officials today negotiated economic union, and Seiters predicted success within a week and the merging of the two economies by summer. West Germany is demanding that the East German economy be completely overhauled. But Lothar de Maiziere, East Germany's prime minister, said his people would face enormous burdens if subsidies on rents, energy and public services are eliminated immediately. Seiters acknowledged that the cost of reviving East Germany's economy and protecting its people from economic shocks will result in West German budget cuts _ in defense and other areas _ and a higher budget deficit. He did not specify what military cuts Bonn envisions, although it is considering a reduction in its 490,000-member armed forces to 400,000. Seiters assured the lawmakers that West Germany's strong economy can absorb much of the cost of unification and noted Kohl's promise not to raise taxes. During the same session, opposition politicians accused Kohl of excluding them from participating in the unification process. ``Unification is not a private matter for the federal chancellor. It is a matter for the whole people,'' said Herta Daeubler-Gmelin, a top official with the opposition Social Democrats. West Germany and East Germany hope to adopt a single currency and join their economies by July 2, which will be huge steps toward ending the two countries' 41-year division. No details were immediately forthcoming from the negotiations in East Berlin on Bonn's proposed ``state contract'' on the monetary, economic and social union of the two nations. The proposal includes terms for replacing East Germany's currency with the mighty West German mark, restructuring the East German economy, and adopting social programs to protect East Germans from resulting economic shocks. The Bonn proposal calls for a basic 1-1 currency exchange for wages, pensions and savings up to $2,300. Savings over that amount would be exchanged at the less attractive rate of 2-1.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges Americans to `Get Moving' on Census
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, acknowledging huge problems with the gathering of 1990 census data, today implored Americans who have not returned their census forms to do so at once. ``We really need to get moving on this,'' Bush said in his first comments on the poor return rate so far in the census undertaking. Nearly 40 percent of more than 95 million census questionnaires sent out in March haven't been returned, and millions more people never received forms. The U.S. Census Bureau this week began sending out door-to-door census ``enumerators'' to help fill in the missing blanks. Bush said that, in light of the poor response, this would be a ``mammoth undertaking.'' He made his appeal at the beginning of a talk to a group of state legislators visiting the White House. ``The census data will help us make important decisions for the states,'' Bush told the American Legislative Exchange Council. Census information is crucial for distributing federal funds in a variety of programs to states and local governments. Accurate census data is also needed for the redrawing of district lines for congressional and legislative seats. Bush called on the state legislators to help the federal government in coaxing Americans into doing a better job of returning their census forms, which where supposed to have been mailed in on April 1. ``I want to take this opportunity to urge every American who has not returned the census form to do so, to stand up and be counted,'' the president said. It was the first time that the vexing problems plaguing the Census Bureau has attracted official White House comment, even though Bush has made the importance of congressional restricting a major feature of his political speeches. The president has told Republican audiences to be vigilant against what he has said will be attempts in states with Democratic-controlled legislatures to redraw congressional and legislative district lines to minimize GOP gains.

DOC.HEAD: Verdict Postponed in Ceausescu's Brother's Trial
DOC.TEXT: The trial of a brother of ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was suspended today for a month after three military judges said there was insufficient evidence for prosecution. Prosecutors asked for more time to investigate Nicolae Andruta Ceausescu, the former head of the secret police academy, who was charged with ordering his cadets to fire on demonstrators during the December revolution and killing seven protesters himself. Also today, hundreds of protesters alleging Communist infiltration of the interim government blocked central University Square. State radio said government supporters would stage a rally to counter the 6-day-old protest. The trial of Nicolae Andruta Ceausescu was suspended until May 29 after the judges said there was insufficient evidence for a verdict. Several high-ranking officers who worked under the 66-year-old former general testified that they saw him on Dec. 21 near the Intercontinental Hotel, where several protesters were killed. One witness, Maj. Nicolae Coman, said he saw Ceausescu ``at one point standing right next to the crowd, about one meter from the protesters ... But I could not see what was in his right hand.'' In an earlier session on the trial, several of Coman's soldiers testified that Ceausescu approached the crowd with his gun and fired on demonstrators. Ceausescu insisted ``the whole story is untrue, staged.'' Romania's provisional government had been criticized for the summary trial and execution on Dec. 25 of ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, for ``grave crimes'' during his authoritarian rule. In March, four Ceausescu bodyguards were acquitted of charges that they had helped him flee Bucharest during the revolution. Nicu and Zoia, Nicolae Ceausescu's son and daughter, are under arrest and awaiting trial.

DOC.HEAD: Impeached Federal Judge Could Go Back To Prison Due To Hunting Violation
DOC.TEXT: A former federal judge who was impeached and removed by Congress could face prison again, this time for parole violations, after being arrested on charges of baiting a field to attract wild turkeys. Because Walter L. Nixon Jr. is on parole for a federal perjury conviction, possession of a firearm could be grounds for revocation of his parole, U.S. probation officials said Thursday. ``He was hunting with a gun,'' said T.J. Jennings, chief investigator for the law enforcement division of the Department of Wildlife, Fisheries and Parks. Federal law prohibits felons from carrying firearms. Conviction is punishable by up to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Nixon, 61, and Austin Cordell Shattles, 72, were booked early Thursday at the Jackson County Sheriff's Department and released under $100 bond each. Nixon was charged with hunting game birds over a baited field, while Shattles, a wildlife area supervisor who has been with the department for 40 years, was charged with conspiracy to bait turkeys, court documents show. The department said he had been placed on leave pending review of the case. ``I'm just sick about this,'' Nixon said Thursday. ``It's a terrible nightmare.'' He had no further comment. Both are scheduled to appear May 16 in Jackson County Justice Court. The Senate convicted Nixon, 61, on two counts of making a false or misleading statement regarding a drug case to a grand jury in 1984. It removed Nixon from his federal judgeship Nov. 3 and stripped him of his $89,500 salary. He was convicted in Hattiesburg in 1986 of lying to a grand jury by denying he had discussed a pending case with a former prosecutor. On March 23, 1986, Nixon began serving two simultaneous five-year prison terms and was paroled in November from a New Orleans halfway house.

DOC.HEAD: L.A. Sets up Drought-Busting Street Patrol
DOC.TEXT: The hydrant's leaking, and the sprinkler's peaking. Who you gonna call? Drought busters. The city's Department of Water and Power said Thursday it will dispatch a street patrol of ``drought busters'' to look for water waste as the region enters its fourth consecutive drought year. The department's commissioners also voted to revive a loan program designed to help home and apartment building owners buy water-saving devices. The moves are designed to avoid the need for mandatory water rationing, said Rick Caruso, president of the board of commissioners. In addition, the board sent Mayor Tom Bradley a list of recommendations to strengthen the city's 1978 conservation law. Included are a ban on landscape watering during daylight and empowering the department to turn off water at residences responsible for repeated runoff into streets. Currently, only City Council can order a violator's service shut off. The department will hire up to 30 drought busters to enforce water conservation laws and work with homeowners on ways to cut consumption, Caruso said. He acknowledged that many residents have ignored a city ban on hosing down sidewalks and driveways. ``If we need to, we can add another 20 drought busters to get the job done,'' he said. Under the loan program, homeowners would be eligible to borrow $300 to $7,500, while apartment owners up to $50,000, to buy and install water saving equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Shootout Over Broken Engagement Leaves Two Dead
DOC.TEXT: A man's decision to break his engagement at the last minute led to a shootout that left two people dead and four wounded, police said. Tempers flared and pistols were pulled when members of the two families met Thursday night to return gifts, police said. The wedding was to have occurred four days earlier. Killed in the burst of fire were two brothers, age 50 and 55, identified as uncles of the jilted woman. A brother-in-law of the bridegroom was reported arrested on murder charges, and at least two other people were held for questioning. According to the Italian news agency ANSA, the prospective bridegroom, 28-year-old Giuseppe Millefiori, refused to go through with the marriage at the last minute. He was to have married 24-year-old Francesca Sanfilippo.

DOC.HEAD: `Cry Freedom' Reopens Quietly In South Africa
DOC.TEXT: When the movie ``Cry Freedom'' appeared in South Africa in 1988, it was greeted by a storm of controversy, two bomb blasts and a police order confiscating the film hours after it opened. The movie reopened Friday without fanfare. The film began showing at more than 40 theaters nationwide to moderate crowds and no incidents, according to police, theater managers and the film's distributor, United International Pictures. ``People have accepted changes,'' said Dave de Villiers, general manager of Ster-Kinekor theaters in Johannesburg and surrounding areas. ```Cry Freedom' opened like an ordinary movie, and we expect it will do decent business. It's not a controversial blockbuster like it was two years ago.'' ``Cry Freedom'' is about black activist Steve Biko, who died in police custody in 1977, and Donald Woods, a white newspaper editor who befriended him. The movie is based on two books by Woods and was directed by Sir Richard Attenborough. ``Cry Freedom'' contains the most emotional and violent scenes involving South African police and black citizens ever shown in a general release movie in South Africa. The Publications Appeals Board, the government's censorship body, approved the film July 29, 1988, and it began showing at 30 theaters the same morning. The movie drew large crowds despite threats by right-wing whites. There were two bomb blasts outside theaters where ``Cry Freedom'' was playing, and several other theaters received bomb threats. Seven hours after the film opened, police ordered it confiscated, saying it ``endangers the safety of the public.'' ``The security forces are portrayed in such a negative light (in the movie) that their public image would be seriously undermined,'' said Stoffel van der Merwe, minister of information at the time. ``Whites are typified as privileged and surrounded by wealth, as opposed to blacks living in great poverty and subjected to exploitation and repression,'' he said. Van der Merwe described that portrayal as inaccurate. But earlier this year, police returned the film and indicated it could be shown. President F.W. de Klerk, who assumed power in August, has eased restrictions on many anti-government activities as part of an effort to negotiate a new constitution with blacks. Under South Africa's apartheid system of racial segregation, the country's 5 million whites maintain political and economic control, and the 28 million blacks have no voice in national affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan Eases Travel Restrictions for Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Taiwan has lifted a ban that prevented Soviet business officials from visiting this island, Foreign Ministry spokesman Huang Hsin-pi said Friday. Also Friday, the Government Information Office reported it would issue a license to allow the Soviet film ``War and Peace'' to be shown in Taiwan. It will be the first Soviet movie shown in Taiwan. Huang told a news conference the ban on business trips was lifted last week to encourage trade between Taiwan and the Soviet Union. Foreign Ministry officials said they have received about 10 applications and two visas have been issued allowing Soviets to visit on business. In the past month, the Nationalist government also has approved direct trade between Taiwan and the Soviet Union and Taiwanese investments in projects in the Soviet Union. Trade between anti-Communist Taiwan and the Soviet Union was conducted through third countries in the past. The Soviet Union has no diplomatic ties with Taiwan and recognizes the rival Communist government in Beijing. The Nationalists have long considered the Soviet Union a hostile nation and have linked their defeat in a civil war in China in 1949 to Soviet aid to Communist Chinese forces.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Considering Major Asset Sales, Newspaper Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with Trump confirming report, add comment from Merrill Lynch. No pickup. ADDS byline. A version moved on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump said today he has discussed selling or refinancing virtually every major asset he owns but it's not because he has any cash problems. The casino and real estate mogul has hired Merrill Lynch & Co. to negotiate a possible sale of the Trump Shuttle less than a year after buying the carrier and attaching his name to it. ``If I got the right offer, I would consider selling it,'' Trump told The Associated Press in a telephone interview. Trump was confirming remarks made to the Wall Street Journal, which published details of his financial plans in a story today after its own interview with him. The Journal's account said Trump was so adamant about his cash strength he threatened to sue the newspaper if it suggested otherwise. He denied that his empire faces any cash shortage problems, saying he has cash reserves of $380 million. ``I'm very liquid now,'' he said. ``I want to build up cash because I think cash is going to be king.'' Among his assets are New York's Plaza Hotel, the glitzy Trump Tower skyscraper on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue, and casinos in Atlantic City, N.J., including the $1 billion Taj Mahal casino, which recently opened with much fanfare. He said he is interested in raising cash now so that he will have funds on hand in the future to acquire additional properties. The Plaza and Trump Tower will not be sold, however, Trump said. Some people in the financial community are watching for signs that Trump might be accumulating cash to cope with a current or anticipated cash crunch caused by a heavy debt load. Several of Trump's biggest holdings don't produce enough income to cover interest payments on loans taken out to pay for the acquisitions. This means that Trump relies heavily on cash cows, such as casinos and condominiums, according to an article today in the Wall Street Journal. The ``cash is king'' strategy Trump is pursuing has led him to consider the sale of the Trump Shuttle, an airline serving New York, Boston and Washington. When Trump acquired the carrier with bank loans from Eastern Airlines last year for $365 million, he said he wanted to transform it into ``one of the really fine airlines in the world.'' Trump said he is weighing a sale because he has been approached by numerous parties interested in it. He declined to say whether he is making money on the shuttle or to identify the potential buyers. ``We've been engaged to explore strategic alternatives for the shuttle,'' Merrill Lynch spokesman Fred Yager said. He declined to elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: French to Reopen Embassy in Kabul
DOC.TEXT: The French Embassy in Afghanistan will reopen in May, a government source said. The embassy closed along with many other Western embassies during the Soviet army withdrawal. The embassy will he headed by a charge d'affaires, Gildas Le Lidec, who currently is consul general in Bombay, India, the source said Thursday, speaking on condition of anonymity. France announced in January that it would reopen the embassy but did not give a date. Its decision was welcomed by the Soviet-installed government in Kabul and criticized by the U.S.-backed rebel forces. No other major Western countries have reopened embassies in Kabul, but West Germany and Italy reportedly are considering this step.

DOC.HEAD: Party Admits More Than 1 Million New Members in 1989
DOC.TEXT: China's Communist Party admitted 1.13 million new members in 1989, a year in which the party was challenged by a widely popular democracy movement, the official People's Daily said Friday. The party newspaper said two-thirds of the new members are under the age of 35 and have at least high school educations. The report did not give the current party membership. An official of the party Organization Department, contacted by phone, said, ``I know but I won't tell you.'' Figures published more than a year ago put membership at about 48 million, 4 percent of China's population. The party launched a review of the qualifications of all party members following the crackdown last June of the democracy movement. Many party members either participated in or voiced their support for the student-led movement for democratic reform. So far, it appears few are being dropped from party ranks for ideological shortcomings. The People's Daily last month said 33,400 people were expelled from the party last year for abuse of power or other reasons, up slightly from previous years. The daily said there were 9.51 million pending applications by the end of 1989, and that there were 2.32 million new applications after the political turmoil of June. In deciding whether to accept someone into the party, officials consider whether the applicant submits to the party line and party discipline and has good moral character. They also check the applicant's personal and family background for such things as criminal records or accusations of political errors. The daily said 5.3 million of the pending applicants were workers, farmers, herdsmen, fishermen, intellectuals and soldiers. The other 4 million are presumably government officials, who need party membership to advance their careers. Despite widespread disenchantment with the party, many young people still see party membership as crucial to obtaining good jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Protester Throws Eggs at Iranian Foreign Minister
DOC.TEXT: A man threw eggs and shouted insults at Iran's foreign minister in a U.N. hallway today before being wrestled to the floor. The official, Ali Akbar Velayati, was not injured and the eggs missed him. The unidentified man, who identified himself as an Iranian, screamed at Velayati: ``He is a murderer and torturer! He does not represent the Iranian people. He should not be allowed in the United Nations.'' The assailant was hustled away by guards, along with a second man who stood nearby during the attack. The second man, who identified himself as Ahmed Mohini of Iran, claimed that the Iranian government had murdered his brother. Both men, who wore dark suits, said they were acting as individual Iranians and that they were not affiliated with any group. One witness said a third man ran away and was captured. There was no immediate statement from U.N. Security or State Department Security, whose guards subdued the assailant. ``I don't know him,'' Velayati said of the attacker. ``He chanted slogans against me and tried to attack me, but guards prevented his doing so.'' The attack occurred as Velayati was on his way to hold a news conference in the Secretariat Building on the second floor. Only two or three eggs were thrown and they landed on the marble floor. Velayati is in New York for discussions with U.N. chief Javier Perez de Cuellar on reviving stalled peace talks with Iraq. No permanent agreement has been reached between the neighboring Middle East countries since an Aug. 20, 1988 cease-fire halted eight years of hostilities.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia Protesters, Security Forces Face Off
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with demonstration ending peacefully, details. Pickup 7th graf, `Students chanted...'
DOC.TEXT: Mongolian security forces ringed the government palace today when thousands of people staged an unauthorized protest, but the opposition demonstrators left peacefully after several hours, sources in Ulan Bator said. It was not immediately clear whether the government had made any concessions that led to the retreat. Most of the police and soldiers later withdrew, one source said, although small numbers remained posted outside the building into the night. It was the first direct confrontation between protesters and security forces in five months of pro-democracy demonstrations in Mongolia's capital, Ulan Bator, and both sides seemed eager to avoid violence. The security forces did not have weapons or riot gear. The protest violated a recent government edict requiring that all demonstrations be approved in advance. The largest opposition group, the Mongolian Democratic Association, had planned to encircle the government palace to press its demands for equal status with the ruling Communist Party and formation of a temporary, multiparty legislature until elections. But police and soldiers of the internal militia formed a protective circle first and blocked adjoining streets, said Suhjargalmaa, an editor at Mongolia's Montsame News Agency. The protesters formed a picket line on only one side of the palace, fronting a large central square where supporters and onlookers gathered. ``There were about 40,000 at noon but now there are much fewer,'' Suhjargalmaa said in a telephone interview. She said the security forces did not have weapons or riot gear, and that no force had been used. Like most Mongolians, Suhjargalmaa uses only one name. Students chanted ``Youth, unite!'' and waved national flags and emblems of the Mongolian Democratic Association, the Soviet news agency Tass said. Mongolian radio said the government was broadcasting appeals over loudspeakers for the crowd to disperse, but protesters were responding with shouts for the soldiers to leave. So far, there has been no violence since opposition groups first emerged in December to demand democratic reforms like those elsewhere in the Soviet bloc. The Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party in March surrendered its constitutional right to rule and agreed to the first multiparty elections in Mongolian history _ apparently believing that its best chance of staying in power will come from embracing reforms. Legislative elections are tentatively scheduled for July. But the opposition has accused the party of cheating by amending the election law to give more delegates to rural areas, where the Communists are strongest. Opposition groups have demanded that this be changed and that the Communist-dominated legislature step down immediately. They want a provisional legislature including all parties to oversee the elections. Earlier this week, the Mongolian Democratic Association set a deadline of noon today for the government to respond to these and other demands. Government and association officials met on Thursday, but the opposition walked out when its demands were not met, Suhjargalmaa said. Other demands included that the ruling party's Central Committee move its offices from the government palace and that all parties be allowed to join a commission that is investigating former high-ranking officials. The commission was set up by the ruling party in early April to uncover alleged abuses of power under former dictator Yumjaagiyn Tsedenbal. He was ousted in 1984, but many of his associates remain in government and the party. Tass said President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat broadcast a speech on television and radio late Thursday and early today urging the public to resist pressure, stay calm and avoid disruptions of work. Public prosecutor Baljinnyam said he would implement a decree issued by Ochirbat in early April that requires advance approval for demonstrations and allows the government to use force, Suhjargalmaa said. But she predicted the government would not use force because that would undermine its own reform efforts.

DOC.HEAD: Major Earthquake in China Kills 115, Leaves Thousands Homeless
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake battered the remote highlands of central China, killing 115 people and leaving thousands homeless, the State Seismology Bureau said Friday. A bureau official said 160 people were injured in Thursday's tremor, which measured 6.9 on the Richter scale. China Central Television reported that the quake, centered in the Hainan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture of Qinghai province, left 5,000 people homeless. Hundreds of people were sleeping on the ground, wrapped in heavy blankets to ward off the cold of the Qinghai high plateau. The news program said 500 soldiers and workers from army and provincial hospitals were rushed to the scene. Soldiers dug through the rubble of demolished packed-earth homes and dragged away corpses. The earthquake's epicenter, about 70 miles southwest of the provincial capital of Xining, is believed populated mainly by Tibetan herdsmen and miners. Qinghai, one of China's largest and least populous provinces, is also home to Moslem Huis, Kazakhs and Mongolians, and contains many prisons and labor camps. The temblor was felt as far away as the city of Lanzhou, 186 miles to the east. The powerful tremor dug large cracks in roads and often left nothing standing but wooden doors. The only house shown in the TV tape that was not destroyed was a concrete structure with half its wall collapsed. A Seismology Bureau official, who gave his name only as Zhai, said more than 1,000 homes collapsed in the initial quake and during more than 600 aftershocks. Some aftershocks were as strong as 6.0 on the Richter scale. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake measuring 6 can cause extensive damage in a populated area, while one measuring 7 is 10 times stronger. The far western Chinese province of Xinjiang was hit by a quake measuring 6.4 on April 19. Some 1,300 homes were damaged and two people were injured. Thursday's quake was the deadliest in China since November 1988 when a temblor measuring 7.6 on the Richter scale killed 730 people in the southwest province of Sichuan. The most devastating tremor in recent years in this quake-prone nation came in 1976, when 240,000 were killed in the northeast city of Tangshan.

DOC.HEAD: Renoir Work Stolen From Gallery in Central Japan
DOC.TEXT: A small oil painting by Pierre Auguste Renoir has been stolen from a gallery in Nagoya, central Japan, police said Friday. Although the painting's official title was not immediately available, an English translation of its Japanese title reads ``Young Girl's Head.'' It was painted by the French artist in 1908 and was estimated to be worth $158,000. Police said the work, which measures 4-by-4{ inches, had been on display at the Nichido Gallery in Nagoya since Sunday. The theft was discovered Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Khamenei Denies Differences Among Iranian Leaders
DOC.TEXT: Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, on Friday denied there were rifts within the Iranian leadership, Tehran radio reported. Khamenei said the Western news media's portrayal of differences among Iranian leaders was a result of ``their blindness and folly.'' He said the West failed to understand the ``divine and spiritual relationships'' among the country's leaders. Sharp differences over economic policy and normalizing relations with the West are believed to exist among Iranian leaders. Khamenei, who is often aligned with the pragmatic President Hashemi Rafsanjani, favors a more laissez-faire economy and mending ties with the West to attract investment and technology for the country's flagging economy. A radical opposition camp, led by former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, wants tighter government control of the economy and eschews good ties with the West. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, said Khamenei was speaking to thousands of worshipers gathered at the shrine of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini on the outskirts of Tehran. The weekly prayer was significant Friday because it coincided with the Islamic celebration of Eid al-Fitr, marking the end of the Moslem fasting month of Ramadan. Rafsanjani won a major victory over his rival camp by helping gain the release Sunday of American educator Robert Polhill from pro-Iranian Lebanese captors. Recognizing the hostages as perhaps the greatest obstacle blocking ties with the West, Rafsanjani is believed to want to end the crisis by gaining release of the 17 remaining Western captives in Lebanon. The radicals, including Mohtashemi, want the captives to remain. Most of the hostages, who include seven Americans, are believed to be held by pro-Iranian Shiite factions in Lebanon. The hostage held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Lava Continues to Burn Houses In Subdivision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with four more homes burned, add detail on how many homes in area total. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Two separate...'. SUBS 12th graf pvs, `The American..', to add how many people in tents.
DOC.TEXT: Despite their best efforts, the residents of Kalapana may be fighting a losing battle to preserve their town from a lava flow from Kilauea Volcano. This rural community lost six more houses Thursday and three early today, said Bruce Butts, a civil defense spokesman. The latest toll brings to 31 the number of houses destroyed this month, or about a quarter of the 125 homes in and around the Kalapana Gardens subdivision. In all, 107 houses have been destroyed along the southeastern coast of Hawaii Island since the volcano began erupting Jan. 3, 1983. Two separate flows were joining together to overrun the subdivision with a sea of fast-moving lava that was heading toward the town's heart. The activity caused Civil Defense officials to extend blockades and to warn residents of the possibility of large methane gas explosions. Lava surges were occurring in several areas, threatening several more homes and continuing the destruction that has gone uninterrupted in the past week. Hawaii County Civil Defense Administrator Harry Kim warned residents that the town's one store and two churches could be destroyed in the next week to 10 days. ``I'm amazed by the constant fluidity. It's losing very little of its temperature,'' Kim said. He said the lava was moving a foot a minute in some places. The coastal community may soon be history, said Kim, who now refers to people being ``relocated'' rather than ``evacuated'' because he doesn't think they'll be able to return. Moving companies were volunteering their services to help residents pack, move their homes or dismantle them for reconstruction later. But the lava swallowed up five homes Thursday. Michael Stephens, whose house was the second to burn up Thursday, had the dubious honor of being the 100th homeowner victimized by the Hawaiian volcano goddess Madam Pele. ``I didn't think it was going to happen at first, then I thought it was,'' Stephens said. ``I really couldn't think straight.'' After his home burned, Stephens helped neighbors pack their belongings. The American Red Cross set up a disaster relief center near the Civil Defense command post at Harry K. Brown Park, on the outskirts of the town. About three dozen residents had set up tents in the park. Tourists continued to flock to the area, trying to glimpse the imminent destruction oozing its way forward. Kini Pea, a custodian at the Star of the Sea church who had watched it being built in the 1930s, said Sunday service is planned as usual. Buidling-moving companies have volunteered to move the church for free, but officials have yet to decide when and where to move it. Meanwhile, the Hawaii's insurance industry has assured state Insurance Commissioner Robin Campaniano that area homeowners will continue to be insured. One company, Royal Insurance Co., had recently drawn Campaniano's ire when it refused to renew a policy for a house threatened by lava. Campaniano said Roayl has agreed to honor its commitments to policyholders in the area.

DOC.HEAD: Rig With Rockets Sideswiped in Kentucky, But No Explosion Or Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with rockets equipped with warheads but `unarmed,' packed in special shipping containers, en route to Missouri from Virginia. Pickup 5th graf, `Mark McDaniel...' Minor editing thereafter to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: A tractor-trailer sideswiped a rig carrying 16 Harpoon rockets on Interstate 64 in rural northeastern Kentucky, but no explosion or fire ensued, authorities said. The tractor-trailer's driver and his wife, a passenger, were injured in the accident about 11:30 p.m. Thursday. The driver of the missile rig and another passenger were not hurt. The missiles, each equipped with a warhead containing a 500-pound explosive, were ``unarmed,'' meaning that further procedures were needed to make them battle-ready, said Navy spokesman Craig Quigley in Washington. He said the missiles were transported in special shipping containers ``so that accidents of this nature will not yield an explosion.'' The interstate highway was closed about 9{ hours following the accident. It was reopened this morning after the rig was towed to the Bluegrass Army Depot near Lexington for inspection, said Kentucky State Police trooper Gary Kistner. The accident posed no threat to the surrounding community and no one was evacuated, officials with the Kentucky State Police and state Disaster and Emergency Services said. Two explosives experts from Fort Knox arrived at the scene by helicopter early today. The missiles were being shipped from the Yorktown, Va., Naval Weapons Station to a McDonnell Douglas Corp. weapons plant in St. Charles, Mo., according to a statement issued by the Navy. Harpoon missiles are a type of cruise missile that can be launched from ships, submarines or aircraft. The 12- to 15-foot weapon is considered a medium-range anti-ship missile. Mark McDaniel, a spokesman for the state disaster agency, said the rockets ``were standard explosives _ not atomic or anything like that.'' Charles Harrell, 49, of Phillipsburg, Mo., was driving the rocket-loaded rig when it was sideswiped by a tractor-trailer driven by Jimmy Scott, 55, of Florrissant, Mo., Kistner said. Scott, a driver for J.B. Hunt Transport of Lowell, Ark., apparently lost control of his truck and crossed the highway's median, colliding with the tractor part of the rig carrying the missiles, Kistner said. Scott was listed in serious but stable condition at King's Daughter's Medical Center in Ashland, said nursing supervisor Sherry Swimm. Scott's wife, Marion, was treated and released. Harrell, a driver for Diablo Transportation Inc. of Pacheco, Calif., and a passenger were uninjured. A state environmental response team was sent to the scene after 200 to 300 gallons of diesel fuel spilled because of the wreck, said McDaniel. ``My best information is that it was contained at the scene,'' said McDaniel.

DOC.HEAD: New Mexico Governor, Staff, Pass Drug Tests in Policy Kickoff
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Garrey Carruthers and two dozen of his top staffers passed drug tests they took earlier this week in an effort to diffuse wrangling over a new state testing policy, the governor's office said. Carruthers on Monday unexpectedly directed the staffers to be tested for drugs. The governor also was tested. Press secretary Eddie Binder said all other staffers in the governor's office and Cabinet members are being asked to voluntarily submit to drug tests. The tests marked the beginning of a policy that will subject applicants and employees in safety-sensitive jobs to random urine tests to check for illegal drugs. Before it takes to effect June 1, state workers may admit to any drug problems and enter treatment programs. They would be offered 30 days' administrative leave with pay during treatment. State employee unions have criticized the policy as punitive and unfair.

DOC.HEAD: Water Bed to the Rescue
DOC.TEXT: A water bed extinguished a fire and probably saved a man's home from burning down, fire officials said. An electrical short in a small oscillating fan started a fire early Thursday in the bedroom of a mobile home owned by Ken Lloyd, fire officials said. Lloyd and three other occupants were sleeping in another room when they were awakened by a smoke alarm and fled. The fire spread to the water bed, causing it to rupture and douse the blaze, said Lt. Gary Pipes of the Arlington Fire Department. He said the fire caused an estimated $5,000 damage. ``It's fair to say the fire would have been more substantial,'' Pipes said.

DOC.HEAD: Builder Blown Up Hours After Officials Warn of IRA Offensive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with police unsure where explosive device was placed, IRA member pleading guilty to charges. Pickup 10th, `The IRA ...'
DOC.TEXT: An explosion killed a builder driving near the border today, just hours after authorities issued public warnings that a new Irish Republican Army terror attack was expected soon. The IRA has targeted people involved in construction work for the security forces in Northern Ireland. It has killed 13 other people in similar attacks since 1985. The killings are an attempt to halt refurbishment and building programs at police stations, which have either been bombed or need renovation. The builder, identified as Ken Graham of Kilkeel, was believed to have done construction work at police and military installations in the province, defying IRA death threats. Police said the explosion was at an intersection near Kilkeel, five miles from the border with Ireland. Police could not immediately determine whether the bomb was placed in the car or planted in the road. Graham later died in the hospital. He was the 20th person killed in political and sectarian violence this year in Northern Ireland. Police said today they discovered a major bomb factory in a vacant house in the border town of Newry, also County Down, and confiscated nine 110-pound bags of explosives and a rifle. No arrests were made. The Royal Ulster Constabulary headquarters warned the public on Thursday night to be ``extremely vigilant'' in ``the period immediately ahead,'' and asked people to report anything suspicious. Road blocks were in place throughout Northern Ireland. At Belfast International Airport today, there were delays averaging 45 minutes at the main security checkpoint on the road leading to the Aldergrove terminal. In Belfast, meanwhile, an admitted member of the IRA pleaded guilty to 42 charges, including two murders in 1974. Sean O'Callaghan, a native of Ireland, said he was not apologizing. ``I would have thought myself cowardly and remiss if I did not set out to end British rule and unify my country,'' O'Callaghan said. He is to be sentenced later. The IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the mainly Protestant province with the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republic. In London, meanwhile, the Court of Appeal today overturned the convictions of three Irish people in 1988 for allegedly conspiring to murder the top British official in Northern Ireland. Three Court of Appeal judges ruled that Tom King, the target of the alleged attack, could have prejudiced the outcome by appearing on television and arguing that terrorist suspects should not have the right to remain silent. The Court of Appeal ruled that the trial judge should have dismissed the jury and ordered a new trial. Shouting and cheering erupted in the Old Bailey courtroom following the ruling. The three prisoners, Martina Shanahan, 24, John McCann, 26, and Finbar Cullen, 29, hugged their lawyers. The three were immediately rearrested under the Prevention of Terrorist Act, and police applied for orders barring them from returning to Britain. Defense lawyers said they expected the trio to leave for Ireland by Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Rostropovich Compares Arts Aid Restrictions to Soviet Censorship
DOC.TEXT: Mstislav Rostropovich, artistic director of the National Symphony Orchestra, on Friday compared restrictions on federal aid to the arts to the Soviet Union's censorship of writers, artists and composers. Testifying before a Senate hearing on financing for the National Endowment for the Arts, Rostropovich recalled how he had chafed under Soviet censorship and smuggled out of that country a symphony, ``Babiy Yar'' by D.D. Shostakovich. ``It was that life under censorship that led me to the United States,'' Rostropovich said. Only now, he said, are Soviet people learning about some of their own writers and seeing their works published. ``Art and literature should be judged by the conscience of the creator, his peers in his field and all of the people, not by a separate bureaucracy, artificially compressing the arteries and veins of this life-sustaining circulation,'' he said. Rostropovich was among the witnesses supporting reauthorization of the NEA before the education, arts and humanities subcommittee of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. The NEA has come under intense criticism for works of art produced by artists who received support from the endowment and which were judged by some to be obscene or offensive. Congress added language to its 1990 appropriation for NEA preventing federal aid for ``obscene'' art, ``including but not limited to depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children or individuals engaged in sex acts.'' A prominent New York producer, Joseph Papp, on Thursday turned down a $50,000 NEA grant rather than pledge that none of the government money would be used for works that might be judged obscene. Phyllis Schlafly, president of the Eagle Forum, a conservative group, argued at the hearing that federal support for the endowment should be cut off. She said the issue was not censorship but responsible use of taxpayers' money. ``Nobody has a right to receive unrestricted grants of the taxpayers' money,'' Schlafly said. ``The NEA was born in the mid-1960s, when unregulated handouts to targeted constituencies were the passion of the day,'' Schlafly said. ``That era is over. ... Having proved its irresponsibility in spending the taxpayers' money, the National Endowment for the Arts should be completely defunded.'' The chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, John E. Frohnmayer, appeared at a House subcommittee hearing a day earlier where he called the restrictive language a compromise ``probably fully satisfactory to none.'' He said ``confusion'' about the restrictions among artists was demonstrated by Papp's action. Frohnmayer said the language ``has made our task more difficult rather than easier,'' and repeated his request that no content restrictions be added to the next appropriation, and said the endowment would pursue its plans to improve a peer panel review process.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: M-I-C ... Original Mouseketeer Darlene wants to see Walt Disney Productions in court. K-E-Y ... Why? Because she says they cheated her out of royalties from the original ``Mickey Mouse Club.'' Darlene Gillespie is accusing Disney of taking advantage of her in 1955 when the then 14-year-old Mouseketeer-to-be signed a contract. Her lawsuit contends the entertainment company failed to tell her the true terms of her employment on the popular television show. Disney spokesman Erwin Okun said the company would have no comment until attorneys had a chance to review the court papers. The Superior Court suit filed Thursday alleges that Disney falsely promised the young Darlene a ``substantial amount of money'' from her percentage of the sales of character merchandising, royalties and residuals from record sales. Disney further ``failed to inform her that her actual realized earnings would be divided in such a way that (she) would not earn any more than a few dollars from the sales,'' the lawsuit says. In court papers, Gillespie said she only became aware of the gravity of her loss in 1987. Disney, the lawsuit contends, has earned more than $10 million from Ms. Gillespie's appearances on the show. The suit seeks unspecified punitive, general and compensatory damages.

Rubber-faced Jim Varney will put the character he plays behind bars for the American Heart Association. He will appear as Ernest P. Worrell at a May 11 fund-raiser called Jail Bail for Heart at the Tennessee state Capitol. Varney, whose most recent motion picture is ``Ernest Goes to Jail,'' will have his own cell. He will be joined by about 300 other ``inmates'' trying to raise at least $250 for bail. He has portrayed Ernest in dozens of television commercials, saying the phrase ``Know whut I mean, Vern.'' He also has appeared in two other comedy movies, ``Ernest Goes to Camp'' and ``Ernest Saves Christmas.''

Ms. Senior California Jane Lindsey was crowned Ms. Senior America 1990 after playing a violin solo and outlining the ``five action words'' that guide her life. The 68-year-old Santa Ana resident beat out contestants from 29 other states to win the title held by Josephine Huyghe, a 63-year-old roller skater. The pageant was open to contestants at least 60 years old. Judges base their decision on interview, evening gown, talent and inner beauty-philosophy of life. Before winning the crown Thursday night, Ms. Lindsey played a violin solo of ``Tea For Two'' and gave an alliterative philosophy of life. ``Five action words describe my philosophy of life _ looking, listening, learning, loving and living life with the expectation of the very best,'' she said.

Former President Reagan, moved by a newspaper account of a little girl blinded by cancer, visited her at the hospital, chatting with her about dogs, horses and unicorns. Reagan traveled across town Thursday to Childrens Hospital to comfort and chat with 4-year-old Kati Sleeman, who suffers from a form of eye cancer and a brain tumor. The cancer has spread and her prognosis is poor. In a recent Los Angeles Times article, officials at Childrens Hospital noted the cheerful, energetic and loving spirit of the little girl. ``She's amazing,'' said nurse Cammie Lancaster. ``If people could only view the world the way Kati views it. ... She just radiates love.'' When Reagan arrived, he brought a stuffed pooch. Immediately the little girl asked him if he had a dog. ``Yes,'' the former president answered. Kati pressed him on the name. ``Rex,'' Reagan replied. She wanted to know if he had horses. When Reagan assured her he did, she asked if they were unicorns. The former president laughed. After visiting with Kati, Reagan visited other children suffering serious illnesses in the hospital.

West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher was awarded the Prince of Asturias International Cooperation prize Friday for seeking disarmament in Europe. Leopolodo Calvo Sotelo, the Prince of Asturias Foundation secretary and former Spanish prime minister, said Genscher won the award for ``his vital contribution to the building of the European community, for his decisive role in the process of disarmament, for his efforts to create a Pan-European security system and for his tenacious defense of human rights.'' The prize is named after Prince Felipe de Borbon, heir to the Spanish throne. It carries a $47,500 prize. Other finalists: South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela and Czech President and playwright Vaclav Havel.

The cowboy music trio Riders in the Sky have signed up to make public service announcements and personal appearances on behalf of the National Park Service. The Grand Ole Opry group plans to perform concerts in national parks, and to discuss their support of the parks on their public radio series, ``Riders Radio Theatre,'' which airs on 100 stations. The show, formerly taped in Nashville, has moved to Cincinnati. The three dress as cowboys and sing songs such as ``Cool Water'' and ``Tumbling Tumbleweed.'' They also do comedy skits. ``They'll help us get a serious message across in a lighthearted way,'' said James Ridenour, director of the National Park Service.

DOC.HEAD: Murderer Executed After Expressing Remorse
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: A murderer responsible for four deaths in a bloody 1979 rampage expressed remorse before he was executed early Friday, but a cheer erupted from a waiting crowd as his body was borne from the death house. Ronald ``Rusty'' Woomer, 35, was electrocuted at 1:05 a.m. and pronounced dead seven minutes later, said William D. Catoe, the Corrections Department's deputy commissioner for operations. The West Virginia native was put to death for the murder of Della Louise Sellers, a Pawleys Island convenience-store clerk. ``I'm sorry,'' Woomer said in a low, shaky voice from the electric chair immediately before his death. ``I claim Jesus Christ as my savior. I only wish everyone could feel the love I feel for him.'' A crowd of about 80 death penalty proponents cheered as the hearse bearing Woomer's body left the death house. But his execution gave little immediate solace to Mrs. Sellers' widower. ``It was too easy. It was too easy,'' said Don Sellers, who was among the witnesses at Woomer's execution. Woomer's death sentence was carried out after the U.S. Supreme Court denied requests for a stay. Gov. Carroll Campbell also turned down a plea for clemency Thursday. ``I'm glad to know Woomer won't ever be on the streets again to harm anybody else,'' said 50-year-old Marion Wright, the brother of Earldean Wright, another of Woomer's victims. Woomer's path to death row began on Feb. 21, 1979, when he and Eugene Skaar left West Virginia to steal rare coins from retired engineer John Turner, 67, in Cottageville, S.C. Upon reaching Turner's home on Feb. 22, they took the coins and fatally shot him in the head, police said. Woomer and Skaar then drove to a neighboring community and forced their way into the home of Arnie Richardson, looking for money and guns. Woomer killed Richardson, 27, and his 35-year-old mentally handicapped sister-in-law, Earldean Wright, authorities said. Later that day, Woomer and Skaar kidnapped Mrs. Sellers, 34, and Wanda Summers, then 24, from the store where the women worked. Both were raped and shot. Mrs. Sellers died, but Mrs. Summers survived, losing half her face to a shotgun blast. Mrs. Summers has taken a public stand to press for Woomer's execution. Skaar killed himself to avoid capture and Woomer surrendered when police surrounded their Myrtle Beach hotel. Woomer was sentenced to death for Mrs. Sellers' murder and two life terms for the deaths of Richardson and Ms. Wright. His conviction and death sentence in the Turner slaying was overturned, but he was never retried. Two other people have been put to death in South Carolina since the death penalty was reinstated in 1976. Woomer was the 123rd person put to death nationwide since 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Aperture Door Finally Opened After Morning Of Problems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to CORRECT attribution of `great news' quote to Shriver sted Hawley, add new quote, and to UPDATE with problem blamed on jarring during door-opening; process under way to fix it. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Steve Terry...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTN1
DOC.TEXT: The lens cover on the Hubble Space Telescope opened today after a morning of worrisome problems, and Mission Control told the Discovery astronauts they no longer are needed to rescue the $1.5 billion instrument. ``You've been released from Hubble support; it's on its own,'' Mission Control told the astronauts when the aluminum aperture door opened. ``Thank you, sir, that's great news,'' said Discovery Commander Loren J. Shriver. ``There are handshakes and smiles all around up here,'' said Steve Hawley, who had been at the controls when the telescope was released into its own orbit on Wednesday. ``I'll bet it's just that way down there, too.'' The successful opening of the lens cover paved the way for the astronauts to return to Earth on Sunday. They had blasted into space Tuesday after a two-week delay and dispatched the telescope from its payload bay Wednesday. ``The Hubble is open for business,'' Mission Control told the astronauts. The telescope still was having problems, however. When the door opened, two of its four position-stabilizing gyroscopes stopped working and the electronic system went into an automatic ``safe mode'' in which all motion is stopped. The team at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland, which guides the telescope, said the door-opening motion jarred the telescope more than had been expected and that the system reacted properly in shutting down. By early afternoon, a step-by-step procedure was begun to bring the telescope's electronics back on line. Steve Terry, a top Hubble engineering official, said tolerances for the telescope systems had been set particularly narrow for the first operations and that was the cause of many malfunctions. In addition to the trouble this morning, there two communications outages Thursday totaling several hours. ``We're cautious, and that's natural,'' he said. ``We've got a very expensive spacecraft here and we don't want to do anything to jeopardize the usefulness. ... We'll get to the point where we know exactly what the spacecraft will do and set the limits appropriately.'' NASA announced that ``at this time the telescope is safe, stable.'' The space shuttle Discovery, which carried the telescope to orbit, was 50 miles behind the telescope, ready to lend a hand if needed. Later in the day, the ship was to do an engine firing that would set it on a preliminary path for home. That path would take the Discovery two miles below the telescope. The lens cover, a 10-foot diameter ``aperature door,'' covers the opening to the telescope's light shield. When it is closed, the telescope is blind. The lens cover had been closed _ except for a tiny wedge opening _ ever since the $1.5 billion telescope was dropped overboard by the Discovery crew on Wednesday. Now that it is opened, starlight can strike the lens for the first time and it can go about its business of photographing and analyzing the universe in ways and with sensitivity never before possible. The door is made from honeycombed aluminum sheets covered on the outside with solar-reflecting material. The inside is painted black to absorb stray light. If the door opening command had failed, the five Discovery astronauts who deployed Hubble were prepared to head back to the telescope. Mission specialists Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan would have performed a space walk to open the door Saturday if necessary. If it had been needed, the rescue would have delayed the landing, scheduled for Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., by a day. The astronauts were awakened at 2:30 a.m. EDT to the mellow sounds of the Beach Boys' song, ``Kokomo.'' ``For Max Q's keyboard, that's the way that song should really be done,'' Mission Control radioed to mission specialist Steve Hawley, a member of the all-astronaut band called Max Q. ``Your next practice is Sunday evening in the gym, don't be late.'' Max Q is a NASA acronym for the point in the shuttle's ascent when the aerodynamic pressure is at its greatest point. ``That sounds just like the way we do it,'' replied Hawley. ``If you get us home by Sunday, I'll go to practice.'' In an orbit high enough to avoid Earth's distorting atmosphere, Hubble will allow astronomers to study stars and galaxies so distant their light has taken 14 billion years to reach Earth. It is capable of detecting objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory. During its 15-year working lifetime, Hubble is expected to help determine the age and size of the universe. It may solve the mysteries of quasars, pulsars and black holes and even find stars with planets that could conceivably support life. On Tuesday, NASA plans to release its first test image from the telescope, an open star cluster in the constellation Carina. Significant data will follow in a month or two. The 12{-ton, 43-foot-long telescope, about the size of a bus, is named for astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, who died in 1953. The Missouri-born Hubble discovered during the 1920s that the universe is expanding, a finding that gave rise to the theory the universe was created about 15 billion years ago by a tremendous explosion.

DOC.HEAD: Economy's Growth Accompanied by `Ugly' Inflation in First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The nation's economy grew at a surprising 2.1 percent rate in the first quarter, the government reported Friday, but analysts said an ``ugly'' inflation rate could mean higher interest rates that would slow growth later this year. ``We have set ourselves up for a halfway decent first half of 1990,'' said Donald Straszheim, chief economist for Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. ``But, by the end of the year, the economy will be slowing.'' In addition to the strength in the gross national product _ the nation's total output of goods and services _ the Commerce Department reported that inflation jumped 6.5 percent, its steepest jump since a 7.7 percent increase in the fourth quarter of 1981. The GNP inflation rate for 1989 was 4.5 percent. ``The inflation number was absolutely ugly,'' remarked Robert G. Dederick, chief economist of the Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. He and other analysts said the pace of inflation _ boosted in part by the weather _ probably will slow during the current quarter to the 4.5 percent-5 percent range. But that still means the Federal Reserve will not lower interest rates and may decide to boost them further to slow the price spiral, they contend. Higher rates curb growth in the construction and other interest-sensitive industries by raising the cost of borrowing. J. Antonio Villamil, the Commerce Department's chief economist, called the inflation report ``disappointing news.'' Without the weather effect and a federal pay raise that went into effect in January, prices still rose 5.2 percent during the quarter, he said. But Villamil was upbeat about the 2.1 percent GNP grow, which nearly doubled the 1.1 percent rate during the fourth quarter and came close to matching the administration's 2.2 percent forecast. The administration is counting on a growing economy to help narrow the federal budget deficit. ``Despite the larger price rise,'' Villamil said, ``the first quarter still had encouraging developments _ signs of the economy's resilience.'' Most economists agreed. ``On the GNP data, one can't find anything wrong with this economy,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist with the Boston Co. ``Everything is up except inventories,'' a development he said was a ``healthy sign.'' Lower inventories usually result in a rise in production as companies restock their shelves and backlots. Other than inventories, however, increases in the GNP were widespread. Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, rose 2.5 percent after a meager 0.5 percent advance in the previous quarter. Durable goods, which had fallen 14 percent from October through December, more than recovered with a 17 percent jump. Automobiles accounted for about two-thirds of the increase. The trade deficit narrowed as exports rose 0.9 percent while imports dropped 2.8 percent. The deficit is the difference between the two. Business investment for expansion and modernization rose 7.6 percent after declining 5.4 percent the previous quarter. Housing construction, which was down 1.1 percent at year's end, jumped 8.5 percent. But analysts said much of the housing improvement was due to the warm weather, which prompted builders to begin projects they normally would not have started until later in the year. The analysts said the early starts will subtract from future growth. The Commerce Department also said the weather played a part in hiking the inflation rate. The 2.1 percent advance was the fastest since a 3.0 percent gain in the third quarter last year. The various changes left the GNP, after adjusting for inflation, growing at an annual rate of $4.196 trillion in the first three months of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian Protest Ends Peacefully After Security Forces Move In
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people gathered outside the Mongolian government palace for an illegal protest Friday but dispersed peacefully after security forces surrounded the palace, sources in Mongolia said. It was the first direct confrontation between protesters and security forces in five months of pro-democracy demonstrations in Mongolia, and both sides seemed anxious to avoid violence. The security forces did not have weapons or riot gear, said the sources in the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator. The protesters, who demanded resignation of the Communist-dominated legislature, violated a recent edict by President Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat that all demonstrations be approved in advance. Ochirbat tried to head off the confrontation by offering Thursday night to set up a council for opposition groups to make suggestions to the legislature. But the opposition demanded that a multiparty interim legislature govern until elections are held. Voting is tentatively set for July. Suhjargalmaa, an editor at the official Montsame News Agency, said in a telephone interview from Ulan Bator that the largest opposition group, the Mongolian Democratic Association, had planned to circle the government palace when the demands were not met by noon. But police and soldiers of the internal militia formed a protective circle first and blocked adjoining streets, Suhjargalmaa said. The protesters were able to form a picket line on only one side of the palace, fronting a large central square where supporters and onlookers gathered. Other opposition groups, including the National Progressives and Social Democrats, also joined. ``There were about 40,000 at noon but now there are much fewer,'' Suhjargalmaa said in the early evening. Other sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the protest leaders had left by mid-afternoon and only curious passers-by remained later. They said the crowd peaked at about 10,000 but that only 1,200 to 1,400 seemed actively involved. Students chanted ``Youth unite!'' and waved national flags and emblems of the Mongolian Democratic Association, said the Soviet news agency Tass. Mongolian radio said the government broadcast appeals over loudspeakers for the crowd to disperse but that protesters responded with shouts for the soldiers to leave. The breakup of the protest appeared to have been gradual, and it was unclear if any concessions were made to end the protest. So far, Mongolia's democracy movement, inspired by change elsewhere in the Soviet bloc, has been peaceful. The Communists, formally called the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, gave up their constitutional right to rule in March and agreed to the country's first multiparty elections, apparently believing they could best stay in power by embracing reforms. But the opposition has accused the party of cheating by amending the election law to give more delegates to rural areas, where the Communists are strongest. Opposition groups want this changed and demand the immediate transfer of power to a multiparty, interim legislature. The Mongolian Democratic Association set a deadline of noon Friday for the government to respond. Ochirbat offered instead to set up an advisory council for the opposition to work with the existing legislature, and to let it join in the work of the Central Election Council. Suhjargalmaa said talks between the two sides ended when the opposition members walked out. The opposition is also demanding that the ruling party's Central Committee move its offices from the government palace, and that all parties be allowed to join a commission that is investigating former high-ranking officials. The commission was set up by the ruling party in early April to uncover alleged abuses of power under former dictator Yumjaagiyn Tsedenbal. He was ousted in 1984, but many of his associates remain in government and the party.

DOC.HEAD: Holy Sites Closed to Protest Presence of Jewish Settlers
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUB 8th graf to correct that land captured by Israel during war. Pickup 9th graf, `Kafiti said...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TLV1,TLV3
