DOC.TEXT: Church bells tolled, black flags fluttered in the breeze and the doors of Jesus' burial site were shut Friday for possibly the first time in 800 years as Christians protested a Jewish settlement in Jerusalem's Old City. In an unusual show of unity, about 150 clergymen from nine major Christian sects gathered to oversee the closing of the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, which marks the site of Jesus' crucifixion and burial. Latin Patriarch Michel Sabbah, Greek Orthodox Patriarch Diodoros I, and Armenian Orthodox Patriarch Torkum Manoogian recited the Lord's Prayer in Arabic, Armenian and Greek before the massive wooden doors swung shut. Wajih Nusseibeh, a Moslem whose family keeps the key of the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, said it was the first time the doors were closed since the Crusaders were driven out of the city by the Islamic warrior Saladin in the 12th century A.D. The Church of the Nativity, which marks the site of Jesus' birth in Bethlehem, and holy sites throughout the country were also closed in the daylong protest. Church bells rang in somber, funereal cadence for about fivehree days in another Army hospital. ``I regret that, at the moment, I am unable to thank you more directly and personally,'' Polhill said in the prepared statement. ``But my voice decided to go on vacation before I did. However, I do want you to know how very much I appreciate the warmth and sincerity of your welcome and the support you've given my wife and family, who join me in hoping that this is the beginning of the end to the hostage situation. ``I am, happily, now free to join you in your continued support for the loved ones of those who remain in captivity and in welcoming the hostages home in the very near future. Let's show the world that we, the American people, want to leave the past behind us, look positively to the future and, once and for all, close the file on the hostage issue.'' Asked whether her husband was angry at his captors, Mrs. Polhill said, ``His being angry has been blown out of all proportion.'' She did not elaborate. As to her own feelings, she said, ``I feel good to have him back.'' She said that she and her husband spent their first night together in the states resting, talking and doing ``everything every normal couple would do.'' She also said that although Polhill and the other hostages received little news in their captivity she believes he knew that George Bush was president before the chief executive telephoned him in Damascus. The Army doctor said he expects the biopsy to be performed ``in the near future,'' although he could not be more specific. He said Polhill ``appears to be in good spirits considering the ordeal he has been through.'' ``There is no evidence that he was beaten,'' the doctor said. He said Polhill had indicated to other physicians that he was not. In addition to the growth on his vocal cords, the doctor said Polhill has some numbness or tingling in his arms and hands as a complication of his diabetes. He said Polhill had told other physicians that he was given insulin for his condition while in custody. With a wave and a broad smile, Polhill stepped off a military jet Thursday onto the sun-drenched tarmac at Andrews Air Force Base in suburban Maryland. He was whisked away by car to Walter Reed Army Medical Center, but not before shaking hands with the small official welcoming party and offering several thumbs-up salutes to reporters and a small group of Air Force personnel on hand for his arrival. Polhill maintained his public silence on his arrival. In private talks with U.S. officials, he reportedly has given a vivid and detailed account of his ordeal. The return of the 55-year-old business professor left behind in the Middle East 17 Western Hostages, seven of them Americans. Although Polhill's release brought hopes that additional American hostages soon would share his freedom, the U.S. debriefing team that traveled to Wiesbaden, West Germany, to meet with Polhill departed Thursday, seemingly a sign that no release is considered imminent. For Polhill, it was back to a military hospital. He left one at the Air Force base in Wiesbaden, where he spent three days after his weekend release, and went to Walter Reed for a complete physical and other tests and treatment. Polhill lost 25 pounds in captivity and also is a diabetic. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush planned to meet soon with Polhill but that a date had not been set. Other administration officials also likely will have questions for Polhill about his captors. Polhill was abducted with two other American educators on Jan. 24, 1987, from the campus of the U.S.-affiliated Beirut University College. The other two remain among the seven American hostages. The longest-held of the U.S. hostages is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Party Chief Says Communists May Soon End Up Opposition
With AM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Communist Party will soon be relegated to a minority role in the Soviet Union unless it figures out how to win over voters, Moscow's party chief warned Friday. ``If we can't learn to understand and defend the interests of the people, we'll have to go into the opposition,'' Yuri A. Prokofiev, leader of Moscow's 1.1 million Communists, told a news conference. ``If there are no improvements in people's lives in the near future, then in the next elections they may not vote at all for the Communist Party, and it could end up in the minority,'' he added. Prokofiev was speaking from experience. In Moscow elections in March, many Communists were trounced by more reformist candidates who blamed the party for the city's many ills. Prokofiev himself was elected to the Moscow City Council, but the bloc in the council that supports the Communist Party platform numbers only about 90, compared with some 400 in the more radical Democratic Russia group. In the Soviet Union's first multi-candidate elections, held over the past year, many Communist leaders have been defeated. Officials say they are victims of the party's ``crisis of confidence.'' Prokofiev acknowledged that 6,000 Muscovites quit the party in the first quarter of this year but said only ``a scattered few'' were leaving for ideological reasons. He said most were elderly or token members who were no longer active Communists anyway. Of those who quit on principle, he said, about half left because they think reforms are proceeding too slowly and the other half because they oppose reform altogether, he said. Prokofiev predicted the Communist Party would formally split soon, losing a reformist group known as the Democratic Platform. But he said he had high hopes for this July's Party Congress, which could help both improve the party's image and heal the rift between party officials and rank-and-file Communists. Meanwhile, he said, the party is working on ``legally strengthening'' its claim on buildings, newspapers and other properties to make sure it won't lose them if it falls from power. Prokofiev said he had learned from the extensive financial losses among Polish Communists whose party did not take such measures before elections last year that ended in a Solidarity-led government. He said Moscow party officials were also seeking commercial ventures they could undertake to earn money to buy television time, pay rent, and foot other bills that never came up when the party and the government were virtually the same. In other Communist Party news, Leningrad party chief Boris Gidaspov was re-elected Friday, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. Gidaspov is considered a leader of the more conservative wing of the Communist Party. He has warned that allowing private property would result in black marketeers dominating the economy. He drew criticism last fall for organizing a party protest at which some speakers denounced the Politburo and Kremlin reforms. Gidaspov, a former factory director, defeated four other candidates in a secret vote, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: City Pays $50,000 to Homeless in Bedroll Confiscation Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Fifteen homeless people, some with only pennies in their pockets, came into a windfall when the city paid out $50,000 to settle a lawsuit protesting the mass street cleanup of stashed bedrolls. ``I've come up a long way in the world in just a matter of minutes,'' said Chuck Daigle, who began Thursday practically penniless and later received his share _ a check for $3,308.46. The unemployed restaurant worker planned a steak and lobster dinner, while co-plaintiff George Ellithorpe eyed a haircut and a shave. Most recipients wanted to use the money to help them get off the streets, said attorney Christopher Mears, who represented the group. ``I hope it's not naive to be hopeful that, for a number of these people, the money is going to help turn things around,'' said Mears, who accepted only $373.10 to cover his expenses and court costs. Plans ranged from finding a room for the night to car buying and traveling to Alaska in search of long-lost relatives, Mears said. Daigle, who said he and Ellithorpe had less than 2 cents between them before receiving the checks, planned a train trip to Marysville in Northern California to visit relatives and look for work. ``I have a one-shot chance to change my life, and I'm going to do it. No more dreaming,'' said Daigle, 40. The plaintiffs, who live in the streets near the Civic Center, filed suit in 1988 after their bedrolls and personal belongings were taken during a street sweep. The confiscated belongings were not returned and some said they lost valuable identification papers, medical prescriptions and irreplaceable mementos. At Mears' request, Sunwest Bank in downtown Santa Ana agreed to open savings accounts or to cash the checks, even though most in the group have limited identification and no permanent address. Most bought travelers checks. Ellithorpe, 61, said his windfall wasn't likely to last long. He planned to rent an apartment, buy eyeglasses to replace a pair he's worn for 20 years, and get a haircut and a shave. ``I need a rest or a vacation from the streets for at least a month,'' he said. ``Then I'll hit the bricks again.''

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in Five-State Spree Pleads Guilty But Mentally Ill in One Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A Kansas man charged in a three-state killing spree that left five dead pleaded guilty but mentally ill to charges of capital murder and armed robbery in one of those deaths, a prosecutor said today. Gregg Francis Braun of Garden City, Kan., entered his plea on Thursday in a closed hearing before state District Judge Jay Harris, said Colfax County Assistant District Attorney Leslie Skinner. Two psychologists testified during the hearing that they believed Braun suffered from a mental illness last July 23 when Geraldine Valdez was shot to death in a Springer convenience store where she worked as a clerk, Ms. Skinner said. Braun was to have gone on trial May 7 in Taos. Braun, 29, also is charged with the July 19, 1989, shooting deaths of two convenience store clerks in Garden City, Kan.; the July 20 slaying of a photo processing shop owner in Pampa, Texas; and the July 21 slaying of a woman in an Ardmore, Okla., flower shop. In an emotional hearing last August, Braun confessed to the killing of Ms. Valdez and blamed his problems on drugs. He said he had been using cocaine heavily in the month before the slayings. Braun was being held in the Colfax County Jail in Raton. Ms. Skinner said today that efforts were under way to transfer him to the state penitentiary near Santa Fe. At the hearing Thursday in Las Vegas, N.M., Harris ordered attorneys for both sides to submit legal briefs on the question of whether a defendant who pleads guilty but mentally ill can face the death penalty in New Mexico. If courts rule that capital punishment is permissible in such cases, Ms. Springer said, a jury will later decide whether Braun deserves the death penalty. If capital punishment is ruled out by either the jury or the courts, Braun would face life in prison for the guilty plea, Ms. Skinner said. Under New Mexico law, guilty but mentally ill means the defendant was mentally ill but not legally insane. ``There was no reduction in charges, no plea bargaining in this case by the state,'' she said. ``The defendant simply admitted to both of the charges and the court found a factual basis for mental illness.'' Braun's attorney, Gary Mitchell, was in court on another case today and could not be reached immediately.

DOC.HEAD: France, West Germany, Push For European Union; Britain Skeptical
DOC.TEXT: France and West Germany are expected to press European Community leaders at a summit Saturday for swift progress toward European political union by 1993, despite Britain's skepticism. The British are demanding to know what political union means. The French and Germans say it's the spirit, rather than definitions, that matters most at this stage. For British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the Franco-German alliance presents a diplomatic challenge: to tone down what she sees as rhetoric without worsening her reputation as a reluctant European. France and West Germany say they want Saturday's summit to agree to set up an inter-governmental conference on political union. That would be in addition to a conference already due late this year on economic and monetary union. ``We are deeply skeptical about the timing,'' British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said this week. ``Nevertheless, if our partners wish to set in hand such work, we shall join actively in the task and contribute our own ideas.'' Ireland, the holder of the community's rotating presidency, called the one-day summit to discuss German unification. It will mean East Germany becoming the first former Communist territory to join the wealthy 12-nation trade bloc. But spurred by fears of resurgent nationalism destabilizing Europe, France and West Germany have plunged the community into the momentous issue of political union. In an April 15 announcement, they said the community nations should each have laws in place by Jan. 1, 1993, for both economic integration and ``political union.'' Five days later, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President Francois Mitterrand wrote to Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey suggesting the inter-governmental conference. No one has defined what political union means. Possibilities range from a centralized government, through a United States of Europe, to the more likely reality of increased powers for the community's elected parliament and its executive commission in Brussels. ``We are witnessing a decisive thrust toward European unity,'' Kohl declared Thursday after two days of talks with Mitterrand in Paris. ``A dream is coming true _ seeing German unity and European unity come into being together,'' he said. Mitterrand agreed. ``A European Community more unified _ that's what we want. A structured, balanced, peaceful Europe _ that's what we are working for.'' Mrs. Thatcher opposes any form of federal Europe or markedly greater powers for the European Commission, arguing that no European government is truly willing to cede national sovereignty to Brussels. A stickler for detail, she plans to ask bluntly what her continental partners mean by ``political union,'' hoping their confusion will prove her point _ that no one knows just what it entails. But as Sir Leon Brittan, a senior EEC official, said Thursday: ``It doesn't have a meaning. It means what you want it to mean.'' Mrs. Thatcher also believes the issue of political union is premature. She wants the community of 320 million people to give priority to more immediate issues, like establishing a single, tariff-free market for Europe by the end of 1992 and incorporating East Germany's backward economy. ``We think the best European cooperation, the best Europe we can build, will be a Europe of 12 sovereign states sitting willingly and freely together,'' Mrs. Thatcher said recently. ``I believe most people want to be proud of their country and want to feel that affinity to it as well as to Europe.'' ``Europe can only live in peace if nationalism is overcome,'' said Irmgard Adam-Schwaetzer, No. 2 to West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. The Irish say they and other member states _ Italy, Spain, Portugal, Greece, Denmark, Belgium, The Netherlands and Luxembourg _ share a general wish for greater political unity. On monetary union, the 12 nations agree on the first stage of a three-stage program, but Britain is resisting the ultimate goal of a single central bank and one currency. The summit will also discuss closer relations with the other newly emerging democracies of Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Killed Himself Wanted Freedom for Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with suicide notes containing political motive for the suicide. Pickup 9th, ``Little was...''
DOC.TEXT: A Lithuanian who died after setting himself on fire outside the Bolshoi Theater left behind suicide notes calling on the Soviet president to permit his republic to become independent, an official said today. In notes the victim left for his wife and Lithuanian government officials, he said he was killing himself to let President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``know that Lithuanians will not live in a Lithuania that is not independent.'' The contents of the notes were disclosed by Rita Radzavicius, a spokesman for the Lithuanian parliament, or Supreme Council. Stanislovas Jamaitis, 52, died on Thursday of burns suffered when he doused his clothes with gasoline and set himself ablaze in central Moscow. Jamaitis, who lived in the western Lithuanian city of Kaunas, left one suicide note for his wife, Stasala, and another for Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis and the Lithuanian parliament. Referring to the Kremlin's economic blockade on Lithuania, which declared its indepenence March 11, Jamaitis' said: ``I went to Moscow to set myself on fire in Red Square. The occupiers have cut off energy supplies, and people are being thrown out of work.'' Thousands of workers have been laid off recently because of the economic embargo, which is meant to break the republic's resolve. Moscow police spokesman Vladimir Martynov said earlier that Jamaitis was ``in a drunken state'' when ``he poured gasoline on himself and lit it.'' Post-Factum, an independent Soviet news agency, reported that bystanders said Jamaitis ``had been shouting various things, including demands for Lithuanian independence,'' in the minutes before he set himself ablaze. Little was known about Jamaitis except that he was the father of two, had been recently unemployed and came from the Alitus region about 30 miles southwest of the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius, Martynov said. Passers-by helped extinguish the flames that engulfed Jamaitis, but he was in shock when brought to the hospital and died five hours later at 10:05 p.m. Thursday, Martynov reported. He never regained consciousness.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Won't Target Japan on Trade
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS wire garbles in 2nd, 7th grafs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, ignoring congressional pressure, announced today that he has decided not to place Japan on a ``hit list'' of countries with the worst trade barriers against U.S. products. India is the only country his administration has decided to keep on its list of nations targeted for unfair trading practices, Bush said in a statement. Bush hailed what he said was recent progress in easing U.S.-Japanese trade frictions. ``Promoting a vibrant, open trading relationship with Japan remains a key trade priority of the administration,'' Bush said. A recent agreement with Japan that included Japanese concessions on opening its markets to more U.S. goods was a ``promising start,'' he said. At the same time, he said, he was under no illusion that the agreement alone would ``lead to an immediate improvement'' in this nation's $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. But, he said, he was persuaded that Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and other Japanese leaders ``share my commitment to ensuring that trade strengthens, rather than undermines, the friendship between our nations.'' A year ago, the administration named Japan, Brazil and India as the countries with the most offensive barriers to American trade. Both Japan and Brazil have won praise from the administration for making significant concessions during negotiations aimed at opening their markets to American products. But India, which was cited last year for a ban on operations of foreign private insurance companies and for controls on foreign investment that distort trade, has refused to make concessions. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said that India was targeted again because it has the most trade barriers of any non-communist country and negotiations over the past year had made no progress. Several members of Congress had warned the administration that it would be making a serious mistake to fail to target Japan once more as a way of keeping pressure on the country to honor its market-opening commitments. But Hills rejected these arguments, saying that the administration needed flexibility in its negotiating efforts with other countries. ``We believe we have made enormous progress with Japan in the past few months,'' she told reporters. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said he was glad that the administration had at least issued a new Super 301 list although he was disappointed that Japan was not included. ``There has been little improvement in our trade deficit with that country and I am a bit of a skeptic as to whether the recent agreements will make much of a difference,'' Bentsen said in a statement. The 1988 trade law required the administration to issue a target list of countries with the most offensive trade barriers in 1989 and 1990. ``Let there be no mistake,'' Bush said. ``This administration is committed to free and fair trade. We want open markets and fair treatment for our products, services, investment and ideas.'' Bush said he had also directed Mrs. Hills to ``give her highest priority'' to seeking a conclusion by December of ongoing international trade liberalization talks now under way in Geneva. Sources said India's refusal to seek a negotiated settlement of last year's trade case prompted the administration to cite India again. While the designation of India was likely to meet with approval on Capitol Hill, the refusal to cite Japan was certain to raise heavy protests. Many members of Congress said that would indicate the administration is not interested in carrying out the requirements of the toughest section of the 1988 trade law, known as Super 301. The law provides a tight timetable for negotiating away barriers and provides for economic sanctions if the talks prove unsuccessful. They said Super 301 was written with Japan specifically in mind and that Japan needed to be targeted again to ensure that it lived up to its newfound willingness to lower trade barriers. In the days before the decision was announced, Hills lavished praise on both Japan and Brazil for their willingness to negotiate in good faith and said that citing Japan again could provoke a backlash in Tokyo, where the Kaifu government has been pushing to change Japan's trading practices. In Japan's case, there has been a flurry of trade agreements over the past month. Japanese negotiators agreed to open their markets for the sale of U.S.-made satellites, supercomputers and forest products _ the three product areas cited in last year's Super 301 case. In addition, Japan and the United States earlier this month completed an interim agreement designed to attack broad-based structural barriers that are preventing American and other foreign companies from doing business in Japan. Hills praised Brazil for undertaking a ``fantastic change in policy'' under newly elected President Fernando Collor de Mellor. Brazil has agreed to cut protectionist barriers and submit for international settlement the licensing restrictions on imports cited by the United States in last year's complaint.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Keeps $420 Million in Aid to Panama
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 6th graf, A provision... to update with second vote on abortion
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's aid requests for Nicaragua and Panama are surviving unscathed in a $3.4 billion spending bill, and the measure plodded forward today as senators dealt with a long list of proposed amendments. The ``dire emergency'' money bill contained $420 million to help rebuild Panama's economy and $300 million to help the new democratic administration of Violeta Chamorro, sworn in Wednesday as president of Nicaragua. ``Mrs. Chamorro's term may expire before we get the aid down there,'' Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., cracked as he surveyed a list late Thursday of dozens of amendments that senators sought to add to the bill. Along with the aid Bush is seeking to shore up the fledgling Central American democracies, the bill has become larded with a long list of pet spending projects of lawmakers, pushing it to nearly four times the original White House request. Senators today adopted an amendment by Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., calling for a study of how foreign aid can be used to promote the fortunes of American businesses overseas. It then turned its attention to a list of proposed amendments that included sanctions on Iraq and relief for Lithuania. A provision in the bill permitting the District of Columbia to use local funds to pay for abortions for poor women survived two early test votes, 51-45 and 54-42. But it appeared the Senate was in for a protracted debate over the perennially divisive issue. Bush has vowed to veto the bill if the abortion language remains in it. The bill grew by an additional $363 million late Thursday when senators voted 62-30 to make up a shortfall in the State Department's current budget. The largest chunk of the money goes to pay U.S. dues to the United Nations, with other amounts for construction of buildings overseas and for salaries and expenses. Earlier in the day Byrd, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, tried unsuccessfully to slash the Panama aid to $300 million and use the savings for a variety of domestic programs. Byrd sought to harness the general unpopularity of foreign aid in Congress and cast his amendment as an effort to make charity begin at home. But Sen. Mark O. Hatfield, R-Ore., said the United States has an obligation to Panama stemming from the U.S. economic embargo and the damage inflicted by last December's military invasion, which ousted dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``We owe them,'' Hatfield said. ``This is a bill that's due.'' Senators then voted 51-48 to kill Byrd's attempt, with eight Democrats joining a nearly solid bloc of Republicans to provide the majority in support of Bush's request. The Senate labored until late evening as it tried to deal with dozens of proposed amendments, but prospects appeared remote for quick approval of the overall aid bill. When finally passed, the measure still must go to a conference with the House to work out differences with that chamber's $2.4 billion version. Most of the new spending in both versions of the bill is covered by cuts in the Pentagon budget. And as it stood, the Senate bill faced a veto threat from Bush, who opposes a provision that would allow the District of Columbia government to use local funds to pay for abortions for poor women. Dealing with related legislation on Thursday, the House Foreign Affairs Committee defied Bush and voted to cut in half and sharply restrict the $85 million in annual U.S. military aid to El Salvador. The action came as an amendment to a bill authorizing spending of the Panama and Nicaragua aid funds, despite administration objections that it could undermine fledgling peace talks between the government of El Salvador and the leftist rebels who have fought a decade-long civil war. It remained unclear whether the restrictions on aid would ever be finally enacted into law. House Democratic leaders plan to meet next week with Secretary of State James A. Baker III in an effort to begin drafting a new bipartisan U.S. policy toward El Salvador that could head off the restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: Trading Halted on New York Futures Markets Because of Glitch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with trading called off for the day. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Trading was...'. DELETES penultimate graf pvs, now outdated. A version moved on the financial wire, slugged `PM-Trading Halt'.
DOC.TEXT: The five New York futures markets halted trading and closed early today after a communications glitch prevented price data from being distributed to customers. The 11:20 a.m. trading halt brought action in the nation's major oil and metals trading pits to a standstill after the exchanges discovered that no price quotes were leaving the building. ``The high-speed futures line is dead,'' said Tom Crisalli, an operations employee with the Commodity Exchange Corp., which oversees the five futures markets. After failing to resolve the problem, the exchanges shut down at 2 p.m. They gave traders five to 10 minutes to finish up pending trades before going home early. The regular closing times for the commodities traded at the exchanges run from 2:20 p.m. until after 3 p.m. Thousands of traders, brokers and investors around the country were not receiving quotes on futures prices on their computer screens. Officials said they were unsure about the origins of the problem. Trading was halted at the Commodity Exchange, the nation's main metals market; the New York Mercantile Exchange, the main oil trading market; the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange; the Cotton Exchange; and the New York Futures Exchange. Exchange executives took to the trading floor in the World Trade Center complex in Manhattan shortly after 11 a.m. to inform participants that the market would be halted. The normally frenzied pace of shouted trading in the so-called pits died down and many players left for the day, traders said. ``All of our members started to call up. People who were not on the floor started calling asking for information,'' said Janet Troy, spokewoman for the Coffeee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange. ``I've been in this business over 10 years. I've never seen it go down this long,'' said John Jonat, a precious- metals trader Deak International Inc. Exchange officials said they believed the problem involved American Telephone & Telegraph Co. lines that feed the data out of the exchanges. But AT&T spokeswoman Linda Haertlein said the difficulty did not appear to be in the AT&T network but at the exchange. After they are recorded on slips of paper and entered into computers on the exchange floor, the futures price information is relayed to an on-site AT&T facility that relays it to outside points identified by the exchange. ``The AT&T facility tests OK at this point and time,'' Haertlein said. ``The problem does not appear to be in the AT&T network.'' The New York markets trade futures contracts from orange juice to gold in an open-outcry system where bids are shouted by designated floor brokers. The New York markets are second to Chicago's commodity markets in trading volume and importance.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Moscow Truckers Block Traffic in Protest of Lithuanian Independence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs penultimate graf, `In Moscow...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with contents of suicide notes left by Lithuanian. Pickup last graf, `Since independence...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Moscow truckers protesting Lithuania's campaign for independence blocked rush-hour traffic in the Baltic republic's capital this morning, while local authorities debated how to ease tension with the Kremlin. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis weighed a proposal from the leaders of France and Germany designed to end the impasse that began with Lithuania's declaration of independence on March 11. The demonstration included about 50 trucks and was organized by Communist Party members and Russian workers, said Rita Radzevicius, a spokeswoman at the Lithuanian Supreme Council, or parliament, in the capital city, Vilnius. The Soviet news agency Tass said the truckers opposed the ``adventurist decisions of the Lithuanian'' parliament. It said supporters of the Lithuanian popular front Sajudis dragged the trucks from the streets with tractors. Ms. Radzevicius said in a telephone interview that local authorities persuaded the truckers to end the blockade after about two hours, but she said force was not used. Because of gas shortages caused by the Kremlin blockade, rush-hour traffic in Vilnius was much lighter than usual. Many people walked to work or used the city's extensive trolley system. The truckers worked for the Autotransport Enterprise in Vilnius and consisted mostly of Russians who are members of Yedinstvo and the splinter of the Lithuanian Communist Party that follows the Kremlin line. Some Lithuanians also took part, she said. The main Lithuanian Communist Party split with Moscow in December. Yedinstvo consists of Russians, Poles and other minorities who believe that the Lithuanian majority is infringing on their rights. Lithuanian authorities, meanwhile, grappled with a partial economic blockade imposed by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev after the independence declaration, and groped for a diplomatic solution to the standoff. Many shop shelves were empty, and the embargo slowed work at 46 businesses and stopped it at two others in Lithuania, the Moscow newspaper Rabochaya Tribuna reported. The Kremlin has cut off all oil and and 80 percent of Lithuania's natural gas supply, causing thousands of workers to be laid off. Lithuania will begin food rationing on Tuesday, Vilnius Radio reported, as the republic of 3.8 million struggles under the economic embargo. A leading politician in the neighboring Baltic republic of Estonia today pledged to help Lithuania survive the Soviet blockade, even at the risk of relatiation by Moscow. ``We have to help Lithuania in every case,'' said Marju Lauristin, a leader of the Estonian People's Front, in what she said was the majority opinion of the Estonian Supreme Soviet. She spoke during a visit to Helsinki, Finland. And in Brussels today, Lithuanian parliamentarians asked Belgium to help offset Moscow's economic blockade. The delegation arrived with ``the precise mission of launching an SOS for our people,'' said Emanuelis Zingeris, chairman of the Lithuanian parliament's foreign affairs panel. Gorbachev, touring an industrial center in the Urals, was confronted Thursday by activists protesting his crackdown in Lithuania, with demonstrators branding him a ``political hypocrite.'' On the diplomatic front, French President Francois Mitterrand and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl delivered a proposal to Lithuanian representatives in Moscow suggesting that the Baltic republic temporarily suspend its secessionist actions ``so that the current crisis ends in a solution acceptable to all parties.'' Landsbergis, in an apparent bid to find something positive in the letter from Mitterrand and Kohl, described it as ``a step forward toward the realization of Lithuanian independence.'' Lithuania wants an immediate dialogue, Landsbergis said, and ``a termination of the Soviet economic blockade against Lithuania would be beneficial to the atmosphere of this dialogue.'' ``The leadership of Lithuania, greatly appreciating this act of good will on the part of two noted leaders, will carefully study this letter's proposition,'' he added. The letter came two days after President Bush refused to impose sanctions on Moscow at this time for bringing economic and military pressure on Lithuania _ a move that clearly angered Landsbergis. When asked if Landsbergis was disappointed by the letter from Mitterrand and Kohl, Lithuanian parliamentary spokesman Ed Tuskenis said the president viewed ``as positive'' the fact that it did not mention revoking the republic's March 11 declaration of independence. The letter discussed the temporary suspension of some decisions by the Lithuanian parliament, the Supreme Council. Kremlin authorities on Monday urged Lithuania to suspend for two years its declaration of independence. Lithuanian leaders have refused to revoke the declaration. But the Baltic republic's leadership has always been willing ``to discuss the timing and the form of independence, whether or not that's a year or two,'' Tuskenis said after talking to Landsbergis. ``They said they never expected independence to come within a matter of days, and they don't expect full independence in a practical sense right away,'' he said by telephone from Vilnius. Also today, Lithuanian authorities disclosed that a Lithuanian man who died Thursday after setting himself on fire outside the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow left suicide notes calling on Gorbachev to let Lithuania become independent. Since independence was declared in Lithuania, which was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940, Gorbachev has imposed the economic embargo and used the military to occupy some buildings in Vilnius and round up army deserters.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Smaller Armed Forces in Store
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, acknowledging his warplane cutbacks could be just the beginning of major Pentagon changes, predicted Friday that America's military is destined to be ``significantly smaller than it is today.'' Cheney met with reporters one day after he informed Congress of plans to nearly halve purchases of the B-2 Stealth bomber and the C-17 transport jet, and delay production of the Pentagon's next generation of fighters. It was Cheney's most significant step to date in his effort to realign the nation's military expenditures in response to the nation's budget woes and the lessened Soviet threat. But during his testimony, Cheney also indicated he's looking at paring the Navy's fleet of aircraft carriers from 14 to 12 and that he was considering further cuts in Air Force tactical fighter wings. These statements come on the heels of disclosures by top Army officials that they may be forced to trim hundreds of thousands of soldiers from the force in the coming years. Asked about such developments, Cheney noted that the service chiefs are scheduled to give him their long-term spending plans next week and that this will set off a debate ``on what we think that force ought to look like.'' ``There's clearly going to be a smaller Navy, clearly going to be a smaller Marine Corps, smaller Army, smaller Air Force,'' Cheney said, adding, ``Obviously, we are looking at a force that is significantly smaller than it is today.'' But he added that there are several assumptions that must be taken into account in any plan to draw down the forces, such as the successful completion of the talks in Europe to reduce conventional forces and the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks with the Soviets. Cheney's aircraft review called for reducing the proposed number of B-2 bombers from 132 to 75 and reducing the proposed purchase of the C-17 long-range transport plane from 210 to 120. The defense secretary also called for cutting back on the Navy's A-12 attack aircraft and delaying purchases of the Air Force's Advanced Tactical Aircraft and Advanced Tactical Fighter. He predicted the changes would trim $2.4 billion from President Bush's $307 billion defense budget for 1991 and would save $34.8 billion through 1997. Meanwhile on Capitol Hill, an Air Force official told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee Friday that a reduction in the 36 tactical fighter wings by 1996 is likely. ``I don't think I can say today whether we'll get below 30, but we're going to get smaller,'' Maj. Gen. Richard E. Hawley, director of operations, told the subcommittee on conventional forces and alliance defense. Pressed by Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., chairman of the subcommittee, about whether 30 wings is a fair assumption, Hawley said: ``I would not be surprised to see numbers in that range.'' The Air Force official also indicated that Cheney's decision to delay procurement of the Advanced Tactical Fighter poses a risk but it was determined that the risk was acceptable. ``There is additional risk imposed by slipping the ATF,'' Hawley said. ``I guess the question is, is it an acceptable risk and I think the judgment is that it is an acceptable level of risk given the changing nature of the threat we face.'' Although Cheney told reporters he was pleased with the response he'd received during his testimony, he had a blunt message for those lawmakers who say he's not cutting enough: put up or shut up. ``It's easy to pontificate about what the overall top line ought to be. But as soon as we get down to the real nitty-gritty of how we're going cut the defense budget ... there's a noticeable lack of any significant, substantive plans on Capitol Hill,'' the secretary complained.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Lawmakers Expect to OK Funds in Wake of Contempt Order
DOC.TEXT: A judge's decision to hold a state official in contempt for failing to request adequate money for mental health programs was unusual but probably justified, a former law school dean said. Paul Bender, retired dean of the Arizona State University College of Law, also said the ruling could spark lawsuits seeking additional money for other state programs. Lawmakers said the ruling likely will result in more money, but probably much less than the $45.2 million Maricopa County Superior Court Judge Bernard Dougherty ordered Department of Health Services Director Ted Williams to request. Dougherty ruled Wednesday that Williams was in contempt for failing to ask for enough money to implement a 1985 court order requiring the state to provide a full range of services for people with chronic mental illness. The judge likely will sign the order next week, and Williams has 15 days after that to comply. The judge offered no specific sanctions that he might apply. Williams' lawyers said no decision has been made about whether to appeal. ``I don't remember seeing another case like it,'' Bender said. ``The idea of a judge getting involved in the state's budgetary process is highly unusual. That doesn't mean that I think it's illegitimate, because I don't think it's illegitimate.'' Dougherty's ruling stemmed from a petition filed by the Center for Law in the Public Interest, which originally sought contempt sanctions against Williams and Gov. Rose Mofford. The state Supreme Court dismissed Mrs. Mofford as a defendant on grounds that she was not a party to the original lawsuit and that the courts had no authority to tell her what to put in her budget request to the Legislature. Charles Arnold, a Phoenix lawyer who served on a governor's task force on chronic mental illness, said he believed Dougherty's ruling ``will provide the impetus'' for legislative action to pay for the programs. ``Of course some legislators will get their feathers up and say, `No court is going to tell us what to do,''' said Arnold, a plaintiff in the class-action lawsuit that resulted in the ruling. ``All we can do is hope the good guys prevail.'' Indeed, House Appropriations Committee Chairman John Wettaw said: ``The judge is in never-never land.'' And Senate Majority Leader John Mawhinney said: ``The Legislature does not respond very well to judicial threats.'' Still, Bender said he expects Williams to request the $45.2 million from the governor and for Mrs. Mofford to include the entire amount in an amended budget request to the Legislature. ``That will put the onus on the Legislature, and that's a whole different story,'' Bender said. ``What the Legislature could do is simply repeal the laws that spell out what services these people are entitled to. There is nothing to say the Legislature couldn't do that.'' House Majority Whip Chris Herstam said he doesn't expect that ``but I'm also not inclined to appropriate the amount of money they want, because we don't have it.'' The Legislature already is holding a special session to deal with a budget deficit estimated at up to $350 million. Arnold said he expected the Legislature to provide $16 million to $25 for the chronically mentally ill next year. ``That would be enough to satisfy the court for now and get the department off the hook,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Proposes Cut in Defense to Fund Unification
DOC.TEXT: West Germany on Friday said it would trim its military spending to help pay for unification but said East Germany also will have to cut costs for the merger to succeed. Rudolf Seiters, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's chief of staff, also said East Germany should not make unreasonable demands in negotiations on merging the countries' economies. West Germany and East Germany hope to achieve economic unity by July 2. This would be a giant step toward ending the two countries' 41-year division. Seiters predicted basic agreement, based on proposals by Bonn, as early as next week. However, Lothar de Maiziere, East Germany's prime minister, said his people would face enormous burdens if all subsidies are immediately eliminated. ``We assume that rent, energy and public services will continue to be subsidized,'' he told the Berliner Zeitung newspaper of East Berlin before talks with a West German delegation began in the city. No details of the six hours of talks were released. They are to continue Monday in Bonn. Guenther Krause, head of the East German delegation, said agreement was reached on ``many questions.'' But he added ``there are still open questions.'' Seiters told West German lawmakers East Germany will have to hold down public spending for economic union with West Germany to work. ``I stress once again: West Germany is prepared to financially support East Germany. But as in West Germany, East Germany must carefully weigh what is financially feasible and what is not,'' Seiters told Parliament. Seiters called for cost cutting by state and local governments and said unification will be financed without any tax increases _ with the help of strong West German economic growth and added borrowing. He said unity costs will also be paid through federal spending cuts in defense and other areas. Seiters said ``re-orienting the armed forces,'' for example, will yield savings that can be used toward unification. He did not elaborate. West Germany is considering reducing its armed forces from 490,000 to 400,000. Regarding monetary union, Bonn proposes exchanging one West German mark for one East German mark for wages, pensions and savings up to $2,300. East German savings over that amount would be exchanged at a 2-1 rate. Seiters said all West Germans must be ready to make contributions toward assisting in the overhaul of East Germany's battered economy and smoothing the way for unification. He said ``basically, this undertaking cannot be compared to any other.'' ``We are not underestimating that many difficult problems need to be solved. With the transition of this washed-up socialist economy to a social market economy, we are treading in many ways on unknown turf,'' said Seiters. ``Such a task requires from us all our courage, energy, imagination and politically creative will,'' said Seiters. During the same parliamentary session, opposition politicians accused Kohl of excluding them from participating in the unity process. ``Unification is not a private matter for the federal chancellor. It is a matter for the whole people,'' said Herta Daeubler-Gmelin, a top official with the opposition Social Democrats.

DOC.HEAD: 20,000 Jews Mark 7-Year Completion of Reading Sacred Text
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The circus elephants and clowns cleared out of Madison Square Garden for a night so that nearly 20,000 people could gather there to finish a good book they began reading in 1982. The book was the Talmud, the repository of age-old Jewish wisdom, and its readers were Orthodox Jews. Every day for the past 7{ years, each had read a page of the 2,711-page tome, and Thursday night they converged on the Garden for a read-in to study the last page. ``These are not dead letters of a printed book. They are alive,'' Rabbi Simon Schwab, of Congregation K'hai Adath Jeshurun of Manhattan, told the assemblage. The daily reading _ known as the Daf Yomi, or daily page _ was synchronized in 1923, so that Jews all over the world read the same page on the same day. Thursday marked the end of the ninth reading of the Talmud since that date; on Friday, the cycle began anew. ``Anyone who studies Jewish law every day is guaranteed a place in the World to Come,'' the text concludes. The Talmud is believed to have been given to Moses by God at Mount Sinai and handed down orally for centuries before it was transcribed. Commentaries from scholars up to the 17th century are included. It is divided into tracts on agriculture, blessings, civil law, matters pertaining to women (including marriage and divorce), holiness and synagogue services, and purity, including foods that are kosher. Many of the readers are laymen, not scholars; they meet in informal study groups or read pocket editions on subway trains. There also are cassette tapes. About 15,000 students around the world pay $8 a month for Dial-a-Daf, a recorded telephone message discussing the day's page in English, Yiddish or Hebrew. There were gatherings around the world Thursday to mark the end of the cycle, but the Garden event was the largest. The organizers, Agudath Israel of America, reserved the Garden two years ago for the occasion. Thus the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus, in town for a monthlong stay, was forced to close for the night. Many of those attending the ceremony were black-suited Hasidic Jews, with long beards and unshorn sideburns that grew several inches long. Although Orthodox tradition does not encourage women to study the Talmud, several hundred sat in the balcony, separated from the men as they are at Sabbath services. It was the first time women were invited to the Daf Yomi celebration; one rabbi said they were welcomed as a gesture of thanks for the sacrifices they made so their husbands could study. ``It's not easy,'' said Jacob I. Friedman, a lawyer who attends a 6 a.m. study group. ``The alarm rings, and I must get up or I miss my daily dose of inspiration.'' There were roughly four times as many participants Thursday night as there were in 1982, when the last cycle ended. ``Next time, we'll fill Yankee Stadium,'' one rabbi said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Security Guard Injured in Explosion at CBN
DOC.TEXT: A mail bomb exploded Friday at Christian Broadcasting Network, injuring a security guard, a CBN spokeswoman said. A package with a Florida postmark was scanned in the mailroom and was thought to be suspcious, said the spokesman, Frankie Abourjilie. Security guard Scott Sheepers was summoned, and the bomb exploded when he opened the package, Mrs. Abourjilie said. Sheepers, 33, was taken to Sentara Norfolk General Hospital. Pat Robertson, founder of the network, accompanied the guard to the hospital, Mrs. Abourjilie said. Rhonda Hoover, a hospital spokeswoman, said Sheepers was in stable condition with shrapnel wounds to his left leg. Officers from the Virginia State Police bomb squad and U.S. postal inspectors were investigating.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Given Task of Forming Gov't After Labor Fails
With AM-Israel-Unrest, Bjt ^LaserPhoto JRL1
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir left the door open Friday to another coalition with the rival Labor Party but said he would prefer a narrow-based government controlled by his hard-line Likud bloc. Shamir, who was given the task of forming Israel's next government by President Chaim Herzog on Friday, immediately ran into trouble. Yigal Bibi, a legislator of the National Religious Party, said he would only back Likud if the center-left Labor joined the coalition. The surprise statement brought the two major parties back to a 60-60 deadlock in the 120-seat Knesset, or parliament. Shamir, 74, head of the interim government, said he hoped to obtain a majority within the next three weeks as required by the presidential mandate. Speaking to reporters, Shamir said the prospects for a new Likud-Labor coalition ``at the moment look unrealistic.'' ``I would never rule out the possibility'' of a coalition with Labor, he noted, ``but my efforts in this period won't be aimed at a national unity government.'' Likud and Labor ruled in an uneasy partnership as a result of stalemated elections in 1984 and 1988. The government was brought down March 15 by a Labor-engineered parliament vote of no-confidence. The crisis was prompted by Shamir's refusal to accept, as Labor demanded, a U.S. formula for arranging Israeli-Palestinian talks. Herzog turned to Shamir after Shimon Peres, the Labor leader, announced Thursday he had failed to assemble a coalition after 35 days of efforts. Herzog urged Shamir to act quickly. ``These days the country is in a state of political and public confusion such as it has never known since its founding,'' the president said. ``There is a heavy and true sense of depression in the public.'' The premier hopes to lure three right-wing factions and three ultra-Orthodox parties into a majority coalition in the Knesset. In such a coalition, important Cabinet posts are likely to be given to Likud members, who control 35 seats. Likud officials have predicted they would get a majority of 65 seats, apparently by attracting four ultra-Orthodox legislators from the Labor-aligned Agudat Israel Party. Labor has vowed to block Shamir, warning that his prospective government would be extremist and derail Middle East peace efforts. ``It can ruin things in a big way for this country,'' Yitzhak Rabin, a former Labor premier, said on Israel radio. Rabin, a rival of Peres, said Labor was ready to form a joint government with Likud in order ``to handle the peace issue and security problems and absorb new immigrants,'' from the Soviet Union. The number of Soviet Jews immigrating to Israel is expected to total 100,000 this year. Peres has said a Labor-Likud government would not be practical and insisted that Labor should condition support for any government on the acceptance of U.S. peace plans. Rabin, a Labor hawk who served as defense minister in the last coalition and took a tough line on the Palestinian uprising, declined to say whether Peres should step down. But he said ``various changes will be required in the Labor Party.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Hears Testimony in Lawsuit Over Noisy French Quarter Musicians
DOC.TEXT: Police do what they can to enforce noise limits in the French Quarter, but brass bands quiet down when officers set up meters to measure their loudness, a city attorney told a judge Friday. ``There's no way we can take the test without the people being tested aware of it,'' assistant city attorney Ron Sholes told state District Judge Richard Ganucheau. Artists and business people who work in the court have filed suit against Police Chief Warren Woodfork and seek an order from Ganucheau instructing police to enforce city noise ordinances in Jackson Square. The square is in the heart of the French Quarter and one of this Dixieland jazz capital's prime tourist spots. Sidewalk musicians have entertained crowds there for years, but artists who sell caricatures, instant portraits and bayou scenes in the quarter say that now too many people play too loudly and too often. They contend that the noise is causing them irreparable damage, including headaches, stress, loss of sleep and irritability. Ganucheau did not indicate when he will rule, but did have some sharp questions for plaintiff attorney Luke Fontana, who lives and owns a store in the quarter. ``At what point does it become my provenance to tell the superintendent of police to send his men to control noise in the French Quarter and ignore cocaine traffic in the Desire Project? ... I would observe that those people whose children are getting killed in the Desire Project might consider that irreparable harm.'' He then added: ``This does not indicate my frame of mind.'' Thoren Rand, a French Quarter caricature artist representing the Association of Businessmen and Artists of Jackson Square, said later that the groups that filed the suit aren't asking for extra officers or time. Police already assigned to patrol the area could set up decibel meters in a store or apartment where the owners had complained of the noise and do it so that musicians couldn't see them, he said. He said police wouldn't even need meters to enforce a law forbidding noise that can be heard more than 50 feet away. Deputy City Attorney Bill Aaron said that if the artists have a gripe against the musicians, they should sue the musicians. ``We don't know who they are or where they live,'' objected Fontana.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Urges Concessions On Both Sides Over Lithuania
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Friday that action by both Lithuanian and Soviet leaders is needed for talks to begin on the future of the rebellious republic. ``We have said all along that dialogue is the only way to solve this problem,'' Richard Boucher, the State Department spokesman, said. ``Both sides need to find a way to get to that dialogue.'' On Thursday, France and West Germany jointly urged Lithuania to suspend its Parliament's moves toward independence as a way of opening talks with Moscow. Asked if the United States supported the proposal by France and West Germany, the State Department spokesman avoided a direct response. He said the letter by President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany ``represents their effort to diffuse the situation.'' Further, Boucher said: ``We didn't sign the letter. It's their idea on how to get a dialogue, and we support anything that could lead to that end.'' At the same time, though, the State Department spokesman called for action on both sides. ``Both sides need to find a way to get to that dialogue,'' he said. On another subject, the State Department official said the administration would extend trading privileges to Moscow only if the Soviets complete legislation guaranteeing the right to travel and implement such a law. The issue was raised after U.S. and Soviet negotiators reached the outline of an agreement on a trade pact in Paris on Thursday. Final details could be resolved before President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev hold their summit meeting here May 30. Boucher said the Soviets were expected to complete the emigration legislation in late May.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnappers Provide Medicines For Hostages
With AM-Polhill, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Despite their obsession with security, the Shiite Moslem militants holding Western hostages in Lebanon sometimes bring in doctors from Iranian-funded hospitals to care for ailing captives, informed sources say. American Robert Polhill, freed Sunday, suffered from diabetes. But apart from loss of weight, a growth on his vocal cords and malnourishment during his 39 months in captivity, he clearly was given medication. ``The hostages have common health problems such as diabetes, high blood pressure or high levels of uric acid,'' said a Shiite physician, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Medicines for such health problems are not a problem. They can be obtained anywhere in Lebanon,'' he told The Associated Press. West German businessman Rudolf Cordes, freed by another Shiite faction Sept. 12, 1988, after 605 days in captivity, said he often considered committing suicide when in captivity. His jailers gave him five tranquilizers a day and brought in a doctor to examine him. In January last year, one group was reported to be seeking a cardiologist to examine an unidentified hostage who was believed to be suffering from a severe heart condition. It underlined that the hostage-holders make some effort to aid ailing captives, possibly because at least one and maybe two captives have died from neglect. Frenchman Michel Seurat, a researcher, died of a severe illness believed to be hepatitis in December 1985, released hostages reported. His captors, Islamic Jihad, claimed on March 5, 1986, that they had killed him in retaliation for France extraditing two pro-Iranian Iraqi dissidents to Baghdad. Briton Alec Collett, a New-York based writer who suffered from diabetes, is believed to have died in captivity through illness. Medical personnel from the Khomeini Hospital in Baalbek in eastern Lebanon, and clinics run by the fundamentalist Iranian-backed Hezbollah in Beirut's southern slums are summoned to help ailing hostages, other Shiite sources said. Baalbek and Beirut's southern shantytowns are Shiite strongholds and most of the 17 Westerners missing in Lebanon are believed to be held in the slums. Various groups hold seven Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. The longest-held hostage is American Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. While medicine might help treat the hostages' physical ailments, there is nothing that can be done to alleviate the immense psychological trauma of being chained day and night, usually blindfolded, beaten and submitted to mock executions, not to mention poor food and unsanitary conditions. ``You have to learn to master your sadness, your desperation, to channel your misery,'' former French hostage Jean-Paul Kauffmann said after he was freed May 4, 1988. ``The worst thing for a hostage is not the physical suffering, but the feeling of having been forgotten.''

DOC.HEAD: This Airline Offers More Than Peanuts
DOC.TEXT: Japan Airlines is offering a new alternative to in-flight food _ no flight. Its new restaurant in Osaka has a full-size replica of a JAL Boeing 767, a cabin crew, videotapes of travel information and seats in executive or first- class sections. ``For some people, airline food is an oxymoron,'' said airline spokesman Geoffrey Tudor. ``But we thought there was a group of people who didn't think so. We're aiming the restaurant at people who maybe don't travel very much, but want to try out the experience.'' Grounded diners have quickly been reserving seats at the restaurant since it opened this month at the International Garden and Greenery Exposition in Osaka, officials say. Before the meal, customers settle into a row of airplane seats in a lounge to watch a five-minute videotape of JAL in-flight service and travel information. A real JAL cabin crew is on duty ``to add a touch of authenticity,'' Tudor said. In concessions to comfort, tables take the place of the plastic, fold-down stands, and diners don't need a seat belt. Dominating the main, 106-seat dining room is the Boeing 767 replica, which houses a second-floor ``VIP cabin'' featuring first-class meals ticketed at $75. Tudor said the new restaurant was the latest attempt by the formerly government-owned airline to brighten its image since going private in 1987. ``This sort of promotion would have been unthinkable four years ago,'' he said. ``We took surveys and found that a lot of younger people thought JAL was a pretty stuffy company.''

DOC.HEAD: Imelda's Medical Problems Delay Trial
DOC.TEXT: Friday's session of the fraud trial of Imelda Marcos was called off so a hypertension specialist could treat the former Philippine first lady, who fell ill a day earlier after testimony about her husband's ouster. Although Mrs. Marcos' attorneys had said she was expected in court Friday, she did not appear on the advice of a doctor who examined her that morning for high blood pressure. ``She said she felt fine, but she didn't look fine to me,'' said one of her attorneys, Gerald Spence. Mrs. Marcos, who turns 61 in July, fell ill during the lunch break Thursday after a customs agent told of the day in February 1986 when she and her husband, former Philippine president Ferdinand Marcos, arrived in Hawaii following his ouster from power. U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan said the trial would resume Monday and that Mrs. Marcos would wear a portable heart monitor to court. Keenan said the physician, Dr. David Case, told him in a phone conversation that it would ``not be a good idea from a health point of view'' for Mrs. Marcos to continue Friday. According to Spence, Mrs. Marcos' blood pressure fluctuated wildly Thursday after reaching the dangerous level of 230 over 100. Spence told reporters that Mrs. Marcos' family had ``a history of death by stroke.'' He said she would wear the monitor, a small rectangular box hung over her shoulder, ``wherever she goes.'' The attorney said Mrs. Marcos had been under extreme stress because of the trial and the death of her husband last September. ``She was with him every day, watching him die, and then she has had to face this situation alone,'' Spence said. Thursday's testimony ``just opened the flood gate for her.'' The U.S. government charges that Mrs. Marcos and her late husband embezzled $220 million from their country's treasury to support a life of luxury and investments such as artwork and New York real estate. Mrs. Marcos has pleaded innocent to racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Her co-defendant, Adnan Khashoggi, is charged with mail fraud and obstruction of justice for allegedly helping the Marcoses hide their ownership of an art collection and four Manhattan buildings.

DOC.HEAD: 12-Year-Old Accused in Computer Hacking for Credit Card Numbers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to CORRECT that charges pending, sted boy charged; boy not taken into custody. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Authorities were ...'.
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old computer hacker is accused of gaining access to the computers of TRW Inc., a national company that checks customers' credit ratings, and distributing charge card numbers to computer bulletin boards. State police said today that authorities were preparing to submit a petition to Wayne County Probate Court to charge the youth of computer fraud and financial transaction fraud. The boy's computer and files were seized Thursday from his Grosse Ile home, said Lt. Tom Meekins, of the Michigan State Police Criminal Investigation Division. ``It won't be hard to prove,'' Meekins said. ``The records we have indicate he was deeply involved.'' Authorities talked to the boy in his home but not take him into custody or charge him, Meekins said. Federal authorities had originally said that the boy was arrested and charged, but that is incorrect, Meekins said. Authorities were uncertain how many files were tapped, who used the credit card numbers, and what was purchased with them, said Michigan State Police Lt. Chris Hogan. But officials said TRW officials noticed the improper entry to their system and contacted authorities. ``TRW's still trying to figure that one out,'' he said. TRW Consumer Relations Supervisor Jean Stevens was not in her Farmington Hills office this morning to comment, her secretary said. The Michigan Computer Crime Task Force of state and federal authorities said the boy broke through TRW security at a Detroit-area branch. ``Hacking is a common problem and is proliferating as the computer industry improves and home computers are more available,'' said U.S. Secret Service Special Agent John Britt in Detroit. ``But tapping into TRW is a new twist and pretty sophisticated.'' The boy's mother said the family owned the computer for several years and friends of her son recently taught him how to use it. He worked on it for up to five hours every weeknight and up to 14 hours on weekends, she said. ``He didn't bother me,'' she said. ``He sat there on his computer. Well, I figured, computers, that's the thing of the day.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Oakland Ordinance Unconstitutional
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AMer upcoming
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Friday struck down Oakland's 1988 ``nuclear-free'' ordinance, one of the nation's strongest measures banning local involvement in nuclear weapons-related activities. U.S. District Judge John Vukasin agreed with arguments by the Bush administration that the measure interfered with the federal government's constitutional authority over national defense and atomic energy. The ordinance, approved by city voters in November 1988, forbids most city contracting and investments with nuclear weapons manufacturers, restricts transportation of nuclear material through the city and is intended to outlaw nuclear weapons work in the city. It is the only such ordinance among more than 160 in the nation to be challenged in court by the federal government. City Attorney Jayne Williams said an appeal would be considered. City Councilman Wilson Riles Jr., a supporter of the ordinance, said he was confident much of the measure would be revived by the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The ruling does not prohibit the city from limiting its investments in government securities or posting ``nuclear-free-zone'' signs at its borders. Those provisions were not challenged by the federal government.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Faces Complaints of Foul Water, Air in Polluted Soviet City
LaserPhoto MOS19
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was besieged with complaints Friday about foul water and air in a city so polluted that children have drawn pictures of smog and written: ``I don't want to die!'' After two days of addressing residents' worries about the sagging economy in the Ural Mountains city of Sverdlovsk, Gorbachev traveled to nearby Nizhny Tagil and confronted a new issue: pollution. ``Metal is metal, but people, Mikhail Sergeyevich, are not iron,'' a metalworker told the president as they met on the shop floor of the Nizhny Tagil Metallurgical Complex. The comment was reported by the Tass news agency. The city of 403,000 people is among 36 in a government ``black book'' listing the most polluted areas of the Russian federation, Pravda reported in September. Other news reports have said smog from the 45-year-old coke-burning furnaces at the steel complex burns children's skin as they walk to school and causes serious lung and heart problems. Factories in the area, 900 miles east of Moscow, spew out more than 600,000 tons of pollutants annually, about 1.5 tons per resident. Local children last year sent the complex's managers drawings of ``smokestacks, smog enveloping living areas and the handwritten words: `I don't want to die!''' the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda reported. Huge demonstrations have been reported in Nizhny Tagil and other Soviet cities as residents demand a cleanup of air and water. They say the pollution was caused by a government policy that emphasized production at all costs, even at the expense of people's health. The Kremlin chief saw the pollution and its sources first-hand Friday, taking a walking tour of the sprawling metallurgical complex, stopping occasionally to field what a Soviet television correspondent said were thousands of workers' questions. Soviet TV's nightly newscast ``Vremya'' showed Gorbachev, wearing a white hard hat with a visor to protect his eyes from the intense light, walking past coke furnaces that spewed orange flames. A camera showed three tall chimneys at the plant spitting out gray smoke. Told by a crowd of shouting residents that the pollution was less than usual because factories had reduced emissions before Gorbachev's visit, the president said: ``They say they turned off something. People are living (here). Surely we could have withstood one day!'' A woman interrupted excitedly, ``We've been breathing fresh air for a week!'' ``I know about the situation with your water and air,'' Gorbachev responded. He said the solution lies in a government plan for modernizing local factories' equipment. Tass said a 35-year-old lathe operator told Gorbachev at a Nizhny Tagil factory that makes railroad cars, ``Even a healthy person like me often has difficulty breathing. And how is it for my two children, all the children of Nizhny Tagil?'' Gorbachev said he noticed the pollution as he flew into the city Friday morning. ``As I looked out of the airplane,'' the president said, ``I immediately understood how neglected the ecology is.'' Another resident told Gorbachev there isn't one clean reservoir in the region and trees are ``barbarically cut down,'' Tass reported. The president also heard complaints from the metalworkers about a shortage of kindergartens, fruits and vegetables, and modern machinery. Gorbachev counseled residents to be patient because the government faces similar demands from citizens nationwide. His wife, Raisa, was shown on TV giving a similar pitch to a crowd of women that surrounded her during a visit to a museum in Nizhny Tagil. Gorbachev wound up his visit to the Sverdlovsk region and returned to Moscow on Friday. In televised remarks, he said he had heard ``many justified demands'' but was convinced the people believe the solutions lie in his reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges Americans to `Get Moving' on Census
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday that completing the nation's problem-plagued 1990 census is becoming a ``mammoth undertaking'' and he urged Americans who haven't returned their forms to ``get moving.'' Thirty seven percent of the 95 million census questionnaires sent in March haven't been returned. ``I simply want to ... urge every American who has not returned the census form to do so; to stand up and be counted,'' Bush said in remarks to a group of state legislators at the White House. ``We really need to get moving on this.'' In his first comments on the difficulties vexing the U.S. Census Bureau, Bush said census takers had begun ``to visit all address from which census forms have not been received, a mammoth undertaking'' in light of the poor mail response. Rep. Thomas C. Sawyer, D-Ohio, chairman of a House subcommittee that oversees the Census Bureau, estimates that fielding the expanded army of census takers needed to cope with the low return rate could add $180 million to the $1.3 billion earmarked this year for conducting the census. Bush told the American Legislative Exchange Council that helping persuade Americans to do a better job of returning their census forms was ``a project that needs your involvement.'' ``Census data will help you make important decisions for the states. And it really fits into this theme of decentralization, part of the decentralization of government, of putting our trust where it belongs _ with the people,'' Bush said. The census will help determine distribution of hundreds of billions of dollars in federal and state aid among states and local communities for the next 10 years. It will also be the basis on which congressional and state legislative district lines will be redrawn. Preliminary data suggests that as many as 14 of the 435 House of Representative seats may shift into different states as a result of the 1990 count. Some Democratic critics have assailed Bush for not doing enough to guarantee an accurate census, even though he frequently talks to Republican audiences about the importance of congressional redistricting in soldifying GOP gains. Some analysts have suggested that a census undercount could work to the benefit of Republicans. The theory is that middle-class households, where response to the census forms has been generally high, contain a proportionately larger number of Republicans; and that there is a higher percentage of Democrats among those not yet counted. Democratic National Committee Chairman Ron Brown urged Bush last week to publicly support a complete census count. Bush has taped two public-service television announcements on the importance of filling out census forms. He also invited cameras and reporters into the Oval Office to watch him and his wife, Barbara, fill out their own census forms last month. Contributing to the poor return rate was the fact that millions of Americans never got the forms. The Census Bureau on Thursday began its door-to-door survey of households that had not returned forms. That portion of the head count is expected to take up to two months. People who did not receive a form may get one by calling the Census Bureau at 1-800-999-1990.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Ask for Help in Coping with Chernobyl Aftermath
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet parliamentary delegation, decrying the secrecy their government imposed after the Chernobyl nuclear accident four years ago, made an urgent appeal to the United States and the world Friday for help in dealing with towering medical and human problems. Severe shortages exist in medical equipment, radiological and other scientific laboratories, radiation detectors, housing for scores of thousands of relocated people and even baby food, the five-man delegation said at a news conference at the Soviet Embassy. ``The history of mankind never knew an ecological catastrophe which is so disastrous and having unknown consequences for the nature, health and life of the present and future generations,'' the delegation said, relaying an appeal made originally by officials of the Ukraine and endorsed this week by the Supreme Soviet. Yuri N. Shcherbak, chairman of the ecology subcommittee of the Supreme Soviet and a physician, said it had taken a political struggle to open secret medical records and uncover the true extent of the damage caused by the radiation that poured from the Chernobyl reactor 80 miles north of the Ukrainian capital of Kiev. The accident, on April 26, 1986, began with a fire in one of four reactors followed by a core meltdown and an explosion, which sent huge quantities of radiation billowing into the atmosphere. Dr. Shcherbak said thyroid disorders are beginning to appear along with the first cases of leukemia and cancer, including thyroid cancer in infants. He said serious medical effects are now expected to last decades, perhaps centuries. ``Chernobyl is the gravest warning to all humankind; the warning that the development of super technology systems may lead to great damage and perhaps a threat to all living things on earth,'' he said. Kakimbek S. Salykov, chairman of the delegation, said that deaths attributed to Chernobyl have reached at least 300, compared to the official report of 31, and that some 150,000 people show some effects of radiation poisoning. But he said the true extent of medical damage may never be known because a shroud of secrecy was placed on data after the accident and no statistics were compiled on the effects of radiation on the 600,000 people who took part in the initial cleanup. He said that after the accident, the death rate among the 600 workers at the Chernobyl plant ``increased tenfold,'' including several deaths from cancer. Dr. Shcherbak said that 1.5 million people ``got a great dose of radiation'' and that the leukemia rate in the Kiev area is 2.6 times to 3.8 times greater than before the accident. ``Thirteen thousand persons must be relocated as soon as possible,'' he said. Soviet Ambassador Yuri Dubinin said that when the effects on other Soviet republics are taken into account, some 4 million people may have been exposed to excessive levels of radiation. The delegation released these other statistics: _12.5 million acres of farmland and 1.5 million acres of forests in the Ukraine alone were affected by contamination. _The contaminated area of the Ukraine contained more than 1,600 towns and villages with more than 1.5 million inhabitants. _More than 90,000 people have been resettled from the contaminated zones to 101 new villages in unaffected areas and thousands more will be soon. _The ``obsolete'' Chernobyl reactors will be shut down permanently this year or next.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Will Return Heavy Water to Norway
