DOC.TEXT: Israel on Friday agreed to sell back to Norway a shipment of heavy water it bought 31 years ago rather than allow an inspection to prove the coolant was not used to make nuclear weapons. ``We have negotiated an agreement that satisfies both sides,'' said Norwegian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Sigrid Romundset. The pact removes a longstanding irritant in relations between the two countries. The accord, signed in Oslo by Israeli Ambassador Yehiel Yativ, obliges Norway to pay about $1.8 million to buy back the remaining 10.5 tons of heavy water. Israel purchased 20 tons of the nuclear reactor coolant in 1959 and one ton in 1970 for use at a research reactor in its southern desert city of Dimona. Inspection rights were written into the sales contract. ``Experts concluded that there is about 10.5 tons left after evaporation and normal use,'' said Romundset. The agreement reached Friday gives Israel one year to drain the heavy water from its facilities and return it to Norway. Heavy water, or deuterium oxide, can be used to convert uranium into the plutonium used in atomic weapons. A former Dimona technician, Mordechai Vanunu, in 1986 charged that Israel had produced up to 100 nuclear warheads. His allegation prompted Norway to demand an inspection of Dimona's heavy water. Israel refused to open Dimona. It had not allowed a Norwegian inspection since 1961, according to Norwegian press reports. Oslo banned exports of heavy water in March 1989 after learning that at least three shipments ended up in countries on a Norwegian blacklist. Fifteen tons were traced to India, which Norway refuses to supply because the country has nuclear weapons but has not signed a non-proliferation treaty. Norway's sole heavy water supplier, the Norsk Hydro A@S industrial concern, stopped production a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: TV Sweeps: It's Time to Get the VCRs Rolling
DOC.TEXT: Drag out the Barcolounger, grab the remote control and hoist that TV Guide. Sweeps season is back. J.R. ends up in the looney bin. The ``Twin Peaks'' murder is finally resolved. ``Beverly Hills Cop II,'' ``Throw Momma From the Train'' _ and, hold onto your hats _ ``Return to Green Acres'' all debut on the little screen. There's also the battle of the bios on Sunday night when ABC's ``The Story of the Beach Boys: Summer Dreams'' goes surfboard-to-mascara with the ``Fall From Grace'' of Jim and Tammy Bakker on NBC. If you've ever wondered just what ``sweeps'' means, don't try to figure it out. It's a scheme in which local stations monitor their viewership so they can figure out how much to charge advertisers for the next season. The sweeps occur four times a year. For viewers, all that really matters is that from April 25 to May 22, there are enough big-name, big-budget movies and cliffhanger series endings to make the eyes of even the most hard-core couch potato glaze over. In the cliffhanger department, ``Dallas'' ends the season on May 11, with the rotten-but-entertaining J.R. in an insane asylum. Does he wake up next season and discover it was all a Librium-induced dream? ABC's highly acclaimed ``Twin Peaks'' will resolve the continuing mystery of who murdered the lumber town's beauty queen, but the last episode on May 24 will leave audiences hanging on a different plot line, said ABC spokesman Bob Wright. And on ``Cheers,'' Sam pops the big question to Rebecca and tries to get the bar back in a two-part season capper that ends May 3. In the showdown-we've-all-been-waiting-for department, Leland McKenzie at last takes on Rosalind Shays before the season's last episode of ``L.A. Law'' on May 17. Any more ground-breaking segments from the yuppie lawyers who have passed gas, hired sex surrogates and cursed on American television sets this season? Tune in, said executive producer David Kelley, ``I don't think you'll be disappointed.'' There's also a glut of docudramas to choose from. ``Voyage of Terror: The Achille Lauro Affair'' screens May 1 and May 2 in most areas (it's syndicated). ``Last Flight Out,'' starring James Earl Jones and Richard Crenna, depicts the Americans who helped U.S. and Vietnamese citizens escape Saigon in 1975 and will be shown May 20 on NBC. ``By Dawn's Early Light'' runs May 19 on HBO and stars Powers Boothe, Rebecca De Mornay and Martin Landau teetering on the edge of global annihilation after an unidentified missile destroys a Soviet city. In a more uplifting vein, ``Archie, To Riverdale and Back'' has the Jughead gang turning ``thirtysomething'' on NBC, May 6. And Eva Gabor, Eddie Albert and three new Arnold the Pigs (even pigs need stand-ins) are back in ``Return to Green Acres'' on CBS, May 18. There's more... The very first ``I Love Lucy'' show _ no, it's not a repeat, it's the never-before-seen pilot _ is on CBS April 30. And the very last ``Newhart'' sees the Stratford Inn coveted by Japanese investors and Bob Newhart and company saying goodbye after eight years on television. New batteries for the remote control, please.

DOC.HEAD: Suicide Victim Leaves Notes Protesting Soviet `Occupiers'
LaserPhoto VIL1
DOC.TEXT: A man who burned himself to death was sending a message to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``that Lithuanians will not live in a Lithuania that is not independent,'' according to suicide notes released Friday. In the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius, Russian truckers lay down in front of their rigs and blocked rush-hour traffic to protest the Baltic republic's declaration of independence on March 11. The suicide victim, Stanislovas Jamaitis, 52, died Thursday of burns suffered when he doused his clothes with gasoline and set himself ablaze in front of the Bolshoi Theater in central Moscow. Jamaitis, a Lithuanian, left suicide notes to his wife, Stasala, and to Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis. The Lithuanian Supreme Council, or parliament, released the texts Friday. Spokeswoman Rita Radzevicius translated them from Lithuanian to Russian and read them over the telephone. The official Soviet news agency Tass also reported the existence of the note but did not mention any political motive. Tass said the letter ``spoke of an impossible family life and a desire to commit suicide.'' The version released by Lithuanian authorities apologized for ``something bad'' in his marriage, but stressed political motives. ``I went to Moscow to set myself on fire in Red Square,'' he said. The Bolshoi is a few blocks from Red Square, where security is heavier. ``The occupiers have cut off energy supplies and people are being thrown out of work,'' wrote Jamaitis, who officials say was recently laid off. ``I have lived my whole life in occupied Lithuania,'' wrote Jamaitis, who was born two years before the Soviet Union forcibly annexed Lithuania and its sister republics of Latvia and Estonia during World War II. He was killing himself, he said, to ``let Gorbachev know that Lithuanians will not live in a Lithuania that is not independent,'' said the note read by Ms. Radzevicius. The suicide recalled the 1971 self-immolation of a Lithuanian student, Romas Kalanta, in the western Lithuanian city of Kaunas. That act was a symbol of Lithuanian resistance in the 1970s and 1980s, activists say. The truck blockade in Vilnius marked a new level of protest by non-Lithuanians in the republic. Demonstrators lay down in front of their trucks in the center of Vilnius to protest ``adventurist decisions'' of the Lithuanian parliament, Tass said. Supporters of the Lithuanian popular front Sajudis dragged the trucks from the streets with tractors, Tass said. It also reported that local authorities released truckers arrested in the protest to keep the peace. Because of gas shortages caused by the Kremlin blockade, rush-hour traffic was much lighter than usual Friday. Many people walked to work or used the city's extensive trolley system. The blockade, shown on the Soviet evening TV news show ``Vremya,'' involved about 50 trucks and was organized by members of a Lithuanian Communist Party splinter that remains loyal to the Kremlin. Other organizers were members of Yedinstvo, consisting mostly of Russian residents of Lithuania, said Ms. Radzevicius. Just over 80 percent of the republic's population is Lithuanian, and some Russian, Polish and other minority residents have expressed fear their rights will be violated. Gorbachev has ordered curbs on supplies of oil and natural gas to Lithuania in an effort to stem the independence movement, and Lithuanian and Soviet media stressed the hardships caused by the embargo. Gorbachev also has refused to negotiate with Lithuania. Soviet authorities have restricted Western reporters from traveling to Lithuania, except by invitation on trips organized by the Foreign Ministry. The Associated Press was not invited on one trip currently under way. In London, maverick Soviet politician Boris Yeltsin criticized Gorbachev's handling of the Lithuanian independence crisis. ``I would consider it immoral to declare an economic blockade in regard to one of our republics,'' he said. ``Even if it were a foreign country, Gorbachev wouldn't have behaved in that way because people would have sat at the negotiating table and would have sought a way for political settlement.'' Kremlin officials have said Lithuania might become independent, but at a slower pace, and Gorbachev's actions appear designed to stem secessionist movements in other republics. The parliament of Estonia has voted to become independent at an unspecified later date, and Latvia is scheduled to vote on the issue next week. An Estonian delegation met Friday with Alexander Yakovlev, a Gorbachev aide, to discuss the independence of the Baltic states, the Estonian News Service reported. The non-governmental news outlet said Yakovlev suggested Estonia suspend its drive for independence and hold a referendum on the issue, but did not demand the republic renounce its recent decisions. In Brussels, Lithuanian parliamentarians Friday asked Belgium to help offset Moscow's economic blockade. Lithuanian President Landsbergis weighed a proposal from France and West Germany that Lithuania temporarily suspend its secessionist actions ``so that the current crisis ends in a solution acceptable to all parties.'' Lithuania wants an immediate dialogue, Landsbergis said, and ``a termination of the Soviet economic blockade against Lithuania would be beneficial to the atmosphere of this dialogue.''

DOC.HEAD: Labor Pushes OSHA Changes on Workers Memorial Day
DOC.TEXT: Harold Gallegos says he still spits up blood and endures rashes, blurred vision and kidney pains that began two years ago after he cleaned out a highway pit contaminated with toxic chemicals. As a Colorado state employee, Gallegos was not covered by federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration laws that require employers to tell workers what kind of hazards they face on the job. Workers such as Gallegos would know their job risks under proposed OSHA changes being pushed by labor unions as they commemorate Workers' Memorial Day on Saturday. The day also marks the 20th anniversary of Congress' creation of OSHA. In Gallegos' case, after cleaning the highway pit he learned that it contained such heavy metals as arsenic, zinc and cadmium and that an EPA clean-up site contaminated with radioactive waste was just a few hundred feet away. The Colorado Department of Highways did not do anything inappropriate because the state had cleaned the same pump house for years without incident, spokesman Dan Hopkins said. The source of the contamination is still being investigated, he said. ``There was never any indication of any hazard. We were shocked when we detected the contamination,'' Hopkins said in a telephone interview. Nevertheless, the state now tests ground water and sand before cleaning similar pump houses and contracts the work out to hazardous substance specialists as a precaution, Hopkins said. Gallegos has not filed suit and the state has paid his medical bills and provided him leave, including three days to visit Washington and spotlight attention on the 10,000 workers killed each year on the job and some 70,000 others who have been permanently disabled by workplace accidents. Under OSHA revisions being pushed by the AFL-CIO, state and local employees and millions of other workers who currently don't fall under the federal law would have to be informed about their job risks. The 14.2 million-member federation also is calling on Congress to require OSHA to increase penalties and enforcement authority; improve record-keeping of job injuries and illnesses; and impose stronger safety and health standards in some industries. Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole is reviewing the proposed OSHA changes and wrote a letter this week to AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland pledging to ``find ways to increase effectiveness and implement improvements'' for OSHA enforcement. Labor's supporters generally praise Mrs. Dole's commitment to workplace safety and consider her efforts a vast improvement over the neglect they felt OSHA received under President Ronald Reagan. Next week, Senate labor subcommittee chairman Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, will hold a hearing on various proposals to strengthen OSHA laws, including one to increase criminal penalties. Metzenbaum said that during OSHA's first 18 years of existence, 200,000 American workers were killed on the job. Many of the deaths were the result of willful violations of OSHA laws, but ``not one employer spent one night in jail,'' Metzenbaum said. Right now, the maximum criminal penalty for an employer who willfully violates federal safety laws, when the violation results in death, is six months in jail. Metzenbaum's proposal would increase that to 10 years. Metzenbaum noted that last weekend, millions of Americans celebrated Earth Day in a push for tough enforcement of environmental laws. ``I applaud their actions. But if we throw corporate criminals in jail for harming our trees and animals and water, we also should throw them in jail for killing and maiming our workers,'' Metzenbaum said. The AFL-CIO, which created the first Workers Memorial Day last year, plans to hold ceremonies in 100 communities around the nation on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts Of Lithuanian Protester's Suicide Notes
DOC.TEXT: Following are excerpts of letters Stanislovas Jamaitis, 52, of Lithuania wrote before he doused his clothes with gasoline and set himself ablaze in front of the Bolshoi Theater in central Moscow on Thursday. The Lithuanian Supreme Council, or parliament, released the texts on Friday, said spokeswoman Rita Radzevicius, who translated them from Lithuanian to Russian and read them by telephone. The Associated Press then translated them into English. A letter to his wife, Stasala: Forgive me. Maybe there was something bad in our common life. I can't live any longer. The occupiers have cut off energy supplies and people are being thrown out of work.
A passage for his two daughters and niece: I went to Moscow to set myself on fire in Red Square.

Letter to Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis: Jamaitis wrote he did not want to see ``our children serve the occupiers. I'm going to Red Square to kill myself.'' He was killing himself, he said, to ``let Gorbachev know that Lithuanians will not live in a Lithuania that is not independent.''

DOC.HEAD: Perez Calls for OAS Role in Easing US-Cuban Frictions
DOC.TEXT: Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez called on the Organization of American States on Friday to play a role in bringing about an easing of tensions between the United States and Cuba. ``Thirty years of confrontation and tension between Cuba and the United States will not disappear overnight,'' Perez said in a speech to the OAS permanent council. ``But the OAS could create a climate for facilitating a dialogue.'' While results over the short term are not likely, Perez said it is possible for the two governments to find an agenda for detente and eventually an agenda for cooperation. Perez, who is here on an official visit, made the recommendation as part of a broader proposal for revitalizing the OAS. Relations between the United States and Cuba have worsened in recent months. The Bush administration has shown little interest in opening a dialogue on reaching an accommodation.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Fire on Stone-Throwing Demonstrators in Nagorno-Karabakh
DOC.TEXT: Troops fired at rock-throwing demonstrators in the disputed southern territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, the official Tass news agency reported Friday. Two civilians and seven soldiers and police were injured, it said. Tass said the incident occurred Thursday night incident in Stepanakert, capital of the mainly Armenian enclave located inside Azerbaijan. The news agency said about 1,000 people gathered outside the military commandant's office to demand the release of two Armenians detained for addressing a rally earlier in the week. State of emergency regulations in effect in the district forbid mass demonstrations. The troops had used shields to move the crowd away from the square in front of the commandant's office but were hit by stones before they began shooting, the news agency reported. Among the injured were five Interior Ministry troops, two policemen and two civilians, Tass said. One of the civilians suffered a gunshot wound, it said, without elaborating. Nagorno-Karabakh has been at the center of a territorial dispute between ethnic Armenians who dominate the region's population and Azerbaijanis since February 1988. Armenians demand that the region be put under control of the Armenian republic, while Azerbaijanis say it should be in their hands. Violence, strikes and demonstrations have erupted repeatedly.

DOC.HEAD: Packers Up Share of Cattle Owned Before Slaughter
DOC.TEXT: Meat packers increased the share of cattle owned or controlled by the companies prior to slaughter last year, the Agriculture Department said Friday. About 26.2 million steers and heifers were slaughtered in 1989, said the department's Agricultural Marketing Service. Of that number, 23.7 million head, or more than 90 percent, were slaughtered by the top 15 companies, which were required to file reports with the agency. The information collected showed that ``captive supplies'' of cattle owned or controlled by the companies increased to a 22.4 percent share last year from 19.3 percent in 1988, the agency said in a report. ``While packing firms and plants have grown over the past few years, the supply of slaughter livestock has been reduced,'' the report said. ``Increased capacity for processing, along with reduced cattle numbers, force packers to actively seek the available cattle.'' Packers get captive supplies through their own cattle feeding programs, forward contracting with other producers and marketing agreements with feeders.

DOC.HEAD: 16 Pelicans Killed By Lightning
DOC.TEXT: Sixteen pelicans found dead near here were killed by lightning, wildlife officials said. ``It's unusual for this to occur,'' said game warden Joe Ulrich, who investigated the birds' deaths southeast of Broadwater. He said weather patterns seldom have such an impact on migrating birds. Pelicans, which are not unusual in Nebraska, are mong the largest of all flying birds. They have wingspans of up to 9 feet. The American white pelicans probably were flying at an altitude of several hundred feet when they were caught in a thunderstorm earlier this week, said Dr. Stephen Kerr, a Gering veterinarian and wildlife enthusiast who examined the birds. ``It's unusual because birds usually avoid bad weather,'' he said Thursday. Kerr said his examination showed that the birds died before hitting the ground. Marks on some of their plumage showed probable contact with an electrical current, he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Naval Base Closes in Greece
DOC.TEXT: Officers at this U.S. Navy communications station near Athens destroyed a giant telecommunications antenna on Friday, symbolically marking the base's closure, the U.S. Embassy said. The United States announced this year it would shut down the Nea Makri base and the Hellinikon Air Force base adjacent to Athens Airport as part of a worldwide reduction of U.S. military installations. About 300 people _ servicemen, dependents and Greeks from nearby villages _ gathered for the toppling of the 660-foot antenna and for a picnic later. The antenna came crashing down, folding in on itself, when base commander Capt. Charles Voltaba III of Berwyn, Ill., ordered its supporting struts released. Nea Makri base, 24 miles northeast of Athens, was established in 1963 as a radio transmitting and receiving relay station in support of the 6th Fleet. It is one of four major military bases installed in Greece under terms of a defense agreement begun in the 1950s and renewed periodically since. Talks on a new defense agreement are expected to begin in May. The conservative New Democracy Party, which won elections April 8, has said it supports a continued U.S. military presence.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Reported Arrested In Cocaine Bust In Cuba
DOC.TEXT: Cuban authorities arrested eight people, including Americans, and seized 110 pounds of cocaine in a cocaine bust, the Mexican government news agency Notimex reported Friday. A dispatch from Havana, monitored in Mexico City, did not identify those arrested other than to say they were Colombians, Americans and Cubans living in the United States who arrived in Cuba in two speedboats from Florida. It quoted an Interior Ministry communique as saying the cocaine was found buried in Cruz Key, a beach in Camaguay province about 380 miles east of Havana. The communique said the drug was confiscated between March 19 and April 23, but it gave no details.

DOC.HEAD: Mystery Surrounds Disappearance of Chinese Farmers from Airport
DOC.TEXT: Authorities on Friday searched fruitlessly for seven Chinese peasants reported abducted upon arriving in this country. Suspicions rose that they may have been trying to escape China. Adding to the mystery was the question of why the Chinese were being brought to a farm in this remote western Massachusetts town to study organic agriculture, an art that has been practiced in their country for centuries. ``The Chinese have never really had a foreign exchange to buy chemicals. They are really knowledgeable from a millenium of organic farming,'' said state Agriculture Commissioner August Schumacher Jr. The seven missing Chinese were among a group of 16 farmers who were brought here by Molly Aitken, president of the World Energy Foundation and owner of Green Gables Farm, a modest spread on the outskirts of town. Federal authorities investigating the disappearance at New York's Kennedy International Airport say they suspect it may have been a scheme to get away from the group and stay in the United States. But Aitken said Thursday she trusted the seven and believes foul play was involved. She said she and the Chinese government selected the group. ``I cannot believe they would deliberately jeopardize our project by running off,'' she said. ``They were very excited about the project. It doesn't make any sense for them to want to do this.'' The group was from Fujian Province in southern China. The seven missing men are in their late 20s and early 30s and are married with families in China, Aitken said. The remaining farmers were staying at her farm Friday. Aitken said she was greeting the group at the airport Wednesday night when she noticed several were being herded off by three men. The alleged abductors, apparently unarmed, were yelling orders in Chinese. The men took the farmers across the crowded lobby, out the terminal doors and into a waiting compact car. Port Authority spokesman Armando Arrastia in New York said Friday investigators were searching for the getaway car, which was registered in Morristown, N.J., to a man named Xueduan Chen, about 30 years old. Authorities were trying to locate the owner, said Sgt. Thomas O'Reilly, a detective with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the airport. Several law enforcement officials said they were reluctant to characterize the incident at Kennedy. ``There's something wrong here,'' said Duke Austin, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Washington. ``If there were other Asians there with cars, they must have known these people were coming.'' The Chinese Embassy in Washington did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment Friday afternoon. Michael Ming Cui, an associate of Aitken's, suggested that overseas relatives of the men may have grabbed them for cheap labor. Austin, however, said the INS knew of no incidents in which Chinese nationals were kidnapped as they entered this country. Cui said it is true the Chinese are expert in organic farming, but the visiting farmers were here to learn more sophisticated techniques such as solar-powered greenhouses and hydroponics. Cui said he doubted the disappearance was an attempt at illegal immigration. He pointed to Chinese immigration papers that showed that at least one member of the group had been cleared of involvement in last year's student-led pro-democracy movement in Beijing, which was crushed by the government. The farmers had been allowed into the United States on temporary H-3 work visas intended for people in practical training programs. Working with the Beijing Vegetable Research Center, Aitken plans to build a model Third World village on her property, said Cui, an American-educated Chinese whose mother is affiliated with the center. He said the project originally was intended to be conducted in China, but supporters backed out after the government crackdown on pro-democracy students. Aitken said the World Energy Foundation is a New York-based, non-profit group that promotes the efficient use of energy and rural electrification in underdeveloped countries.

DOC.HEAD: Kent State Reconsiders, Puts Victim Names at May 4 Shooting Memorial
DOC.TEXT: Kent State University, under pressure from angry parents, has agreed that a memorial to be dedicated to the students killed and wounded in a 1970 anti-war protest will include a plaque inscribed with their names. The announcement was made Thursday by the university president, Michael Schwartz. The granite plaque was placed near the hillside memorial in preparation for the dedication ceremony on May 4, the 20th anniversary of the shootings. Schwartz made the decision after discussing the issue Wednesday with Martin and Sarah Scheuer, the parents of one of the slain students, Sandra Scheuer of Boardman, said Janet Thiede, a university spokeswoman. In an interview with The Associated Press published last week, Mrs. Scheuer expressed anger that no names were carved in the reddish granite of the memorial. ``What good is a memorial if they don't have their names?'' Mrs. Scheuer said. ``The Vietnam Memorial has names. Maybe the university just wants to forget about it _ 20 years is probably enough, they'll probably think.'' Schwartz said the plaque was inscribed, ``In loving memory of: Allison Krause, Jeffrey Miller, Sandra Scheuer and William Schroeder,'' who were killed by Ohio National Guardsmen on May 4, 1970. Referring to the wounded students, the plaque also says, ``Respectfully remembered: Alan Canfora, John Cleary, Thomas Grace, Dean Kahler, Joseph Lewis, Donald MacKenzie, James Russell, Robert Stamps and Douglass Wrentmore.'' ``The plaque will speak to what happened here at Kent while Bruno Ast's design will speak to the larger issue of the disruption going on in our country at that time and the impact the events here had on our nation,'' Schwartz said in a statement. The plaque was placed near the sidewalk north of the memorial plaza. Ms. Thiede, the university spokeswoman, said none of the finalists in the architectural design competition had called for including the names of the victims on the memorial. The memorial plaza, made of granite, is built on a 2{-acre site atop a hill. It consists of four standing slabs of increasing size that spread out from the center, signifying that the impact of May 4, 1970, spread far beyond Kent State. Ast's name appears on the memorial along with the words ``Inquire, Learn, Reflect,'' which the university has outlined as its goal in building the memorial. The memorial, which cost $200,000, was scaled down from a $1 million proposal that the university said it had been unable to finance through private fund-raising.

DOC.HEAD: Bennett: Orphanges May Be Haven From Drug Environment
DOC.TEXT: William Bennett, the nation's drug czar, said Friday that orphanages and youth camps may become sanctuaries for youngsters facing ``systematic child abuse'' in drug-plagued homes and neighborhoods. ``We may just have to find some way for children to get out of the environment they are in to go to orphanages, to go to Boys Towns, to institutions where they will be raised and nurtured,'' Bennett told about 3,000 delegates to a world drug conference. ``There are communities in America where children are not being raised at all.'' But Bennett offered no details about how children would be separated from families or what facilities would be used under such as plan. ``I think before this is over we will see a dramatic increase in orphanages,'' he said. ``No one is a stronger proponent of family. But when it reaches a level of systematic child abuse, we have got to do something.'' Nearly 7,000 adults and children attended the 13th annual conference sponsored by the Atlanta-based Parent Resource Institute for Drug Education. The convention ends Saturday. Bennett stressed drug education for young people but vigorously opposed any efforts to legalize drugs or weaken present laws. He also charged the nation's colleges have ducked responsibility in the battle against drug use. ``It's interesting how many of these colleges want to take on ethnocentrism, racism and sexism, but when we ask them about drugs they say it's a societywide problem and they can't do anything about it,'' he said. ``They can certainly do something about it, such as adopting strong rules and strong principles.''

DOC.HEAD: Michigan Companies Recall Sausage
DOC.TEXT: Two Michigan food processors are voluntarily recalling 3,500 pounds of sausage because the products may contain sulfite, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Dave's Sausage Factory in Detroit recalled 3,000 pounds, and Mancini Sausage Co. in Harpers Woods 500 pounds, officials said. ``Sulfites can pose serious health risks for people who are sensitive to these compounds,'' said Lester M. Crawford, head of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service. The sausage links produced by Dave's are sold under the names ``Wisbisky's Polish Sausage,'' ``Vetro's Italian Sausage'' and ``Dave's Pork Links.'' The first two products are sold in clear plastic bags and weigh about 1{ pounds each. The label shows the product name and has ``Est. 10198'' printed inside the USDA inspection seal. ``Dave's Pork Links'' are repackaged by stores and may be sold under a private brand name, Crawford said. All three products are distributed to grocery stores, delicatessens and restaurants in Michigan. The Mancini Sausage Co. product is sold only to delicatessens under the name, ``Polish Brand Sausage'' and is also in clear plastic bags, with a weight of 1{ pounds each. White printing on the bag shows the product name, ``Est. 10210'' printed inside the inspection seal, and the words ``produced by Mancini Sausage Company.'' ``Although no illnesses have been reported, we urge consumers to immediately return the sausage to the place of purchase,'' Crawford said. ``Consumers who suspect they may have purchased `Dave's Pork Links' under another brand name should ask the seller where the sausage came from and return it if necessary.'' Grocery store managers, delis and restaurants should return the meat to the distributor. ``Sulfites are not permitted as direct additives to meat or poultry food products,'' Crawford said. ``When ingredients that contain sulfites are added to a meat poultry product, such as vegetables in a stew, sulfites must be listed in the ingredients statement on the label.'' However, he said, pork sausage does not contain any ingredients to which sulfites would normally be added. Consumers with question about the recall may phone the toll-free USDA hotline at 1-800-535-4555 Monday through Friday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. EDT. At other times a recording with information about the recall will be provided, officials said. Callers in the Washington, D.C., area should call 447-3333.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Says He's Considering Selling Properties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Grafs 7-8 about Forbes magazine report are embargoed for release until 6:30 p.m. EDT. A version also moved on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump, the king of glitzy real estate and casinos, now says he wants to become the king of cash. The tycoon said Friday he has discussed selling or refinancing virtually every major asset he owns to raise money to buy new properties. Trump said he has hired Merrill Lynch & Co. to negotiate a possible sale of the Trump Shuttle less than a year after buying the airline from Eastern Airlines. ``If I got the right offer, I would consider selling it,'' Trump told The Associated Press in a telephone interview. Trump was confirming remarks made to the Wall Street Journal, which published details of his financial plans in a story Friday after its own interview with him. The Journal's account said Trump was so adamant about his cash strength he threatened to sue the newspaper if it suggested otherwise. Speculation about Trump's net worth and business intentions have gathered momentum ever since his marital problems became the latest gossip-tabloid fodder earlier this year. Forbes magazine, for example, says it has slashed an estimate of Trump's net worth by more than $1 billion, to around $500 million. In its May 14 cover story, which Forbes made available Friday, the magazine says it revised the estimate after examining nonpublic documents submitted by Trump last year to a government body, which Forbes declined to specify. The article questions whether Trump's cash flow is sufficient to cover the debt and interest payments from his vast holdings. Trump denied that his empire faces any cash shortage problems, saying he has cash reserves of $380 million. ``I'm very liquid now,'' he told the AP. ``I want to build up cash because I think cash is going to be king.'' He did not elaborate, but said he is interested in raising cash so that he will have funds on hand in the future to acquire additional properties. Among Trump's assets are New York's Plaza Hotel, the glitzy Trump Tower skyscraper on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue, and casinos in Atlantic City, N.J., including the $1 billion Taj Mahal casino, which recently opened with much fanfare. Some people in the financial community are watching for signs that Trump might be accumulating cash to cope with a current or anticipated cash crunch caused by a heavy debt load. ``He's in a cash squeeze. Why else is he doing this?'' said a hotel industry analyst. He and other analysts spoke on condition they not be identified, partly out of fear of arousing Trump's lawsuit threats against people whose views he doesn't like. Last month, gaming industry analyst Marvin Roffman was fired by his firm, Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia, after he made negative comments published in the Journal about the Taj Mahal's long-term prospects. Trump threatened to sue the firm and Roffman was fired after he rescinded his initial written apology to the developer. Several of Trump's biggest holdings don't produce enough income to cover interest payments on loans taken out to pay for acquisitions. This means that Trump relies heavily on cash cows, such as casinos and condominiums, according to the Journal article. The Plaza and Trump Tower will not be sold, Trump said.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: The ninth annual international gathering of crew cuts was abuzz with tales of the perils involved in keeping closely cropped. The crew assembled at the restaurant where it all began when someone told one of the group's originators, Jerry Brown: ``You crew cuts are a dying breed.'' To prove that wrong, Brown began recruiting people with crew cuts for the annual gatherings and found they all carry a sense of pride. ``Not too many are shy individuals. Maybe it has something to do with the hair standing erect,'' Brown said. Brown even went so far as to get Gov. Rudy Perpich to declare Thursday Crew Cut Day in Minnesota. The 20 who congregated swapped haircut tales Thursday night. Brown remembered going into a Washington, D.C., barber shop and the barber's ``hand was shaking so bad. I walked out of there, and my head was like the Rocky Mountains.'' Brown said people with long hair can have the length uneven by a quarter inch and it's hardly noticeable. Not so with a crew cut. ``One slip and you could draw blood,'' Brown said. Among the first-timers was Russ Mansmith of Wyoming, Minn., who said: ``I've had a crew cut since 1940 except for a six-month period in eighth grade. That was my rebellious period.''

Any plans to visit Kresge College, part of the University of California, Santa Cruz, will require a passport and visa. Students at Kresge, one of eight UCSC residential colleges, voted overwhelmingly this week _ 306-79 _ to secede from the main campus. The students on Thursday were making plans to issue passports and entry visas. They also intend to set up toll booths at ``border checkpoints.'' It all started with a ballot measure that sought a secession. Initially, it was considered a ``symbolic initiative,'' but Steve Parks, chairman of the Kresge Student Parliament, said, ``We're going to take this thing a bit further.'' Hence, the toll booths and visas. The ballot measure blasts school administrators as ``managers and demagogues rather than the visionaries and idealists'' who established the university among the redwoods above downtown Santa Cruz in the 1960s. ``We secede in the name of the environment; we secede in the name of the Earth,'' stated the initiative. Parks said the secessionist movement was spurred, among other things, by concerns about fast campus growth. A UCSC spokesman said administrators are baffled. ``We are not sure what this means,'' said John Harvith, the school's assistant director of public information.

The Rev. Calvin McCutcheon has two purposes in life. One: his congregation. The other: fleecing sheep. Both are sheer pleasure, he says. ``The two things I've done in my life are preach and shear sheep,'' said McCutcheon, 52. ``I try to feed my flocks as well as fleece them.'' A Methodist minister, McCutcheon has been pulling the wool off of eyes since he was 14, when it took him 25 minutes to strip a sheep. His skills were on display at the fifth annual Sheep to Shawl, an agricultural exhibit earlier this week at Fayette Plateau Vocational-Technical Center. Shearing and preaching have plenty in common, McCutcheon says. At least three Bible verses speak about the relationship between God and man using the word shepherd, he said. ``I understand that better because I've sheared sheep,'' McCutcheon said. McCutcheon is a seven-time state champion, and once sheared 300 in one day. His fastest official time is one minute, 19 seconds. He charges $1.75 a head, and has sheared throughout West Virginia, Virginia, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Indiana and Illinois. But he said he's too busy looking after his own flocks at Memorial United Methodist Church in Summersville and Bennett Memorial United Methodist in Glade Creek to keep his own sheep.

DOC.HEAD: Byrd Sets Voting Record
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Robert C. Byrd was honored Friday for casting more votes than anyone in Senate history. Byrd's vote on an amendment to a $3.4 billion supplemental spending bill was No. 12,134. The West Virginia Democrat cast his first vote on Jan. 7, 1959, on a procedural matter. ``Senator Byrd has maintained a voting attendance record of 98.4 percent during his Senate service,'' said Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell of Maine in a tribute on the Senate floor. The previous record was held by former Sen. William Proxmire, D-Wis., who cast 12,133 votes during his 31 years in the Senate. Among those praising Byrd was Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., who at 87 is the oldest member of the Senate. ``He has made a remarkable record in the Senate,'' Thurmond said. ``He is one of the ablest parliamentarians who has ever served ... throughout the history of the Senate.'' Byrd, 72, responded to the tribute by saying: ``Records are made to be broken, and this record will be broken in time.'' The former majority leader is a Senate historian and accomplished fiddler. Proxmire is still a record-holder. He cast 10,261 consecutive votes from 1966 to 1988, and had a 99.85 percent voting attendance record, according to Senate records. Byrd went back to business after the tribute, delivering a speech criticizing the Bush administration for not finding Japan in violation of trade agreements.

DOC.HEAD: Truck Carrying Harpoon Missiles Sideswiped; 2 Injured
DOC.TEXT: A semi-trailer carrying 16 Harpoon missiles with unarmed non-nuclear warheads was sideswiped by another truck on a highway, injuring two people, officials said Friday. No explosion or fire was reported. The accident on Interstate 64 in eastern Kentucky didn't pose a substantial threat to the area, but a section of the road was shut down for about 9{ hours, said state police and state Disaster and Emergency Services officials. U.S. Army explosives experts from Fort Knox arrived by helicopter early Friday to inspect the wreckage. The accident was reported at 11:30 p.m. EST Thursday. The interstate was reopened about 9 a.m. Friday after the trailer rig containing the rockets was towed under state police escort to the Lexington Blue Grass Army Depot, said Kentucky State Police trooper Gary Kistner. In Washington, Lt. Cmdr. Craig Quigley, a U.S. Navy spokesman, said 16 Harpoon missiles were being shipped from the Yorktown, Va., Naval Weapons Station to the McDonnell Douglas Astronautics plant in St. Charles, Mo., a St. Louis suburb. The weapons, complete with non-nuclear 500-pound warheads and guidance systems, would have required further procedures before they were battle-ready, he said. Each missile is shipped in a separate container ``designed to cradle the missile ... so that accidents of this nature will not yield an explosion,'' he said. The missile's protective canisters were not broken but were undergoing inspection at the Blue Grass Army Depot, said depot spokesman Robert Armogeda. Harpoon missiles are a type of cruise missile that can be launched from ships, submarines or aircraft. The 15-foot-long weapon is considered a medium-range anti-ship missile. A truck and trailer rig driven by Charles Harrell, 49, of Phillipsburg, Mo., was carrying the missiles when it was sideswiped by a rig driven by Jimmy Scott, 55, of Florrissant, Mo., Kistner said. Scott, a driver for J.B. Hunt Transport of Lowell, Ark., apparently lost control of his rig and crossed the highway's median, colliding with the tractor portion of the missile truck, Kistner said. Scott was listed in serious but stable condition in the intensive care unit of King's Daughter's Medical Center in Ashland, said nursing supervisor Sherry Swimm. The driver's wife, Marian Scott, 55, was treated for injuries and released. Harrell, a driver for Diablo Transportation Inc. of Pacheco, Calif., and a passenger were not injured.

DOC.HEAD: New York State Halts Deposits at Five Sperm Banks
DOC.TEXT: The state Health Department said Friday it has barred deposits at five sperm banks, including two being sued by women who say they were impregnated by the wrong sperm. In a letter delivered Wednesday, each bank was told to ``cease collecting and processing human semen for artificial insemination and to either destroy all anonymous semen samples or hold them until ... it meets requirements for (anonymous) donor screening and testing.'' Authorities said none of the banks had applied for a state license as required by a regulation that took effect in October. The banks, all in Manhattan, included Advanced Fertility Services, which has been sued by Julia Skolnick, and University Fertility Center of Research, which has been sued by a married couple identified in court papers as Jane and John Doe. Mrs. Skolnick gave birth to a daughter who is half black. Mrs. Skolnick is white, as was her late husband, whose sperm was supposed to have been used in the insemination. Jane Doe sued University after she gave birth to a child whose blood type allegedly did not match her's or her husband. She arranged to be impregnated by his sperm. The three other banks were Fertility Research Foundation, the Fertility Institute of New York, and the Mary Wilson Fertility Center. According to investigators, the most serious problems were at Advanced Fertility. The investigators said there was no evidence: _that Advanced Fertility quarantined semen from anonymous donors for six months before it was used; _that donors were given appropriate physical exams; _that semen was frozen within an hour of collection; _that semen was screened for HTLV-I, a virus linked to leukemia that can be sexually transmitted. In addition, the bank failed to apply for a state license even after it being told, said Maryanne Gardineer, a Health Department regulator. Robert Whittaker, a lawyer for the bank, said its operator, Dr. Hugh Melnick, ``is working with the state and has indicated that whatever bookkeeping problems exist will be corrected.'' Vicki Zeldin, a health department spokeswoman, said Advanced Fertility ``claimed these were only paperwork problems, but if they can't document that something happened, how do we know they did it?'' Ms. Gardineer declined to comment on a report published earlier this week that investigators also found semen at the bank bearing the code of Mrs. Skolnick's husband. Mrs. Skolnick says she was told by the bank that all of her husband's semen there had been used; she says the finding is proof that she was artificially inseminated with the wrong sperm. Mrs. Skolnick also has sued Idant Laboratories, where her husband deposited his sperm and which was supposed to send it to Advanced Fertility for insemination. Ms. Gardineer said the state's review of Idant, New York's largest sperm bank, was not finished. Investigators found that Wilson Fertility was using fresh semen that had neither been frozen nor quarantined, Ms. Gardineer said. Ian Wilson of Wilson Fertility said fresh semen is more effective than frozen, and he complained that the state order would inconvenience patients without increasing safeguards against disease. Zeldin said the three other banks were cited because they had not applied for the license. Ms. Gardineer said she does not know how many semen banks operate in the state. So far license applications have been received from nine banks, including five in other states. Officials at University said it no longer collected semen. The state's order only bars the five banks from collecting or processing semen, not from releasing semen already on deposit. Accordingly, the move does not affect semen of known donors like those involved in the two lawsuits. But sperm banks' record keeping is at the heart of those cases, and Ms. Gardineer said the inspections raised questions. ``You should be able to trace semen much in the same way you can blood,'' she said. ``But from what we've seen, the paper trail just isn't there.''

DOC.HEAD: Author Rushdie Describes Life in Hiding
DOC.TEXT: Author-in-hiding Salman Rushdie said Friday he misses everyday pleasures like taking a walk, but will not allow his prison-like circumstances to defeat him. In a telephone interview with BBC radio, the British author of ``The Satanic Verses'' also said he finds it odd no one has been prosecuted for making the threats that keep him in hiding 14 months after Iran's Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini imposed a death sentence. ``I'm not a lawyer, but it seems to me that people have been prosecuted for incitement in the past on less grounds than this,'' he said. ``I see what everyone else has seen on television and I find it hard to believe that's not sufficient evidence.'' At U.N. headquarters in New York, Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati said in reply to a question at a news conference Friday that the death sentence stands and has been supported by the Islamic world. Khomeini, Iran's spiritual and revolutionary leader, condemned Rushdie's novel as blaspheming Islam. Khomeini died June 3, but Iranian authorities reaffirmed his death decree, and Iranian clerics offered millions of dollars to anyone who killed Rushdie. Some British Moslems have expressed support for Khomeini's decree. Rushdie, born in India of Moslem parents, is not a practicing Moslem. Asked how he was coping with life in hiding and under guard, Rushdie said, ``Well, it's amazing what people can get used to. ``I'm doing my work, and I suppose that keeps me going. But I would like to think that this isn't a permanent condition. ... It is a very difficult situation, but I don't intend to be defeated by it. ``I spend my life reading and writing. It's a simple life,'' he said. ``I get up in the morning and I work, and I do whatever you might do if your life were confined to the interior of a house.'' The British Broadcasting Corp. said it was the 42-year-old writer's first broadcast interview since the Feb. 14, 1989, death threat drove him into hiding. Rushdie said he regards the confines of his safehouse as a prison. ``The fact that I cannot leave the house is a colossal restriction, and is, indeed, a loss of freedom, '' he said. ``The worst about it is the loss of ordinary life. The worst about it is not being able to do things that everybody else would take for granted, like walking down a street.'' Rushdie said he has finished a novel for older children, and a selection of his essays and criticisms. ``When I've had a bit of a rest, (I) try to dive into a grownup novel,'' Rushdie said. He gave no indication of where he was. Rushdie indicated it was not his responsibility to bring the campaign against him to an end. He called it a political problem ``that needs to be solved at the political level, and I have to remain optimistic that it will be.'' ``I wrote a book quite legitimately that was published quite legitimately, and it's not really for the person who is the object of an attack to solve the problem,'' he said. But Liquat Hussain, leader of the Moslem community in the central England city of Bradford where ``The Satanic Verses'' was first burned, said Rushdie ``is the key to the problem.'' ``He and his publishers can only solve the problem by withdrawing the book from publication,'' he said. Hussain said the Moslem campaign against the book would continue until it was withdrawn and the British law on blasphemy applied to all citizens. The law now applies only to Christian religions. Rushdie agreed to the interview on behalf of the Charter 88 campaign for a written constitution in Britain, which is the only country in Western Europe without one. Rushdie said newspaper reports that he was sighted in various places and had to be hustled away from a dinner in Oxford after Moslems arrived, were wrong. ``I've been sighted all over the place. I'm told I've been in Switzerland; there was a point where I was supposed to be in Paris,'' Rushdie said. ``The fact is that I'm in none of those places.'' The BBC said Rushdie placed the call and they did not know from where he called.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Foreign Minister Dodges Eggs in U.N. Hallway
DOC.TEXT: Three men accosted Iran's foreign minister in a U.N. hallway Friday shouting ``Murderer!'' and ``Torturer!'' and one hurled eggs at Velayati before being wrestled to the floor. The eggs missed and the minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, was untouched and unharmed. The three well-dressed men, who identified themselves as Iranians, were apprehended and held for questioning. One man, giving his name as Ahmed Mohini, said the Iranian government killed his brother. ``Velayati does not represent the Iranian people and should not be allowed here,'' he said, before being hustled off by guards. Velayati proceeded to his scheduled news conference, where he told reporters he didn't know the men. It was not known how the men got through U.N. security. U.S. State Department security guards also were protecting Velayati. The ambassador told the conference in response to a question that Iran's 14-month-old death sentence against British author Salman Rushdie still stands and has been supported by the Islamic world. The sentence was decreed by the late Iranian leader Ayatolla Ruhollah Khomeini, who found Rushdie's novel, ``The Satanic Verses,'' blasphemous. Velayati also repeated statements calling for international efforts to free all ``hostages,'' Western and Middle Eastern, held in Lebanon and Israel. ``It helps this positive process if the United States and Britain use their moral influence over the government of Israel and also the Phalangist groups (in Lebanon) to get the release of Iranian hostages ... and also some Moslems in Lebanon and Palestine.'' He was referring to Iranians who disappeared in Lebanon in the early 1980s and to prisoners held by Israel and its South Lebanese Army militia allies. Velayati said Iran-Iraq peace talks were stalemated and he blamed Iraq. The two Persian Gulf neighbors fought an eight-year war which was halted by a truce in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Removes Japan From List of Unfair Traders; Lawmakers Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Restores material dropped in a0691 that had been in a0687, also slugged AM-US-Japan Trade, 1st Ld-Writethru. a0691 should have been slugged 2nd Ld-Writethru.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday removed Japan from a ``hit list'' of countries judged to have erected the most offensive trade barriers against American products, rewarding Japanese efforts to ease trade tensions between the two economic superpowers. Instead, the president said he had decided to cite only one country _ India _ under a tough section of U.S. trade law which provides for economic retaliation if the offending barriers are not removed. The decision brought immediate protests from members of Congress, who charged the administration had made a serious mistake in not naming Japan, the country Congress specifically had in mind when it wrote the provision, known as Super 301, into the 1988 Trade Act. ``I am thunderstruck,'' Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., said in a Senate floor speech. ``Excuse me, Mr. President, but this boggles the mind. ... Letting Japan off the hook is a serious mistake and I think Congress ought to take a look at it.'' Critics said Japan needed to be targeted to keep pressure on the government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu to live up to a flurry of trade concessions he has made aimed at lowering America's huge $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. ``It is clear that Japan should be on the list,'' said Sen. Don Riegle, D-Mich., one of the sponsors of the Super 301 provision. ``Our government is not using the tools that are available to correct this continuing hemorrhage of U.S. capital and jobs.'' But Bush, in announcing his decision, said he was persuaded that Kaifu shared ``my commitment to ensuring that trade strengthens, rather than undermines, the friendship between our nations.'' Administration officials said targeting Japan could provoke a public backlash against the United States and make Kaifu's job of reforming Japan's trading system even more difficult. ``We believe that the most effective way to achieve results is through cooperation, not confrontation,'' U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills told reporters. Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama praised the president's decision, saying it upheld his government's position that it would not negotiate with the United States under threat of retaliation. But House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt called the decision a ``free trade furlough.'' ``If we have learned anything over the years as we have fought to reduce our monumental trade deficit with Japan, it is that the only thing that works is clear, constant, consistent pressure for needed change,'' Gephardt said. A year ago, the administration used the Super 301 provision to target Japan, Brazil and India as the countries with the highest barriers to American trade. Japan was cited for barriers to sales of U.S.-made supercomputers, satellites and wood products. In the past month, U.S. and Japanese negotiators have reached market-opening agreements in all three areas. Brazil was targeted for restrictive import licensing practices. Hills said recently enacted legislation in that country should meet U.S. concerns in this area. But India, which was cited last year for a ban on operations of foreign private insurance companies and for controls on foreign investment that distort trade, has refused to make concessions. The 1990 target list names those barriers again. Hills said India was singled out because it had erected more trade barriers than any non-communist country and the negotiations over the past year had made no progress. The Indian government issued a statement saying it would continue to refuse to ``negotiate bilaterally under threat of sanctions.'' It said the best way to resolve the dispute was in the current round of global trade talks being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Members of Congress said it made no sense to target India, with its modest $850 million trade surplus with the United States, and neglect Japan, whose trade surplus accounted for almost half of America's $109 billion deficit last year. ``Naming India and not Japan makes a mockery of Super 301 and U.S. trade policy,'' said Rep. Sander Levin, D-Mich. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen said he was glad the administration had at least issued a new Super 301 list although he was disappointed that Japan was not included. Bentsen, D-Texas, had warned earlier in the week that if the administration ignored the law completely this year he would work to block congressional passage of trade agreements the administration is expected to seek this year with the Soviet Union, China and the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. The 1988 trade law required the administration to issue a target list of countries with the most offensive trade barriers in 1989 and 1990. The law provides a tight timetable for negotiating away barriers and provides for retaliatory tariffs against the nation's imports into the United States if the negotiations prove unsuccessful. Some in Congress said they would propose legislation to make the Super 301 designation an annual event, thus forcing the administration to address again next year Japan's success in opening its markets.

DOC.HEAD: Chad Says Hundreds of Rebels Die in Fighting
DOC.TEXT:
Chad said Friday that its troops killed more than 700 Libyan-backed rebels in recent fighting, and that France promised to keep a reinforced military contingent in its former colony. The Libyans ``continue to want to impose their will on Chad'' despite a peace agreement the two countries signed Aug. 31, said Foreign Minister Asheik Ibn Oumar. ``We have had the assurance that ... French backing will not be lacking when we need it,'' he said. The Chadian government of President Hissene Habre accuses Tripoli of arming and training the Islamic Legion rebels fighting in eastern Chad, but Libya denies the Legion exists. The two North African countries, which border each other, have a long-running dispute over a territory in northern Chad called the Aouzou Strip. Casualty figures released by the Chadian Embassy in Paris listed 736 rebels killed and 328 captured in attacks April 18 and 20 on two columns of the Islamic Legion. Chad's High Command gave government losses for the first time: 47 soldiers killed, 102 wounded and about 150 vehicles and 63 heavy arms captured. The Legion operates along Chad's eastern border from bases inside neighboring Sudan's lightly populated Darfur province, where the Khartoum government exercises virtually no control. Renewed fighting in the sporadic civil war broke out last month when rebels took government outposts at Bahai and Tine. Chadian troops later recaptured the positions.
Ibn Oumar said France assured him 1,200 French troops will remain in Chad indefinitely but added that no active support of the soldiers would be needed. ``What we need is materials and weapons, not the men to use them,'' he said. Libya, which once occupied most of northern Chad, was chased out three years ago in a series of defeats. It still claims the Aouzou Strip as its own. In the August agreement signed in Algiers, Libya and Chad reconfirmed a cease-fire, agreed to the exchange of prisoners of war and to submitting their territorial dispute to international arbitration. But Ibn Oumar said Chad has encountered ``only endless obstruction'' from the Libyans in trying to implement the agreement. Every meeting of experts on the territorial dispute ended in failure. Ibn Oumar said Libya wanted to discuss freeing an estimated 2,000 Libyans held by Chad, while Chad wanted to discuss the future of the Aouzou Strip. He said unless there is a breakthrough, Chad is plans ``to place the problem before the International Court at the Hague as from Sept. 1, as entitled by the Algiers agreement.'' Ibn Oumar also complained that European countries have an increasing tendency to neglect Africa because their attention is focused on events in Eastern Europe. ``We have repaid our total debt three or four times, yet today we are more indebted than ever,'' he said. ``The European countries refuse even to discuss our urgent needs, although the responsibility is theirs for colonizing us and for looting our economies during and since the colonial era.'' Chad gained independence from France in 1960.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Unveils 1990 Alaska Cleanup Plan
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Corp. on Friday unveiled its second _ and last _ cleanup plan for the Exxon Valdez oil spill, saying it will spread fertilizers that promote oil-eating bacteria and send squads to pick up debris. ``This year's work is scattered, so we want to use a very flexible, squad-type group that can move in and move out and move over to do other work,'' said Don Carpenter, Exxon's logistics and operations manager. The plan, submitted to Coast Guard Rear Admiral David E. Ciancaglini for approval, contradicts conclusions by state officials that more than three quarters of beaches surveyed were still oiled from last year's spill. The plan's call for bioremediation _ the use of the fertilizers _ also has been controversial. State environmental officials said earlier in the week they won't approve its use until further studies have been done to allay fears about possible toxicity. Exxon plans to return its crews to the beaches May 1. A multi-agency task force has been conducting a shoreline survey this month and determined that conditions in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska have improved dramatically over the winter, Exxon said. The oil company said its studies of 574 miles of shoreline so far showed two-thirds without any oil at all, 22 percent with ``very light oiling'' and 13 percent with ``a narrow to wide band of weathered crude along sections.'' Those figures include subsurface oil as well, they said, which went below 4 inches on 16 miles of shoreline. The state Department of Environmental Conservation reported those survey results differently Wednesday, saying 79 percent of the shoreline sites surveyed were still oiled. ``I don't understand their numbers _ what the statistics are based on,'' Exxon's technical manager, Bob Mastracchio, said Friday. ``We've got 20 teams out there surveying shorelines.'' A more serious clash, however, may develop over bioremediation. Of 209 sites Exxon has targeted so far for cleanup, it hopes to use bioremediation on 160 of them. Some state and federal policymakers are worried about the release of still more toxins. If they don't allow the fertilizers, ``that's gonna be a dilemma for the agencies and the plan,'' Mastracchio said. ``If you can't use bioremediation, you can let nature remove the oil over the next few seasons. Bioremediation simply speeds up a natural degradation process.'' The company will meet with federal parks officials and state environmental officials to continue talking about the use of the fertilizers, he said. Exxon said it plans to manually pick up oily debris and tarballs on the majority of sites targeted for cleanup, spotwash certain areas and till and rake sediment in others. Mastracchio said manual pickup was the least environmentally destructive kind of cleanup, comparing rock-washing an entire beach to ``strip-mining'' it. The size of Exxon's crews this summer will be about 10 percent of last summer's. The company expects to have 1,100 people at work on the cleanup by June 1. Exxon's plans call for eight mobile teams supported by eight berthing vessels and 12 landing craft. The teams would be supported by 24 helicopters, 10 other aircraft, 20 work boats, eight supply vessels and about 30 smaller boats and skiffs. That compares with more than 10,000 workers and 1,000 boats leased for last summer's $2 billion program. Exxon officials wouldn't estimate how much this summer's cleanup will cost, but they expect it will be their last. ``We're putting out more than enough resources so the work can be done by the end of this summer,'' said Carpenter. Hundreds of miles of Alaska shoreline were fouled when the tanker Exxon Valdez slammed into a charted reef March 24, 1989, releasing nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into the water. It was the nation's biggest oil spill, coating hundreds of miles of shoreline and killing hundreds of otters and thousands of birds and other animals. Ciancaglini, the federal on-site coordinator, said it will take him several days to review Exxon's plan and the comments on it submitted by various state and federal agencies, and other parties. The review won't delay the start of cleanup, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Wildlife Group Campaigns against Indonesian Fish-Bombing
DOC.TEXT: A wildlife advocacy group said Friday it has begun a campaign to warn fishermen on Indonesia's Padaido Islands that damage caused by their catching fish with explosives will ruin the fishing grounds. The warning came in an article published by the feature service of the World Wide Fund for Nature, or WWF, known as World Wildlife Fund in the United States, Canada and Australia. It informed the fishermen that the explosives they fashion from recovered World War II bombs are ruining fragile coral reefs and devastating marine life. ``What will we live on tomorrow?'' ask a WWF poster in the local language. ``Where will we fish? Don't ruin your future'' WWF, said that at the end of the war the U.S. 7th Fleet, which operated out of the Padaido Islands, dumped thousands of live bombs in the center of the chain's atoll. Villagers dredged up the bombs, emptied their contents ``and developed a local fish bomb industry'' that proved destructive to the environment, the WWF said. The contents of a large bomb can fill hundreds of small fishing bombs. The concussion from the bombs kills the fish and they float to the surface for fishermen to collect. It takes 38 years for a bombed reef to grow back to half its original area, Don McAllister, a specialist with the Switzerland-based World Conservation Union, was quoted as saying. WWF said fish catches fall dramatically when reefs are damaged, but the bombing problem has been largely ignored because damaged reefs are hidden beneath the sea.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Passengers Rebel At Prospect of Flying With Politicians, Bodyguards
With AM-Colombia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A day after a Colombian presidential candidate was slain in a hail of bullets aboard an Avianca Airlines flight, passengers were up in arms Friday at the prospect of flying with a politician and her 25 bodyguards. About 100 ticketed passengers refused to board a domestic Avianca flight in the coastal city of Barranquilla when they learned that a leftist congresswoman and her heavily armed security contingent would be traveling with them, radio reports said. It was on a flight to Barranquilla from Bogota Thursday that a submachine gun-toting assassin fatally wounded Carlos Pizarro, a former guerrilla and presidential candidate. Pizarro's dozen bodyguards quickly killed the assailant, and the plane landed safely. The radio chains Caracol and RCN said in Friday's incident, the plane stayed at the ramp at the Barranquilla airport for 2{ hours until about 50 of the ticketed passengers finally decided to board, and the plane departed. The congresswoman, Vera Grave, is a longtime member of the April 19 Movement guerrilla group, known as the M-19, which Pizarro commanded. She was elected to Congress after the guerrilla group disbanded six weeks ago. Meanwhile, the pilot of the plane on which Pizarro was assassinated suggested that new guidelines might be needed to prevent airliners from becoming the scene of gunbattles between would-be assassins and their targets' security details. Capt. Fabio Munevar told a news conference that in his view, passengers traveling with armed bodyguards should not be allowed on commercial flights.

DOC.HEAD: Ulster Bobby-Trap Kills Northern Ireland Builder
DOC.TEXT: A booby-trap bomb blew up a car near the Irish border Friday and killed a builder whose company had been threatened by the Irish Republican Army over its work for the security forces. In London, the Court of Appeal overturned the 1988 convictions of three Irish people accused of conspiring to kill Tom King, then Britain's Northern Ireland secretary, on grounds that comments King made may have prejudiced the trial. Martina Shanahan, 24, John McCann, 26, and Finbar Cullen, 29, were freed, but then were immediately rearrested under the Prevention of Terrorism Act and ordered returned to Ireland. Friday's bombing in the fishing village of Kilkeel came a day after police said they received intelligence reports that the IRA planned to step up its terror campaign, and police called on the public to be ``extremely vigilant.'' The Royal Ulster Constabulary said the explosion at a road junction five miles from the border with Ireland mortally wounded the driver. He died soon after in a hospital. Neighbors identified the victim as Ken Graham in his mid-30s. The IRA had warned Graham's firm to stop construction work at police and military installations in the province, according to Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency. As part of its campaign to drive the British out of Northern Ireland, the IRA has killed 13 people involved in such construction work since August 1985. The IRA wants to unite Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland with the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland. In nearby Newry, police reported confiscating more than 1,000 pounds of explosives and a rifle in a vacant house in a Catholic neighborhood. The three Irish people whose convictions were overturned had been found guilty of conspiring to kill King after his daughter saw them in the grounds of their home in Northern Ireland and notified security men. The court ruled that King, now defense secretary in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet, could have prejudiced the outcome of the trial by appearing on television and arguing that terrorist suspects should not have the right to remain silent.

DOC.HEAD: Palace-Picked Local Governing Bodies Dissolved in Transition to Democracy
DOC.TEXT: The new pro-democracy government said Friday it has dismantled the last remnants of King Birendra's 29-year-old political system, which had given the monarch an absolute grip on power. C.K. Prasai, a spokesman for the Nepali Congress Party, said the Cabinet had moved late Thursday night to dissolve the system of ``panchayat.'' The term means ``grassroots government,'' but it actually gave the palace the power to choose local and national government representatives. The new government took office April 19. Birendra legalized political parties April 8, two days after security forces opened fire on pro-democracy deomstrators, killing scores of people. Witnesses said 200 people were killed, but Birendra's government said 10 were killed and 107 were injured. Prime Minister Krishna Prasad Bhattarai announced the Cabinet decision during a Nepali Congress executive committee meeting Friday, Prasai told reporters. ``From now on there is no panchayat from village level to national level in the country,'' Prasai said. ``This is a very drastic and swift step towards fulfilling the aspirations of the people. It is happy news.'' The panchayat system was introuduced by Birendra's father, King Mahendra, in 1961, and extended from local levels to the Rashtriya Panchayat, or National Assembly. Birendra dissolved the Rashtriya Panchayat on April 16, succumbing to demands of the pro-democracy movement spearheaded by the Nepali Congress and the seven-party United Left Front. His order did not formally disband local branches of the system, although they had become practically defunct. Prasai said the district panchayats will be run by local development officers and that village secretaries will handle administrative duties until a new system is announced. The Nepali Congress headed the country's only democratically elected government in 1959, but it lasted only 20 months before it was dismissed by Mahendra as part of his plan to set up the panchayat system.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Says South Dakota Plans To Sue Corps Of Engineers
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Mickelson said Friday South Dakota will file a lawsuit seeking to force the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to reduce water releases from drought-stricken reservoirs on the upper Missouri River. Despite a three-year drought, the Corps of Engineers has continued to discharge large amounts of water to support a small amount of barge traffic from Sioux City, Iowa, to St. Louis, Mo., Mickelson said at a news conference. The governor said he's still willing to settle the dispute through negotiation, but it's unlikely such an agreement can be reached before the lawsuit is filed sometime next week. ``I'm tired of the inaction and the indifference we have seen from all of our efforts,'' Mickelson said. He said governors of other Missouri River states and leaders of Indian tribal governments may join South Dakota in the lawsuit. Gov. George Sinner of North Dakota said Friday his state is likely to take part. The state has hired former Gov. Bill Janklow, a lawyer, to handle the lawsuit. Dropping water levels have threatened city and rural water supply systems, left boat ramps far from the water's edge and prevented irrigators from using the water in the huge reservoirs, Mickelson said. ``The citizens of South Dakota deserve and have the right to expect that we will equitably share in the benefits of the Missouri River reservoirs, and to this point we have not,'' he told reporters. G. Edward Dickey, acting deputy secretary of the Army for civil works, said the agency doesn't comment on lawsuits or potential lawsuits. But Dickey said groups that use rivers and reservoirs get worried when a drought cuts the water supply. The corps is following the policy in its master manual in operating the Missouri River reservoirs, he said. ``We have a drought out there, a very severe drought. ... It's not surprising we have a lot of anxieties,'' Dickey said in a telephone interview from his Washington office. ``Until it rains, there's going to be continuing unhappiness among all users because everybody gives up something.'' The water levels in Fort Peck Lake in Montana, Lake Sakakawea in North Dakota and Oahe Reservoir in South Dakota have suffered the greatest drops in water levels during the drought. The other three, smaller reservoirs in South Dakota have not been affected as much. The water level in Oahe Reservoir, which stretches 230 miles from the middle of South Dakota to southern North Dakota, has fallen 20 feet below normal at times during the past year. Mickelson said the Corps of Engineers' own study estimates downstream barge traffic is worth only $12 million a year, while recreation in the upstream states is worth more than $63 million annually, he said. ``What we're seeing now is massive, record releases that are going out of the reservoirs in our state to support a dying navigation industry between St. Louis and Sioux City,'' Mickelson said. Sinner, the North Dakota governor, said the Corps of Engineers relies on the downstream navigation channel more than private shippers do. He said the lawsuit might seek a court order reducing reservoir releases to the point where downstream navigation is shut down. Mickelson said the lawsuit will seek a court order requiring the corps to determine new long-term priorities for water use in the Missouri River. The lawsuit would harm only the navigation industry in downstream states, Mickelson said.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th graf, About 100 ... UPDATING with Tambo leaves Swiss clinic. Picks up 10th graf, De Klerk legalized . .. with minor editing to trim
DOC.HEAD: Leading African National Congress Exiles Return Home
DOC.TEXT: Five long-exiled leaders of the African National Congress made an emotional return to South Africa on Friday to prepare for groundbreaking talks next week with the white-led government. The five, who arrived from the group's exile headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia, will join ANC Deputy President Nelson Mandela for discussions with President F.W. de Klerk's government May 2-4. ``As I was saying before I was so rudely interrupted 27 years ago, `We are really on the way,''' said Joe Slovo, a member of the ANC's National Executive Committee. He fled South Africa in 1963. ``We who left by the back door ... have now entered the very front door of South Africa,'' said Slovo, the ANC's highest-ranking white. ``It's a remarkable feeling.'' In addition to Slovo, the group included the ANC's secretary-general, Alfred Nzo; head of foreign affairs, Thabo Mbeki; commander of the movement's guerrilla wing, Joe Modise; and head of the women's section, Ruth Mompati. The five, who had been in exile since the 1960s, arrived on a private charter and held an airport news conference. ``It is an exciting moment for all of us,'' said Nzo. ``Regrettably, our South Africa is still a bleeding country ravaged by the apartheid system which continues to divide our people into warring clusters.'' Mbeki wept as he stood beside his 80-year-old father, Govan Mbeki, an ANC veteran who spent 23 years in prison before his release in 1987. About 100 supporters greeted the ANC leaders at the airport. Hundreds more lined the road outside, waving the banners of the ANC and its ally, the South African Communist Party. Meanwhile, exiled ANC President Oliver Tambo, 73, quietly left Sweden on Thursday after a recuperating there since Jan. 3 from a stroke he suffered late last year, officials in Stockholm said Friday. The Swedish news agency TT said Tambo wanted to return to South Africa soon, but it was unlikely he would be able to resume an active leadership role in the ANC. De Klerk legalized the ANC in February after a 30-year ban. Many of the estimated 15,000 members in exile are likely to return this year. Four lesser-ranking ANC officials returned this week but have not appeared in public. The government promised that the exiled ANC leaders would not be prosecuted upon returning to South Africa for the talks.
