Under South Africa's apartheid system of racial segregation, the country's 5 million whites maintain political and economic control, and the 28 million blacks have no voice in national affairs. Next week's talks are designed to clear the way for negotiations on a new constitution that would include blacks. The ANC has said the government must lift the 3{-year-old state of emergency and release prisoners convicted of politically motivated crimes before negotiations can begin. The government wants the ANC to renounce its armed struggle. The government has said constitutional negotiations will include several black opposition groups in addition to the ANC. Slovo is general secretary of the Communist Party. About half of the ANC's top 35 leaders also are Communists. In other developments: _Police said Friday six people were killed in black factional fighting in Natal Province during the preceding 24 hours. _Justice Minister Kobie Coetsee said he plans to introduce legislation that would end racial segregation of prisons. _A former member of the Johannesburg City Council security department alleged that a military intelligence operative was responsible for the assassination last year of prominent white anti-apartheid activist David Webster. Hannes Gouws made his allegation at an inquiry into a spy ring conducted by the city council. No one has been arrested for Webster's killing.

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin Mandates Statewide Recycling, Tax to Pay for It
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Tommy G. Thompson on Friday signed what he called the nation's strictest recycling law, which bans bottles, newspapers and other recyclable waste from Wisconsin dumps by 1995. The law requires every community to draw up a mandatory recycling plan by that year. And it imposes a $15 million-a-year tax on big businesses to help pay for stemming the tide of trash. Sponsors of the measure, along with some environmentalists, also called it the most far-reaching in any state because of its one-two punch of mandatory statewide recycling and a tax on business. ``As far as I know, Wisconsin is the first state to use a broad-based business tax to pay for recycling,'' said Jeanne Wirka, policy analyst for the Washington-based Environmental Action Foundation. The advocacy group has 30,000 members nationwide. The Wisconsin bill is similar to a measure pending in the Vermont legislature, and is likely to serve as a model for other states, she said. Thompson, a Republican, surprised some by retaining part of the business tax, which he had been expected to excise from the bill using his power of partial veto. ``Overall, it's a very tough bill and it's making a lot of people nervous,'' said Douglas Johnson, a lobbyist for an industry group called the Wisconsin Consumer Packaging Council. Nothing will change immediately because of the bill, which will work largely by banning recyclable products from the state's landfills. Communities, many of which have already begun work on plans that require residents and businesses to recycle, must have mandatory recycling in place by 1995. That is also when the dumping restrictions take effect. A detailed list of products barred from dumps includes aluminum, glass and plastic containers, newspapers, cardboard and office paper, steel containers and old tires. Wisconsin dumps will have to stop taking refuse from out-of-state _ except from communities with the same strict recycling rules. Private Wisconsin dumps now accept large amounts of refuse from Minnesota and elsewhere. The state will put up $18.5 million a year to finance the effort. Added to that will be an estimated $15 million from a tax on larger businesses. The tax would be graduated: Firms with annual receipts of $1 million would pay $63 a year, and that would rise to rise to $2,170 for firms with $6 million or more in gross receipts. Companies with gross annual receipts of less than $1 million would be spared the tax. Businesses would begin paying the tax in 1992, to accumulate money for the recycling program. The tax method would be reassessed after two years. ``This is the most progressive, far-reaching and potentially effective recycling law in the United States,'' Thompson said during the Capitol bill signing-ceremony. Wisconsin previously enacted legislation banning grass clippings and other yard wastes from landfills beginning in 1993. The original bill called for about $30 million in business taxes. But Thompson used his partial veto power to cut the gross receipts tax in half, and to set an expiration date of two years to force the Legislature to seek others forms of funding. The governor also removed sections that would have banned some types of packaging. He said that ``represented a potential threat to Wisconsin jobs with little or no demonstrated environmental gain.'' The Legislature approved the measure in late March, after removing some strict features. Among them was a proposed penny-per diaper tax on disposables to pay for recycling.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Astonomers Make Detailed Pictures of Comet Austin
DOC.TEXT: Japanese astronomers reported Friday that they have produced detailed pictures of Comet Austin, which is observable through telescopes in the northern hemisphere as it nears the Earth. An observatory official said researchers took the photographs Wednesday night through a telescope at Tokyo University's observatory in northern Japan. He said details of the comet's 4.4-million-mile-long tail showed up clearly in the pictures, affording researchers the opportunity of studying it. The tail of a comet is essentially a vapor trail created by solar wind striking the comet's icy surface. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the photos are the first of Comet Austin taken by Japanese researchers for astronomical observation. The comet is advancing about 3.8 million miles a day, he said. Unlike periodic comets such as Halley's, he said, Comet Austin, having circled the sun, will never return. Comet Austin was named for amateur astronomer Rodney Austin of New Zealand, who discovered it last year. It will be observable throughout much of the Earth's northern hemisphere until the end of May, but it is not bright enough to be seen by the naked eye, the official said. It is traveling in a westerly direction, he added. The official reported that the observation effort is being conducted at 30 locations throughout Japan and that photos and other data on Comet Austin will be shared with the Smithsonian Observatory in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Houston Policeman Found Guilty of Manslaughter in Woman's Death
DOC.TEXT: A jury Friday convicted a former Houston policeman of voluntary manslaughter in the shooting of a black woman on a Houston freeway after a Halloween night of drinking among off-duty officers. Alex Gonzales, who was himself critically wounded by the victim in what prosecutors said was self-defense, faces up to 20 years in jail for the conviction in the death of Ida Lee Delaney on Oct. 31. The all-white jury, which began deliberating late Wednesday afternoon, delivered its verdict shortly before 2:30 p.m. Friday. State District Judge Ted Poe instructed jurors that they could find Gonzales guilty of murder, voluntary manslaughter or innocent of either charge. The punishment phase of the trial is scheduled to begin Monday. The trial was moved to Dallas because of heavy pretrial publicity in Houston, where the death of Ms. Delaney became another cause for groups that maintain that Houston police are hostile toward blacks. She was a janitor at The Houston Post. Gonzales, 25, was accused of provoking Ms. Delaney, 50, into the pre-dawn shooting, then killing her. Tests after the incident showed Gonzales had a blood-alcohol level of .19, nearly twice the amount to be considered legally drunk in Texas. According to trial testimony, Gonzales was riding in a private car with two other off-duty officers, none wearing uniforms, when they encountered Ms. Delaney's pickup truck about 5:15 a.m. Prosecutors said Gonzales and the other officers, who have also been dismissed from the department since the incident, chased Ms. Delaney for 12 miles after she cut them off in traffic on her way to work. ``He stepped out of his police suit to become a thug on the street,'' said Harris County prosecutor Chuck Rosenthal in closing arguments on Wednesday. Ms. Delaney had no way of knowing that the men chasing her were police officers, prosecutors said. The shooting occurred after Ms. Delaney pulled off the freeway. Defense attorneys Wednesday said Gonzales shot Ms. Delaney in self-defense. ``She was a violent, aggressive hair-trigger individual,'' defense attorney Joe Bailey said. Fellow defense attorney Mike Hinton told the jury, ``She was discharging her weapon because she was discharging her temper.'' Gonzales said he and fellow officers Alexander Romero and R.C. Gonzales Jr. followed Delaney to arrest her after she nearly hit their car with her pickup and shot at them. Prosecutors say the three harassed and terrified the woman and that Gonzales, who was drunk and out of uniform, slugged Delaney in the face before shooting her to death.

DOC.HEAD: $1.5 Billion Eye in the Sky Opens; Astronauts Prepare for Return
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 20 grafs to UPDATE with details of communication problem, shuttle passing beneath telescope. Pick up 18th graf pvs: `NASA said...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos HTN1,4
DOC.TEXT: The Hubble Space Telescope orbited with its big eye open Friday after ground controllers overcame communications problems and lifted its lens cover, but its electronics were shut down due to a malfunction. Those problems, however, were not the immediate concern of shuttle Discovery's astronauts, who prepared for Sunday's return to Earth. ``You've been released from Hubble support. It's on its own,'' Mission Control's Story Musgrave told the five crew members. ``That's great news,'' replied Discovery commander Loren J. Shriver. ``There are handshakes and smiles all around up here. I'll bet it's just that way back down there, too,'' added mission specialist Steven Hawley. ``Who's buying tonight?'' ``We'll buy when you all get back,'' Musgrave replied. Flight director William Reeves said it was too early to cheer. `We still have an important part of the mission to go,'' Reeves said. ``We reserve our celebration until the crew is safely on the ground.'' Discovery is to land at 9:48 a.m. EDT Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Landing would have been delayed a day if astronauts Bruce McCandless and Kathryn Sullivan had had to perform a space walk to crank open the telescope's lens cover, or aperture door. The shuttle trailed 50 miles behind Hubble when the aperture door opened 380 miles above Earth, but passed 3.7 miles beneath the telescope later in the day. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration had planned to release its first test image from the $1.5 billion telescope on Tuesday, showing an open star cluster in the constellation Carina. But Steve Terry, director of orbital verifications, said that would be delayed by problems with Hubble's high-speed antennas. Scientific data will follow in a month or two. Hubble's 10-foot aluminum aperture door was opened to the heavens at 10:30 a.m. EDT, nearly four hours later than planned, exposing its finely polished 94.5-inch mirror to starlight for the first time. Ground controllers sent a signal commanding the door to lift even though the telescope was in an automatic ``safe mode,'' with all motion stopped because of problems in linking its high-speed dish antennas with a relay satellite. One of the two antennas apparently had swung too far, and the telescope shut down, said Jean Oliver, a Hubble deputy project manager. If future movements of the antenna have to be limited to avoid the problem, it would have only slight impact on the telescope's observing time, Oliver said. Terry said the opening of the aperture door could not have been delayed much longer. ``There has to be a point where you say they have to go their way and we have to go ours,'' he said of the astronauts. When the door opened, two of Hubble's four position-stabilizing gyroscopes stopped working; later, engineers got them back on line. The motion of the lens cover knocked out the gyros, said Dave Drachlis of the Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland. That, too, kept it in the safe mode. Oliver said it would be Saturday morning before the telescope is brought out of the safe mode. It will take another day to get the instrument operating normally again, putting controllers at Goddard several days behind. ``We're trying to be very deliberate and trying not to cut any corners and do anything fast because we feel there's a lot at risk here and we want to make sure we're doing it properly,'' Oliver said. ``We've got a long future ahead of us, and we want to make sure it starts off on the right foot.'' NASA said the telescope was safe and in a stable position. Tolerances for the telescope systems were set particularly narrow for the first operations and that was the cause of many malfunctions, Terry said. In addition to that trouble, there were two communications outages totaling several hours. ``We're cautious, and that's natural,'' Terry said. ``We've got a very expensive spacecraft here and we don't want to do anything to jeopardize the usefulness. ... We'll get to the point where we know exactly what the spacecraft will do and set the limits appropriately.'' Terry said Hubble is designed with safe modes so it can be ``the master of its own destiny'' in case contact with an orbiting communications system is lost for extended periods. The telescope will share the system, known as Tracking and Data Relay Satellites, with other space craft. Except for a tiny wedge opening, the lens cover had been closed and the telescope blind ever since Hubble was released by the astronauts Wednesday. From its orbit high above Earth's distorting atmosphere, the telescope will enable astronomers over its 15-year working lifetime to look back 14 billion years and possibly determine the age of the universe. The universe is believed to have been created about 15 billion years ago in a cosmic explosion. The late astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, for whom the telescope is named, provided the basis for the Big Bang theory of creation. He discovered during the 1920s that the universe is expanding and that the farther the galaxy is from Earth, the faster it is moving away. In honor of the astronomer, Sullivan carried with her into space an eyepiece from the 100-inch telescope at California's Mount Wilson Observatory that Hubble used to make his pioneering observations. ``It's a great pleasure to have something of such historical significance and something that so directly symbolizes Edwin Hubble's fundamental contributions to astronomy,'' she said Friday afternoon. Once back on Earth, the eyepiece will be displayed at the observatory.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Loses Arms, Legs From Rare Toxic Shock Bacteria
DOC.TEXT: A 6-year-old girl's arms and legs were amputated after a rare form of toxic shock bacteria infected chicken pox lesions on her body, doctors said. ``This is exceedingly rare,'' said Dr. John Bradley, director of the division of infectious disease at Children's Hospital. He said he knew of no documented case of this strain of bacteria infecting children, although there have been dozens of cases involving adults and it is fatal about 30 percent of the time. Jessica Lynn Esquivel was admitted to the hospital April 1 with what was believed to be a routine case of chicken pox. But a toxin-producing streptococcal bacteria infected the lesions on her body caused by the chicken pox and spread to the other parts of her body. The onset of toxic shock caused what Bradley termed ``full cardiac arrest,'' in addition to kidney, liver and respiratory failure, before infusions of penicillin began to reduce the effects of the bacteria. Because the illness had obstructed circulation to her limbs, doctors severed Jessica's legs at the knee and her arms at the elbow on April 18, Bradley said Wednesday. Jessica had been in critical condition after the surgery, but was upgraded to serious this morning, said hospital spokeswoman Sharon Ross. ``With what we know about this toxin-producing strain of strep, the shock that we saw here at the hospital was an extremely difficult one to reverse,'' Bradley said. He said he doubted that Jessica's condition could have been prevented because there is no vaccine for chicken pox and because of the rarity of the bacteria. He said the child would not have incurred the bacteria without first having had the chicken pox, but that streptococcus infections as an adjunct to chicken pox are common. Dr. Brad Peterson, who treated Jessica, said the girl suffered damage to her vital organs but they are ```100 percent'' better now. Jessica, who had been in an artificial respirator until this week, is now able to speak. Peterson said the loss of her arms and legs have been explained to her and that a psychiatrist has been made available. Ms. Ross said a trust fund has been established to help pay for the child's long-term recovery. Lisa Esquivel, 25, said she and her husband, Felix, 27, the girl's parents, are devastated by the turn of events. ``Now my daughter doesn't have hands or feet ... and it's hard,'' said Felix Esquivel.

DOC.HEAD: Chemists' Laboratory-Created Molecule Makes, Stores Energy
DOC.TEXT: A synthetic molecule that converts light into energy almost as efficiently as the natural process of photosynthesis could be used to enrich soil and genetically design herbicide-resistant crops, scientists say. The device, which stores energy the way a battery would, may even help speed up computers _ if someone can figure out how to hook up the microscopic device to wires many times its size. Thomas Moore, one of the 12-member team from Arizona State University's Photosynthesis Research Center who worked on the molecule, said it might be able to drive chemical reactions in the soil such as nitrogen fixation, known more commonly as fertilization. Crops grown in such soil would be healthier and more robust. The researchers published the details of their work in the April 13 issue of the journal Science. Devens Gust, a leader of the research group, said the device is called a ``pentad molecule'' because of its five active parts, which are based on natural materials. A previous device they built in 1983 consisted of three parts but was only 5 percent as efficient as the new one, which is capable of storing 83 percent as much energy as natural molecules do in photosynthesis. Gust said the device does that by separating the positive and negatively charged parts of atoms and holding them about one-billionth of a centimeter apart at opposite ends of the ladder-like molecule. Photosynthesis is the solar-powered process by which plants convert nutrients and water to food. Dr. Mark Wrighton, chairman of the chemistry department at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said in a telephone interview that efficient molecular electronic components also could radically increase the speed and capability of computers. Gust, however, said one roadblock to employing the ASU molecule in consumer electronics is its size in relation to wires leading to circuits. ``The traditional approach to electronics really has been a materials approach,'' Gust said. ``You start out with something such as bulk silicon. Then you devise ways to make devices from that bulk silicon that are smaller and smaller.'' Using the molecular-electronics approach, he said, ``You design the device at the molecular level. Then you try to figure out ways to incorporate these molecular-sized devices into large, macroscopic electronic circuits.'' Such applications may be years away, Gust said. But he said the device would be easy to apply in agriculture almost immediately. Besides its use in fertilizing soil, Gust said, the molecule could be used to genetically design plants resistant to herbicides, many of which are designed to interrupt photosynthesis. Then farmers could spray their fields with a herbicide that would not affect the desired plants.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Attack Kills Five in Afghan Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with relief camp incident, edit for transition; picks up 3rd graf pvs, `The state-run'
DOC.TEXT: A dozen rockets slammed into the Afghan capital and killed five people Friday, the 12th anniversary of the bloody coup that began Communist rule in Afghanistan, Radio Kabul reported. In Pakistan, relief officials said fundamentalist Moslem clerics railing against Western influence led about 5,000 people on a rampage against a private aid group's facilities at a camp for Afghan refugees. No one was hurt in Thursday night's attack at Nasir Bagh, a sprawling compound near Peshawar that has been home to about 60,000 refugees during the decade-long war in Afghanistan, the officials said. But Shelter Now International, which is financed by several Christian organizations and delivers relief supplies to refugee children and widows, said it sustained almost $1 million in damage. ``We've been here seven years,'' said Thor Armstrong, director of Shelter Now. ``It's incomprehensible that this would happen.'' Armstrong says the trouble apparently was caused by fundamentalists angry over what they consider corrupting Western influence on Afghan women. Radio Kabul said Friday's fatal rocket attack was the second in as many days on the Afghan capital. The state-run broadcast blamed the latest attack on ``extremist opposition members backed by Pakistan,'' presumably referring to U.S.-supported anti-Communist rebels. No group claimed responsiblity. Rebel fighters routinely deny hitting civilian targets. Radio Kabul said eight people were wounded and five killed in the raid. It said two people died and 11 people were hurt Thursday when five rockets blasted the capital. Hundreds of people have been killed in rocket attacks on the Afghan capital in the past several years. The worst attack in recent weeks occurred Monday when a rocket hit a mosque and killed 13 people. Another six people died that day when rockets slammed into other parts of the city. Moslem insurgents, bankrolled by the United States, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and other Arab states, have been fighting 12 years to topple Kabul's ruling Communists. Friday's attack coincided with the 12th anniversary of a bloody coup that put the Communists in power in Afghanistan. On April 27, 1978, Communist leader Nur Mohammad Taraki overthrew Mohammad Daoud in what was called the Saur Revolution, named after the Moslem month in which it occurred. Within two years of the 1978 coup, more than 100,000 Soviet soldiers marched into the Central Asian country to replace one Communist government with another and to crush a burgeoning Moslem insurgency. After nine years of direct involvement, Moscow withdrew its troops from Afghanistan in 1989. Rebel fighters, headquartered in Pakista, have vowed to continue their fight until Afghanistan's President Najib and his ruling People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan is overthrown. The radio broadcast condemned the rebel fighters for the attack, particularly during Eid-il Fitr, one of Islam's holiest holidays. Traditionally the Saur Revolution anniversary has been marked by pomp and ceremony, military parades and speeches lauding Communism's contributions to Afghanistan. But since the Soviet withdrawal, Najib has toned down the anniversary. The only reference to the Saur Revolution on Radio Kabul's broadcasts Friday was a message of congratulations from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Since withdrawing its troops, Moscow has sent billions of dollars worth of military and humanitarian assistance to Kabul. Last year, Najib delayed the Saur Revolution celebrations one day after his government's secret police reportedly uncovered a plot to assassinate him. The state-run radio broadcast did not say whether celebrations had been canceled Friday or whether they had been delayed.

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta Mayor Pleads for Handgun Laws in Surrounding Counties
DOC.TEXT: Three days after a mental patient took his new gun to a suburban mall and shot five people, Mayor Maynard Jackson pleaded Friday with outlying counties to adopt a handgun waiting period similar to Atlanta's. ``No one is trying to prohibit the use of handguns,'' Jackson said at a hastily called crime summit at City Hall. ``What we're talking about is a sane and civilized system _ where someone who's insane and crazy cannot get a gun and blow somebody's brains out.'' Atlanta and surrounding Fulton County currently require a 15-day wait for the purchase of a handgun, to allow public safety officials time to investigate the buyer's background. But virtually anyone can visit towns in surrounding counties to buy a gun with no delay, since Georgia's local and state governments have traditionally been hostile to any kind of gun control. About three dozen elected officials and police leaders from the metro area attended Jackson's meeting. None spoke up to oppose the waiting-period proposal. ``We've got to do something,'' said Mayor T.O. Smith of College Park, near Atlanta's southside airport. ``It's got to be at the state level, but we can set an example.'' After the meeting, Commissioner Nate Mosby of DeKalb County, where the shootings occurred, said he would draft waiting-period legislation. ``I think the majority of the commission would be amenable to some kind of deterrent, and the waiting period is the most palatable,'' he said. ``My plea is a consistent waiting period in the eight counties of metro Atlanta _ that's all I'm asking,'' Jackson said. ``When somebody's got a record as a homicidal maniac, it gives us a chance to check.'' James Calvin Brady, identified as the gunman who killed one and injured four Tuesday at Perimeter Mall, had been released a day earlier from a state mental hospital, even though a medical form he was still carrying listed him as ``homicidal.'' After being released, he bought the gun in suburban Avondale Estates. Atlanta police officials attending the summit said handgun applications in Atlanta fell from 846 in 1985 to 197 in 1989, presumably because purchasers bought guns elsewhere. Those attending the summit included representatives of DeKalb, Clayton and Fulton counties and the cities of Atlanta, Hapeville, Alpharetta, Doraville, McDonough, Roswell, Smyrna, East Point, Mountain Park, Fairburn, Palmetto, Chamblee and Decatur. Skipping the meeting was Mayor J.O. Stephenson of Kennesaw, the Cobb County town that passed a mandatory gun ownership bill several years ago in response to gun control initiatives elsewhere. ``It's ludicrous to think you can penalize law-abiding people when criminals and crazy people are going to try to get them (guns) any way they can,'' he said Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Creates Shorter Milk Hormone Moratorium
DOC.TEXT: The nation's No. 1 dairy state on Friday approved a temporary ban on use of a synthetic hormone that makes cows give more milk. The measure, signed into law by Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, prohibits all but experimental use of bovine growth hormone in Wisconsin until June 1, 1991. After that, farmers would be able to inject their cows with the hormone, which some consumer groups contend hasn't been adequately tested for potential heal affects on humans who drink milk. A similar bill is pending in Minnesota, another major milk-producing state. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration is allowing private companies to test the hormone on farms, but has yet to approve it for commercial use. Some of the milk from test herds has reached the market, and the FDA contends that milk is safe. In signing the ban, Thompson vetoed a separate, stricter bill. That measure would have banned used of the genetically engineered hormone until six months after the FDA approved it for commercial use. The Republican governor said the more extensive moratorium would have put Wisconsin dairy farmers at a disadvantage against competitors in states where the hormone could go into commercial use immediately after FDA approval. The hormone, a copy of that which occurs naturally in cows, is said to boost milk production by 10 percent to 20 percent. Under the new law, the hormone can be used over the next 14 months in Wisconsin, but only for experiments. Any milk produced by injected cows would have to dumped. Supporters of the hormone warned that Wisconsin dairy farmers could be hurt if the state became an ``island'' surrounded by states that permitted its use. Opponents contended increased production could push milk prices down, thus driving smaller dairy farmers out of business.

DOC.HEAD: Oakland Anti-Nuclear Ordinance Ruled Unconstitutional
DOC.TEXT: Oakland's 1988 ``nuclear-free'' initiative, one of the nation's broadest local bans on nuclear weapons-related activities, was declared unconstitutional Friday by a federal judge. The ordinance forbids most city contracting, purchases and investments with nuclear weapons manufacturers, restricts transportation of nuclear material through the city and outlaws most nuclear weapons work in the city. The federal government's lawsuit last September, the first it has filed against any of the more than 160 local nuclear-free laws in the country, said the Oakland ordinance interfered with exclusive federal control of national defense, atomic energy and shipments of hazardous materials. U.S. District Judge John Vukasin agreed with the government's arguments in a brief ruling from the bench Friday. Earlier, Vukasin had refused to let city officials or anti-nuclear groups examine federal officials or documents to determine the extent of possible interference with government operations. ``The Oakland ordinance is so comprehensive, so complete, so all-encompassing that it is invalid on its face,'' the judge said. ``(It) cannot help but conflict with the rights of the federal government.'' The ruling is a potentially serious blow to a spreading campaign by anti-nuclear activists to put teeth into previously symbolic nuclear-free ordinances, chiefly by limiting local government purchases and investments. A similar measure is on the June ballot in Alameda County, home of the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, where many of the nation's nuclear weapons are designed. City Councilman Wilson Riles Jr., a supporter of the Oakland ordinance, predicted that most of it would be revived by a higher court. ``A lot of the things Oakland is trying to do with respect to protecting the health and welfare of its citizens have long standing in the law,'' Riles said. He said ordinances imposing similar restrictions on South Africa-related purchases and investments have been upheld in court. Steve Bloom, principal draftsman of the ordinance and coordinator of a group called Nuclear-Free California, said the decision was ``the kind of ruling Vukasin was appointed (by former President Ronald Reagan) to make, not based on law but based on political expediency.'' Vukasin said he would issue a written decision later. It was not clear whether his ruling extended to portions of the ordinance that do not involve the government directly, such as a ban on city purchases of products made by companies engaged in nuclear weapons work. But the government's suit argued that enforcement of the ordinance against its private contractors would also harm the national defense. ``Private contractors are relied on a great deal by the United States top carry out the national defense,'' Justice Department lawyer Richard Stearns told Vukasin. He said any effort by the city to ``punish contractors by denying them business with the city'' would harm the government as well. The only provisions expressly exempted from the ruling allow the city to limit its investments in government securities and post ``nuclear-free-zone'' signs at its borders. Those provisions were not challenged by the government. The Oakland ordinance, approved by a 57 percent vote in November 1988, declared that all ``nuclear weapons work,'' including production, storage or classified research on nuclear weapons, would be outlawed within two years in the city of 350,000. It also prohibited all city contracts and investments with nuclear weapons-makers, unless no reasonable alternatives existed, and authorized the City Council to choose the safest routes for shipment of radioactive material.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Says U.S. Policy Hurts Angola, Namibia
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said Friday that the United States is making a grave mistake in assisting rebels fighting Angola's leftist government and is depriving Namibia of needed help. He called for a Marshall Plan for Namibia and southern Africa. The civil rights leader and politician said newly independent Namibia is getting $10 million in U.S. assistance, compared to $500 million for Poland. The Marshall Plan, first urged in 1947 by then-Secretary of State George C. Marshall, fostered European economic recovery after World War II through enormous infusions of U.S. aid. Jackson spoke during a news conference sponsored by the Organization of African Unity dealing with Namibia's achieving independence this month from South Africa. Jackson said ``troublesome signs'' were emerging in U.S.-southern African policy. He called it ``incoherent'' and asked for a ``comprehensive plan and real commitment to end apartheid.'' In Angola, he said, the United States was wrongly aiding rebels led by Jonas Savimbi. He said the United States is sending the wrong signal to southern Africa at a time when the Angolan government has announced direct peace talks with the rebels and is trying to liberalize its centralized economy. Jackson also said he learned through a newspaper article that the United States was evading its own sanctions on South Africa and was wrongly allowing imports of South African steel, through a technicality. ``When we find this steel, we should protest and hold vigils against it,'' he said. He called on states, municipalities and individuals to oppose such imports. ``We need to keep strict sanctions against South Africa,'' he said. Black leader ``Nelson Mandela is out of jail, but he is not free. But (Solidarity leader) Lech Walesa of Poland is truly free.''

DOC.HEAD: Talk Canceled Because of Actress' Abortion Views
DOC.TEXT: Actress Marcia Wallace's scheduled appearance at a hospital cancer program this weekend has been canceled because of her pro-choice position on abortion. The actress, probably best known for her role as Bob Newhart's receptionist on ``The Bob Newhart Show'' in the 1970s, was scheduled to speak about her successful fight against breast cancer during a breast cancer awareness and education program. Officials at Providence-St. Margaret Health Center made the decision Tuesday after the actress refused to take a ``no comment'' stance if the abortion issue arose, said spokeswoman Therese Horvat. The hospital, which is anti-abortion, feared that Ms. Wallace might talk about her abortion views if asked by the media or someone else attending the event, Ms. Horvat said in a statement Thursday. Ms. Wallace said in a telephone interview from her Los Angeles home that she was upset with the hospital's decision because her views on abortion had nothing to do with her fight against cancer. She said she had no intention of raising the abortion issue in her talk and had never taken a public stand. It came up only when the hospital asked her for her views, she said Thursday. ``I cannot imagine why the hospital thought I would bring it up,'' she said. ``I don't get the connection, but I hope women really take advantage of the cancer awareness program.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Announces Price Hikes, Higher Indirect Taxes
DOC.TEXT: The new government on Friday announced an economic austerity program including price increases, higher indirect taxes and cuts in inflation-linked pay raises for public employees. The moves came only hours after Premier Constantine Mitsotakis and his conservative party won a vote of confidence in Parliament. The measures, aimed at increasing state income by $2.4 billion this year, are also expected to trigger higher inflation, National Economy Minister George Souflias told journalists. As it was, inflation hit 17.8 percent in March. Consumers will quickly feel the pinch. Under the program, electricity rates will rise by 12 percent, postal services by 15 percent, train tickets by 25 percent and domestic airfares by 25 percent. ``We have reached a dead end,'' Souflias said. ``Of every 100 drachmas the state spends it has to borrow 40. This has to come to an end.'' Mitsotakis told lawmakers before the confidence vote that the total public debt would be $91.4 billion by the end of the year. Souflias said uncoupling state workers' pay and inflation will mean a wage reduction of 6 percent in real terms. But he said it would increase state revenue by $457 million. Companies and professionals will pay an extra 7 percent surtax on profits this year. Fuel prices will rise immediately, with super-grade gasoline going from $2 per gallon to $2.68. The value added tax will increase, as will alcohol and tobacco taxes. The conservative New Democracy party won elections on April 8, following two inconclusive polls last year. Mitsotakis has placed the blame for the current economic woes on his Socialist predecessors, who ruled for eight years.

DOC.HEAD: State Won't Spray Malathion on Kangaroo Rats' Home Turf
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of aerial spraying against the Medfly are angry over a state decision to ban spraying in an area where the endangered kangaroo rat roams. ``This says to me that kangaroo rats are more important than humans,'' said Adelaide Nimitz of Burbank, who heads a group called Families Opposed to Chemical Urban Spraying. The decision marked the second time this year the state has granted an exemption from the malathion spraying program that some people fear poses health hazards to humans. Three months ago, state agricultural officials angered Orange County residents by ordering helicopters to spray around the Rev. Robert H. Schuller's Crystal Cathedral in Garden Grove because of an outdoor event, attended by several thousand guests, that coincided with the spraying. After the outcry, the state pledged to stop issuing exemptions _ until the kangaroo rat matter came up. State officials say federal law protecting endangered species left them no choice but to avoid spraying areas where the rat lives. The kangaraoo rat is a small, long-legged desert rodent known for its jumping ability. ``This is a whole different thing,'' said Pat Minyard, deputy director of the Medfly Project in El Monte. ``There's a radical difference between doing something to be nice guys as in the case of Crystal Cathedral and doing something because of the law.'' The exemption affects a 5-square-mile area where the rats live within a 19-square-mile Medfly spraying zone near Woodcrest and March Air Force Base. ``I'm just appalled to think that rats have more rights in the state's eyes than I do or my children,'' said Garden Grove anti-malathion activist Mollie Haines. Malathion has been sprayed for months over a wide area of Los Angeles County. Recent Medfly discoveries in Orange, San Bernardino and Riverside counties prompted officials to widen spraying zones. Mediterranean fruit flies are under attack because they threaten the state's multibillion dollar farm economy.

DOC.HEAD: Gabon Gets New Prime Minister To Oversee Democratic Reform
DOC.TEXT: President Omar Bongo on Friday named a new prime minister to oversee the transition to a multiparty democracy in this Central African nation. Bongo, who named Casimir Oye-Mba as the new prime minister, said in a nationwide television address that Gabon is at the dawn of a new era with a commitment ``to the democratic process.'' Bongo has ruled this small, oil-rich nation since Nov. 28, 1967. He has been under pressure for months to end one-party rule. Anti-government demonstrations turned into riots in the capital, Libreville, and in the oil center of Port Gentil. Last week Bongo met with opposition leaders and agreed to permit opposition parties to contest the next legislative elections against his Gabonese Democratic Party. No election date was set. The opposition also demanded that Bongo appoint a new government before the elections. Friday night, Bongo announced Prime Minister Leon Mebiame would be replaced by Oye-Mba, who would set up a new government. Mebiame had been a leading member of Bongo's government for 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Rally To Support President Iliescu
LaserPhoto XBUC2
DOC.TEXT: Romanians gathered at one of the biggest rallies since the December revolution Friday in support of interim President Ion Iliescu and in defiance of anti-communist protesters seeking his resignation. Iliescu is the target of a six-day, round-the-clock protest by Romanians who doubt he has really abandoned communism. On Friday he urged more than 10,000 supporters to exercise tolerance of opposition views, but attacked those who want him to step down. ``They can't rebuild the country if they choose to camp out on the street without working,'' he told the crowd overflowing the square in front of the military academy. Iliescu, 60, a former Communist Party secretary under Nicolae Ceausescu, fell from Ceausescu's favor after opposing the dictator and was given relatively minor party posts. He rose to prominence in the revolution that toppled Ceausescu _ who was executed Christmas Day _ and resulted in the disintegration of the Communist Party. His foes accuse Iliescu and others in the National Salvation Front of seeking to re-establish some form of Marxist rule, despite repeated assertions that the Front embraces democracy. The Front dominates the interim government running Romania until May 20 elections. Both Iliescu and Premier Petre Roman, another former Communist, sought at the rally to emphasize their commitment to a pluralistic democracy and a market economy. The president characterized the demise of communism as ``an irreversible process taking place in all the countries which were subjected to the so-called socialist society.'' Iliescu defended his opposition to rapid economic change, saying, ``It's well-known that we have already taken steps toward a market economy ... but a brusque change is an adventure.'' ``We have been burned before by the automatic transplanting of foreign models here,'' Iliescu said, clearly alluding to the disastrous attempt to introduce the Soviet system of the early 1950s that placed emphasis on heavy industry. The trial of Nicolae Andruta Ceausescu, former head of the Securitate secret police academy and brother of the dictator, was suspended on Friday until May 29. The prosecution said it needed time to investigate further. The panel of three military judges held that not enough evidence now existed for a verdict. He is charged with ordering his cadets to fire on demonstrators during the revolution and killing seven protesters himself.

DOC.HEAD: Security Guard Injured in Explosion at CBN
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to CORRECT spelling of guard's name to Scheepers sted Sheepers, UPDATE with quotes from guard and raise reference to earlier attacks. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `This is evidence...
DOC.TEXT: A bomb in a package addressed to the Rev. Pat Robertson exploded Friday at his Christian Broadcasting Network's mailroom, injuring a security guard, CBN officials said. Police confirmed there was a bombing but refused to release details. Robertson said the package was addressed to him, and suggested it could be related to recent attacks on a Houston preacher and gospel singer Sandi Patti. ``This could be part of a pattern of attacks against evangelical Christians,'' Robertson said. The package had a North Carolina postmark and looked suspicious to station workers, said Frankie Abourjilie, a CBN spokeswoman. Security guard Scott Scheepers was summoned, and the bomb exploded when he opened the package, Mrs. Abourjilie said. Scheepers, 33, was taken to Sentara Norfolk General Hospital, were he was in stable condition with shrapnel wounds in his left leg, said hospital spokeswoman Rhonda Hoover. Scheepers, who estimated he has handled 75 to 80 suspicious packages, said from his hospital bed that he opened the brown-paper parcel only after checking it twice with an X-ray machine. ``It appeared to be safe, it wasn't heavy at all,'' he said. ``I'd opened it about a half-inch and it just exploded.'' Robertson, a 1988 Republican presidential hopeful, noted two recent attacks _ the explosion of a letter bomb at the church of the Rev. John Osteen of Houston that injured his daughter and an arson fire at the Indiana recording studio of gospel singer Sandi Patti. ``This is evidence of extreme hatred by some deranged individuals who want to silence the Christian voice in this country,'' Robertson said. ``They should realize that devices sent through the mail will never reach those for whom they are intended. Their victims will be innocent men and women who have devoted their lives to serving God.'' Virginia Beach police spokesman Lou Thurston declined to give details about Friday's bomb. ``We don't want to jeopardize our investigation or prosecution,'' Thurston said. He said the explosion caused no damage but debris from the package was scattered about. Participating in the investigation were officers of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, the FBI, postal inspectors, state and city police and the city fire dpeartment. Robertson said the bomb was a ``crude device. If it had been a bit more sophisticated, it would have killed Scott.'' Robertson, whose ``The 700 Club'' TV program is seen by an estimated 965,000 households daily, said he did not plan to tighten security. ``What we have to recognize as Christians is we are in a spiritual battle. The work we are doing is effective but dangerous. It's a front line activity,'' said Robertson, who noted he receives monthly death threats. On Jan. 30, a shoebox size package exploded in the lap of Osteen's daughter, Lisa, in Houston. She was not seriously injured. Houston police said the package was postmarked from North Carolina. On April 17, Ms. Patti's recording studio in Anderson, Ind., was heavily damaged by arson. An anonymous caller claiming to represent a group called the Equal Religious Coalition claimed responsibility for the blaze and said the studio was burned because Ms. Patti ``put herself on the pedestal of God.'' Police in Anderson said they had never heard of the group but were taking the claims seriously.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms in South and Midwest; Snow in Plains; Heat in East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after lead to UPDATE with Texas twisters.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BRY1
DOC.TEXT: A late-season snowstorm blasted parts of the high Plains on Friday, while thunderstorms, tornados and hail moved on to bedevil the South and Midwest after deluging Texas with killer floods. In Texas, high winds from at least 18 twisters and large hail damaged houses and toppled power lines and trees Friday after three days of severe thunderstorms. No major damage or injuries were reported. But in the East, many were surprised by unseasonable weather of a different kind: Temperatures soared as high as the low 90s, toppling records from Cape Hatteras, N.C., to Sault Ste. Marie, Mich. Snow fell over parts of the Dakotas, Nebraska and Wyoming on Friday, and wind from the icy blast toppled power lines, temporarily blacking out up to 30,000 homes in the Black Hills of South Dakota. Power was restored to most customers within two hours of the early-morning blackout, power company officials said. Snow piled up to 7 inches deep in the Black Hills overnight, 6 inches at Gillette, Wyo., and 5 inches at Sundance, Wyo. Forecasters warned more snow and freezing rain could fall Saturday over parts of the Dakotas, western Montana and Idaho. Snow was forecast Friday night in the mountains of northeastern Oregon and the Cascade Range. A band of thunderstorms stretched from eastern Texas across to Alabama and up through the Midwest on Saturday, producing small hail at Des Peres, Mo., and freezing rain in Minnesota. Tornado watches were posted in Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama. In Texas, some communities ravaged Thursday by the storm system began to return to normal Friday, but hard-hit Brown and Parker counties in the north-central part of the state remained flooded. Workers struggled Friday to contain at least 2,500 gallons of crude oil that spilled into Bass Lake, about 120 miles southwest of Dallas, when pressure from high water burst a pipeline. They hoped to stop the oil from flowing down the Sabana River to Lake Proctor, a water source for three counties. The line of storms was forecast to continue east Saturday, stretching from Alabama to Michigan. Snow or rain was forecast for the high Plains, while the rest of the country was expected to get clear or partly cloudy skies. Among the spots where temperature records were broken Friday were Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., 83; Toledo, Ohio, 87; Syracuse, N.Y., 88; Boston, 92; Newark, 91 and Cape Hatteras, 89. The low for the nation this Friday was 19 degrees at Big Piney, Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Gloria Estefan Files Lawsuit in Bus Accident
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for singer Gloria Estefan filed suit in federal court Thursday seeking damages for a March accident that broke two vertebrae in her back. The lawsuit named two truck drivers, their employers and other companies associated with the trucking firms at the time of the accident. Ms. Estefan, lead singer of the Miami Sound Machine, was joined in the lawsuit by her husband, Emilio; her son, Nayib; her personal aide, Barbara Arencibia, and her son's tutor, Lori Rooney. Estefan works with his wife as her producer and manager. The lawsuit seeks damages in excess of $50,000 on each of eight separate counts filed on behalf of the singer, individually and jointly. The other plaintiffs are also seeking more than $50,000 each on numerous counts. Named as defendants were Heraldo E. Samuels; Ventura Transport, Inc.; Flexi-Van Leasing, Inc.; Maersk, Inc.; Maersk Canada, Inc.; Maersk Line Limited, Maersk Container Service Co., Inc.; Anthony D. Naro and Naro Enterprises, Inc. The lawsuit charges the defendants with recklessness, carelessness and negligence and alleges Ms. Estefan, ``a world famous professional performer and entertainer,'' was prevented from pursuing her profession, which resulted in the loss of ``many millions of dollars.'' Ms. Estefan and her family and staff were headed from Washington, D.C., to a concert engagement at Syracuse, N.Y., when their bus came upon the scene of a tractor-trailer accident shortly after noon on March 20. The truck, operated by Naro, an employee of Naro Enterprises, had jack-knifed, bringing westbound traffic on Interstate 380 to a standstill. As the bus waited in traffic, it was rear-ended by another tractor-trailer, operated by Samuels, an employee of Ventura Transport. The truck was owned by Flexi-van Leasing, and was hauling a Maersk container, the suit charged. The accident left Ms. Estefan with two broken vertebrae. The day after the accident, she was airlifted from a Scranton where she was initially treated, to the Orthopedic Institute Hospital for Joint Diseases in New York City, N.Y. Surgery to repair her back was performed in New York and she later moved back to her Miami area home to recuperate. She has not yet resumed her career.

DOC.HEAD: NIreland Authorities Warn Serious IRA Attacks May Be Imminent
DOC.TEXT: Police in Northern Ireland on Thursday called for public vigilance to try to stave off an expected series of attacks by the Irish Republican Army. The British domestic news agency Press Association quoted unidentified sources as saying the warning was not a routine one, and that it was based on intelligence information that a wave of bombing and shooting attacks was planned. The Royal Ulster Constabulary headquarters warned the public to be ``extremely vigilant'' in ``the period immediately ahead,'' and asked people to report anything suspicious. News reports meanwhile said Thursday that police believed a 23-year-old Protestant man gunned down in a Roman Catholic neighborhood was slain by a Protestant gang. Brian McKimm, a father of three, was hit by several gunshots Wednesday night as he walked along the boundary of the Ligoniel housing estate, police said. He lived in a Protestant area nearly. Press Association, BBC-TV and Channel 4 TV News reported that police believe the killers were Loyalist extremists, but a spokesman in the Royal Ulster Constabulary press office declined to comment on those reports. Witnesses said four gunmen drove away slowly in two cars, as if they were looking for other targets, according to Press Association. Belfast council member Brian Feeney, of the predominantly Roman Catholic Social Democratic and Labor Party, on Thursday called the slaying a reminder of ``the terrifying random nature of attacks by Loyalist gangs.'' Loyalist extremists favor British rule in the Protestant-dominated province while the Irish Republican Army and other republican groups are fighting to unite Northern Ireland with the overwhelmingly Catholic Republic of Ireland. McKimm was the 19th person to die in political and sectarian violence this year in Northern Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Shooting of Two Policemen Prompts Dragnet in Lima's Shantytowns
DOC.TEXT: Maoist Shining Path rebels gunned down two policemen Thursday who were eating breakfast at a roadside restaurant north of Lima, police said. The rebels then blew up the officers' car and fled on foot, abandoning their own auto near the site of the attack, 14 miles north of the capital. The shootings set off a police manhunt in Lima's northern and western shantytowns. Dozens of buses were stopped and hundreds of people detained. The night before, acting on information that an attack was imminent, police rounded up more than 4,000 people in a similar sweep of Lima shantytowns. Meanwhile, police said Thursday that six members of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement had died in a battle Wednesday night with police in the central Andean town of Chupaca. Police said they suffered no casualties in the attack on their post by about 50 guerrillas. The pro-Cuban group, which took up arms in 1984, is a smaller, less radical guerrilla organization than the Shining Path. The first half of April was the bloodiest two-week period since the Shining Path rebels took up arms in 1980. The government said about 300 people died in political violence during the period, immediately before and after general elections. More than 18,000 people have died in Peru's political violence since 1980, the government says.

DOC.HEAD: Haitian Demonstrators Protest Army Violence
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ More than 500 demonstrators marched through the capital on Thursday chanting slogans demanding an end to army violence and asking for justice for victims of military repression. The marchers, mostly young slum dwellers, moved along to drumbeats, carrying signs reading ``There is no Democracy without Justice!'' and ``Justice before elections!'' The protest was called in memory of seven people killed in front of the prison fortress Fort Dimanche during a demonstration in 1986. The prison has been closed. ``We must stand up and be heard, so that the government will satisfy the people's demands,'' read a communique of the leftist Committee of United Popular Forces that organized the march. The demonstrators also protested army occupation last week of Cabaret, a village outside the capital of Port-au-Prince. Residents there were marching to protest a monthlong power outage when soldiers moved in. The army allegedly burned down 34 homes after protesters killed a sergeant who had shot and wounded three people. Almost 50 villagers were arrested and reportedly beaten. Nearly 20 people remain in custody. Thurday's demonstration ended without incident in the public square facing the Presidential Palace. The civilian caretaker government of Mrs. Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, which took power on March 13, is not believed to wield much power with the army, which turned power over to her until elections are held this year. She was named to head a caretaker government after violent demonstrations against the military rule of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril forced him to flee Haiti. The commemorative demonstration began in front of the charred ruins of St. Jean Bosco Church, where goon squads killed at least 12 worshipers and wounded 70 on Sept. 11, 1988. Only one person has been charged with complicity in the incident and no investigation is in progress. Similarly, no one has been charged with the November 1987 election day massacre in which 34 voters were killed at the polls by thugs backed by soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: Li Peng Returns From Soviet Summit
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng on Friday returned from a four-day visit to the Soviet Union. He was China's first head of government to make the trip in 26 years and helped to mend relations between the two Communist giants. During Li's meetings with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov, the two sides agreed to improve political and economic relations and work toward easing military tension along their common border. According to official reports, the leaders discussed the war in Cambodia, the Korean peninsula and disarmament. The Soviet Union, which has had increasing unofficial contacts with Taiwan, expressed support for the Chinese position that Taiwan is an inalienable part of the territory of the People's Republic of China. Li, who favors strong central control over the economy, also discussed the two countries' reform policies with Gorbachev, and the two leaders agreed there is no single model for realizing communist ideals. Chinese leaders are reportedly critical of Gorbachev's policies of perestroika and glasnost _ restructuring and openness _ and blame the Soviet reforms for East Europe's rejection of traditional socialist models. The Soviet Union was China's main benefactor and closest ally from 1949, when the Chinese communists gained power, until 1960. Differences over ideology led to a split in the early 1960s, and the two fought a brief border war in 1969. Relations have slowly improved since the mid-1980s but were not formally normalized until Gorbachev visited Beijing last May. The last Chinese premier to visit Moscow was Li's foster father, Chou En-lai, in 1964. During Li's visit, agreements were signed on cooperation in energy, transport, agriculture, environmental protection and space. The two sides agreed to mutually reduce armed forces on the 4,300-mile border and keep troops to a ``minimum corresponding to normal good-neighborly relations.'' China said it will grant credits to the Soviet Union to buy $330 million worth of consumer goods, while the Soviet Union is to provide credits to build two nuclear power plants generating 1 million megawatts each.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Returns to Third State
DOC.TEXT: Perrier returned to a third state Thursday despite a last-minute wrangle with health authorities that took some of the sparkle out of the promotional blitz over the bottled mineral water. Perrier, absent from the market since February because of a chemical scare, was reintroduced in Connecticut and New Jersey on Tuesday. The company _ which has been advertising its impending return for some time _ launched a promotional campaign in New York on Thursday that included passing out the green bottles on Manhattan streets. ``We're calling it Perrier Day,'' said Jane Lazgin, a spokeswoman for Greenwich, Conn.-based Perrier Group of America Inc. Distribution is planned for other states in the east later this month and in the Los Angeles area by mid-May, said. The company recalled its bottled water worldwide in February after tests showed traces of benzene, a cancer-causing chemical. The company said the amounts were so small as to pose no health threat, and said the benzene came from improper filtration of carbon dioxide gas added to the water. Then last week, in the midst of the build-up for reintroduction of Perrier _ in bottles labled ``nouvelle production'' _ the U.S. Food and Drug Administration refused to let the water be labled ``naturally sparkling.'' That brought another round of bad press for Perrier, touted as a healthful, naturally sparkling mineral water. Perrier officials went along, even though they insist the carbonation and water both come from the spring, but the carbon dioxide is separated and filtered before being put back in the water. In New York, reintroduction planned for Wednesday was delayed by yet another disagreement with health regulators, this one over salt content. One of many chemical test results submitted by the company showed higher levels of sodium than allowed under federal standards for products advertising themselves as being low-sodium, said William Fagal, department spokesman. Perrier, already nervous about consumer questions about its purity, said many other tests showed no problems with sodium, he said. The company and Health Department finished negotiating terms of the reintroduction Wednesday night. New York inspectors were still finding old bottles of Perrier from before the recall on store shelves and also wanted to make sure the company had sufficient plans for retrieving them, according to William Stasiuk, director of the Health Department's Center for Environmental Health.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Farmers Dump Potatoes To Protest Government Policy
DOC.TEXT: Angry farmers dumped three truckloads of potatoes and blockaded entrances to the state television building on Thursday to protest government refusal to buy surplus crops. A report on the evening TV news showed passers-by scooping up the potatoes. Earlier, the same farmers drove past the Ministry of Agriculture and Parliament in their trucks. Deputy Prime Minister Czeslaw Janicki received a delegation of farmers and pledged that state-run potato processing plants and other factories would buy some of the surplus. The previous Communist government routinely intervened to purchase surplus crops, but the Solidarity-led government is committed to free market principles. A government economic reform plan that took effect on Jan. 1 ended most state subisidies and price supports. Farmers say the government should compensate them for the drop in demand, especially since the cost of equipment, fuel and electricity have risen significantly. The farmers were also demanding greater access to the media.

DOC.HEAD: Salvador To Renew Contacts With Rebels
DOC.TEXT: President Alfredo Cristiani said Thursday his government will resume peace talks with leftist rebels next week but the talks would be indirect, with a United Nations official acting as a go-between. He told a news conference no specific time and place have yet been set for direct talks, but that U.N. official Alvaro de Soto will be on hand as of May 2 to mediate. De Soto's mission will be mainly to arrange direct talks. The contacts come under an agreement reached in Geneva last month by Cristiani's conservative administration and the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front guerrillas. ``We believe that with the renewal this effort ... we are on our way toward initiating the process of dialogue,'' Cristiani said. Last week, Cristiani said his government planned to resume the talks May 3 in a Central American capital or in Caracas, Venezuela, but did not go into specifics. Human rights groups estimate that 72,000 people, most of them civilians, have been killed since civil war began in El Salvador in October 1979. Attempts to initiate a dialogue by a previous Christian Democratic administration in 1984 and 1985 ended in deadlock. Direct talks between the two side started shortly after Cristiani took office last June, but broke down after the guerrillas launched a major offensive in early November. In a communique, the front on Thursday expressed willingness to resume the talks and said it will continue to refrain from attacking businesses, communications, transportation and civilian government officials. But the communique warned the guerrillas will continue sabotaging the nation's power grid and harassing military positions ``to make sure the government sits down to negotiate.'' In Washington, the House Foreign Affairs Committee voted to halve U.S. military aid to El Salvador and impose strict new conditions on the money. On a voice vote, the Democratic-controlled panel moved to cut the $85 million a year that the United States provides to help El Salvador's military. The action amended a bill that would authorize spending of emergency aid President Bush wants this year for Nicaragua and Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Six-Month Sentence For Dog-Shooting Mailman
DOC.TEXT: A former mail carrier was sentenced to six months in jail Thursday for shooting a dog to death just as its owner was about to hand him his Christmas present. Floyd Bertran Sterling, 35, pleaded no contest to felony cruelty to animals in a plea-bargain agreement with prosecutors on Feb. 21. In return, charges of carrying a concealed weapon and negligent gun use were dropped. Sterling could have faced one year in jail. He was on probation for illegal possession of a handgun at the time of the shooting. ``I have sold all of my guns,'' Sterling told Superior Court Judge Meredith Taylor before sentencing. ``I have no intention of ever owning a gun again.'' The mail carrier killed Tammie Brody's German shepherd mix named Skippy in the front yard of her home on Dec. 26. Brody said her dog was shot just as she was about to hand Sterling a bottle of vodka as a Christmas gift. The shooting was witnessed by Brody's 10-year-old son, Brian. Sterling had said Skippy was a vicious dog and had bitten him before. Brody testified that he ``freaked out'' and fired a .22-caliber revolver without provocation. The bullet entered the dog at the rear and traveled to the front of its body, suggesting the animal may have been shot while running away from Sterling. Taylor imposed sentence after reviewing psychiatric reports on Sterling, who resigned his job in March. The U.S. Postal Service paid the $773.50 bill for Skippy's funeral and burial in a silk-linked casket at a pet cemetery in Calabasas.

DOC.HEAD: Ivana Trump Tries to Cancel `Singles' Contract
DOC.TEXT: The tempestuous Trumps are at it again. Ivana Trump, appalled at press coverage of a pact that allowed her and estranged billionaire husband, Donald, to date, Thursday ordered her attorneys to cancel the contract. But Trump's attorneys said the contract, which reportedly would allow her and Trump to date without providing grounds for divorce, remains in effect. The contract drew attention earlier this week from New York's tabloids which published headlines such as ``Safe Sex,'' and ``Donald and Ivana Playing Singles Games.'' In a statement, Mrs. Trump said the agreement was misunderstood and misrepresented by the press. The intent of the pact, she said, was to protect her children. ``The last thing I want in the world is to start to date,'' Mrs. Trump said. ``I love my husband. Men are the last thing on my mind and I do not want my husband's lawyers to misinterpret my going out socially with friends or having male employees.'' Mrs. Trump also said, ``I cannot be hiding or reclusive for the rest of my life. I want to go on seeing my friends and go on living. I had hoped that this agreement would preclude any speculations about my friends, friendships, male employees.'' Stan Lotwin, Trump's attorney, said he doubted the cancellation would be challenged because, as far as he was concerned, the pact remains in force. Lotwin noted the April 11 contract was to be in effect for 60 days at which point either party could cancel. Of the ``dating'' contract, Lotwin said, ``It was requested by her attorney. It was written by her attorney. And, now, because she doesn't like the public reaction, she wants out,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: New York City, State Reach Agreement on $600M Cleanup of City Dumps
DOC.TEXT: The city and state reached agreement Thursday on a $600 million plan to clean up the city's contaminated garbage dumps, including the world's largest landfill, Fresh Kills on Staten Island. The agreement obligates the city and state to clean up landfills where hazardous wastes were dumped illegally, Mayor David Dinkins and state Environmental Conservation Commissioner Thomas C. Jorling said at a City Hall news conference. ``We all know the damage that we, the human species, have done to our home,'' Dinkins said. ``Now we must begin to undo it.'' The agreement includes a five-year $200 million cleanup at the 3,000-acre, 150-foot-high Fresh Kills landfill, and $400 million to purge four of the city's now-closed dumps of pollutants. Under the agreement, the state has withdrawn its 1989 threat to close the Fresh Kills landfill and dropped the $81 million in fines it had levied against the city. The pact allows the city to operate Fresh Kills until 1998 as long as it goes ahead with cleanup operations. The Fresh Kills facility handles nearly 17,000 tons of solid waste and ash daily and is one of only two operating municipal landfills in the city. It was described in 1981 by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency as an ``open dump.'' Jorling said the agreement represents ``a full commitment by New York City to eliminate the sources of contamination from these major facilities and remove the environmental and public health threats that the landfills pose.'' The agreement paves the way for the city to receive about $300 million under the 1986 state Environmental Quality Bond Act to cover 75 percent of the cost of cleaning up the four closed landfills by 1998. The city already has collected $30 million in settlements from 13 corporations that generated toxic waste in a case involving Exxon, the mayor's office said. The city has filed claims against 150 other companies it said were responsible for pollution. Any proceeds from the lawsuit will be used to pay for the cleanup operations at the four inactive landfills.

DOC.HEAD: Hedrick Smith Redux: `Inside Gorbachev's U.S.S.R.'
DOC.TEXT: It was 1971, and Nikita Khrushchev was three days dead without a mention in the Soviet press. Hedrick Smith, in his first week as Moscow bureau chief for The New York Times, went for the man-in-the-street angle. ``They didn't want to talk to me. They ran the other way,'' Smith said. But that was before Mikhail Gorbachev's glasnost opened Soviet society. It was different in May 1988, when Smith was beginning work on ``Inside Gorbachev's U.S.S.R.,'' an insightful, four-part series starting tonight on PBS. Again, he went for the man-in-the-street interview. ``Instead of having people run the other way, they gathered,'' Smith said. Some even complained about their country. And even though they were surrounded by police, no one was shouted down or dragged away. ``To have that happening on the street and to hear the kinds of things people had to say was just an extraordinary change for me,'' said Smith, a two-time Pulitzer Prize-winner and author of the 1976 best seller ``The Russians.'' ``Inside Gorbachev's U.S.S.R.'' puts a fascinating, human face on the fundamental changes resulting from Gorbachev's doctrine of perestroika, or restructuring of Soviet society. ``I don't think that people in America understand the enormity of the change,'' Smith said. ``We're talking about people being jerked bodily into the 21st century from a mentality somewhere in the autocratic 18th or 19th century.'' The four programs cover the changes in Soviet politics, the mass media, the foundering economy and the recent tumultuous events in the ethnic republics. The first episode, ``The Taste of Democracy,'' examines the foundations of perestroika, using excellent archival photos and footage to track Gorbachev's rise to power and the systemic failure of the Soviet bureaucracy. It also identifies Nikita Khrushchev's denunciation of Josef Stalin in 1956 as the central event of Gorbachev's political generation, and documents the Soviets' growing awareness of their power over their government and themselves. The second installment, ``Comfortable Lies, Bitter Truths,'' shows the burgeoning influence of Soviet television, and the Soviets painfully relearning and rewriting their own history. The episode, elegiacally photographed by Wiley Foster, visits the forests of Kuropaty, one of eight mass gravesites around Minsk holding the bodies of an estimated 250,000 victims of Stalin's purges. It is powerful and moving. ``That's one of the most horrible places I have ever been,'' Smith said in a small, sad voice, describing a forest pocked with thousands of declivities, each marking six to a dozen bodies. ``The land ... it looks like it's got scarlet fever,'' he said, his voice breaking. ``The holes everywhere ... there's no way a camera can get how many there are.'' The third episode, ``In Search of Perestroika,'' shows a centralized economy frustrating its fledgling capitalists and its state factory managers, who face shortages of labor, raw materials, transportation and marketing. It's in the economic domain where Gorbachev's moderation most clearly is failing, Smith said. ``Piecemeal measures just ain't going to work,'' he said. ``I really do wonder whether he has not gotten about as far as he can go.'' The fourth installment, ``Coming Apart,'' focuses on the restive republics of Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan and Lithuania. Smith said he expects Gorbachev's U.S.S.R. in the next quarter-century to reflect a ``roller coaster'' of conservatism vying with liberal reform. The Soviet Union, he said, has to make up for 200 years of history that took place in the West. Can Gorbachev succeed? ``In a way, the answer is that he could succeed wildly in the next five years and disappear,'' Smith said. ``Somebody else would come along and you'd still be asking the same questions, because the task is so enormous.''

Elsewhere in television ... TIMESHIFTER ALERT DEPT.: PBS opens the May sweeps Tuesday with a rattling good edition of ``Frontline,'' which is far and away the best _ some say the only _ investigative journalism on television. If you've ever wondered how the savings and loan debacle came to be, watch ``Other People's Money,'' a long, hard look at Charles Keating Jr.'s stewardship of the Lincoln Savings and Loan. It is a balanced account of how Keating, in just five years, took the billion-dollar thrift more than $2 billion into debt while piling up tremendous political capital with a group of U.S. senators dubbed ``The Keating Five.'' The program was produced by Marion Goldin, a former producer for CBS' ``60 Minutes'' and ABC's ``20-20,'' and reported by Ms. Goldin and Joe Rosenbloom. They just don't do this kind of reporting on network TV any more. Check your local listings and pounce.

DOC.HEAD: Oprah Winfrey Back In ABC's ``Brewster's Place''
DOC.TEXT: Oprah Winfrey's ``Brewster Place,'' which began as the high-rated ``The Women of Brewster Place'' miniseries of last year, starts life anew tonight as a half-hour ABC series. Alas, it has an oddly tame, although pleasant, premiere. Filmed in Chicago at Harpo Studios, where Winfrey also does her syndicated talk show, the series is about the lives of big-city blacks in 1967. It has a lot of things going for it, particularly Winfrey's acting. She's eminently believable as the lead character, Mattie Michael, a wise, steady single woman to whom fate has dealt a few hard knocks, but who faces life with dignity and a certain down-home grace. The show's other pluses: an optimistic view of life, a fine ensemble cast and David Shire's sprightly, lovely no-words theme song that verges close to Bach in its rendition by the fine a capella group, Take Six. (A first-rate singer and composer, Oscar Brown Jr., also lurks in the cast as Jessie, the husband of the neighborhood busybody.) But the show's future episodes are going to need a bit more bite and true grit if the series is to make its way in this wicked world, a world in which the new buzz phrase of networks is ``get weird,'' as in ``Twin Peaks.'' Co-written by Earl Hamner, who did ``The Waltons,'' the premiere is a gentle lesson on the need, after misfortune strikes, to pick yourself up, dust yourself off and start all over again, preferably in a new direction. But Winfrey's Michael, with all her strength, can't bring herself to make such a dramatic move, even when fired from her hairdresser's job at a local beauty parlor after refusing to help bilk her trusting customers. Save for work as a domestic, her job prospects are dim because of her lack of formal education and skills that could lead to, say, a secretary's job. She has a nest egg that she's saved up in recent years. But she can't bring herself to bet it on herself in a business venture. The reason: she was financially ruined before by her own son. It turns out he had been arrested _ the charge isn't specified _ and jumped bail. He left his mother, who had put up her home as security for bail money, flat broke. When she's fired from her hairdresser's job, her best friend, Etta Mae (Brenda Pressley), urges a big change _ becoming her partner in a local Italian restaurant. Etta Mae has a beau who will loan her half the money. Etta Mae isn't embarrassed that her friend says she's dreaming. ``Damn right,'' she snaps. ``And you look to me like you could use a good dream.'' The restaurant is being sold by an old, decent man who blames age, not the changing racial nature of the neighborhood, for the slide in his business. ``The neighborhood's changed,'' he says. `` All my customers, they got old like me, moved to Miami.'' There are such men, to be sure. But this suggestion of racial harmony just doesn't ring true. Neither does the generally sweet, good-hearted nature of most everyone in and around this make-believe Brewster Place. And you know, almost from the start, that Mattie is going to see the light and take a chance. Of course, that's after other characters are established and she helps her widowed cousin and his three kids, all fresh in from Arkansas, move into their new Brewster Place apartment. In a way, the opening show is almost a black urban counterpart of Hamner's ``The Waltons,'' with its emphasis on decency and optimism, and even occasional narration by the lead charatcer. It's all well and good to revive what that rural, predominantly white-cast CBS series represented _ kinder, gentler television. But a bit more realism would help ``Brewster Place,'' too. Incidentally, the show will be seen again next Tuesday. The day after that, it will settle into ABC's Wednesday night schedule. Two Tuesday showings may seem an odd way to get a Wednesday night series going. But gosh, folks, that's why they invented TV executives.

Elsewhere in television ... AL FLOSS, THE SEQUEL: Not really. But CBS is returning ``The Famous Teddy Z,'' complete with Alex Rocco as noted agent Floss, to its schedule this month, along with the low-rated new ``City'' starring Valerie Harper. New episodes of two comedies will go into the Saturday slot of ``Tour of Duty'' on May 12 when CBS' Vietnam War series finishes its original episodes. According to a CBS spokesman, ``Teddy Z'' has eight new episodes ready. ``City,'' a midseason entry that CBS removed from its schedule on April 16, has but three new shows in the wings.
