DOC.HEAD: Liberia 10 Years Later: Economic Collapse and Civil War
DOC.TEXT: Many Liberians cheered 10 years ago when a young army sergeant threw out the autocratic old order, but no more. Now Samuel K. Doe presides over a shattered economy and civil war is feeding tribal hatreds. Some who welcomed the coup even wish for the days before President Doe, when this West African country was dominated by a small elite descended from the freed American slaves who founded it in 1847. At a banquet April 12, the coup anniversary, Doe blamed the poor economy and high unemployment on low world prices for Liberia's raw materials. The president, now a portly, self-appointed general, told the scores of diplomats, officials and business leaders invited for Redemption Day: ``We recall the events of the past 10 years with considerable pride.'' Applause for the speech was so feeble the master of ceremonies exhorted guests to raise a cheer. A Liberian muttered, ``What we need is redemption from Doe.'' Doe has changed army commanders five times in an effort to defeat rebels led by Charles Taylor, a former aide who was accused of embezzlement and fired. Army soldiers have held Ganta, a garrison town, but lost most of the rest of Nimba County, an area of 4,400 square miles that juts east between Guinea on the north and Ivory Coast. Since Dec. 24, when they invaded Nimba from Ivory Coast, Taylor's ragtag rebels have pushed south into River Cess County, southwest to Grand Bassa County and west to Bong County. They have halted traffic on the railroad serving an iron mine that normally earns half Liberia's foreign exchange. All but two of the Americans and Britons who run the mine have left. Nimba, which covers about 10 percent of the country, is an area of dense forests, highlands and mountains. It produced more than 20 percent of Liberia's food, but at least four-fifths of its 350,000 people have fled the fighting to Ivory Coast, Guinea and other parts of their own country. Killing, raping and looting by government soldiers have won the rebels hundreds of recruits. What could have been a minor rebellion has become a major tribal conflict. Most of the refugees are of the Gio and Mano tribes, as are many rebels. Members of those tribes have been army targets, and rebels retaliate by killing civilians of Doe's Krahn tribe and the Mandingo tribe, which supports Doe. No one knows how many civilians have been killed. International human rights organizations and aid agencies estimate soldiers have killed hundreds of civilians and the rebels have slain scores. Diplomats and aid workers in Monrovia said rebels ``lined up and shot'' Krahn and Mandingo civilians when they captured Kombo Town in River Cess County, southwest of Nimba. Refugees admitted seeing such reprisals. Young men have been pressed into service to strengthen the 5,000-man army and criminals freed by presidential amnesty have been put into uniform, Liberian and Western sources reported. ``Most of them fire 15 shots in training,'' a European diplomat said. ``They are a frightened, illiterate, superstitious bunch expected to put their lives on the line for $1.50 a day.'' Many desert, but the government denies it. The government will not say what the war costs, but Doe announced in January he was diverting money set aside to register voters for 1991 elections. By Redemption Day, many civil servants had not been paid for three months. Taylor, the 42-year-old rebel leader, escaped from a jail in the United States in 1984. He was being held for extradition to face charges of embezzling $1 million. Thousands of Liberians embraced the revolution when Doe seized power April 12, 1980, even though he killed ousted President William S. Tolbert and 30 other prominent Americos, as the descendants of Liberia's founders are called. The 29-year-old master sergeant promised equality regardless of tribe and an end to corruption, human rights abuses, nepotism and domination by the Americos. Doe also pledged to return power to civilians. He delivered economic collapse and brutal repression of dissent. He held an election and won it, but Western diplomats say it was rigged. Then came the rebellion. ``Tribal hatred engendered by the conflict is terrifying,'' one Liberian said. ``Many of us are saying our only hope is to look for a leader among reasonably minded Americos.'' William Gabriel Kpoleh, leader of the opposition Liberian Unification Party, said: ``What Doe has done is replace one privileged set of rulers with another, his Krahn tribe.'' Kpoleh was freed last month by presidential pardon after serving two years in jail for plotting against Doe. The charges were phony, he said in an interview at the office of a friend. Security agents told the friend ``they will burn down his building if he lets me work here,'' Kpoleh said. Last month, the offices of the independent Daily Observer in Monrovia burned down. A night watchman said four men in military uniforms set the fire and told him it was punishment for anti-government reports. Two U.S. government warehouses were destroyed by fire, just as U.S. relations with Liberia reached their lowest ebb. American aid, including millions for the military, used to be the highest per capita in sub-Saharan Africa, totaling more than $500 million in 1980-85. It was cut to $10 million this year by congressmen who cited human rights abuses and failure to repay loans. Doe told reporters recently his government has faced ``all kinds of coup attempts and invasions'' intended to ``discourage potential investors.'' Businessmen say corruption is enough deterrent, that Liberia is rich in resources but Doe has emulated previous administrations whose leaders looked after themselves. Miners from Lebanon extract gold and diamonds, one businessman said, ``But the country gets little out of it because they pay huge bribes to government officials to smuggle them out.'' There is little industry. Liberia is one of the world's richest sources of rubber, but imports tires. An overvalued currency, set at parity with the U.S. dollar, makes imports expensive. Grapefruit and pineapples are grown in Liberia, but restaurants offer imported canned juices at up to $5 a glass. ``It's easy to ask what a country of just 2.2 million people did with all the aid money,'' former Finance Minister David M. Farhat said in an interview. ``Most of it was poured into projects that are completely useless.'' Kpoleh said Doe's bloody method of dealing with rivals sickens Liberians. It began with the killings at the time of the coup. Since then, more than 20 government ministers and army officers have been executed for allegedly plotting coups, and dozens more have died in unexplained circumstances.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, May 6

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Refugees Overrun Guinean Villages
With A Decade of Doe
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of refugees fleeing the brutality of Liberian soldiers are crossing the border and inundating villages like Gossopa. Many are filled with tribal hatred and vow to return home for revenge. ``They killed my mother. They killed my sister. They killed my little brother,'' a 34-year-old businessman said. ``Now, I'm joining the rebels and I'm going to kill them, especially those Krahns.'' Liberia's president, Samuel K. Doe, is of the Krahn tribe. Guinean officials complain of slow international response to help feed a refugee population they said had doubled in April to more than 150,000. ``Up to now, we have received nothing but promises from the international community, with the exception of France, Ireland and Sierra Leone,'' said Aboubacar Fabou Conde, the second-ranking government official at N'zerekore, a provincial capital near the frontier. The World Food Program said emergency food approved Feb. 26 was bought locally in Conakry, capital of Guinea, and was being sent to the refugee area 635 miles away. Diane Weather, an information officer at the U.N. agency's Rome headquarters, said poor roads along the heavily forested border often deteriorated into rutted tracks, so transportation was uncertain. She said 3,640 tons of rice, canned fish and oil were being sent and would help feed 80,000 people for six months. Ms. Weather said the agency believed the estimate of 150,000 refugees was high. Guineans expressed fear that, by the time the size of the refugee population was recognized, it would be too late to deliver food before a six-month rainy season. ``The Guinean government has done everything it can,'' Conde said. ``Our villagers have exhausted their food reserves and even eaten seed grain, so now there is nothing to plant and the rainy season is upon us.'' Diplomats said politics also had slowed aid. Relief agencies had hoped to move food by truck from Monrovia, capital of Liberia, a drive of six to 10 hours over a good road. The journey from Conakry takes four or five days in the rainy season. Doe's government refused because it wants the refugees repatriated, then the point became moot April 13, when rebels cut the road with an attack on Ganta, near the border. The most recent refugee influx came from Sanniquellie, capital of Nimba County, a part of Liberia that juts east between Guinea and Ivory Coast. The town is believed to have changed hands four times in the second week of April. At N'zerekore, Guinean officials welcomed more than a dozen civil administrators from Sanniquellie. Their abandoned vehicles could be seen across the St. John's River, the border at that point, which they crossed on foot. Gossopa, nearby, normally has 800 residents but was sheltering 3,500 refugees in March and 5,906 in April. Fifteen of the refugees were Liberian army soldiers who fled the fighting across the river. ``We were plotting to kill those soldiers,'' said a 20-year-old high school student. Like other refugees, he would not give his name because he feared for relatives still in Liberia. Warrant Officer George Newray and the other soldiers denied allegations of brutality. Of his own retreat from the fighting, he said: ``The rebels were stronger than us and better armed. My friend was killed beside me when the rebels attacked. We ran out of ammunition, So I decided to effect the army code of SEE: survival, evasion and escape.'' He claimed he ran into and escaped from a white man dressed in an ``olden-time red military dress uniform like the Romans and a gas mask ... who is known to help command rebels.'' Then he was confronted by ``a medicine woman at the rebel command post who started performing juju (magic) and turned into a snake,'' Newray said. Such stories are common. One Liberian in Gossopa said soldiers believe ``rebels hide powder in their pants that makes them disappear or fly away.'' Refugees were openly sympathetic to the rebels, who they said ordered all civilians into Sanniquellie Hospital when they took the town ``because they said they did not want us harmed in the fighting.'' One said refugees had returned regularly for food and other belongings. ``When I went the last time,'' he said, ``the rebels drove me to my house, helped me pack up my belongings, killed my hog for me and transported it to the border.'' After the government announced April 14 that the army had retaken Sanniquellie, they were afraid to return, the refugees said. ``The soldiers steal everything _ food, clothing _ and they burn down our homes,'' one of them told a reporter. Refugees said villagers who remain in Nimba had formed militias allied with the rebels to protect property from marauding troops. The men of Nimba are traditional hunters and most have shotguns.

DOC.HEAD: New Visa Rules Worry Music Industry
DOC.TEXT: Boundaries may be opening worldwide, but some in the entertainment industry say the United States border is getting tougher to cross for anyone with a guitar and the ability to carry a tune. They're concerned that new visa rules will allow superstars such as Paul McCartney to pull in millions at U.S. concerts while singers who have more promise than paychecks are left trying to win over an audience of American immigration officials. ``There's clear and away an aversion by some people to contemporary, international music being brought into this country,'' says Bill Kitchen of Cellar Door Productions, a major East Coast concert promoter. The new U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service rules spell out tougher standards for temporary workers coming into the United States. Would-be visitors have to prove that American workers can't do the same job, and artists have to show they've gained recognition _ and made a living _ at their art. French Culture Minister Jack Lang complained this month that if impressionist painter Vincent van Gogh were working today rather than 100 years ago, he couldn't get a visa for the United States. So far, say promoters and agents, it doesn't appear as if any fledgling Beatles have been turned away at Customs since the new rules took effect Feb. 26. But they say the regulations follow tighter rules over the past decade that have led to some tours being canceled at the last minute. And they fear American stages may be out of reach for artists who can't afford immigration lawyers to lead the way. ``There is a concern about how the regulations could be interpreted,'' said Jeffrey Gabel, an immigration lawyer in New York who has written about the new rules for Billboard magazine. The big change is in the two categories of visas the United States gives to enter the country for temporary employment. In the past, most artists were given H-1 visas, handed out without much question to film directors, singers and groups. The new regulations make clear the H-1 is for aliens of ``distinguished merit and ability'' and ``sustained achievement.'' One-hit wonders aren't favored, while the winner of an Academy Award or Nobel Prize, the INS suggests, should have no trouble getting a H-1. Others are directed to the H-2, which requires an application first to the Labor Department and then to the INS. That can take from two to six months, which concerns entertainers who may not be able to set tour plans more than a few weeks ahead of time. ``We're not getting into judging what they do,'' Rick Kenney, an INS spokesman, said in an interview. ``They would have to show that they're going to be providing a service that's good for the United States.'' It shouldn't hinder the Royal Danish Ballet from touring, but the Philadelphia Orchestra might have to answer a lot of questions if it wants to hire a third violinist from Great Britain. ``We just make judgments of who is and who is not just a regular worker,'' said Kenney. Kitchen recalls that even before the new rules, British folk rocker John Wesley Harding's performance at a Washington club consisted only of an explanation to the crowd that he didn't have a visa to perform. And he says a French rock group, ``Niagara,'' canceled one date and got to play another only after France's cultural attache and Sen. John Warner, R-Va., interceded with immigration officials who were unimpressed with the group's French clippings and videos. ``I have yet to hear an explanation of why a band shouldn't be brought over,'' said Seth Hurwitz, owner of Washington's 9:30 Club, a small venue for international acts on the rise. ``This takes business away from American businessmen like me, and it deprives the American public the chance to see someone they want to see,'' said Hurwitz. The INS says the new rules mean promoters are going to have to be better prepared _ no more booking garage bands from Liverpool on Friday to play in New York next Wednesday. ``You have to be aware that it's going to take more information and you're going to have to file longer in advance,'' said Joel Peresman, an agent with The National Talent Group in New York. ``Unfortunately, this is a big change for everybody,'' said the INS's Kenney. ``It's going to be a change in practice for a lot of people and they're going to have to get used to it and stop taking it personally.'' As for Lang's comment that Dutch-born van Gogh _ who sold only one painting before he died in 1890 _ Kenney says the French official was exaggerating. ``That's just political,'' said Kenney. ``He probably wouldn't get an H-1, but that doesn't mean he'd be denied entry. He would apply for an H-2.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, April 29

DOC.TEXT: Ames Department Stores Inc., the giant discount retailer that stumbled after purchasing the Zayre chain two years ago, has filed for bankruptcy court protection, the company said. The filing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York late Wednesday followed a tumultuous week in which Ames stock traded wildly amid speculation that the chain would seek protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code. ``The Chapter 11 filing will give our suppliers the assurance they need to resume the steady flow of merchandise into our stores,'' Peter B. Hollis, chief executive of the Rocky Hill, Conn.-based chain, said Thursday.

The United States and the Soviet Union reached basic agreement on an economic pact that would normalize trade relations between the two superpowers for the first time in nearly a half century. U.S. Deputy Trade Representative Julius Katz said Thursday he expected the agreement would be ready for signing at the May 30-June 3 summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The agreement would clear the way for the Soviet Union to obtain significantly lower tariffs on its products sold in America while expanding opportunities for U.S. companies to do business in the Soviet Union.

Members of the House joined their Senate counterparts and told the Bush administration that Japan has not done enough to be stricken from the list of nations that don't trade fairly with the United States. ``When it comes to fair trade, it would appear that the administration is considering giving up, but we have not begun to fight,'' House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said Thursday. Gephardt joined more than a dozen other lawmakers at a news conference Thursday following introduction of a resolution in support of continuing retaliation against Japan for failing to remove objectionable import barriers.

Standard & Poor's Corp. downgraded about $30 billion in credit of Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, because of concerns over troubled loans involving real estate and corporate takeovers. The move comes one week after Citicorp reported a 56 percent drop in first-quarter earnings, in large part because of domestic real estate loan difficulties in slumping regions that are expected to worsen this year. Citicorp said in a statement Thursday it was disappointed by the downgrading.

Some service stations pass off regular gasoline as higher-priced super premium, according to a congressional study that said ``octane cheating'' may be costing motorists $150 million a year. The report released Thursday by the General Accounting office estimated that 9 percent of gasoline sold nationwide is mislabeled by half an octane number or more. And in several states where pump testing has actually proven mislabeling, the federal government has done little to stop the deception, the report said.

The Labor Department promised quick new safety rules for the petrochemical industry in an effort to prevent disasters such as last year's Phillips explosion that killed 23 workers in October in Texas. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration plans to establish the new safety guidelines by the end of the summer, the agency said Thursday in a report to President Bush.

The head of McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. topped Business Week's annual ranking of the nation's highest-paid chief executive officers, the magazine said. Craig O. McCaw, 40, chairman and chief executive officer of the nation's largest cellular phone company, earned $53.9 million in salary, bonuses and stock options last year, the magazine said Thursday.

A housing developer announced plans to build an American-style suburban residential complex in Moscow to meet the needs of foreign businessmen frustrated by the Soviet Union's scarce and low-quality housing. The $130-million project will bring a taste of Western comfort to 80 acres of rolling land on the northwest outskirts of Moscow, Chris Senie, secretary of Senie Kerschner International Housing Ltd., said Thursday.

The government approved the sale of most Eastern Airlines foreign routes to American Airlines and awarded a new Texas-Tokyo route to Continental Airlines. President Bush has authority to reject either deal if he believes it will harm U.S. national security or foreign policy interests. The Transportation Department's decision, made tentatively 10 days ago but announced Thursday, includes transfer to American of Eastern's Central and South American routes as well as its Miami-Madrid flights and a Miami-London route operated by Continental, Eastern's sister corporation in the Texas Air group.

The stock market was mixed Thursday as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 10.14 to 2,676.58 while declining issues outnumbered advances by about 9 to 8 amonmg issues listed in the New York Stock Exchange. Bond prices declined, pushing yields above 9 percent for the first time in almost a year. The dollar was mostly higher in U.S. trading after falling in Europe. Grain and soybean futures prices closed higher; precious metals futures were mostly lower; energy futures declined and livestock futures were mixed while pork mostly was higher.

DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press reported erroneously on April 26 that Ames Department Stores Inc. announced earlier this month that it lost an estimated $288 million in the fiscal year ending Jan. 27. Ames said it lost an estimated $228 million in the period.

DOC.HEAD: Wolf Says UAL Non-Contract Workers Getting Short Shrift
Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s 26,000 non-contract employees are being treated unfairly by the three union groups leading the charge for employee ownership of United Airlines' parent, says Chairman Stephen Wolf. Wolf said he agreed with Daryl Thorogood, a United reservations agent from San Francisco, who told the company's shareholders Thursday that the exclusion of salaried and management employees from buyout negotiations was ``rude, illegal and undemocratic.'' Still, Wolf told several hundred shareholders at the annual meeting that the proposed $201-a-share employee buyout is the best deal possible under the circumstances. He also said UAL plans to announce soon a large order for wide-bodied jetliners that may include the new Boeing 777. Ms. Thorogood read a letter she said had been sent to a number of large banks and brokerage firms explaining the non-contract workers' dissatisfaction with their treatment in the fashioning of the $4.38 billion buyout proposal. At a news conference after the two-hour meeting, Wolf declined to speculate on whether opposition by non-contract employees could scuttle the deal, then added: ``I don't think you'd want them against it.'' ``I cannot possibly conceive of acquiring this corporation in terms of 100 percent employee participation when 26,000 are being disenfranchised,'' Wolf said. ``I think it's important to have them involved and have them involved fairly.'' The non-contract employees represent about a third of UAL's 71,500 workers. They include reservations and ticket agents, professional and technical staff and management and supervisors, excluding Wolf and other top officers. Under the deal approved April 6 by UAL's board, United's pilots would own 37.9 percent of the company's stock, Machinists would own 35.7 percent, non-contract employees would get 14.3 percent and United flight attendants 12 percent. The union group has proposed overall employee wage and benefit cuts totaling $2 billion over five years to help offset buyout costs. Ms. Thorogood said the non-contract employees have had no voice in deciding how much they would give up. Responding to other shareholder questions at what could be UAL's last public stockholder meeting, Wolf said the employee bid is ``financeable'' and ``do-able'' but declined to speculate on whether the deal will get done. He tried to reassure skeptical stockholders that the proposed deal is better than the union group's initial bid, which was $11 a share lower but included partial public ownership. Wolf also said selling all the company's stock to the employees was better than the alternative: a threat by UAL's largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, to oust the company's directors and sell UAL to the union group at a price that Wolf said would have been lower than the one negotiated by the board. Coniston, which owns 11.8 percent of UAL's stock, ``didn't have any regard for the other 88 percent of our shareholders,'' Wolf said. ``Under the circumstances, we got the highest price we possibly could have obtained for our shareholders and we spent a diligent amount of time on doing that,'' he added. Investor skepticism about the ability of United's pilots, flight attendants and Machinists to borrow the $4 billion they need to complete their proposed buyout has contributed to a steady slide in UAL's stock price. The shares closed Thursday at $152.50 on the New York Stock Exchange, down from $163.50 on April 6, the day the board accepted the offer. Wolf said UAL plans to announce, possibly by June 15, the largest order in aviation history for wide-body aircraft. He said the order will include some twin engine aircraft _ either Boeing 777s or Airbus A330s _ and also possibly some McDonnell Douglas MD11s. Wolf would not elaborate on the number or dollar value of the aircraft. At the meeting, shareholders re-elected 13 of UAL's 15 directors to one-year terms. The two remaining directors had reached the mandatory retirement age of 70 and were not replaced.

DOC.HEAD: Big Discounter Files For Chapter 11
DOC.TEXT: Suppliers who helped pushed troubled Ames Department Stores Inc. into bankruptcy welcomed the discounter's Chapter 11 filing, saying it would provide the security needed to keep goods on store shelves. ``The air has been cleared as far as where the money will come from,'' said Robert Luehrs, president of Chic Jeans. Ames filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code late Wednesday, largely because of its inability to digest the Zayre chain it bought two years ago. The purchase doubled Ames' size and turned it overnight from a little-known New England-based chain to the nation's fourth-largest discounter. The bankruptcy filing will allow Ames to reorganize its business and pay suppliers under a new credit arrangement. In its filing, Ames listed a total of $1.44 billion in liabilities and $1.66 billion in assets. It listed the company's biggest creditor as Societe Generale Financial Corp., which is owed just over $14 million. Others listed among the top 20 creditors include Thermos Co. at $5.2 million owed; Rubbermaid Inc., $4.5 million; J.P. Stevens, $3.2 million, and Fisher Price, $2.9 million. Ironically, it was skittishness on the part of Ames' suppliers that pushed the company to file for protection from its creditors. Several suppliers began cutting off shipments to Ames last month after the company announced it lost an estimated $228 million in the fiscal year that ended Jan. 27. That news, coupled with an apprehensive retail climate following the January bankruptcy filing by Campeau Corp.'s U.S. retailers, put suppliers into a near-panic. ``It's unprecedented in the history of retailing that suppliers cut you off like that, but when you have Numero Uno go into receivership ... it makes people very nervous,'' said Alan Millstein, publisher of a monthly newsletter for retailers and manufacturers. Ames' stock rebounded slightly after Thursday's announcement, closing at $1.62{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange, up 12{ cents. Ames stock had been trading at nearly $30 a share in late 1987, but dipped to $9 a share in early January as Ames' troubles mounted after a dismal Christmas season. Under the bankruptcy filing, Chemical Bank has agreed to lend the Ames chain $250 million, with use of the money under control of the bankruptcy court. The money will allow Ames to continue operations and pay for merchandise shipments as it prepares it reorganization plan. Suppliers said the new credit arrangement offers them a measure of security they didn't have before the filing. The Gitano Group Inc., a sportswear supplier that is owed $5.3 million, said it plans to meet with Ames to talk about resuming shipments now that they have some assurance of payment. Gitano stopped shipments about four weeks ago. Analysts were unanimous in blaming Ames' downward spiral on its $788 million acquisition of the 392-store Zayre chain in October 1988. ``This had to happen,'' said Howard Davidowitz, chairman of a New York-based retail financial consulting firm. ``They took on a company that had been sinking and the sinking just accelerated. They couldn't save themselves.'' The Zayre stores had been known for frequent promotions, heavy advertising and discounted fashion items. Ames, in contrast, stocks more traditional merchandise and runs fewer promotions. Ames has since closed 90 Zayre stores and converted others to the Ames name. Further, the company's attempts to quickly merge Ames and Zayre computer systems resulted in some glitches that delayed payments to suppliers, which led some suppliers to cut off the chain's credit. Douglas Ewing, Ames vice president for investor relations, said a dismal Christmas season at Zayre stores after a disappointing year pushed Ames over the edge. ``I think the fourth-quarter results, coupled with the sales shortfall overall, did it for us,'' Ewing said. Ewing said Ames will continue normal operations while it works out a payment plan with its creditors. He said the chain has no immediate plan to cut staff or close additional stores, but would not speculate on what will happen under the restructuring. Founded in 1958, Ames operates more than 600 stores in 20 states and has about 55,000 employees.

DOC.HEAD: Milken Faces Avalanche of Litigation
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken's guilty plea may have settled criminal charges, but his days as a target of civil litigation are only beginning. Lawyers said Thursday about a dozen class-action lawsuits already have been filed against the former junk bond financier, on top of some 30 still pending over his relationship with ex-stock speculator Ivan Boesky. More lawsuits are planned. The investors suing Milken claim a $400 million fund established as part of his plea bargain to compensate defrauded investors won't be enough. But it could be years before investors ever see a penny. Attorneys first must sort through millions of documents to build their cases, and Milken's defense lawyers promise to take the claims to trial if necessary. Proceedings already have been delayed in the Boesky-related lawsuits because prosecutors have prevented witnesses such as Milken and Boesky from testifying while criminal cases were pending. Lawsuits already have been filed in New York, Phoenix, San Diego and elsewhere alleging that Milken defrauded investors in connection with hostile takeovers, the junk bond market and the nation's troubled savings and loans. ``The plaintiffs bar is drawn to something like this like bees to honey. We're not surprised,'' said Milken attorney Steven B. Rosenfeld. ``Most of the litigation out there is totally, totally unrelated not only to anything he pleaded guilty to but anything the government ever investigated him for,'' he said. Milken, the former head of junk bonds for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., pleaded guilty Tuesday to six tax and securities fraud charges and agreed to pay $600 million to settle his four-year-long battle with the government. Under the plea, Milken will put $400 million in a fund to be administered by the Securities and Exchange Commission for investors who can prove they were swindled by Milken's actions. The fund is not restricted to the limited transactions and transgressions in the plea bargain, any civil claim against Milken has a right to part of the money. In structuring the plea, Milken's lawyers tried to limit his potential exposure to civil litigation. ``You could spend the next 10 years investigating Milken on these things,'' said Daniel Berger of the Philadelphia law firm Berger & Montague, which is involved in Milken litigation. ``The stuff he was indicted on was peripheral. That doesn't mean there isn't other stuff.'' Berger's firm doesn't believe the fund will be large enough. If the money runs out, Milken is personally liable for civil claims. Milken attorney Arthur Liman said in court he believes $400 million will be plenty. One lawsuit filed last month on behalf of Unocal Corp. shareholders accuses Milken, Drexel and about 100 other defendants of a sweeping conspiracy to rig the financial markets in major takeover deals of the 1980s. The sprawling claims _ Unocal was a takeover target in 1985 _ portray Milken as mastermind of a racketeering enterprise that engaged in stock manipulation, insider trading, stock parking and other felonious activity. It names takeover strategists including T. Boone Pickens Jr., Carl Icahn and Saul Steinberg; Boesky and his cronies; dozens of former Drexel employees; other convicted Wall Street figures such as stockbroker Boyd Jefferies and GAF Corp. executive James Sherwin; even Milken's wife, Lori. The lawsuit seeks $2.3 billion in tripled damages under the racketeering law. Said Rosenfeld: ``It's a bunch of nonsense.'' Two shareholder lawsuits _ involving Columbia Savings & Loan Association and Lincoln Savings & Loan Association _ recently added Milken as a defendant. The thrifts, which lost hundreds of millions of dollars, had large junk bond holdings acquired through Drexel. Another lawsuit filed on behalf of an estimated 10,000 junk bond holders claims Milken rigged securities prices by controlling a ``daisy chain'' of buyers and sellers. Drexel lawyers claim that suit is invalid because the main plaintiff lacks legal standing. ``A lot of things are in the works,'' said attorney R. Bruce McNew of the Philadelphia firm Greenfield & Chimicles, which specializes in shareholder actions. Similar funds were set up in other Wall Street fraud cases _ $50 million for Boesky, about $20 million for investment bankers Dennis Levine and Martin Siegel, and $350 million for Drexel. But $150 million of the Drexel fund _ which also could be used for Milken plaintiffs _ is tied up in bankruptcy court. The 30 lawsuits involving Boesky's dealings are consolidated before U.S. District Judge Milton Pollack, who also will handle the Milken civil litigation. No money yet has been paid out from the Boesky fund, which was created more than three years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Ranks Highest-Paid Chief Executives
DOC.TEXT: The head of the nation's biggest cellular phone company got the right number last year. He topped Business Week's annual ranking of the nation's highest-paid chief executive officers. Craig O. McCaw, 40, chairman and chief executive officer of McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., earned $53.9 million in salary, bonuses and stock options last year, the magazine said Thursday in a release from its May 7 issue. That put him on top by a wide margin. The ranking differs considerably from one released earlier this week by Forbes magazine. That list ranked Coca-Cola Co.'s chief executive officer, Roberto C. Goizueta, as highest-paid, with $10.8 million in salary and other compensation last year. Business Week placed Goizueta eighth, listing his compensation at $10.7 million. The Forbes list included only CEOs from the magazine's ranking of the 50 largest U.S. companies, while Business Week surveyed 356 public companies in its 40th annual ranking. McCaw Cellular was not among Forbes' 50 largest companies. Business Week said that among those it surveyed, the average chief executive's salary and bonus rose just 3.4 percent in 1989, to $1,172,533, the smallest increase since the 2 percent rise in 1970. According to Labor Department figures, the gain trailed the increases for white-collar professionals, 4.9 percent, and factory employees, 3.7 percent. McCaw, whose company has yet to turn a profit, earned only $289,000 cash in salary but received $53.6 million from exercising stock options that he and other McCaw executives received before the company went public. Second on Business Week's list was Steven J. Ross, co-chairman and CEO of Time Warner Inc., who received $34.2 million as co-head of the media company. The bulk of his earnings _ $29.4 million _ was in long-term compensation such as stock options. In third place was Donald A. Pels, who received $22.8 million as chairman and chief executive of Lin Broadcasting. McCaw Cellular acquired Lin, a cellular phone, broadcasting and publishing company, earlier this year. Jim P. Manzi, chairman, president and chief executive of Lotus Development Corp., ranked fourth. Manzi received $16.4 million from the computer software company. In fifth place was Paul Fireman, chairman and chief executive of athletic shoe maker Reebok International Ltd. Fireman was paid $14.6 million, all in salary. Ronald K. Richey, chairman and chief executive of Torchmark Corp., earned $12.7 million from the insurance and financial services company, placing him sixth on the list. At seventh place was Martin S. Davis, chairman and CEO of Paramount Communications Inc. The entertainment company paid him $11.6 million in salary and other compensation. Goizueta of Coca-Cola was eighth at $10.7 million. No. 9 was Michael D. Eisner, chairman and chief executive of Walt Disney Co., at $9.6 million. In 10th place was August A. Busch III, chairman, president and CEO of Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc. Busch received $8.9 million as head of the brewery.

DOC.HEAD: S&P Downgrades Citicorp Credit
DOC.TEXT: Worries about the quality of real estate and takeover loans reached the nation's largest bank as Citicorp had its credit rating lowered by a major rating agency. Standard & Poor's Corp. on Thursday downgraded about $30 billion in credit of Citicorp. The move comes one week after Citicorp reported a 56 percent drop in first-quarter earnings, in large part because of domestic real estate loan difficulties in slumping regions that are expected to worsen this year. Citicorp said it was dissapointed by the move. ``We are confident that the strength of Citicorp's core businesses and well-positioned global franchises will continue to provide excellent returns and growth,'' it said in a statement. Standard & Poor's said it was lowering key credit ratings because ``Citicorp's aggressive capital philosophy leaves it diminished flexibility to face increased risks in the general business environment.'' S&P said Citicorp has successfully resolved most of its problems related to loans to developing countries, but is in a ``weakened condition'' to deal with problems loans for real estate and leveraged buyouts. S&P also said Citicorp's capital levels are low, especially considering the bank's relatively low reserves to guard against failed loans. A number of major banking institutions have seen their debt ratings downgraded recently by S&P and Moody's Investors Service _ the two major credit rating agencies _ due to similar problems. But the downgrade _ to double-A-minus from double-A on the bank's senior debt _ is noteworthy because of Citicorp's size, prestige and credit rating, which is higher than many banking institutions. Moody's last week said it was considering a downgrade for Citicorp. A lower credit rating could make it more expensive for Citicorp to borrow money by prompting investors to demand higher interest to compensate for increased risk. The ratings have no effect on customer deposits. Robert Albertson, a banking analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Co., criticized the downgrade as unnecessary. ``I think it's two rating agencies trying to be more bearish than the regulators and I think it's a mistake,'' he said. ``Everybody's trying to sound tougher and be tougher in an environment that's uncertain.'' Albertson said he believes Citicorp in the past has accurately forecast its losses and that if regulators had problems with the bank's exposure to commercial real estate loans, ``they would have said so by now.'' Analysts said 7 percent of Citicorp's outstanding real estate loans, excluding residential mortgages, were nonperforming in 1989, about in line with other banks. But the amount of nonperforming loans _ on which payments are not being made _ are expected to increase. About 5 percent of Citicorp's highly leveraged transactions were non-performing, fifth worst in a survey by ICBA Inc., a credit rating agency. Citicorp has $7.8 billion in highly leveraged loans outstanding, about twice as much as the next biggest bank. S&P said Citicorp has withstood problems in its portfolio of loans to developing countries. The bank charged $135 million against earnings for loans to developing countries in the first quarter, including $56 million of real estate loans, mostly in North America. About half of a $548 million quarterly increase in loans not paying interest reflected loans to highly leveraged companies involved in takeovers or refinancings. Citicorp allocated $570 million in the first quarter for loan losses, a $212 million increase over the previous year. Citicorp had $1.3 billion in nonperforming U.S. real estate loans, up $119 million from a year earlier. S&P said that Citicorp, despite the downgrade, has advantages over other banks because of its diversification, strong consumer businesses such as credit cards and varied forms of corporate banking.

DOC.HEAD: B-2 Builder Says Proposed Production Cut Will Hurt Subcontractors First
DOC.TEXT: From suppliers to the aerospace giant Northrop, the defense industry will feel the pinch of the Pentagon's plan to slash production of the B-2 stealth bomber nearly in half. ``It would mean that we would not recognize the buildup and growth we had anticipated when we set out to do this,'' John Kvasnosky, spokesman for Boeing Military Airplanes, said Thursday. He spoke after Defense Secretary Dick Cheney outlined to Congress proposed cuts aimed at saving $34.8 billion through 1997. The savings would be achieved partly by purchasing 75 B-2 stealth bombers instead of 132 and delaying the start of production of Advanced Tactical Fighters. With 10,000 people working on the B-2 project in the Seattle area, the Boeing Co. is one of the largest contractors for the stealth, built by Los Angeles-based Northrop. Northrop employs 12,000 people on the B-2 project, including about 1,700 who work on assembling the radar-evading bomber in Palmdale, Calif. Stealth bomber subcontractors and suppliers across the nation employ 30,000 to 40,000 workers, said Tony Cantafio, a Northrop spokesman. Production of five B-2s was proposed in the fiscal 1991 budget at a cost of $5.5 billion. Under the new plan only two jets would be built that year. ``The immediate effect may be felt by suppliers and subcontractors around the country,'' said Cantafio. ``From an employment standpoint at Northrop, there won't be an immediate effect.'' Northrop still will need to hire several hundred more workers for the Palmdale plant because of prior orders, Cantafio said. However, Cheney's proposal would halve production in peak years to 12 from 24 aircraft. ``Obviously, in the long run we won't build up our employment to the original schedule,'' Cantafio said. Just last Sunday the company ran full-page newspaper advertisements for a B-2 job fair, using a photograph of the ominous-looking flying wing and an appeal to many types of aerospace workers to help ``make history.'' Northrop has also been running television ads focusing on employees talking about their work and featuring famed test pilot Chuck Yeager. Building fewer stealth bombers would reduce the program's projected cost from $75.4 billion to $61.1 billion but would raise the cost of individual planes to more than $800 million, according to Cheney. Northrop also is competing for a role in a new generation aircraft known as the Advanced Tactical Fighter, which will replace the Air Force's F-15. Cheney still wants 750 planes built but would push back purchases two years, from 1994 to 1996. The Northrop spokesman characterized the impact of that change as minimal because the aircraft is not yet in full-scale development.

DOC.HEAD: Executives of Marshall Field Announce Resignations
DOC.TEXT: The top two executives of Marshall Field & Co. announced their resignations one day after Dayton Hudson Corp. said it would consolidate Field's corporate headquarters with its own in Minneapolis. Field Chairman Philip B. Miller and President Burnett W. Donoho will resign when Minneapolis-based Dayton Hudson's $1.04 billion buyout is complete, Miller said Thursday. A week ago, Dayton Hudson beat out several suitors including a group of managers led by Miller in a bidding war for Marshall Field's. ``I was terribly disappointed that our bid wasn't successful,'' Miller said. ``We couldn't have reached that (price) level with our partnership group. One of the ways (Dayton Hudson) got to their number was their plan to consolidate, which we couldn't do.'' Dayton Hudson expects to complete the deal within two months. BAT Industries PLC of Britain put the 24-store chain up for sale last year as part of its restructuring to fight a takeover attempt by corporate raider Sir James Goldsmith. Goldsmith dropped his takeover effort Monday. In a letter Wednesday to Marshall Field's employees, Dayton Hudson said it will offer jobs in Chicago and Minneapolis to some central office employees. A Marshall Field regional organization, focused on customer service and community involvement, will be based in Chicago, the letter said. Of the 1,700 corporate employees, 350 to 400 are in the merchandise group, including buyers and managers. Remaining jobs are largely administrative and operational. Miller said he believes the consolidation will result in the loss of about 1,450 jobs in Field's central organization. ``We will know by the time of the closing at the end of May or the first few days of June how many people will be let go,'' said Ann Barkelew, a spokeswoman for Dayton Hudson. She also said the company tried to work with Miller to see if it had anything that interested him. ``To say anything more would not be appropriate because he has made his decision,'' she said from Minneapolis, adding the company has no idea who will replace Miller. Miller said he had discussions with Dayton Hudson about staying with the company, but it became apparent to him it was time to move on. Under the consolidation plan, ``the responsibilities are so changed I don't feel I can be effective,'' he said during a news conference. ``I don't have any plans right now. This has come about very quickly.'' Miller won wide credit for making Marshall Field's an attractive target. He came to the chain in 1983 from Dallas-based Neiman-Marcus, where he was president. His retailing history also included stints as merchandise manager of Filene's in Boston, vice president and general manager of Wallach's in New York, vice president and general merchandise manager of Bloomingdales, and president of Lord & Taylor, both of New York. Donoho joined Field's in 1984, from Gimbel's Midwest _ at the time a subsidiary of New York-based Gimbel's Department Stores _ where he was president and chief operating officer.

DOC.HEAD: Insect Repellent Pulled From Stores Because of Tumor Finding
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Dionn correct in 14th graf, bgng: Cutter's, however. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of brands of insect repellents, including some types of OFF and Cutter's, are being withdrawn from stores because a long-used ingredient to repel biting flies gave tumors to lab rats and withered their ovaries. The ingredient's manufacturer, McLaughlin Gormley King Co. of Minneapolis, gave the government test information disclosing the problem and asked that its license to produce and sell it be withdrawn, said Albert Heier, a spokesman for the Environmental Protection Agency. ``The company has voluntarily canceled their registration on this product and informed all the users,'' Heier said Thursday. ``They did the responsible thing.'' Some 200 brands of insect repellent, including Deep Woods OFF and Cutter's, use the ingredient 2,3,4,5-Bis(2,butylene)tetrahydro-2-furaldehyde as an additive to repel flies that bite, Heier said. Two of the major users of the additive are S.C. Johnson and Son Co. of Racine, Wis., which makes OFF, and Miles Co. of Chicago, producer of Cutter's, Heier said. Both companies began notifying retailers a couple of weeks ago to take the products containing the ingredient off their shelves. In both cases, the withdrawal affects only a portion of the product line, and does not include every insect repellent the companies make. S.C. Johnson publicly announced its withdrawal of OFF earlier this month, but Cutter's said nothing in public, although it did notify retailers. About 25 percent of all insect repellents on the market use the additive, known industrially as R-11 although that name does not appear on the label of any consumer product. The labels, instead, carry the long technical name, Heier said. The manufacturer's test results showed that the additive caused ``adverse reproductive effects, ovarian atrophy and oncogenicity, or tumors,'' in laboratory rats and mice, the EPA spokesman said. ``These are the preliminary results; the studies aren't completed,'' he said. The government has done no independent testing of the additive _ it requires pesticide manufacturers to conduct safety tests _ and does not know how dangerous it may be. The ingredient has been used for 35 years. ``We just don't have enough data to do a risk assessment,'' Heier said. ``We have no evidence that it hurt anybody.'' In the case of Deep Woods OFF, the withdrawal affects about 150,000 cases of aerosol and pump containers and boxes of towelettes, the company said in its public announcement nearly three weeks ago. Cutter's, however, did not make a public announcement and instead quietly informed retailers to take products from their shelves, said spokeswoman Dionn Tron. ``Because there was no safety reason for doing this, it was simply a precautionary measure on our part, there was no public announcement,'' she said. The voluntary recall involved several products carrying the Cutter's name, Ms. Tron said. Three Cutter's products did not contain the ingredient in question: the tick repellent, the maximum strength formula and the stick repellent. The recalled products are being replaced with new ones carrying a yellow sticker saying it is a new formula, the spokeswoman said. Sixty-five other companies also produce repellents using R-11 under a variety of brand names. Among those are pet products, including some flea and tick repellents marketed under the Adams or Mycodex brand names, said Linda Kriesman, a spokeswoman for SmithKline Beecham Co. The products have been reformulated, and those new formulas either have been approved already by the government or are awaiting approval, she said. People with repellents containing R-11 who want to throw it away should handle its disposal as they would any pesticide in accordance with local ordinances, Heier said. Ms. Tron said people with Cutter's products containing R-11 can contact the company, which will send a mailer to dispose of it. However, she said there was no need to get rid of the repellent. ``People who have the stuff can continue to use it,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Newsletter Reportedly Gets Copyright Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A major corporation reportedly has agreed to pay more than $100,000 to a newsletter publisher for violating the publisher's copyright by circulating photocopies of the newsletter to its employees. The publisher, Washington Business Information Inc., declined to reveal the name of the offending company, The Washington Post reported today. Washington Business Information publishes 11 newsletters, including Product Safety Letter, Hazardous Materials Transportation, Plastic Waste Strategies and Devices and Diagnostics Letter. WBI also would not say which of its publications was involved, the Post reported, citing a confidential agreement included in the settlement. But the publisher said the amount was in six figures. David Swit, president of WBI, was not immediately available for comment on the report.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Group Ends Boycott of Clorox Products
DOC.TEXT: A religious group has ended a nine-month boycott of Clorox Co. products, citing a marked reduction in the company's sponsorship of ``sex, violence, profanity and anti-Christian stereotyping'' on television. But the boycott ``was a success in both dropping the sales of Clorox products and in encouraging Clorox to enforce their advertising policy,'' said Billy Melvin, executive director of National Association of Evangelicals and chairman of the group known as Christian Leaders for Responsible Television, or CLeaR-TV. Without disclosing whether the boycott cut into sales, Clorox communications director Fred Reicher said, ``certainly we are gratified the boycott has been lifted. The boycott made us aware that implementation of our standards were flawed and we tightened those.'' CLeaR-TV describes itself as a coalition of 1,600 Christian leaders with constituencies totaling 60 million people. The Rev. Donald E. Wildmon, a United Methodist preacher who founded the group and serves as its executive director, said the organization would continue a one-year boycott of products made by the Mennen Co., also accused of sponsoring what the group sees as objectionable television programming. When the boycotts were announced nine months ago, CLeaR-TV said it had found the two manufacturers had placed advertisements on offensive television programs from April 27 through May 24, a ``sweeps'' period during which the popularity of network programming is gauged. Programs considered particularly offensive during that period _ both carrying advertising by the targeted companies _ included NBC-TV's ``Miami Vice'' and ``Dream Street,'' Melvin had said. CLeaR-TV said it found a reduction of almost two-thirds in the amount of sex, violence and profanity sponsored by Clorox last fall as compared with last spring. The group said it had been approached by Clorox officials in February noting that standards had been tightened and requesting that the boycott be lifted. Clorox, whose products include bleach, Act laundry detergent, Formula 409 cleaner and Lucite paint, ranked 66th among the leading national advertising spenders at $148 million in 1988, according to the trade publication Advertising Age.

DOC.HEAD: Revco Agrees to Sell 221 Stores to Reliable Holdings Corp.
DOC.TEXT: Financially troubled Revco D.S., Inc. said Friday it has agreed to sell 221 of its midwest drug stores to Reliable Holdings Corp., of Fort Worth, Texas, for an undisclosed price. The agreement marks the first step in a restructuring plan announced in January designed to sell off 712 of Revco's 1,873 stores. Revco is currently operating under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code because of a debt-financed takeover that soured. Included in the transaction, which will require bankruptcy court approval, area all of Revco's stores in Illinois, Iowa, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan, Missouri and in western Tennessee, the Twinsburg company said in a release. Reliable Holdings Corp. was formed by Acadia Partners, L.P., and the management of Reliable Drug Stores, Inc., a 112-store chain based in Indianapolis. ``All our customers can continue to shop at Revco with full confidence that their needs will be met,'' said Boake A. Sells, Revco chairman and chief executive officer. ``We anticipate a very smooth transition of these stores to Reliable.'' The goal of Revco's restructuring plan is to concentrate on 10 eastern states, which account for 64 percent of the chain's sales. The states include Georgia, Maryland, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, eastern Tennessee, West Virginia andVirginia. Revco has annual sales of more than $2.7 billion. The company filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors in July 1988, about a month after it failed to make an interest payment on outstanding high-risk junk bonds used to finance its $1.5 billion, management-led leveraged buyout.

Stock prices declined slightly today as traders studied the latest data on economic growth. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dipped 1.81 to 2,674.77 in the first half hour of trading. Losers held a narrow edge on gainers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 421 up, 469 down and 512 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 16.86 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Before the trading day began the Commerce Department estimated that the gross national product grew at a 2.1 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation, in the first quarter of the year. An accompanying gauge of inflation showed prices in the January-March period rising at a 7{-year high of 5.7 percent annually. Analysts said those figures tended to reinforce fears on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve might soon feel compelled to tighten credit in its campaign to keep inflation in check. But interest rates declined a bit in the credit markets, where yields on Treasury bonds climbed past the 9 percent level Thursday for the first time in nearly a year. Brokers said many bond traders had been braced for a bigger GNP increase than was actually reported. Sun Microsystems rose 1[ to 24[ in the over-the-counter market. Late Thursday the company reported earnings for its fiscal quarter ended March 30 of 40 cents a share, up from 38 cents in the comparable period a year earlier. DOC.HEAD: Company Offers to Buy Clunkers to Reduce Smog
DOC.TEXT: A giant oil company is offering $700 to motorists who are looking to unload their old clunkers and would like to help reduce smog in the Los Angeles area. ``We want to take the heaviest polluters off the road and hand them over to a scrap yard, which will shred and recycle the metal,'' Unocal Corp. Chairman Richard J. Stegemeier said Thursday. Unocal executives said pre-1971 vehicles pollute 15 to 30 times more than 1990 models, although air quality officials don't consider buy-back programs for old cars the most effective way to reduce pollution. There are 410,000 pre-1971 cars registered in the Los Angeles area. Unocal said it would pay $700 for the first 7,000 cars turned in. ``We want to demonstrate ways of reducing smog that are efficient and cost-effective,'' Stegemeier said. The program is scheduled to begin June 1. Another voluntary program, to take effect in July, offers free smog checks and emission control tune-ups for pre-1975 cars at participating Unocal 76 service stations. Such tune-ups could remove 17 million pounds of carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides and reactive organic gases from the Los Angeles basin, which has the worst air quality problem in the nation, Unocal said. A buy-back program was suggested last year to regional smog control officials by the Claremont Institute, a conservative non-profit think tank. The institute suggested paying about $1,500 apiece to remove 850,000 pre-1980 vehicles from the region at a cost of $1.3 billion, said Lucas Morel, a research associate at the institute. While unusual in its approach, Unocal's announcement was hardly unique. ``They're all becoming environmentally pro-active,'' said Kenneth B. Funsten, an oil industry analyst. Funsten attributed the trend largely to Exxon Corp.'s handling of the Alaska oil spill, which has hardened political opposition to oil industry operations. Tom Eichhorn, a spokesman for the South Coast Air Quality Management District, said estimates of pollution eliminated by vehicle buy-back programs are questionable because old cars are less reliable and probably driven less than newer cars. In addition, agency officials estimate that most old cars will stop running in a few years anyway, which doesn't really help the region attain federal clean air standards by 2007, as required by Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Economy Rebounds With First Quarter GNP Growing at 2.1 Percent
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts 3 grafs of administration reaction after 3rd graf: But the.; also moved general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy, which ended last year on a weak note, rebounded during the first quarter of 1990 at a surprisingly healthy annual rate of 2.1 percent, the government said today. The Commerce Department said the gross national product _ the total output of goods and services _ grew nearly twice as fast as the feeble 1.1 percent gain from October through December. But the faster growth was accompanied by a worrisome pickup in inflation as a price gauge tied to the GNP jumped at an annual rate of 6.5 percent, up from the 4.5 percent rate for last year and the biggest gain since a 7.7 percent advance in the fourth quarter of 1981. J. Antonio Villamil, Commerce Department chief economist, said the weather contributed to both the economy's strength and the price hike and that inflation would moderate over the rest of the year. Excluding the weather factor and a federal pay raise that went into effect in January, inflation rose only 5.2 percent, he said. ``Despite the larger price rise, the first quarter still had encouraging developments _ signs of the economy's resilience,'' he told a news conference, noting that the 2.1 percent GNP growth was close to the administration's forecast last January of 2.2 percent. While the Bush administration is counting on a growing economy this year to help close the federal budget gap, many private analysts are pessimistic about whether the first-quarter rate can be sustained. These analysts believe the first-quarter GNP strength resulted from special, one-time factors and many fear the Federal Reserve could slow it further by increasing interest rates to curb inflation. In fact, for the entire year, the consensus forecast is for a meager GNP growth of just 1.9 percent, far below the 3 percent increase of 1989 and a half-percentage point below the administration's 2.4 percent forecast. Still, the first quarter performance was a far cry from most forecasts when the year began. At that time, many economists forecast GNP growth in the first quarter would be little improved from the fourth quarter rate, the slowest in three years. Some even said the economic recovery, now in its eighth year, was in danger of toppling into a recession. The unexpected strength in the first quarter was credited in part to the unusually warm weather during the quarter, which boosted building construction and helped to hold down America's demand for foreign oil. But the weather also was partly responsible for the jump in inflation. December was the fourth coldest on record, destroying fruits and vegetables and driving up prices in the following months. The frigid temperatures also resulted in higher fuel costs as dealers sought to replenish their stocks. The GNP's 2.1 percent advance was the fastest since a 3.0 percent gain in the third quarter last year. DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Set Back On Profit-Taking
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid aggressive pre-weekend profit-taking in the soybean market. A powerful soybean rally on Thursday reflected concerns about the continuing slow pace of the Brazilian soybean harvest and strong world demand for soybean meal, analysts said. Forecasts for warmer- and drier-than-normal weather in the Midwest next week also helped fuel Thursday's run-up in soybeans as well as in grains. Corn and wheat futures were off slightly this morning, in sympathy with the soybean market and in reaction to continued good growing weather for the winter wheat crop. In early trading, wheat futures were 1\ cents to 1} cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.68} a bushel; corn was { cent to 1 cent lower with May at $2.80 a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent higher with May at $1.60{ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 4 cents lower with May at $6.24\ a bushel. DOC.HEAD: Senate Committee Votes to Set Standard for Organic Food
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Agriculture Committee voted today to set a national standard for organically grown food. The regulations requiring farmers to follow specific methods in order to label their products ``organically produced'' will be part of the 1990 farm bill that the full Senate will vote on later this year. ``This legislation sets one tough national standard for organic foods,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the agriculture committee. He said the label will mean that the food has been grown without substances known to be harmful to human health or to cause environmental pollution. ``A March 1990 Harris poll showed for the second year in a row that more than four out of five Americans want organic fruits and vegetables and over half are willing to pay more for them,'' he said. ``Consumers who want organic food should get what they pay for.'' Leahy said current farm programs encourage chemical-intensive agriculture by discouraging crop rotation and limiting diversity. ``This legislation will help American farmers learn to use fewer synthetic pesticides and fertilizers,'' he said. The bill that will be incorporated into legislation setting federal farm policies for the next five years was passed unanimously by the Senate committee. The bill requires: _ Minimum standards for the label ``organically produced.'' _ Periodic on-site inspections and residue testing. _ An accreditation program for state officials and private individuals who certify farms and food-handling operations. _ A second label indicating the state of origin of the product. _ Establishment of a national organic promotion advisory committee to gain insight and advice from the organic farming sector of the agriculture industry to help develop legislation on organic promotion, research and education. The House, which is also working on the 1990 farm bill, has not passed any similar legislation yet.

DOC.HEAD: 2nd Quarter Auto Earnings Down by More Than Two-Thirds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to CORRECT that Chrysler may have a marginal profit sted marginal profit increase; uppicks 7th graf pvs: ``The earnings....
DOC.TEXT: Earnings for the nation's Big Three automakers are expected to take another double-digit dive, reflecting production slashes and economic problems in South America, analysts say. First-quarter profits for General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. are expected to be less than a third of last year's levels, auto analysts said Thursday. The companies will report their quarterly earnings next week. ``The pricing environment was extremely weak and there wasn't a lot of production in the first quarter,'' said John Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Co. of New York. During the January-March period this year, automakers cut production and laid on incentives in an effort to deflate ballooning new-car inventories. The inventories were brought back to more manageable levels, which was good for the companies, but the moves apparently clobbered first-quarter earnings. A spot check of analysts showed forecasts that GM's quarterly earnings would be down about 70 percent from the $1.55 billion earned during the first three months of last year, when GM had its best quarter since the second quarter of 1984. Ford's earnings should be down about 75 percent from the $1.64 billion the company earned in last year's period. Chrysler Corp. may show a marginal profit, if any, compared with the $351 million in profits it posted last year, the analysts said. ``The earnings are going to be almost a yawn,'' Kirnan said. ``People have been bracing for the weakened earnings report. The bigger question is when we are going to get the turn.'' Auto company executives and other analysts have predicted that the first half of the year would be tough and that things would pick up in the second half. ``In the second quarter, earnings will still be below last year, but the comparisons won't be as bad as the first quarter,'' said David Healy of Barclays-BZW of New York. A second-half rebound may be delayed, though, Kirnan said. ``The and truck) sales numbers have certainly gotten back into a sluggish territory and with interest rates continuing to escalate, it may choke off a major turn in second-quarter and second-half earnings of these companies,'' he said. Chrysler, which has relied heavily on incentives to sell its cars and trucks, had an aggressive incentive program for its popular minivans during January that pumped up sales. But incentive costs come directly out of profits, and the No. 3 automaker doesn't have overseas operations to prop up any sag in North American operations. During the past year or so, GM and Ford relied on their overseas businesses, especially in Europe and South America, to help maintain profit levels for the entire corporation. That reliance may be ending. ``A lot of people got surprised by the extent of the damage in Brazil,'' said analyst Mary Anne Sudol of Fitch Investors Service Inc. in New York. ``Everything is at a standstill in Brazil.'' In March, the new Brazilian government froze 80 percent of the nation's savings, sharply curtailing economic activity. On March 26, Ford and the West German automaker Volkswagen AG shut down production at Autolatina joint venture in Brazil and put 2,800 employees on a paid leave. Ford spokesman Rex Greenslade said Thursday those workers would be recalled next Wednesday. Ford, in a recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said if current conditions continued in Brazil there was a potential for a substantial negative effect on the company's earnings. Greenslade declined to comment on whether the employee recall meant that Ford has more confidence in the Brazilian economic situation.

DOC.HEAD: Wang Posts Third-Quarter Loss And Drop In Revenue
DOC.TEXT: Wang Laboratories Inc. said Friday it lost $146.6 million in its most recent quarter, in part due to a number of significant one-time charges, including one related to the sale of its international lease-financing operations. The loss, which came to 89 cents a share, was double the loss of the same period a year earlier, when Wang reported a deficit of $63.7 million, or 39 cents a share. The office computer company said its revenue dropped to $583.1 million in the three months ended March 31, which is Wang's third fiscal quarter, from $721.4 million for the same quarter of 1989. ``A significant portion of our third-quarter loss is the direct result of one-time charges associated with our highly successful program to sell non-strategic assets and the ongoing fundamental reordering of Wang's business operations,'' Richard W. Miller, Wang's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. Miller said the Lowell-based company's debt-reduction plan would have a positive effect in the future by eliminating about $55 million in annual interest payments, which accounted for $15.9 million of Wang's fiscal third-quarter loss. For the first nine months of its fiscal year, Wang reported a net loss of $219.2 million, or $1.33 a share, compared with a loss of $49.6 million, or 33 cents a share, for the same period a year earlier. ``Since August 1989, our aggressive actions to sell non-strategic assets and our consolidation programs have enabled Wang Laboratories to cut operating expenses by more than $300 million annually,'' Miller said. ``With future asset sales anticipated, Wang hopes to eliminate completely its bank-group debt and associated future interest payments, while strengthening its cash reserves.'' Wang said Friday it completed the sale of its international lease-financing operations to GE Capital Corp., a division of General Electric Co., for about $240 million. The company said it expected to record a book loss of about $19 million on the sale, which was recorded in Wang's third-quarter results. Officials said $215 of the proceeds from the sale will be used to reduce the company's bank debt to about $90 million. The remaining $25 million will be used to increase the company's cash reserves, officials said. Wang's bank debt had totaled about $575 million last August.

DOC.HEAD: General Electric Eliminating 4,200 Jobs at Five Plants
DOC.NOTE: EDS: precedes Syracuse-dated sty; UPDATES throughout with details of company-wide plans, no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co. said Friday it will eliminate about 4,200 hourly and salaried jobs over the next two years at five GE Aerospace locations. The cuts are part of GE's efforts to reorganize its aerospace defense businesses so the company can remain successful despite a shrinking market and increased competition. GE says it will take advantage of projected attrition and retirements of about 2,000 employees to reduce significantly the number of employess actually laid off. The reductions are scheduled to take place at plants in Binghamton, Syracuse and Utica, N.Y. and Camden and Moorestown, N.J. ``We are taking decisive actions now to enable our business to meet its future commitments to customers and ensure that GE Aerospace will be a vital, industry-leading business for many years to come,'' said Jon Rittenhouse, senior vice president for GE Aerospace. ``We're entering a decade that will provide a difficult challenge for defense companies,'' he said. ``The world's changing political outlook will result in a smaller, more intensely competitive worldwide defense market.'' Where layoffs are necessary, GE will offer financial assistance based on length of service and medical and life insurance coverage for up to one year from the date of layoff. The company also will offer job-finding assistance. The cuts affect about 15 percent of the company's 6,000 employees at three Syracuse-area plants. They are the first significant local layoffs since the company shut down its picture tube production operation in November 1986. GE, Syracuse's largest employer, will cut 200 salaried jobs by the end of 1990, said GE spokeswoman Connie Grasso. Another 420 hourly jobs and 250 salaried will be eliminated over the next two years. Layoffs at the three local sites in the towns of Geddes, DeWitt and Salina will begin as early as June 1. In 1989, GE Aerospace cut 4,000 jobs, decreasing its work force from 44,000 to 40,000 through layoffs, business cutbacks, attrition and retirement. The company plans a similar reduction this year and a smaller one in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 3 Percent Increase in 1st-Qtr Profit
DOC.TEXT: Aetna Life & Casualty Co. on Friday reported a 3 percent increase in net income in the first quarter, with increases in most of its divisions but sluggish results from its auto and homeowner lines. The insurance company recorded net income of $180 million, or $1.61 a share, in the latest three months, up from $174 million, or $1.52 a share, in the same 1989 period. Total revenues were $4.77 billion, up 4 percent from $4.57 billion in the same period in 1989. ``We had significantly better group insurance and pension results,'' said Aetna Chairman James T. Lynn. ``However, our personal auto insurance business continues to suffer from high loss costs and inadequate prices.'' The auto-homeowners' line earned $1 million in the quarter, on premiums of $677.3 million, compared to a $4 million loss in the 1989 period on premiums of $680.3 million. Aetna had much stronger results in its employee benefits division, which recorded $77 million in earnings compared to $42 million in the 1989 period. Premiums totaled $1.1 billion, up from $1.04 billion in the first quarter last year. The personal financial security division had $20 million in earnings, up from $13 million last year. Premiums totaled $752.5 million, up from $738 million.

DOC.HEAD: Retirement Prospects Not Rosy for Service Sector Employees
DOC.TEXT: An increasing number of service workers won't have adequate retirement income promised by the 1965 Older Americans Act, a Florida State University professor reported Friday. A study co-written by associate sociology professor Melissa A. Hardy said service workers are less likely to retire, and more likely to leave the work force through disability or death, than those in most other career fields. ``The study suggests that retirement among service workers is an option that is financially unavailable or unattractive,'' Hardy said. ``It indicates that, as the service sector grows, fewer Americans will be able to retire early enough to enjoy their retirement years.'' Mark D. Hayward, a professor of sociology at the University of Southern California, and William R. Grady, a researcher at Battelle Memorial Institute in Seattle, co-wrote the study. Service jobs include such occupations as waitress, porter, bartender, janitor, cab driver and kitchen worker. ``Clearly, workers with different occupational histories do not have equal access to adequate retirement income promised by the Older Americans Act because inequalities are built into the system,'' Hardy said. The 25-year-old law, a major piece of President Lyndon Johnson's ``Great Society'' program, says Americans should have ``equal opportunity to the full and free enjoyment of ... retirement in health, honor and dignity.'' But the study found only 67 percent of service workers nationwide leave the job for conventional retirement. The rate was higher for managers, craftsmen, factory workers, clerical help, farm laborers and general laborers. ``One reason fewer service workers retire is because pension systems tend not to be in place in service industries as they have traditionally been in manufacturing industries,'' Hardy said. ``And they're often low-wage jobs, so the probability of service workers accumulating savings and investments is much reduced as well.'' The result is that more service workers stay on the job until they become disabled or die compared to other occupations, she said. According to the study, which tracked 2,816 men from age 55 through retirement, 9 percent of all service workers leave work because of disability. Only farmers at 10 percent leave at a higher rate, the study noted. And only professionals are more likely to die on the job than service workers. Among professionals, 15 percent died while still working, as opposed to 13 percent of service workers. Professionals traditionally stay on the job longer than others because they enjoy the challenge, have more control over their work and sometimes find it harder to maintain their lifestyles on pensions, she said. About 11 percent of the service workers were still employed at the end of the study period.
