DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Announces 2,750 Layoffs Day After Douglas Announces 3,000 Job Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp. said today it would lay off 2,750 workers in its plane-building division, including about 2,000 of them in Southern California. The job cuts, which had been expected, were the second big round of aerospace layoffs in as many days to hit the region. McDonnell Douglas Corp. said Wednesday it will eliminate 3,000 jobs at its Long Beach-based Douglas Aircraft unit this summer to reduce the costs of jet aircraft production at the money-losing division. In yet another indication of hard times for the defense industry, General Electric Co. said today it will eliminate about 4,200 jobs over the next two years at GE Aerospace locations in New York and New Jersey. The cuts are part of efforts to make GM's aerospace defense businesses leaner so the company can compete despite a shrinking market and increased competition. James Ragsdale, a spokesman for Lockheed's Aeronautical Systems Co. in Burbank, said the other 750 employees who will lose their jobs are based in Marietta, Ga., where Lockheed had built the huge C-5 cargo plane. The C-5 is just one of four Lockheed military planes whose production had ended recently or is to end soon. The others are the P-3 sub-hunter, the TR-1 high-altitude reconnaissance plane, and the F117A stealth fighter. ``It is unlikely we will have any large new military aircraft production project that will begin before the mid-1990s,'' Ken Cannestra, the president of the aeronautics unit, said in a statement. Lockheed, the nation's sixth-biggest military contractor, saw its profits fall from $624 million in 1988 to just $2 million last year. One big reason was that the company underestimated by hundreds of millions of dollars the costs of developing a new warplane, the P-7, a replacement for the P-3. As of April 1, Lockheed's aeronautical division had 10,124 workers in Georgia and 12,752 in Southern California. Employment in the division peaked in mid-1988. About 9,000 workers already had been laid off. Douglas Aircraft hasn't managed any profit recently. In its first-quarter report last week, St. Louis-based McDonnell Douglas said the quarterly operating loss at Douglas was $84 million. Douglas is home to the MD-80 jetliner and where the MD-11 jetliner and C-17 cargo plane are being developed. Employment rose from about 15,000 in 1984 to 50,000 as orders for the twin-engine MD-80 surged and the other planes were brought along. But the losses forced the elimination of 3,000 of those jobs, about 6 percent, the company said. ``The bottom line is, we've got to reduce costs because the performance has not been up to expectations,'' said spokesman John Thom. Thom said the cuts had been under discussion for some time and were not a reaction to Thursday's proposal by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to buy 120 of the C-17 long-range transport planes instead of the 210 originally planned. Cheney projects that such cuts would save $11.9 billion over the life of the program.

DOC.HEAD: Fixed Mortgage Rates Rise
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.56 percent, their highest rate in nearly a year, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. It was the highest rate since fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.61 percent last May 19. They averaged 10.41 percent last week. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.56 percent this week, unchanged from the week before. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers Troubled by Advertising and Readership Declines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Dave Lyons remembers the glory days in Odessa, Texas, when the oil boom brought roustabouts and rig workers to west Texas and the circulation of his newspaper, The Odessa American, shot skyward. ``They were blue-collar workers. But they were sophisticated,'' he said. ``They were world traveled. Some of them had served overseas in Saudi Arabia or Libya.'' They were people who read newspapers. Now, many of the oil people are gone, and, like other Texas papers, The Odessa American is struggling back from a precipitous tumble in readership and advertising. Texas papers are not alone. Odessa's story was typical of tales of woe told this week at the American Newspaper Publishers Association's 104th convention, a gathering that annually takes the pulse of the U.S. newspaper industry. This year, the pulse was slower than ever and the prognosis for the patient's future was anybody's guess. Was the problem a recurring depression or something more life threatening? A transfusion of advertising would help, all agreed. A healthier readership was advised. The Odessa American, a member of the Freedom Newspapers group with a circulation of 38,000, is bouncing back, Lyons said, due to aggressive changes. Those include conversion from an afternoon to a morning paper and a heavy focus on local sports to attract notoriously indifferent younger readers. ``Since 1986, we've lost about 20 percent (of circulation),'' Lyons said. ``But that was because we lost population. Our home county had a population of 144,000 before the oil bust. Now the population is 116,000. ... ``These days, every time I see an obituary for a person over 50, I think, oh, no, there goes another subscriber,'' Lyons said. Advertising, the life blood of newspapers, has been draining away at an alarming rate all over the country. In the worst slump since the 1970s, advertising was down 2.8 percent in 1989 from a year earlier, according to Leading National Advertisers, a firm that tracks newspaper ad revenue. In the first quarter of 1990, even the normally robust Times Mirror Co. reported a 33 percent fall in net income. The drop was blamed on a soft ad market, particularly for the company's East Coast newspapers. Times Mirror's flagship paper, the Los Angeles Times, announced a dramatic circulation climb of 9.5 percent to an all-time high of 1,225,189 daily, buoyed by readers from the Los Angeles Herald Examiner, which folded in November. But the Times' advertising revenue was down about 2 percent. Ironically, the financial news that fills newspaper business pages has had a boomerang effect, striking the messengers in the pocketbook. Acquisitions, mergers, store closures and a falling real estate market mean decreased advertising. Classified pages, the newspaper's financial backbone, shrank as ads for automobiles, real estate and help wanted declined. ``The question is whether it's cyclical or not,'' said John J. Curley, chairman of Gannett Co., which owns more dailies than any other group. ``We honestly don't know.'' In its first-quarter report, issued last week, Gannett profits rose by only the narrowest of margins, from $74.9 million a year ago to $75 million this year. Curley sees the newspaper recession as regional rather than nationwide. He linked it to last winter's bankruptcy protection filing by the Campeau Corp., the Toronto-based conglomerate that controlled some of this country's best-known retail stores, including Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh, Lazarus and Abraham & Straus. ``West is best,'' Curley said, noting that the Southwest, recovering from the oil crisis, is doing well. ``Northwest is second-best. Midwest is more down than out. Southeast is mostly down _ that's retail related. Northeast is worst, with automotive ads a big factor.'' Craig Standen, president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, an arm of ANPA, stressed that newspapers aren't the only media-related companies suffering. ``The whole media market, the advertising business, is not going as fast as it has in the past,'' he said. ``Yes, it's a problem for newspapers. But I don't think it means something is structurally wrong with newspapers.'' Declining readership was the other major problem troubling publishers. It was the topic of panel discussions, speeches and workshops. Poor education was denounced. More literacy was demanded. A note of hope was sounded by Steven L. Isenberg, associate publisher of Newsday, who said that in spite of a general economic downturn, New York remains a bastion of newspaper readers. ``In New York City, the number of people who read two or more papers a day is remarkable,'' he said, adding, ``Opinion is the mother's milk of New York life. We give them columnists with different opinions and views, and they come back with a real signature of daily life.'' Isenberg warned that while newspapers are besieged with financial woes, they shouldn't forget their underlying purpose. ``Newspapers are part of helping us to be intelligent citizens,'' he said. ``We are an engine of democracy and we have a responsibility to the whole community,'' said C. Shelby Coffey III, editor and executive vice president of the Los Angeles Times. ``I think newspapers are central to the survival of a free society,'' said John E. Cox, Jr., president of the Foundation for American Communications. Their statements could be taken as an echo of the enthusiastic standing ovation the 1,600 ANPA members gave to two special guests _ the publishers of a Bogota, Colombia, newspaper that fought that country's drug lords and managed to publish after its plant was bombed. No mention was made of the paper's advertising and circulation numbers.

DOC.HEAD: Revco Agrees to Sell 221 Stores
DOC.TEXT: Revco D.S. Inc. said Friday it agreed to sell 221 of its 1,873 stores to Reliable Holdings Corp. of Fort Worth, Texas, as part of its restructuring under bankruptcy court protection. Revco, one of the largest drugstore chains in the country with a work force of 26,800 people, announced Jan. 26 that it planned to sell 712 of its stores. The price of the deal with Reliable Holdings was not disclosed. Weighed down by debt incurred in a takeover, the chain had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law in July 1988. Its restructuring involves selling stores in the western United States and emphasizing its operations in the East, where it gets most of its sales. Revco will sell to Reliable Holdings all its stores in western Tennessee and in Illinois, Iowa, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan and Missouri, Revco said. Reliable Holdings Corp. was formed by Acadia Partners LP, and the management of Reliable Drug Stores Inc., a 112-store chain based in Indianapolis. ``We anticipate a very smooth transition of these stores to Reliable,'' said Boake A. Sells, Revco chairman and chief executive officer. Friday's announcement is the first involving buyers for the stores. Any sales are subject to bankruptcy court approval. Revco officials in January said they hoped that those working in stores targeted for sale would be hired by eventual buyers. The company said its business in 10 Eastern states accounts for 64 percent of the chain's sales. The states are Georgia, Maryland, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, eastern Tennessee, West Virginia and Virginia. Other Revco stores are in Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, Colorado, Florida, Louisiana, Michigan, Mississippi, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Texas. Revco has annual sales of more than $2.7 billion. The company filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors in July 1988, after it failed to make an interest payment on outstanding ``junk bonds'' used to finance its $1.5 billion, management-led leveraged buyout the previous year. In a leveraged buyout, the buyer of the company borrows the purchase money with the idea of repaying it through asset sales and earnings.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Soybeans Surge, Grains Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices closed sharply higher Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a late flurry of speculative buying underpinned by strong demand and slow shipments from Brazil. Grain futures ended mixed with new-crop wheat prices rising strongly. Analysts were somewhat bewildered by the performance of the soybean market, which had opened lower after a powerful advance on Thursday. Mickey Luth, grains analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said underlying support was provided by strong world demand for soybean meal and by the slow pace of soybean and soymeal exports from South America due to harvest delays and sweeping economic reforms in Brazil. But analysts said there had been no change Friday in supply and demand factors that might account for the surge in the soybean market. Friday's rally was led by speculative funds, they said. The soybean market also may be reflecting speculation that the past week's unusually warm, dry Midwestern weather could extend into the growing season, analysts said. But they added that it is too early in the growing season to worry about a repeat of the 1988 drought. At the close, wheat futures were { cent lower to 5} cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.70 a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to 3 cents higher with May at $2.79} a bushel; oats were 1 cent lower to 2\ cents higher with May at $1.62{ a bushel; soybeans were 7 cents to 11} cents higher with May at $6.36 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices finished mixed Friday in a session shortened by a computer glitch that disrupted trading on five futures and options markets. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, gained 7 cents to settle at $18.54 a 42-gallon barrel after losing 19 cents on Thursday. Subsequent contract months posted somewhat stronger gains. Home heating oil for May delivery rose 0.67 cent to 53.74 cents a gallon matching Thursday's gain. Other contract months also advanced. But the May contract for unleaded regular gasoline lost 0.39 cent on top of a 1.26-cent decline Thursday to settle at 60.95 cents a gallon. Subsequent months also lost ground. And natural gas for June delivery closed at $1.550 per million British thermal units, down from $1.558 on Thursday. Traded halted at 11:20 a.m. EDT after computer screens when blank, leaving traders unable to monitor price quotes. Activity came to a standstill in the nation's major oil and metals trading pits. ``It was a surprisingly short day,'' said Peter Beutel, assistant director at Elders Futures Inc. The exchanges gave traders about five minutes to close out their positions before shutting down officially at 2 p.m. EDT. ``We may have seen more activity if we had had a full day,'' Beutel said. But he noted that trading often subsides ahead of an OPEC meeting. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' price monitoring committee is scheduled to meet Wednesday to to discuss ways of holding down the cartel's production and stopping oil prices from falling.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Signs Pennsylvania Anti-Takeover Law; Two Suits Filed
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Robert P. Casey Friday signed the nation's toughest anti-takeover law, saying it would discourage corporate raiders from stripping jobs and economic vitality from Pennsylvania. Within hours, the law was challenged by two suits filed in federal court that claimed unconstitutional infringment on shareholder and investor rights. Analysts expect the law, which took effect immediately, will create ripples in boardrooms and legislatures throughout the nation. For the first time in any state, raiders will be forced to surrender short-term profits from thwarted takeover attempts. The law also restricts the voting rights of raiders and preserves labor contracts when corporations change hands. Casey said the buyout spree of the past decade had left a wake of broken dreams for both workers and companies. The law, he said, would protect their interests in the face of greed-driven profiteers. ``We're interested in long-term, stable economic growth. We're not interested in corporate raiders that see short-term profits for narrow interests,'' Casey said. Hostile takeovers have cost Pennsylvania thousands of jobs and such corporate mainstays as Gulf Oil Co., which closed its headquarters in Pittsburgh after it was merged with Chevron Corp. The AFL-CIO estimates 90,000 jobs were lost nationwide over the last decade because of mergers, takeovers and leveraged buyouts. Casey signed the bill at city council chambers blocks from the corporate headquarters of Armstrong World Industries Inc., the floor covering manufacturer that the legislation was first drafted to protect. Its enactment comes three days before Armstrong's annual stockholder meeting, where the Belzberg family of Canada plans to wage a proxy fight to place four of its representatives on the company's board. A suit filed on behalf of the Belzbergs in U.S. District Court in Philadelphia alleges the law conflicts with federal legislation and violates the First and Fifth amendments of the Constitution. ``The federal statutory scheme is designed to create a level playing field for management and those who would oppose management. This new legislation dramatically tilts the playing field in favor of management,'' said Lawrence Fox, an attorney who filed the suit on behalf of First City Financial Corp. and other Belzberg-owned entities. The second suit was filed by Richard Greenfield, a Montgomery County attorney, on behalf of a New York resident and an Arizona resident who own stock in Pennsylvania companies. ``The shareholders are concerned with the provision of the new law that effectively takes away the very fundamental rights they've traditionally had. We don't think, for that reason, that the law is constitutional,'' Greenfield said. The central provision in the law requires raiders, after a failed buyout or proxy fight, to forfeit any profit made from the sale of the target company's stock for 18 months. Shareholders who initiate proxy fights could avoid sanctions in most cases, providing they don't intend to take control of the corporation. The law would also allow management to give first consideration to employees, customers, suppliers or the community, rather than shareholders, when weighing takeover bids. Another provision would deny raiders voting rights in a corporation until they are restored by other shareholders. If corporate ownership changes hands, labor contracts would have to be honored and severance paid to laid-off workers. Up to 90 days after the law takes effect, corporations would be able to exempt themselves from the legislation. The chairman of PNC Financial Corp. in Pittsburgh has said he plans to recommend to directors that the company exempt itself. PNC is the parent company of Pittsburgh National Bank and is the nation's 14th-largest bank holding company. The legislation had been criticized by the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, among others. Critics contend the bill would insulate bad management from shareholders and ultimately depress stock prices for state companies. Some also claim the law is too late because the pace of hostile takeovers slowed considerably and the junk bond market is in shambles. But supporters assert the law will give companies breathing room from the threat of takeovers, freeing them to concentrate on growth and long-range planning. ``I clearly think that it's going to mean stabilization and preservation of Pennsylvania corporations, jobs and payroll,'' said Clifford Jones, president of the Pennsylvania Chamber of Business and Industry, which drafted the bill.
Stock prices fell today, closing out their second straight week of declines. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 29.06 at 2,647.52.

Stock prices posted a broad loss today as traders studied the latest data on economic growth. An accompanying gauge of inflation showed prices in the January-March period rising at a 7{-year high of 5.7 percent annually. Analysts said those figures tended to reinforce fears on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve might soon feel compelled to tighten credit in its campaign to keep inflation in check. Interest rates were mixed in the credit markets, where yields on Treasury bonds climbed past the 9 percent level Thursday for the first time in nearly a year. Brokers said some bond traders were relieved that the GNP increase wasn't any bigger than it turned out to be.

DOC.HEAD: Posts Loss in 1st Qtr After Profit a Year Ago
DOC.TEXT: National Steel Corp. said Friday it lost $4.2 million in the first quarter in contrast to a profit of $9.8 million a year earlier, and cited reduced demand in the markets it serves. Sales decreased 7 percent to $611.7 million from $654.5 million in the same quarter of 1989, the company said. The 1989 first-quarter results included an extraordinary credit of $2.6 million, which represents the tax benefit of operating loss carryforwards not previously recognized, the company said. National Steel Chairman Howard M. Love attributed the first-quarter loss largely to sluggishness in most markets, in particular automotive. ``Because of the softness in demand, we experienced both a decline in prices and an unfavorable impact on our product mix,'' he said. Also contributing to the loss were higher raw material prices, especially zinc and scrap, and higher operating costs, Love said. ``Despite the first quarter decline, there is continually rising long-term market demand for value-added goods such as galvanized and tin-mill products,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Glitch Halts Trading on New York Futures Markets
DOC.TEXT: The five New York futures and options markets shut down early on Friday after a communications glitch prevented thousands of traders, brokers and investors from receiving price data. Action in the nation's major oil and metals trading pits came to a standstill when the exchanges discovered that no price quotes were leaving the building. Exchanges employees and participants said it was the first time in recent memory that the markets were closed because of a technical problem. Traders reported no panic and an orderly shutdown. Some players took an early weekend. Trading was halted at 11:20 a.m. at the Commodity Exchange, the nation's main metals market; the New York Mercantile Exchange, the main oil trading market; the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange; the Cotton Exchange; and the New York Futures Exchange. ``It's a Friday afternoon and it's a gorgeous day outside. If it didn't look like Comex was going to open up, it was, `I'm going to get a tee time or put my boat in the water,''' said Scott Hinton, a metals broker with Elders Futures Inc. The problem involved communication lines inside the exchange at the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan and prevented price quotations from being transferred from the trading floor to computer screens in the outside world. ``The high-speed futures line is dead,'' Tom Crisalli, an operations employee with the Commodity Exchange Center, which oversees the five futures markets, said early Friday afternoon. Failing to resolve the problem, the exchanges shut down at 2 p.m. after giving traders a few minutes to settle pending deals. The regular closing times for most commodities run from 2:20 p.m. until around 3 p.m. The New York Stock Exchange composite index-futures contract continued to trade until its normal 4:15 p.m. close. Employees said the system began transmitting data again at 2:49 p.m. Officials said the exchanges would reopen Monday. But the exact cause of the glitch remained unclear. Exchange executives took to the floor shortly after 11 a.m. to inform participants that trading would be halted. The normally frenzied pace of shouted trading died down. One floor worker played a George Thorogood rock tune on the harmonica. ``It's closed, baby,'' Michael Wilner, president of Hilltop Trading Co., an energy futures trader, told a California trader who was unaware of the problem. ``We're done for the day. Period.'' Wilner said there was some confusion after the halt was announced but trading had been slow so participants didn't panic. The problem was further minimized because foreign markets already had closed for the weekend. But market participants said such a shutdown could have caused chaos if the stock market, for instance, was in turmoil or rumors about world events that often buffet the markets had been circulating. ``I've been in this business over 10 years. I've never seen it go down this long and I've never seen it close down early,'' said John Jonat, a precious- metals trader Deak International Inc. Wilner said the event indicated the kinds of perils that affect financial markets, which rely on sophisticated computer and telephone communications networks that could go down at any time. ``If you go skateboarding you should wear elbow pads, knee pads and a helmet,'' he said from the exchange floor. ``There are a lot of forces that impact on the market.'' Exchange officials said the glitch was in its internal communications network, not with American Telephone & Telegraph Co. lines that feed data from the exchanges. After trades are recorded on slips of paper and entered into computers on the exchange floor, the futures price information is relayed to an on-site AT&T facility that in turn relays it to outside points identified by the exchange. ``All indications are that the problems encountered by the commodity exchanges were not caused by AT&T's network or equipment,'' AT&T spokeswoman Linda Haertlein said. The New York markets trade futures contracts from orange juice to gold in an open-outcry system where bids are shouted by designated floor employees. The New York markets trail Chicago's commodity markets in trading volume and importance.

DOC.HEAD: Ames Trades Places With Its Former Conquests
DOC.TEXT: For years, Ames Department Stores Inc. flourished by gobbling up other bankrupt or ailing discount chains. Now, the once-thriving retailer is learning what it's like to be on the other side. Analysts say Ames can recover from its own bankruptcy filing by ridding itself of its unprofitable Zayre stores and reorganizing its own stores. But that will be an especially difficult task in a turbulent retail climate, where bankruptcy filings have become almost as common as dollar-day sales. Ames became the latest casualty in the retail industry when it filed for protection from its creditors Wednesday under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. The Ames' filing came three months after Campeau Corp.'s Allied and Federated stores filed for Chapter 11 protection, a move that sent a wave of panic through the industry. Last summer, the Bonwit Teller and B. Altman units of the Hooker Corp. also filed for protection. Coupled with the downfalls of smaller retailers, the troubles of the upscale-Campeau companies and the discount Ames chain has left suppliers skittish and retailers worrying about who will be next. ``The drink of choice used to be Absolut (vodka) on Seventh Avenue. It's now Maalox,'' said Alan Millstein, publisher of a monthly newsletter for retailers and manufacturers. Retail analysts blame Ames's problems on its 1988 acquisition of the Zayre discount chain, a deal some analysts now describe as the albatross that brought Ames down. But they also say Ames may have been able to save itself in a healthier retail climate. Howard Davidowitz, chairman of a New York-based retail financial consulting firm, said Ames's problems are symptoms of the competitive squeeze that has gripped retailers for the last five years. ``America is badly over-stored and over-shopping centered, and what happens in that environment is the strong get stronger and the weak get weaker and fall out,'' Davidowitz said. Other analysts say those who blame a new breed of competition in retail are just whining, and that the recent spate of bankruptcy filings are really caused by mismanagement and bad decisions. The bankruptcy filings by Ames and the Campeau units ``have nothing to do with anything but people making bad financial decisions,'' said Jeffrey Branman, managing director for Financo Inc., a New York investment bank that specializes in retail industry transactions. ``There really is not a revolution that's going on,'' Branman said. ``This is the normal evolution where the strong get stronger and the weak get weaker and get shaken out.'' The tense retail climate caused by recent bankruptcies has led to a growing number of consolidations, especially among discounters. Ironically, Ames rode the crest of the consolidation trend, swallowing up competitors who were either bankrupt or on the brink of bankruptcy. From 1974 to 1985, Ames had consumed nearly 500 new stores by capitalizing on the weaknesses of competitors, including stores owned by Giant Stores Corp., W.T. Grant Co., KDT Industries Inc., G.C. Murphy Co., and Neisner Brothers Inc. Ames's purchase of the Zayre chain in 1988 is widely seen as the company's one big blunder. Its $788 million acquisition of the 392-store Zayre chain doubled Ames' size and transformed the company from a little-known New England-based chain into the nation's fourth-largest discounter. The Zayre stores had been known for frequent promotions, heavy advertising and discounted fashion items. Ames, by contrast, stocks more traditional merchandise and runs fewer promotions. The two styles never meshed successfully. Analysts who have watched Ames through its glory days and its more recent turmoil say the chain's recovery will depend on its ability to scale back its operations to the manageable and successful size it had before acquiring the Zayre chain. ``It will be a difficult road back for Ames because they have to divest themselves of all of the Zayre stores and of their own under-performing stores, and they have to go back to a promotional discount store to regain consumer recognition,'' said Walter S. Loeb, president of a New York retail consulting firm. Ames's ability to win back the confidence of its suppliers is also considered critical for any comeback. The discounter listed a total of $1.44 billion in liabilities and $1.66 billion in assets in its bankruptcy filing. Its top 20 creditors include Societe Genenerale Financial Corp., which is owed just over $14 million; Rubbermaid Inc., which is owed $4.5 million; and the Sara Lee Group, which is owed nearly $3.9 million. Suppliers began cutting off deliveries to Ames last month, after they were not paid for earlier shipments because of Ames's cash shortage. ``Their basic customer couldn't care less whether the store is in bankruptcy or not,'' said Millstein. ``All they care about is seeing their favorite merchandise on the shelves, and to do that you need suppliers.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower, Gold Down Slightly
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined against most major currencies Friday in trading dominated by the West German mark and Japanese yen. News that inflation has picked up this year initially caused heavy dollar buying but it tapered off by late morning. Gold prices fell modestly. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for June delivery settled down 30 cents at $373 a troy ounce after an abbreviated session. Trading ended early on the Comex, before noon in New York, because of a communications problem. Later, Republic National Bank of New York quoted a troy ounce of gold bullion at $371.50 as of 4 p.m. EDT, 90 cents higher than Thursday's late bid. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar traded within a narrow range as most of the buying and selling interest was directed toward the mark and yen. ``Really, the day was dominated by cross trading, particularly the mark-yen,'' said Bob Morrissey, senior trader at the Bank of Boston. Traders snapped up dollars in the morning after the government reported that U.S. inflation jumped 6.5 percent in the first quarter of this year, the steepest increase since a 7.7 percent advance in the fourth quarter of 1981. They bought on the assumption that the Federal Reserve Board might step up its battle against inflation by pursuing a tighter credit policy, which would lead to higher interest rates. Higher rates would boost returns on dollar-denominated investments and tend to increase demand for dollars. But the buying enthusiasm soon waned. Traders apparently concluded that the central bank wouldn't adjust its policy in the immediate future. Activity typically slows on Fridays because traders prefer not to establish significant new positions ahead of a weekend. The inflation reading came in a report that showed the gross national product, the country's total output of goods and services, grew at a 2.1 percent annual rate in the first three months of 1990. The GNP figure was in line with expectations and therefore had little impact on the dollar. The dollar's trading day began in Tokyo where it rose to 159.08 Japanese yen from 158.77 yen on Thursday. Later in London, it fell to 158.80 yen. By the time trading was done for the day in New York, the dollar had risen to 159.30 yen from 159.23 yen late Thursday. The British pound rose to $1.6360 from $1.6340 late Thursday. Sterling also strengthened in New York and one pound fetched $1.6350 in late trading, up from $1.6342 the day before. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's quotes, included: 1.6775 West German marks, down from 1.6797; 1.4530 Swiss francs, down from 1.4575; 5.6290 French francs, down from 5.6355; 1,230.00 Italian lire, down from 1,231.75; and 1.16375 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1603. Selected late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates were: 1.6755 West German marks, down from 1.6810; 1.4560 Swiss francs, down from 1.4605; 5.6240 French francs, down from 5.6395; 1.8845 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8915; 1,228.00 Italian lire, down from 1,231.00, and 1.1632 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1602. Gold prices moved lower on most world markets while silver was mixed. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $370.75 a troy ounce, from $372.65 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $370.00, from $372.75 bid late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose 11 cents to close at a bid 373.14. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $4.95 a troy ounce from $4.96 bid late Thursday. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery closed at $4.920 a troy ounce, up from $4.913 late Thursday.
