DOC.HEAD: SEC Hits Denver Penny Stock Brokerage Again
DOC.TEXT: In the latest round in a decade-long struggle with penny stock mogul Meyer Blinder, federal regulators on Friday suspended the firm he founded from trading in the low-cost, high-risk securities for 45 days, and from underwriting such offerings for two years. The Securities and Exchange Commission, in an administrative action, also barred Blinder himself from associating with any registered broker-dealer for at least two years. Lawyers in Washington for the firm and Blinder were out of their offices Thursday afternoon and had not returned a reporter's telephone call for comment by evening. Lawyers in the SEC's enforcement division were at a conference Friday and also unavailable for comment. Normally, however, such findings are appealable either to the full commission or to a federal judge. Blinder, 69, of Denver, Colo., and four associates were indicted in February on racketeering and securities fraud charges by a federal grand jury in Las Vegas. The indictment followed a 1988 Internal Revenue Service raid on Blinder Robinson's Denver office. Blinder Robinson was once the nation's largest penny stock brokerage. Penny stocks are low cost, high risk securities, usually trading for less than $3 per share. They are not listed on stock exchanges and thus reliable, up-to-the-minute information about them is hard to obtain. That makes penny stocks _ which typically are used to raise capital for new or small companies _ prone to fraud by unscrupulous traders and promoters. The SEC action dates back to the early 1980s and has see-sawed back and forth through hearings in the federal courts in Denver and Washington, as well as administrative actions before the full commission and administrative law judges. The SEC has accused Blinder and the firm of fraud and manipulative practices involving the securities of America Leisure Corp., a company that told investors it planned to build and operate an Atlantic City, N.J. casino-hotel but only owned 1.72 acres of land in Atlantic City, an area deemed too small for such a venture.

DOC.NOTE: $adv29
For Release Sunday, April 29
DOC.HEAD: Glances of the Major Competitors
With BC-HDTV Race
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at the six competitors for a U.S. standard for either high definition TV or enhanced television: _ZENITH ELECTRONICS CORP.: Zenith says it has devised technology to compress the 30 megahertz signal of HDTV into 6 megahertz, the band width of today's television broadcasts. The system transmits the-low frequency portion of the signal digitally, or in computer language, sharply reducing the power required for HDTV transmission. By reducing the power, Zenith says it can boost the high-frequency, picture-side of the signal. Zenith has joined American Telephone and Telegraph Co. in developing its HDTV system, which it says would be available in 1994. Zenith says it is spending $10 million on HDTV research this year. --- _SARNOFF CONSORTIUM: Composed of the David Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton, N.J., NBC, Philips Consumer Electronics Co. and Thomson Consumer Electronics Inc. It plans to introduce HDTV in two steps. The first, Advanced Compatible Television, or ACTV, would produce images 30 percent clearer than today's broadcasts, digital sound and ``ghost-free'' images. The group's HDTV proposal is a Philips concept based on an analog system, the conventional way of sending television signals. But it says the system will not be ready for testing until late 1991. The consortium, which has spent $100 million on these projects over the past seven years, plans to have ACTV available by 1993 and full HDTV by 2000. --- _NHK (JAPAN BROADCASTING CORP.): NHK is proposing two systems: MUSE, an HDTV system, and MUSE-6, which provides an enhanced version of today's TV. It remains unclear how much the company is spending for research on these projects. --- _MASSACHUSETTS INSTITUTE of TECHNOLOGY: MIT is proposing a Channel Compatible System, similar to Zenith's. MIT says the difference is it provides a more robust signal that eliminates distortion of regular broadcast channels by the high-definition signal. The system uses a hybrid digital-analog signal developed during seven years of research that cost $2 million. --- _PRODUCTION SERVICES INC.: The Tuscon, Ariz.-based research company proposes a system it calls GENESYS, in which a high-definition signal would be superimposed on a regular broadcast signal. The completely digital system uses technology to shrink the HDTV transmission into a 6 megahertz band. The company says it has spent $2 million over six years developing the technology. --- _FAROUDJA LABORATORIES: The Sunnyvale, Calif., research company proposes an enhancement of the current TV signal that removes some of the ghosts and squiggles. It is not HDTV. The amount of money spent on research remains unclear.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for Sunday April 29

DOC.HEAD: Reports Decline in 1st-Qtr Profit
DOC.TEXT: Wendy's International Inc. on Friday reported its first-quarter profit fell 44 percent from results that included a onetime gain a year earlier. The fast-food restuarant operator said it earned $3.5 million, or 4 cents per share, in the three months ended April 1, down from $6.3 million, or 7 cents per share, a year earlier. The company said its 1989 results included a $5.2 million gain due to an accounting change. Revenues slipped 7 percent to $241.3 million from $259.5 million for the same period of 1989. Wendy's said there were 56 fewer company-owned restaurants during the 1990 quarter, most of them sold to franchise owners. Wendy's said its Super Value Menu has helped improve the company's operating performance. The Super Value Menu is a collection of seven menu items priced at 99 cents in most markets. James W. Near, company president and chief executive officer, said improved efficiency led to higher profit margins. ``Although produce costs were higher in the first quarter of 1990, ... the company was able to improve margins through increased efficiencies,'' Near said. ``We reduced operating expenses to $200.2 million from $223 million, and raised restaurant operating margins to 9.8 percent from 6.4 percent.'' The company has also reduced its reliance on price discounts. Discount coupons accounted for only 1.4 percent of company sales, compared to 6 percent in 1989, the company said. At the end of the quarter, there were 3,744 Wendy's Old Fashioned Hamburgers restaurants worldwide, including 1,103 operated by the company.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Unveils the Extent of its 1990 Summer Cleanup Campaign
DOC.TEXT: The Exxon Corp. said Friday its 1990 summer cleanup program on the still-oiled shorelines of Prince William Sound will consist of small, mobile squads of workers using techniques that are the least intrusive on the environment. The giant oil company has said its crews will be returning to the beaches on May 1 for a second and final year. Hundreds of miles of Alaska shoreline were fouled when the tanker Exxon Valdez slammed into a charted reef March 24, 1989, shredding its hull and releasing nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into the water. Exxon submitted its cleanup plan Friday to the Federal On-Scene Coordinator, Coast Guard Rear Adm. David Ciancaglini, who must approve the proposal before any work is allowed to begin. A multi-agency task force has been conducting a shoreline survey this month and determined that conditions in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska had improved dramatically over the winter, Exxon said. As of April 20, 574 miles of shoreline had been inspected. Still more sites remain to be checked before the survey ends next week. Exxon said the inspections showed no evidence of surface oil on 372 miles of shoreline, or 65 percent, very light oiling along sections of 130 miles, or 22 percent, and a narrow to wide band of weathered crude along sections of 72 miles, or 13 percent. ``The remaining oil is on generally short lengths of shoreline in scattered locations,'' Otto Harrison, general manager of Exxon's Alaska operations said in a news release. The state Department of Environmental Conservation reported the results of the survey another way Wednesday, saying that 79 percent of the shoreline sites surveyed were still oiled. While there may be some debate over the extent of the campaign, it's expected that the real controversy may be over the way Exxon goes about cleaning up what's left of the mess. Exxon said it plans to pick up oily debris and tarballs manually, spotwash certain areas, till and rake sediment and use bioremediation _ oil-eating bacteria _ to hasten the breakup of the tarry coating on some beaches. But state policymakers are not yet certain they want to use the fertilizers on the beaches, fearing the release of still more toxins. Exxon expects to have 1,100 people at work on the cleanup by June 1.

DOC.HEAD: Equimark Pulls Out Of National Bancshares Deal, Opening Way For Feds
DOC.TEXT: The proposed recapitalization of National Bancshares Corp. of Texas Inc. fell through Friday when Equimark Corp. pulled out, laying the basis for the federal takeover of the largest remaining insolvent bank in Texas. Equimark, a $3.7 billion financial services company based in Pittsburgh, agreed last July to take over the ailing San Antonio bank holding company, providing $31 million of its own money along with $250 million from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. However, the deal was contingent on approval by holders of at least 85 percent of $25 million National Bancshare's debt, and on Thursday the bank holding company said holders of only 25 percent had given their approval by the 5 p.m. deadline. ``Obviously we are disappointed that this transaction cannot go forward as planned,'' said Equimark Chairman Alan S. Fellheimer. National Bancshares had assets of $2.3 billion last July, but that has shrunk to about $1.9 billion. ``The FDIC and other regulatory agencies are proceeding to consider alternative resolutions to the NBC situation, including contact with qualified prospective acquirers,'' FDIC spokesman David Barr said Friday. Those alternatives include closing National Bancshare's insolvent banks, and selling them immediately to another institution, or operating them as ``bridge banks'' until a buyer can be found. A sale offer could rekindle the interest of a host of other banks who had originally taken a look at National Bancshares last year. Included in that list were NCNB Texas National Bank, the state's largest holding company; Minneapolis investor Carl Pohlad together with Norwest Corp.; and Security Pacific Corp. However Robert Rieke, banking analysts at Rauscher Pierce Refnes Inc. brokerage in Dallas, predicted two Texas banks _ First City Bancorp. of Texas Inc. and Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc., a subsidiary of Chemical Banking Co. _ will show the greatest interest. ``I cannot imagine an out-of-state organization coming to Texas and using (National Bancshares) as a platform,'' he said. National Bancshares, once the eighth largest bank holding company in Texas and second largest bank in San Antonio, lost $28.5 million in the first quarter of this year, following a loss of $429.1 million in the previous four years. Declining real estate and energy markets have sapped many Texas banks in recent years, forcing many of the into private or federally funded recapitalizations.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Rise, But Yield Remains Above 9 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices rose slightly Friday in light trading as the market shrugged off a government report showing strong economic growth and rising inflation. But long Treasury bond yields remained above 9 percent. The Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond rose 5-32 point, or $1.56 for each $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, dipped to 9.02 percent from 9.04 percent late Thursday. The yield on the 30-year Treasury finished above 9 percent Thursday for the first time in almost a year. The yield is important since it is used to calculate some mortgage and other loan rates. The Commerce Department said the gross national product rose 2.1 percent in the first quarter, almost double the previous quarter's rate. A price gauge tied to the GNP shot up an annual rate of 6.5 percent from the 4.5 percent for all of last year. Both reports normally would be bad news for the bond market because inflation erodes the value of fixed-income securities such as bonds and because a healthy economy makes it less likely the Federal Reserve will act to ease interest rates. But the figures had been expected by bond traders _ in fact, some anticipated the inflation figure would be even higher, said James Marshall, a trader with Clayton Brown & Associates in Chicago. After the release of the numbers, bond prices rose, then fell, then rose again. Some traders said the market appeared to be reacting to different components of the report. ``The market didn't know which way it wanted to go,'' Marshall said. Bond prices had been down all week. ``People have been saying it (the market) is oversold and can't go down forever,'' Marshall said. ``But then we've got a lot of supply coming up for the quarterly refunding. That always causes a lot of consternation,'' he said, referring to the Treasury's quarterly refunding auction next month. ``You have these two forces at work and they really kind of washed each other out today.'' Another force at work was the need by some traders to cover their short positions before the weekend by buying bonds, he added. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term government issues rose by between 5-32 point and 3-16 point, intermediate maturities rose by 3-32 point to 5-32 point, and long-term issues rose by [ point to 7-32 point, according to figures provided by Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 1.84 to 1,129.54. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 11-32 point to 89 5-32. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.73 percent from 7.70 percent late Thursday. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 8.02 percent as the discount fell 5 basis points to 7.77 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 8.34 percent as the discount fell 9 basis points to 7.91 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 8.51 percent as the discount fell 10 basis points to 7.92 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 percent, down from 8 3-16 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Paramount Execs Accused of Taking Kickbacks
DOC.TEXT: Two former Paramount Pictures Corp. executives were accused in a federal indictment Friday of taking kickbacks such as cash and free use of a summer house from two companies doing business with the movie producer. The indictment, filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, charged Gordon Weaver and Stephen Rose with not reporting the kickbacks as income on their 1983 and 1984 tax returns. Weaver, 52, the former president of the Worldwide Marketing Division of Paramount's Motion Picture Division, additionally was charged with conspiracy. He resigned in 1984 after a company investigation. Weaver and Rose, formerly the vice president of marketing of the Motion Picture Division, allegedly extorted the kickbacks under threat that Paramount would withhold its business, the indictment said. ``These unsupported allegations were first made six years ago. They were subsequently reviewed by two different organizations with which I was associated and found to be utterly lacking in credibility,'' Weaver said in a statement. ``I now at least will be provided the opportunity to once and for all put these slanderous charges to rest,'' he said. It was not clear to what organizations Weaver was referring in his statement. A call to Rose's attorney, Gerald Walpin, was not immediately returned. Weaver was accused of receiving numerous cash payments from Spiros Associates, an advertising company, and Filmland Production Inc. He also allegedly had free use during the summer of 1983 of a house on Fire Island rented by Filmland. The indictment said Rose solicited a kickback from Filmland by asking the company to buy him a Mercedes-Benz automobile. It also said Rose received about $1,000 a month between April 1983 and May 1984 as payments for a car loan. Rose additionally was accused of receiving $2,260 from Filmland in November 1983 to pay expenses for his daughter's bar mitzvah. Weaver and Rose also allegedly received color television sets from Filmland. Weaver was charged with conspiracy and filing false tax returns in 1983 and 1984. If convicted, he faces a maximum of 11 years in prison and $600,000 in fines. The indictment charged Rose with the filing of a false tax return in 1983, which carries a maximum penalty of three years in prison and a $100,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Surge To 9-Month High On Supply, Weather Fears
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices surged Friday to their highest levels since last summer, extending a rally linked to the rain-slowed Brazilian harvest and fears that the recent hot, dry Midwestern weather might be a harbinger of drought. On other commodity markets, grain futures ended mixed, cattle were higher; pork futures were mixed; oil futures were mixed; and precious metals were mixed. Trading in oil, precious metals and a number of other commodities ended before noon EDT after a communications glitch at New York's Commodity Exchange Center prevented price quotes from the five New York markets from reaching customers. The trading halt affected the New York Mercantile Exchange; the Commodity Exchange; the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange; the New York Cotton Exchange; and the New York Futures Exchange. Officials said the problem was corrected Friday afternoon and normal trading would resume on Monday. Soybean futures settled 7{ cents to 10} cents higher on the Chicago Board of Trade with the contract for delivery in May up 8} cents at $6.35 a bushel, the highest settlement of a near-month soybean contract since July 28. Wheat futures settled unchanged to 5} cents higher with May at $3.70{ a bushel; corn was } cent lower to 1{ cents higher with May at $2.80 a bushel; oats were 1 cent lower to 2 cents higher with May at $1.62\ a bushel. The rise in soybean futures followed leaps of 17 cents Thursday and 10} cents Wednesday in the May soybean contract. Soybean meal for May delivery settled $3.90 higher at $184.40 amid the heaviest trading volume in exchange history. The Board of Trade said Friday's volume of 54,815 meal contracts surpassed the previous high of 45,411 set Oct. 20, 1987. Analysts said some of the underlying support in the soybean complex was provided by the relatively slow pace of soybean and soymeal exports from South America, mainly due to wet-weather harvest delays in Brazil, the world's second-largest soybean producer. ``They've had rain pretty much on a steady basis for a month now,'' said Walter Spilka of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. He said the Brazilian harvest was about half complete but would be 80 percent finished by now if the harvest was progressing at a normal pace. The slow Brazilian harvest is fueling speculation that European nations may need to buy U.S. soybean meal for livestock feed, according to Spilka and others. The strong soybean market also may have reflected speculation that the past week's unusually warm, dry Midwestern weather could extend into the growing season, analysts said. But several said it was too early in the growing season to worry about a repeat of the 1988 drought. After the close of trading Friday, a National Weather Service forecast predicted normal to below-normal temperatures and normal to above-normal rainfall for the region through the end of July. Cattle futures posted modest gains on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid buying prompted by the low price of futures versus the cash cattle markets. Further support came from a a strong rally in the adjacent pork-belly pit early in the session, although those gains were later trimmed. Live cattle settled .40 cent to .55 cent higher with June at 73.15 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .35 cent to .73 cent higher with May at 82.15 cents a pound; live hogs were .57 cent lower to .10 cent higher with June at 63 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .80 cent lower to .95 cent higher with May at 64.65 cents a pound. In a shortened session on the New York Merc, West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 9 cents to 12 cents higher with June at $18.54 a barrel; heating oil was .14 cent to .67 cent higher with May at 53.74 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .39 cent lower to .20 cent higher with May at 60.95 cents a gallon. Gold settled 10 cents to 30 cents lower in a short session on the Commodity Exchange with June at $373 a troy ounce; silver ended 0.6 cent to 3.2 cents higher with May at $4.92 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Camps, Pharmacies Get Rid of Recalled Repellents
DOC.TEXT: Summer camp directors planned letters to parents and pharmacies yanked cans from shelves Friday after two top insect repellents were recalled because a long-used ingredient made lab rats sick. The Environmental Protection Agency announced Thursday that the makers of Deep Woods OFF! and Cutter's insect repellents had voluntarily recalled their products because of the findings. The ingredient's manufacturer, McLaughlin Gormley King Co. of Minneapolis, told the government that preliminary testing showed an additive known as R-11 gave tumors to lab rats and withered their ovaries. The company asked that its license to make the product be withdrawn. About 200 brands of repellent use R-11, which helps repel flies that bite. ``I will just make sure that when my final notice goes out to parents, if they don't know about it not to send anything with their child that's on the recall list,'' said Betsy Cobb, owner of Camp Runoia, a small girls camp in Belgrade Lakes, Maine. Cobb said the camp does not recommend a brand of insect repellent children should bring, but said she would check to see what children were using. ``I would not put it on a child,'' said Dolly Jacobson, owner of Buck and Beaver Camp in Shohola, Pa., in the Poconos mountains, which attracts about 100 boys and girls ages 7 to 15. ``I'm planning on covering it during orientation _ telling them to be on the lookout in case parents haven't heard about it,'' she said. Two of the major users of the additive are S.C. Johnson and Son Co. of Racine, Wis., which makes OFF! products, and Miles Co. of Elkhart, Ind., producer of Cutter's. OFF! spokeswoman Barbara Jorgensen said 150,000 cases of Deep Woods OFF! containing R-11 were in circulation. The company on April 6 asked retailers to return the product and exchange it for a newly formulated one. Deep Woods OFF! has contained R-11 since it was first manufactured in 1973. The new version will will bear a red sticker on the cap saying ``New Forumla,'' she said. Other OFF! products are not affected by the recall. ``There's a huge concern that there would be product confusion,'' said Jorgensen. ``We don't want people to overreact to this and not use insect repellents this season ...'' Miles Inc. on April 10 asked its retailers to return Cutter's aeresol, pump spray and lotion, which contained R-11. The new versions without the chemical will have a yellow sticker. ``Our concern is that consumers not become overly alarmed because this does not pose a health risk,'' company spokeswoman Dionn Tron said. Rite Aid Corp., one of the nation's leading drug-store chains, notified its 2,350 stores in 22 states to pull the problem repellents from shelves. A Rite Aid official said the company was waiting to retrieve all the old formula before stocking the new versions. ``We do have the new formula in warehouses but we want to make sure we only get the product that manufacturers have approved as safe on the shelves,'' said the official, who asked not to be named. Bonnie Carmody, manager of Naults Heights Pharmacy in Concord, N.H., said she pulled the remaining 12 cans of the products off the shelves Friday after a pharmacist heard a news report about the recall. She said Deep Woods OFF! and Cutter's products were big sellers in New England _ dreaded for its summer bug migration _ and she expected consumers to buy the replacement versions. About 25 percent of all insect repellents on the market use the additive, formally known as 2,3,4,5-Bis(2,butylene)tetrahydro-2-furaldehyde. The technical name appears on product labels. The government said it has done no independent testing of R-11, requiring pesticide manufacturers to conduct safety tests, and does not know how dangerous it may be. The ingredient has been used for 35 years.

DOC.HEAD: House Resolution Introduced Urging Strike Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A resolution urging a resumption of bargaining in the eight-week-old Greyhound bus strike and deploring strike violence was introduced Thursday in the House by Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., and about 100 co-sponsors. ``The toll exacted by this increasingly bitter dispute is worsening with each day that passes without negotiations,'' Williams said. Greyhound has refused to resume negotiations until a week passes without a shooting or bomb threat; the last confirmed incident occurred Monday. Talks broke down March 18 in Tucson, Ariz., and have been stalled ever since. The Amalgamated Transit Union, which has condemned the nearly 40 shootings and other violent incidents that have occurred, has said it was willing to resume contract talks at any time. ``We wish that the company would see the error in its ways, particularly in regard to this business of putting the bargaining process in the hands of some kook out there who might make a phone call or pick up a weapon,'' said union spokesman Nick Nichols. Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said the company welcomed Congress' condemnation of the violence and that Greyhound executives would resume bargaining when seven days passed without violence. The bus line's 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 of its office and maintenance workers walked out March 2 over wages and job security. The company, which operates the only nationwide bus system, has been running on a reduced schedule since then, using replacements and union members who cross picket lines.

DOC.HEAD: Board Remaining Neutral on Japonica Debt Bid
DOC.TEXT: Allegheny International's board of directors said it intends to remain neutral on a suitor's proposed purchase of the company's debentures. Japonica Partners, which is challenging Allegheny's bankruptcy reorganization plan, has offered to buy the debentures of Allegheny and its wholly owned subsidiary, Chemetron Corp. ``The board of directors does not recommend that debenture holders accept or reject the Japonica offer and is remaining neutral,'' the company said Thursday in a statement. ``Just as voting on a reorganization plan is an individual matter, so is the decision whether to accept or reject Japonica's offer.'' The board also said it supports the company's reorganization proposal as ``the only viable plan'' that ``is in the best interests of all creditors and shareholders.'' The manufacturer of Sunbeam and Oster appliances also announced Thursday it posted a net loss of $7.4 million in the second quarter of its fiscal 1990, or $1.38 a share. That compared with a loss of $4.6 million, or $1.12 a share, a year earlier. Sales were $253.7 million vs. $268.3 million. Allegheny International blamed this year's losses on a decline in the sale of small appliances and outdoor patio furniture, as well as ``highly competitive market conditions and an unstable retail environment.''

DOC.HEAD: Mercedes-Benz Recalls 1584 of its 300-class Cars
DOC.TEXT: Mercedes-Benz of North America is recalling 1,584 of its 300-class medium-size cars to replace a part for an auxiliary engine cooling fan, the automaker said Friday. The company said that when the auxiliary fan is working at a low speed, heat from the pre-resistor could cause its protective plastic cover to melt and possibly burn. Three incidents of the plastic cover melting have been reported, but none have involved injury, the company said. Dealers will replace the pre-resistor with one that has a metal cover at no charge, according to the company, which has its North American base in Montvale. The cars being recalled are some 1990-model 300E 2.6, 300E and 300E 4Matic sedans, 300TE and 300TE 4Matic station wagons and 300CE coupes, the company said. The pre-resistor is a device to reduce the voltage supplied to the auxiliary fan to enable it to run at different speed, depending on the engine coolant temperature. Mercedes-Benz suggested owners of the involved cars only operate the climate control system in the economy mode until the faulty unit is replaced.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Reportedly Asks NASD to Explore Electronic Pricing for Junk Bonds
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Securities and Exchange Commission has asked the National Association of Securities Dealers to explore the development of an electronic pricing system for the junk bond market, a newspaper reported. Such a system could improve liquidity in the ailing market for high-yield bonds and increase investor interest in the securities, The New York Times said in an early edition of Friday's paper. The request is based on a new computerized trading system the association has developed for securities issued via private placement. The SEC authorized big institutional investors to trade such securities last week and at the same time approved the trading system, known as Portal. SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden has asked the association to examine whether Portal could be used to quote prices of junk bonds, the Times reported. ``At the request of the SEC, we are exploring whether we can use the same software that we developed for Portal in the pricing of high-yield securities,'' Joseph Hardiman, president of NASD, was quoted as saying. ``There is obviously a void in the pricing of those securities, and there is strong demand among buyers, legislators and regulators to see if we can come up with something.'' Prices and trading activity in the junk bond market have been depressed for months by defaults, bankruptcy filings by major issuers and the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which used to dominate the market.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Executive Banned from Business
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators on Friday said they banned the former president of the second-largest savings institution in New Jersey from working for a a bank, thrift or credit union. Office of Thrift Supervision Director Timothy Ryan signed the order Thursday after an administrative law judge found that Gerald R. O'Keeffe, former president of First Atlantic Savings and Loan Association, South Plainfield, N.J., ``had been personally dishonest and had acted in willful disregard for First Atlantic's safety and soundness.'' The agency said O'Keeffe: _Accepted unauthorized compensation in excess of $40,000 from a subsidiary. _Carried large interest-free overdraft balances in his checking account at First Atlantic for lengthy periods. _Took out mortgage and personal loans at advantageous rates. _Participated in investor partnerships that dealt with First Atlantic's real estate ventures at advantageous terms. O'Keeffe, who resigned in January, is banned from working for a federally insured institution without advance permission from regulators. His institution was seized by the government Feb. 23.

The nation's economy grew at a 2.1 percent rate in the first quarter but private analysts said an ``ugly'' inflation rate could mean higher interest rates that would slow growth later this year. Besides strength in the gross national product _ the nation's total output of goods and services _ the Commerce Department reported Friday that inflation jumped 6.5 percent, its steepest jump since a 7.7 percent increase in the fourth quarter of 1981. The GNP inflation rate for 1989 was 4.5 percent.

President Bush has spared Japan from a ``hit list'' of countries judged to have erected the most offensive trade barriers against American products. Bush's move Friday amounted to a reward for Japan because of its efforts to ease trade tensions between the two economic superpowers. The president said he had decided to cite only one country _ India _ under a tough section of U.S. trade law.

Billionaire Donald Trump, the king of glitzy real estate and casinos, now says he wants to become the king of cash. The tycoon said Friday he has discussed selling or refinancing virtually every major asset he owns to raise money to buy new properties. Trump said he has hired Merrill Lynch & Co. to negotiate a possible sale of the Trump Shuttle less than a year after buying the Northeast airline.

The five New York futures and options markets shut down early after a communications glitch prevented thousands of traders, brokers and investors from receiving price data. Action in the nation's major oil and metals trading pits came to a standstill at 11:20 a.m. Friday when the exchanges discovered that no price quotes were leaving the building. Exchanges employees and participants said it was the first time in recent memory that the markets were closed because of a technical problem. Traders reported no panic and an orderly shutdown.

The proposed recapitalization of National Bancshares Corp. of Texas Inc. fell through when Equimark Corp. pulled out, laying the basis for the federal takeover of the largest remaining insolvent bank in Texas. Equimark, a $3.7 billion financial services company based in Pittsburgh, agreed last July to take over the San Antonio bank holding company, providing $31 million of its own money along with $250 million from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.

Gov. Robert P. Casey signed the nation's toughest anti-takeover law, saying it would discourage corporate raiders from stripping jobs and economic vitality from Pennsylvania. Within hours, the law was challenged Friday by two suits filed in federal court that claimed an unconstitutional infringment on shareholder and investor rights. For the first time in any state, raiders will be forced to surrender short-term profits from thwarted takeover attempts. The law also restricts the voting rights of raiders and preserves labor contracts when corporations change hands.

General Electric Co. and Lockheed Corp. announced thousands of job cuts, a move analysts say is fueled in part by decreases in defense spending. GE said Friday it will eliminate about 4,200 hourly and salaried jobs over the next two years at five GE Aerospace locations in New York and New Jersey. Lockheed, of Burbank, Calif., plans to lay off 2,750 workers in its plane-building division, including about 2,000 in Southern California.

In the latest round in a decade-long struggle, federal regualtors suspended penny stock mogul Meyer Blinder's firm from trading in the securities for 45 days, and from underwriting such offerings for two years. The Securities and Exchange Commission, in an administrative action Friday, also barred Blinder himself from associating with any registered broker-dealer for at least two years. Penny stocks are cheap, over-the-counter securities.

The Commodity Exchange said its president and chief executive, Arnold Staloff, was resigning effective May 1 after only nine months on the job. The Comex said Friday only that Staloff was leaving to pursue other business opportunities. But published reports said he resigned under pressure amid strained relationships with Comex's trader leadership, including chairman Martin Greenberg.

The stock market closed its second straight week of losses with a broad decline Friday. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 31.53 to 2,645.05, extending its drop for the week to 50.90 points. Bond prices rose slightly in light trading. The dollar declined against most major currencies. Gold prices fell modestly. Soybean futures prices surged to their highest levels since last summer, grain futures ended mixed, cattle were higher, pork futures were mixed, oil futures were mixed and precious metals were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: GM To Include Electronic Ignition On Nearly All Models
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. will install electronic security devices as standard equipment in the ignition systems of nearly all its cars by 1994, GM Chairman-elect Robert Stempel said Friday. The Pass-Key system, currently available on about one-eighth of GM's fleet, relies on a computer chip embedded in a key. The chip communicates electronically with the engine through the ignition lock. If the lock reads an unfamiliar code, the car's starter and fuel lines are disabled for several minutes, according to Delco Electronics, the GM division that makes Pass-Key. The system shuts down the starter and fuel lines if a thief tries to start a car without a key, Delco said. Stempel said the 1991 Saturn line of cars, scheduled for release this fall, would include the Pass-Key as standard equipment. ``By the time we get through 1993, virtually all of our cars will have this electronic system,'' Stempel said in a telephone interview from Detroit. ``The thief will have to pick the car up and cart it away if he wants to steal it.'' ``It's not an end-all to the theft problem, but it helps,'' said Stempel, a senior GM executive who was recently named to succeed Roger Smith as chairman. GM spokeswoman Toni Simonetti declined to say how much the Pass-Key project would cost, either in total or on a per-car basis. The system first appeared on the 1986 Chevrolet Corvette. It since has been installed on the Chevrolet Camaro, Pontiac Firebird, Oldsmobile Toronado, Buick Reatta and Riveria and Cadillac Allante, Seville, Eldorado, DeVille and Fleetwood, GM said. In January, February and March, GM sold 101,807 of the 11 Pass-Key-equipped cars, or 12.3 percent of the company's total sales. Spokesmen for Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said the companies, which with GM make up the nation's Big Three automakers, had announced no plans to install electronic-security devices in car ignitions.

DOC.HEAD: First Quarter Profit Drops
DOC.TEXT: Pennzoil Co. announced Friday its first quarter earnings declined 38 percent largely because of a poor performance by its sulphur division and a decline in its motor oil and automotive products operations. For the first three months of 1990, Pennzoil earned $32.7 million, or 85 cents per share, compared with earnings of $52.5 million, or $1.34 per share, during the first quarter of 1989. Revenue fell 4 percent to $553.2 million from $576.3 million a year ago. ``Operating income from the company's oil and gas operations was up sharply over 1989 levels, due to higher crude oil and natural gas prices,'' said James L. Pate, Pennzoil's president. ``However, the gain was largely offset by lower prices and volumes in the sulphur division.'' ``Operating income for the motor oil and automotive products segment was somewhat lower due to decreased motor oil volumes and increased cost,'' he said. The company's oil and gas division posted profits of $45.8 million, up 92 percent from $23.8 million in 1989. The sulphur division, however, had a 67 percent decline in its operating profit to $9.9 million from $30.1 million a year earlier. Its motor oil and automotive products sector had a 22 percent decline in profits for the first quarter _ to $19.6 million this year from $24.7 million in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Cuts Spark Aerospace Company Layoffs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, Lockheed of ... to CORRECT headquarters to Calabasas from Burbank.
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co. and Lockheed Corp. announced thousands of job cuts Friday, a move analysts say is fueled in part by decreases in defense spending. GE said it will eliminate about 4,200 hourly and salaried jobs over the next two years at five GE Aerospace locations in New York and New Jersey. Lockheed, based in Calabasas, Calif., plans to lay off 2,750 workers in its plane-building division, including about 2,000 in Southern California. The job cuts, which had been expected, were the second big round of aerospace layoffs in as many days to hit Southern California. On Thursday, McDonnell Douglas Corp. said it will eliminate 3,000 jobs at its Long Beach-based Douglas Aircraft unit this summer to reduce the costs of jet aircraft production at the money-losing division. ``The basic reason for the reductions is we're looking at cuts in the defense budget,'' said Wendy Abramowitz, an analyst for Argus Research Corp. in New York. ``If they keep all those people, they will be expending money and will not have the same amount coming in.'' Steven Binder, an analyst at Bear, Sterns and Co. in New York, said the job cuts are ``reflective of future defense cuts and spending.'' ``During recent years the Defense Department has had to cut procurement and research and development. That has made it necessary for companies to reduce employment,'' he said. GE's cuts stem in part from efforts to reorganize its aerospace defense businesses so the company can remain successful despite a shrinking market and increased competition. GE says it will take advantage of projected attrition and retirements of about 2,000 employees to reduce significantly the number of employees actually laid off. The reductions are scheduled to take place at plants in Binghamton, Syracuse and Utica, N.Y. and Camden and Moorestown, N.J. ``We are taking decisive actions now to enable our business to meet its future commitments to customers and ensure that GE Aerospace will be a vital, industry-leading business for many years to come,'' said Jon Rittenhouse, senior vice president for GE Aerospace, which is based in Valley Forge. ``We're entering a decade that will provide a difficult challenge for defense companies,'' he said. ``... By taking these steps, we are protecting the long-term competitive outlook for the business.'' Where layoffs are necessary, GE will offer financial assistance based on length of service and medical and life insurance coverage for up to one year from the date of layoff. The company also will offer job-finding assistance. The cuts affect about 15 percent of the company's 6,000 employees at three Syracuse-area plants. They are the first significant local layoffs since the company shut down its picture tube production operation in November 1986. GE, Syracuse's largest employer, will cut 200 salaried jobs by the end of 1990, said GE spokeswoman Connie Grasso. Another 420 hourly jobs and 250 salaried will be eliminated over the next two years. Layoffs at the three local sites in the towns of Geddes, DeWitt and Salina will begin as early as June 1. James Ragsdale, a spokesman for Lockheed's Aeronautical Systems Co. in Burbank, said 750 employees who will lose their jobs are based in Marietta, Ga., where Lockhee had built the huge C-5 cargo plane. The C-5 is just one of four Lockheed military planes whose production had ended recently or is to end soon. The others are the P-3 sub-hunter, the TR-1 high-altitude reconnaissance plane, and the F117A stealth fighter. ``It is unlikely we will have any large new military aircraft production project that will begin before the mid-1990s,'' Ken Cannestra, the president of the aeronautics unit, said in a statement. Lockheed, the nation's sixth-biggest military contractor, saw its profits fall from $624 million in 1988 to just $2 million last year. One big reason was that the company underestimated by hundreds of millions of dollars the costs of developing a new warplane, the P-7, a replacement for the P-3.

DOC.HEAD: Comex President Resigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to fix typos.
DOC.TEXT: The Commodity Exchange said Friday that its president and chief executive, Arnold Staloff, was resigning effective May 1 after only nine months on the job. The Comex said only that Staloff was leaving to pursue other business opportunities. But published reports said he resigned under pressure amid strained relationships with Comex's trader leadership, including chairman Martin Greenberg. Staloff could not be reached for comment. A successor was not named. Staloff won a reputation as an innovator of financial products when he was a senior officer of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange and president of the Philadelphia Board of Trade. But he apparently encountered conflict at Comex where members, mainly trading houses and individual traders, have a reputation for being strong-willed and who effectively run the exchange. The Comex is the nation's major gold, silver and copper futures exchange, but it is a distant fourth in size behind the Chicago Board of Trade, Chicago Mercantile Exchange and New York Mercantile Exchange. Trading volume at the exchange has been sluggish and the Comex has had trouble developing innovative futures products to compete with the big Chicago exchanges.

DOC.HEAD: Forbes Cuts Estimate of Trump's Worth by More Than $1 Billion
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS new 10th graf to UPDATE with response from Forbes spokesman; picks up 10th graf pvs bg'ng, Using the ...; ADDS byline
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Trump, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump may not be nearly as rich as he claims, Forbes magazine says in an article that if true would bump the tycoon out of the world billionaire's club. Forbes has slashed its estimate of Trump's net worth by more than $1 billion, to around $500 million. In its May 14 cover story, which Forbes made available Friday, the magazine says it revised the estimate after examining nonpublic documents submitted by Trump last year to a government body, which Forbes declined to specify. The article challenges Trump's claim in the documents to have a net worth of $1.5 billion. It also questions whether Trump's cash flow is sufficient to cover the debt and interest payments on his vast holdings. The developer said Friday he has discussed selling or refinancing most of his major asset to raise money to buy new properties. Trump said he has hired Merrill Lynch & Co. to negotiate a possible sale of the Trump Shuttle less than a year after buying the airline and sticking his name on it. Trump said he is interested in raising cash now so that he will have funds on hand in the future to acquire additional properties. His assets also include New York's Plaza Hotel, the glitzy Trump Tower skyscraper on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue, and casinos in Atlantic City, N.J., including the $1 billion Taj Mahal casino, which recently opened. In a statement released late Friday, Trump Organization said Forbes made a ``mathematical mistake or purposeful omission'' by not including $160 million a year in anticipated operating profit from the Taj Mahal, while including the new casino's debt service. ``They (Forbes) made a major mistake here,'' said a Trump spokesman, who asked not to be identified by name. He declined comment on the broader question of Trump's total net worth. ``Only Donald Trump's accountants know this,'' he said. ``Forbes magazine may guess, as others do, but they really don't know.'' Ray Healey, a spokesman for the magazine, responded, ``We've done a very thorough analysis and we stand by our story.'' Using the list of properties in Trump's 1989 documents, and updating their values, Forbes said it came up with a total market value of slightly less than $3.7 billion. However, with nearly $3.2 billion in debt, Trump's cash shortfall may be nearly $40 million a year, the business magazine estimated. Some of the interest on his debt is accruing rather than being paid in cash. In the documents, Trump claims a net worth, after deducting all debts and mortgages, of $1.5 billion, Forbes noted in the article entitled ``Manhattan's Favorite Guessing Game: How Rich is Donald?'' The magazine's own estimate in 1989 was $1.7 billion. ``Double-whammied by a real estate recession and problems with his gambling casinos, Donald Trump may be down to his last half-billion in net worth and he has little liquidity,'' the article says. ``That's not comfortable for a guy with more than $3 billion in debt.'' In an interview Friday with The Associated Press, Trump insisted that he is ``very liquid now.'' ``I want to build up cash because I think cash is going to be king,'' he said.
